HEADLINE: Arabic-Speaking Pop Stars Spread the Joy 

BYLINE:  By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
Half a dozen languages drifted across a music studio in West Chelsea last week. Hakim, a singer from Egypt, was sharing a duet with Olga Tanon from Puerto Rico, their voices rising and twining as they traded verses in Arabic and Spanish, while the Palestinian oud player Simon Shaheen plucked hints of flamenco. Khaled, from Algeria, had finished rehearsing John Lennon's "Imagine" with Noa, an Israeli singer. Youssou N'Dour, from Senegal, had just arrived. 
 It was the dress rehearsal for last Friday's World Economic Forum music showcase, overseen by Quincy Jones. It was also a rightfully polyglot preamble to a long-delayed tour that will take Hakim and Khaled, with Mr. Shaheen sitting in, to theaters across the United States and Canada. The New York show, this Friday at the Beacon Theater, had originally been scheduled for Sept. 16. 
 Khaled and Hakim are major stars in their home countries and in Arabic-speaking communities from Paris to Brooklyn, which is where Hakim recorded a jubilant concert last year for his most recent album, "The Lion Roars: Live in America." Each singer has merged the North African music he grew up on -- rai (which means opinion) for Khaled, shaabi (of the people) for Hakim -- with an international assortment of rhythms and instruments that reflect and reach out to the wider world. "Technology is not just for making weapons and bombs," Hakim said in Arabic after the rehearsal, speaking through a translator. 
When air travel was halted on Sept. 11, the singers and their 33 musicians -- about to fly in from Egypt, Algeria, and France -- were among the thousands of passengers who could not reach New York. Their first American concert together had been scheduled for Sept. 13 in Washington, and tour stops were expecting full houses. 
The tour was a sign of growing Western interest in music from the Arabic-speaking world. Dance music and hip-hop producers have long been sampling music from North Africa and the Middle East, and Sting's hit "Desert Rose" featured guest vocals from the Algerian rai singer Cheb Mami. While Western pop was dipping into their music, singers from North Africa and the Middle East were devising their own fusions, working with European and American producers to annex funk, reggae, rock and electronica. 
Last year American labels, including Putumayo World Music, Stern's, Six Degrees and Ark 21/Mondo Melodia (the label that represents Khaled, Hakim and Mr. Shaheen), released albums of Arabic-language pop. The cover headline on the Aug. 11 issue of Billboard, the music-business barometer, was "Arabic Music Moves West." 
Then came Sept. 11. The tour went into limbo. Even if they could have gotten to the United States, Khaled and Hakim would have considered their upbeat music inappropriate during the 30-day Muslim mourning period. But they did not want the tour to be another casualty of Sept. 11. 
"The extremists are a select group of bad people," Khaled said through a translator. "We are not what Americans have seen of these extremists who are covered from head to toe and who preach this completely monastic life. We drink, we party, we live, just like everybody else."
Concert promoters remained eager to present the tour. "A lot of them, from a pure business standpoint, said there were people who wanted to see this music, so let's put it on at a more appropriate time," said Miles Copeland, president of Ark 21. After Sept. 11, he said, more Americans became curious about Islamic culture. "It's one of those curious times when negatives become positives," he said. "The Koran started selling like hot cakes. Arabic lessons sold out. And we certainly saw interest in the music increase. This has added another dimension. There's now a political significance to this tour."
Both Khaled and Hakim have had cosmopolitan ambitions from the start. Khaled, widely recognized as the king of rai, is a pivotal figure in the music: the singer and songwriter who carried rai from the privacy of parties to the public realm of recordings and broadcasts. But rai's ascent eventually brought grim consequences.
Rai arose in Oran, Algeria, a Mediterranean seaport where Arabic, European and Jewish music were in the air. The songs were plainspoken and uninhibited, most often sung at weddings at which the singer could improvise bawdy lyrics about love and drinking. By the end of the 60's rai was already mixing its traditional flutes and drums with accordion, piano and bongos; influences from Spain and Morocco mingled with Algerian melodies. 
Khaled (whose last name is Brahim) was born in 1960 and started his first group, the Five Stars -- "like the Jackson 5," he said with a laugh -- when he was 10, singing on the streets for spending money. He was 14 when a record producer discovered him and recorded a song, "Trigue Lycee," that expressed teenage perspectives on girl watching and skipping school. At a time when approved Algerian pop was circumspect -- never mentioning a woman by name, for instance -- Khaled was determined to speak openly.
"What really propelled everything I did was that I wasn't going to fall for hypocrisy," he said. "If I wanted to say the name of the girl, or say I didn't like school, or anything about what was happening in my day-to-day life, I was going to sing about it, and I wasn't going to let anybody stop me. The thing that bothered me the most was that they would play this music at weddings, but it was never allowed on to be spread through the television or the radio."
Khaled's first recordings were 45-r.p.m. singles, but in the mid-70's cassette tapes transformed rai. Suddenly music could be recorded and distributed cheaply, and singers and producers proliferated, meshing rai melodies with tinny electric keyboards and ad hoc combinations of Western and Arabic instruments.
A generation of pop-rai singers emerged, most taking the honorific Cheb (for men) or Chaba (for women), which means young. Government radio stations ignored their music, worried that it might incite debauchery. Yet cassette distribution made Cheb Khaled and Chaba Fadela full-fledged recording stars. By the 80's, when fans were writing letters to broadcasters demanding to hear the music, rai finally made its way to Algerian radio and television. And in 1985 Cheb Khaled organized the first official Festival of Rai in Algeria. A year later Algerians in Paris sponsored a rai festival there.
But the political situation in Algeria was deteriorating. Khaled left for France in 1986, in part to escape mandatory military service. "They said that if you went in the army, Khaled, all the young boys would want to serve, too, just like Elvis Presley," he recalled. By 1988, when Algeria was racked by riots, many other rai stars had left the country.
A fundamentalist regime took over Algeria's government in the early 90's, imposing harsh restrictions. "They would tell people that it was the music of the devil, of Satan," Khaled said. During the 90's factions carried out random killings. One rai singer, Cheb Hasni, accepted an offer to return and perform at a stadium in 1994. Afterward members of the Armed Islamic Group shot him dead, reportedly because he let girls kiss him on the cheek during the televised concert. 
"We kept the music alive in other countries," Khaled said. In 1992 his "Didi," with a strong funk undercurrent, became an international hit. Expatriates like Cheb Mami and a generation of rai singers born in France have produced a glossier, more worldly version of rai.
Under its current government, Algeria has become more hospitable to rai. An 8 p.m. curfew has been lifted, and cabarets have reopened in Oran "every 200 meters," Khaled said. An Algerian rose wine has been named Cuvee Khaled, and he has gone back to play stadium shows. "They look at me as the treasure of Algeria now," he said. 
Hakim's music, shaabi, could be a cousin of rai: another streetwise homegrown style with a pop makeover. Songs often begin with a mournful vocal improvisation called the mawal before leaping into melodies with a galloping beat. In early years shaabi's irreverence and amorous metaphors sometimes faced censorship; lately it has been accepted as mainstream Egyptian pop.
Hakim is part of shaabi's modern generation. After singing in shaabi groups as a teenager, he earned a degree in communications before defying his parents to go back into music. In the early 90's he became one of the first shaabi singers to add electric instruments to the traditional drums, flutes and violin. "For me it was a musical challenge, and I didn't care if it was going to succeed," he said. "I was 99 percent sure I was not going to make it, but I succeeded 101 percent." 
Hakim most often sings about love and longing. His favorite among his current songs is a letter from an expatriate son to the mother he dearly misses. But a listener who does not speak Arabic might not notice the sadness of the words. 
"I sing everything with happiness," Hakim said. "Some of my songs, with the words that I sing, I could have tears in my eyes, but I will be dancing at the same time. We came to this world to be happy and peaceful and not to fight. So we are here to make people happy, and to make them understand that there is hope and life." 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Hakim, left, and Khaled are big recording stars in their home countries. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)(pg. E3); Khaled, left, from Algeria, and Hakim, from Egypt, are touring North America. (Steve Hart for The New York Times)(pg. E1)

HEADLINE: This Time, Chocolate Takes a Powder 

BYLINE:  By REGINA SCHRAMBLING 

 BODY:
COCOA has always had an image problem.
 For years it was considered the poor substitute for chocolate, the pallid powder that needed major help from margarine and still could not produce a decent brownie. Then it became scorned as the low-fat but sad alternative to chocolate used by so many pastry chefs during the recent reign of nutrition terror. It even lost its cachet as a hot drink once it was replaced by melted Callebaut and cream. 
 But lately cocoa has been turning up on all the best shelves. High-end chocolate producers like Val rhona, Christopher Norman and Fauchon now make cocoa powders that leave Hershey's in the dust. I first noticed the phenomenon a couple of years ago in France, where every good chocolatier sells bags of cocoa, but lately even supermarkets here carry Ghirardelli alongside the Nestle's and the house brand. Natural food stores known for carob now offer a choice in cocoa: organic Ah!laska or Green & Black's Fairtrade Organic Cocoa. 
Last week, in a whirlwind of shopping and baking, I was able to buy and try no fewer than 15 varieties. I made shortbread, muffins, two kinds of cookies and many cakes, using powders that cost as little as $2.50 and as much as $16 for about half a pound.
What I found would surprise any baker accustomed to starting a dessert recipe by melting a pound of pricey chocolate with a stick or two of equally extravagant butter. Cocoa, even inexpensive cocoa, has a deep, dark intensity of flavor and an amazing versatility that even the best brands of 77 percent cacao chocolate lack. It cannot replace chocolate. But in recipes designed to make the most of its sharp taste and chemical capabilities, nothing works better than cocoa.
Some brands, particularly La Maison du Chocolat and Fauchon, are so thick and rich that they almost turn into ganache if you do nothing more than blend them with sugar and a little water. They are far too strong just to brew into hot chocolate, but then most of these new cocoas do not seem to be intended for something so common. There are dozens of other, lesser cocoas for that, the kind mixed with sugar, powdered milk and unknown flavorings. The best cocoa for baking is just cocoa.
The explosion in the cocoa category is all the more surprising considering how completely the powder fell out of favor in the age of excess that followed the era of fat fears, as Americans traded Snackwells for molten chocolate cakes. Death by chocolate was not going to come in powdered form. If a pastry chef picked up a container of cocoa at all, it was only to dredge chocolate truffles or sift over tiramisu. Today, cookbooks by pastry wizards like Claudia Fleming do not even mention cocoa in the index.
But in their rush to melt high-quality chocolate in increasingly extravagant quantities, chefs and recipe writers lost touch with a remarkable ingredient. It was as if they had abandoned mushrooms after discovering black truffles. One is not better than the other. They just have to be treated differently.
Maury Rubin, the owner of City Bakery, acknowledges that several versions of his deep, dark, rich cookies are made with cocoa. Combined with chocolate, it creates an intensity neither component can provide on its own. And even at the high-priced end of the spectrum, it is an extremely economical addition to a baker's bag of tricks. As little as a tablespoon can flavor a dessert.
Chefs brave enough to admit they use cocoa tend to sing its praises in florid terms. Amy Scherber, the owner of Amy's Breads, said Valrhona in particular adds a special color and depth to baked goods. "You get a chocolatey chocolate flavor," she said.
Richard Chirol, a French-trained pastry chef, agreed in explaining why he uses cocoa lavishly in pear tarts and other desserts at Musette, a takeout shop on Third Avenue (19th Street). "It's like you get two different flavors," he said. "For some reason, cocoa leaves more bitterness in the mouth." And that's a good thing.
But in my experience, cocoa does more than intensify flavor and sharpen edges. It also creates a moist, perfect crumb in a cake, a crisp bite in a cookie. Ms. Scherber likens it to "black flour." As it blends into dry ingredients, it transforms the results no less than baking powder does.
The big lie of baking is that three tablespoons of cocoa powder combined with one tablespoon of fat can replace an ounce of chocolate. Every basic cookbook repeats it, but I learned at any early age that Betty Crocker was fooling. Nothing replicates the richness of chocolate.
Cocoa works best in recipes that are designed for it. Buttermilk brings out its tanginess, and the two combine to produce a springy texture in a cake. Even something as simple as the classic Amazon, or black-bottom, cake found in so many cookbooks uses no dairy products or eggs, only vegetable oil and vinegar with cold water. The cocoa reacts to the combination to produce the darkest, moistest cake seen outside the photo on a box of mix.
Some cocoas, particularly the dark, strong ones from Fauchon and La Maison du Chocolat, are vital in a recipe like a crisp shortbread or plain cookie in which the chocolate flavor is all important. But you can fudge if the cookie or cake recipe calls for a tiny bit of real chocolate, or chocolate chips, and use a lesser brand. The whole will be greater than the chips.
Until last week, I always thought the type of cocoa made a difference. I had switched to Droste, a Dutch brand, about 18 years ago after discovering how much better it worked in baking than Hershey's, which has a harshness that no amount of sugar can temper. Now the cocoas on the market are almost evenly divided between Dutch style and natural, like Hershey's.
Step 1 of producing any cocoa powder is always the same: after cocoa butter is extracted from cacao, the pods are pressed again to make a cake with no fat, just flavor. What happens next separates the sharp from the mellow. If the cake is just converted into a powder, it is considered natural and has a more aggressive, unadulterated chocolate taste. If it is first Dutched, or treated with an alkali like potassium carbonate (similar to sodium bicarbonate), the color and flavor are enhanced. Alkalization makes a mellow cocoa, but it can also be a way of camouflaging inferior cocoa beans.
Not all labels disclose the processing, but you can guess a brand is natural if the box says "100 percent cocoa." Many either say Dutch process or list alkali as an ingredient.
Some of the newly available cocoas have a powerful chocolate taste even though no alkali is involved. But the Dutched varieties are almost uniformly exceptional. In particular, I could discern no difference in texture, taste or color between a cake baked with Valrhona natural and one made with Master Choice alkalized cocoa, a house brand from Food Emporium for less than half the price.
Chefs tend to use Valrhona. Amy Scherber adds it to her dough for chocolate bread for Valentine's Day because it contributes chocolate flavor without any sweetness; the contrast is that much sharper when she kneads chocolate chunks in.
At Payard on the Upper East Side, Francois Payard uses cocoa as a flavoring agent in the crisp phyllo dough that forms the foundation for napoleons and mille-feuilles layered with chocolate mousse. He said he liked the "crunch and bitterness" the cocoa added. It's like the dusting of cocoa powder seen on so many dessert plates, but it lets a diner savor the flavor as much as the effect.
Wayne Harley Brachman, who is famous for pulling dessert ideas out of a 50's oven, simply likes how cocoa performs in his respectfully retro creations. As consulting pastry chef at the new Lawrence Scott Restaurant on the Upper East Side, he uses it as the foundation of the chocolate pudding that is in turn the base of his banana cream pie. He also mixes it into the mocha filling for his mocha icebox cake. But he said his biggest revelation came when he tried it in ice cream, after finally reading the label on Haagen-Dazs chocolate and realizing that it was cocoa, not chocolate, that contributed the singularly intense taste and texture.
Mr. Brachman also pointed out that cocoa has a huge advantage over chocolate for a home cook because it is simply so easy to work with. No melting is required, only a little sifting at most. It will never seize up or turn bitter as chocolate can.
Those are no small virtues, but to me there's one more advantage. Cocoa is tidier. Chocolate leaves a kitchen looking like a crime scene. After working with cocoa, you only need to dust.

CHOCOLATE QUAKES
Adapted from "Got Milk? The Cookie Book" by Peggy Cullen (Chronicle Books, 2000)
Time: 30 minutes, plus 1 hour's chilling

3 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted
1/2 cup sugar
1 large egg
1/2 teaspoon vanilla
3 tablespoons cocoa, preferably Dutch process
1/2 cup flour
1/2 teaspoon baking powder
1/8 teaspoon salt
1/4 cup finely ground pecans or almonds
1/4 cup semisweet chocolate chips
About 3/4 cup confectioners' sugar.
1. In a medium bowl using an electric mixer, beat the butter, sugar, egg and vanilla on low speed until pale yellow in color and thickened, about 1 minute. Sift the cocoa, flour, baking powder and salt into the bowl, and mix on low speed until incorporated. Fold in the nuts and chocolate chips. 
2. Cover, and chill until dough is firm enough to handle, about 1 hour.
3. Heat oven to 350 degrees. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper or foil. Place confectioners' sugar in a medium bowl.
3. Form the chilled dough into 1-inch balls. Place in confectioners' sugar, and roll to coat completely. Place on a baking sheet, leaving about 1 1/2 inches between each cookie. Bake 12 minutes, or until the cookies are puffed and the sugared surfaces have cracked apart. The centers will appear underdone. Remove from the oven and let sit for 5 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.
Yield: About 2 dozen.

CHOCOLATE BANANA CREAM PIE
Adapted from Wayne Harley Brachman
Time: 30 minutes, plus about 2 hours for cooling and refrigerating the pie filling

For the filling:

4 ounces bittersweet chocolate, chopped
2 tablespoons unsalted butter
2 tablespoons cornstarch
1/4 cup unsweetened Dutch process cocoa
1/2 cup sugar
2 1/2 cups milk
1 large egg
2 large egg yolks.

For the pie:

1 prebaked 9-inch pie shell or 9 1/2-inch tart shell
2 ripe bananas, peeled and sliced 1/4 inch thick
1/2 cup confectioners' sugar
1/4 cup unsweetened cocoa
2 cups heavy cream.
1. Prepare the filling: Using a microwave oven or double boiler, melt together the chocolate and the butter. In a medium bowl, combine the cornstarch, cocoa and 1/4 cup of sugar. Add 1/4 cup of the milk, and stir to blend. Add the eggs and yolks, and whisk until smooth.
2. In a medium saucepan, combine the remaining 2 1/4 cups milk and the remaining 1/4 cup sugar. Place over medium heat until scalded. Slowly drizzle the milk into the cocoa mixture, stirring gently with a whisk to blend the mixture without aerating it.
3. Return the mixture to the saucepan, and cook over medium heat until tiny bubbles boil up for 3 seconds. Remove from the heat, and strain into a clean bowl. Add the melted chocolate mixture, and stir until thoroughly blended. Place wax paper directly on the surface of the pudding and let cool at room temperature 1 hour, then refrigerate until completely chilled.
4. To assemble, spoon half the pudding into the baked pie shell (reserve the remainder for another use, or eat it plain). Arrange the banana slices evenly and decoratively over the top. Sift the confectioners' sugar and cocoa together into a bowl, and add the heavy cream; mix well. Whip until the cream is the consistency of shaving cream. Spoon over the bananas in the pie shell, and serve.
Yield: One 9-inch pie (8 servings).

AMAZON CAKE
Adapted from "Cafe Beaujolais" by Margaret Fox and John S. Bear (Ten Speed Press, 1984)
Time: 40 minutes

1 1/2 cups flour
1/3 cup unsweetened cocoa
1 teaspoon baking soda
1 cup sugar
1/2 teaspoon salt
5 tablespoons corn oil
1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla
1 tablespoon cider vinegar
Confectioners' sugar.
Heat the oven to 350 degrees. Whisk together the flour, cocoa, baking soda, sugar and salt. In a separate bowl, whisk together the oil, vanilla and vinegar with 1 cup cold water. Whisk in the dry ingredients, blending until completely lump-free. Pour into a greased 9-inch round cake pan. Bake for 30 to 35 minutes, or until the top springs back when pressed gently. Cool before removing from the pan and dusting with confectioners' sugar, or frosting if desired.
Yield: 6 to 8 servings.

F6); A BIT BITTER -- At Payard, cocoa flavors the phyllo dough of a mille-feuille with chocolate mousse. (Michael Rogol for The New York Times)(pg. F1)

HEADLINE: A Taste Of the Town, Or Letdown City? 

BYLINE:  By AMANDA HESSER 

 BODY:
SMITH & WOLLENSKY, the steakhouse, is not a place I would usually choose for lunch. But it was Restaurant Week, and for $20.02, it seemed the perfect time to try it.
 "Here you go, young lady," the waiter said as he handed me the menu, clearly angling for a good tip. He was off to a good start. 
 Three courses later, I left, having paid $58. How, you ask? The add-ons. I ordered a $9 side of sauteed spinach with my lonely fillet. I had a $5.25 cup of coffee and a $10.75 glass of wine, the cheapest red on the list. 
Then I stomped back to work. 
It was the beginning of an odyssey shared by thousands of New Yorkers, who descend on the city's restaurants during Restaurant Week. Forget the World Economic Forum. Commerce and traffic more likely slowed over the last week because diners were skipping out of work and filling up the restaurants offering $20.02 lunches and $30.02 dinners. Many diners, foodies and novices alike, are taking advantage of the two-week promotion, which ends Friday, trying restaurants they couldn't normally afford or wouldn't want to dole out $100 to try. And the restaurants are showing off, trying to convert the newcomers into full paying devotees. 
That's the theory, at least. And it is so popular that other cities, including London and San Francisco, have begun their own Restaurant Week. And New York restaurants like Gotham Bar and Grill and Nougatine have adopted the $20.02 lunch formula year round.
But while I listened to other diners recall each exquisite course at Chanterelle, my batting average plummeted. This year, the 10th anniversary of Restaurant Week, I set out to dine at as many places as I could, to see what $20.02 would buy. I had 156 restaurants to choose from, up from about 100 the first year. The range of experiences was stunning. 
There were menus, like the one at San Domenico, that seemed to have nothing in common with the regular menu or the style of the chef. There were schemes that managed to double and even triple the menu price. At Nougatine, a request for chardonnay brought a $14 glass of wine. More than once, I got the eye roll from waiters when I asked for the $20.02 menu and had my courses slung at me as if at a diner.
But I was also delighted. A restaurant I had dismissed as passe was transformed before my eyes as I savored a splendid lunch. Another, which I had considered a tourist trap, presented a sensible and delicious menu.
It took me a few tries, however, before I reached such high notes. On the way to my table at Michael Jordan's: The Steak House in Grand Central Terminal, I commented to the hostess how pleasant it must be to work in such a beautiful space. "It just pays my bills," she told me. "I don't get all psyched up about it." I was, however, psyched up about my meal. I was hungry. A friend and I began with chopped salad with corn, peas and a tomato vinaigrette. Only it had that sad leaf quality of a salad forgotten in the hot sun. Sauteed halibut was pleasant, with tender slivers of eggplant beneath the fish, but I was distracted by my friend's filet mignon sandwich. Could I trust a steakhouse that serves a flavorless cut like filet mignon as its special? Dessert answered that. A single scoop of tangerine sorbet arrived in a giant round bowl. I peered in, and it reminded me of a pebble at the bottom of a well. 
It made me think of what Tim Zagat, a founder of Restaurant Week, said. "It's in the interest of the restaurant to do it well," he said. "If the restaurant goes cheap, the restaurant is just damaging its own image."
Indeed. Next time, I'll buy a hot dog and take in the view from the terminal steps.
I forged onward. I hadn't yet spent what I might have at just one expensive restaurant on a normal night. Which is exactly what Restaurant Week is about. 
Restaurant Week grew out of a 1992 promotion meant to impress the thousands of delegates and journalists who came to New York for the Democratic National Convention. Joe Baum, then the owner of the Rainbow Room, and Mr. Zagat, forged the plan. "A lot of restaurants were shocked that someone would ask them to do a meal for $19," Mr. Zagat said. "We explained that it was just for four days." The response was nothing they ever expected. After an advertisement in The New York Times announced the event, restaurants drowned in calls for reservations, not from visiting delegates, but from New Yorkers. Bouley received more than 2,000 calls in a single day.
It was such a success that Restaurant Week became an annual event and eventually a biannual event to boost business in the slow weeks of summer and winter. This year, after the attacks on the World Trade Center, a third week was added in October, to bolster restaurants whose business had nearly halted. In many cases, it worked.
"What it really turned out to be," Mr. Zagat said, "was a kind of insurance policy for people from getting burned when they go to a fancy restaurant. It was saying you could walk in and out with dignity for $20."
It's also a chance to compare apples with apples, said Danny Meyer, the owner of restaurants like Gramercy Tavern and Tabla, and the director of the restaurant committee at NYC & Company, the convention and visitors bureau, which organizes the promotion. "For the same price, for the same amount of courses," he said, "you get an expert's view of how a restaurant approaches cooking, hospitality and service."
The restaurants must be invited by NYC & Company -- they cannot volunteer. The restaurants are chosen by Mr. Zagat and a committee of five restaurateurs: Mr. Meyer, Rita Jammet of La Caravelle, Steve Hanson of Ruby Foo's, Tony May of San Domenico and Tracy Nieporent of the Myriad Restaurant Group. The criteria, Mr. Meyer said, are quality and diversity.
For the restaurants chosen, Mr. Meyer said, "It's almost impossible to make money at $20.02 -- 1992 to 2002 does not represent the rate of inflation. If it was a good deal in 1992, it's a stupendous deal now."
Such is the case at Gotham Bar and Grill, where you almost feel guilty for the deal you get. I went to Gotham for a simple reason. Its fashionable days are past, and I wasn't sure I wanted to spend $85 on a meal there. Now I will. 
There were two choices for each course. Their Caesar salad came as it always has, in a generous portion with the inner romaine leaves slicked with a garlicky dressing and stacked on top of one another like logs. The soup was a hearty celery root puree. In the center of the bowl was a small pile of braised short ribs ringed with thin swirls of olive oil. Pappardelle with duck sausage and broccoli rape was a spray of color with bits of carrot, green broccoli rape, dark green herbs and pink pieces of duck. It was sweet, bitter and a touch spicy. The salmon lay on a fluffy pillow of potato puree. Slices of leek, mushrooms and carrot filled in the gaps. Desserts, especially chocolate cake with espresso ice cream, silenced us and made me sorry I had agreed to share. 
Perhaps better than the food was the deal on wine. For $20.02 more, you may choose 3 wines from a list of 10 to match your meal. For mine, that included a 1997 Zind-Humbrecht Muscat Gueberschwihr Goldert, normally $78 a bottle, and a 1996 Verset Cornas from the Rhone Valley, which would have cost $62 a bottle (The reds included a valpolicella from a $105 bottle or a $110 Corison cabernet sauvignon). That kind of special could keep me coming daily, if I didn't have a job to keep.
Our waiter didn't flinch when we ordered the $20.02 menu and never urged us to hurry. When we were ready to leave, he packed up our extra petits fours.
At this time of year, filling a restaurant for lunch is a distinct challenge -- something readily apparent as I marched into Artisanal. The restaurant was just half full. It took almost my entire meal to get bread delivered to my table, but in the meantime, many delicious dishes arrived. There was raclette with bacon and fingerling potatoes, speckled with flakes of sea salt. And chicken paillard, branded with grill marks, with a chestnut dressing. It looked like a crepe covering the plate. For a moment, the idea of being able to dine on a well-prepared old-fashioned dish like this was moving. Restaurant Week and its good intentions made their imprint. 
The next day, I was back in the ring, fighting for a spot at Rock Center Cafe, which hummed along, with lines of people waiting for tables. I was led to one in the center of the room, right in front of the windows by the skating rink. I was handed a regular menu, and when I asked for the Restaurant Week menu, the waiter paused, suspicious. "Did you specify Restaurant Week when you reserved?" 
"No," I said. And, of course, I wouldn't have. Had I, given this reaction, I might not have gotten a prime table. It's something I encountered all week long. Many restaurants quietly discourage you from ordering by not letting you know they have these menus. As a result, at restaurants like Rock Center Cafe, an average of only 15 percent of guests order from the Restaurant Week menu. 
Experienced Restaurant Week diners told me they often order from the prix-fixe menu anyway or order an expensive bottle of wine. But it is difficult to feel such liberty when you sense the restaurant is hiding something from you. Meanwhile, at Gramercy Tavern, it is the only menu you are offered and you have six appetizers, six entrees and six desserts to choose from. The only problem is that you can't get in unless you speed-dial the morning the ad appears in the paper.
Still, my lunch at Rock Center Cafe was quite good. I made my way through a large fluffy salad with celery, fennel and tender pieces of roasted tomato, while an ice show unfolded before me. Then there were short penne, called bomboloni, huddled in a bowl under a light, sweet Bolognese with tiny cubes of beef. I chose it over roasted salmon and roasted Amish chicken. There was Key lime pie, chocolate mousse parfait and apple crumb cake for dessert.
By the time I went to One C.P.S. in the Plaza, I was unafraid to ask for the menu. In a brazen moment, I mentioned to a man sitting alone that there was a special $20.02 menu they weren't telling him about. He nodded and smiled in the careful, controlled manner of someone trying both to appease and dismiss a crazy person on the subway. (He ordered lamb chops and a creme brulee and left.) 
Given my lunch -- onion soup with an impenetrable bulge of cheese on top, a salade nicoise that was plenty for four and creme brulee, which came out completely cold -- perhaps he knew better. 
My last lunch was at Patria. After I ordered scallops ceviche for my appetizer, it arrived so quickly I wondered if the cook were telepathic. Ceviche takes a few minutes to marinate, for the citrus to "cook" the scallops. What I got was something more like prefab ceviche, delivered less than a minute after ordering. 
A similar thing happened at San Domenico, where after I asked for the Restaurant Week menu, which offered no choices, it was delivered to our table in a cafeteria style rush.
The food, however, was good. Next, I got a piece of mahi-mahi, perfectly cooked, perched on top of a circle of coconut rice with dabs of chimichurri sauce. The plate was blue-green glass, and the fish and rice took up such a small part of it that they looked like an atoll in the middle of the sea. I ate every last drop of my dessert -- chocolate cake on skewers, which you dip into a hazelnut sauce. An hour later, I was ready for dinner. 
These are quibbles, of course. But I am not quibbling when I mention that the coffee I ordered with my dessert cost $6. 
For $20, you can become a regular. But for just $6, you can become a detractor spreading the bad word.

HEADLINE: Mixed Economic Reports Bolster Caution by Fed 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Factory orders rose 1.2 percent in December, bolstering recent evidence that manufacturing may be poised for a recovery. But a separate survey showed that growth in the service sector stalled in January.
 Together, the data helped solidify a view outlined by the Federal Reserve last week, when it left interest rates unchanged, that despite hopeful signs of improvement in recent months, there are significant risks of further economic weakness. 
 "There are still major risks to the U.S. economy as today's data clearly show," said Drew Matus, financial economist at Lehman Brothers. "We expect the Fed will remain on hold throughout most of the year."
The Commerce Department said yesterday that factory orders climbed to $322.2 billion, after a revised 4.3 percent decline in November. It was the second rise in the last three months and was mostly in line with forecasts.
Transportation equipment orders had the largest gains, rising 3.6 percent, to $49.8 billion, largely because of increased orders for missiles, space vehicles and parts.
Orders for computers and electronics parts were up strongly, gaining 3.1 percent in December, to $33.2 billion, bolstered by a 12.7 percent rise in orders for semiconductors.
In a hopeful sign for future production, inventories fell 0.6 percent in December, to $448.8 billion.
The outlook for the service sector, however, dimmed somewhat last month. 
The Institute for Supply Management, formerly the National Association of Purchasing Management, said yesterday that its nonmanufacturing index edged lower to a reading of 49.6 in January from a revised 50.1 in December. That followed two consecutive months of increases. Economists had forecast a rise to 52.
A reading below 50 indicates contraction in the services sector, which includes everything from transportation to legal and financial services. The institute's more closely watched manufacturing index has been mired below 50 for the last year and a half, but rallied to 49.9 in January, spurring recovery hopes.
Another report from the outplacement firm of Challenger, Gray & Christmas showed that layoff announcements surged 32 percent, to 212,704 in January from 161,584 in December, raising concerns a recent stabilization in first-time unemployment claims could to be fleeting.

HEADLINE: After Closing, Longing for the Old School 

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

DATELINE: ARMONK, N.Y., Feb. 5 

 BODY:
There was considerable strife in affluent Armonk when, in the 1980's, the Byram Hills Central School District decided to sell the Bear Ridge School, one of its three elementary schools. A big notion held the day: the district's enrollment was declining and the decline would not reverse itself in the foreseeable future.
 And so the 23,500-square-foot school on 15 hilly, leafy acres was sold to the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. for $2 million. The sale closed in 1987, right about the time when the district's population began to cycle back up. In the past 10 years, in fact, enrollment has risen every single year, and many times the $2 million made from the sale of Bear Ridge has been spent to add back the space that was sold, leaving a legacy of raw feelings. 
 "Anyone with any sort of vision or brains," said Merril Sobie, who sent two children through the district, "could have seen that all that open land in Armonk would be built on and the school district's population would eventually go back up." 
Armonk has not been alone in its botched forecast. Other suburbs in Westchester County -- as well as ones across the country and in cities like New York, which sold off 65 school buildings in the fiscally painful 1970's, have been proven embarrassingly and expensively wrong after they shuttered or sold off schools that seemed unneeded.
While the decision to shutter, sell or build a school is often the biggest emotional and economic decision in the life of a community, it is often made on little more than a hunch.
The process casts the district's superintendent, a career educator, in the unlikely role of real estate mogul, a job for which he may have no training.
"You have this local guy, and he's trying to do his job, but as he's doing it, he has to read the tea leaves of all these national trends," said Dr. Saul Cooperman, the former commissioner of education for New Jersey and author of "How Schools Really Work: Practical Advice for Parents From an Insider" (Open Court Publishing Company).
A sense must be developed for birth rates, housing starts, economic trends, everything, Dr. Cooperman added, "right down to the question of how many old Coopermans are going to move out of the community and how many new Coopermans will move in."
Intuiting such matters, "five years out is always a cinch. But 10 to 15?" Dr. Cooperman laughed. "It ain't easy."
And then there are the school boards. "Politics can get very devious," Dr. Cooperman said.
He said there are plenty of sincere school board members everywhere who have legitimate concerns that the old buildings in question are "dogs" and will drain their district financially. There is also a healthy supply of board members who have political ambitions and want to avoid raising school taxes in the short term, no matter what the costs might be later on.
As the population grew in the suburban ring around New York City during the 1950's and 1960's, school growth followed. But by 1974, when Dr. Cooperman sat for an interview to be superintendent of schools in Madison, N.J., the district's population had been decreasing for several years. "During my interview, the board told me that the Green Village Road School was way under functional capacity, so I said, 'Why haven't you closed it?' They smiled and said they were waiting for the new superintendent to give his view."
Thomas Maguire was the superintendent of the Byram Hills Central School District at the time of the Bear Ridge sale. "It was a good decision at the time," said Mr. Maguire in a recent interview. "We might have held onto the property, if we could have used it for any other purpose." This was difficult, however, in a neighborhood zoned residential and faced with community opposition to many other uses. "The building would have had to just sit there for 10 years," he said. 
When the Parkway Elementary School in Greenwich, Conn., which was built in 1959, was closed in June 1981, enrollment in the Greenwich Public Schools had fallen to 8,570 students, down about 15 percent in just two years, and the district sought a buyer for the school.
"Parkway was marketed as a corporate headquarters," said John H. Spang Jr., the assistant director of business for the Greenwich School District, "but there were no takers." As a plan B, the 52,000-square-foot building, which sits on 17 acres in a prime location of town known as "backcountry Greenwich" was used by the town for everything from voting machine storage to emergency medical service space.
Holding onto the building proved to be a lucky choice. In the summer of 1990, another school in the district burned down and Parkway was brought up to code and recommissioned by fall. The major challenge:
"The lawn around the school had not been mown by the town," Mr. Spang said, and the grass "was full of snakes."
By this school year, the district's population had returned to the level it was at when Parkway was originally closed. The district is anticipating an increase to 9,469 students (from 8,800 this year) by the 2011-12 school year.
During flush economic times, schools are built and added onto with little hesitancy. In 2000, after the economic expansion of the late 1990's, for example, construction of new buildings and add-ons for elementary, middle and high schools in the United States, topped $21 billion, according to American School and University magazine, representing a doubling in such activity since 1995. .
But in slow economic climates, districts tend to scale back -- as in the era in which New York City closed the 65 buildings during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's.
"Theoretically there was still going to be enough capacity in the future," explained Noreen Connell, the executive director of the Education Priorities Panel, a coalition of 24 civic organizations that monitors schools.
Enrollment projections made when the schools were closed in the 1970's "were not based on the premise that there would be a big new wave of immigration into the city," Mrs. Connell said. But there soon was. Nor, she added, did the projection allow for the fact that new immigrants might settle in areas of the five boroughs where previous waves of immigrants had not settled before.
"Queens was always the borough of the stable, working middle class," said Mrs. Connell. 
Today, as its school system struggles with serious issues of overcrowding and a sagging economy forcing cutbacks in the capital budget, the city misses those buildings it scuttled. "Repairing a plumbing system will not increase academic achievement, but reduce overcrowding and you might," said Mrs. Connell. 
Overcrowding wasn't the problem, however, when Dr. Cooperman took that superintendent's job in Madison, so one of his first acts was to go on a "dog and pony" show to explain why the Green Village Road School should be closed. Community reaction? "They wanted to run me out on a rail," Dr. Cooperman recalled. Residents had favorite teachers, a favored principal and some had chosen their homes specifically because they were near the school. "People were saying, 'If my little Alfie can't go to that school, I'm going to move.' And some did. It was pretty darn emotional and I didn't blame the people one bit."
A quarter of a century later, the fate of the Green Village Road School is still an open question. It was closed in the mid-1970's and has been used to house a nursery school, a theater group and for other community purposes. "But it's getting more and more difficult to keep, especially in this economy," said Art Travlos, the current superintendent of Madison schools. "We've been spending a good amount of time deciding what to do with the school."
Demographic studies have been commissioned, consultants have been brought in to do comparisons of how much it would cost to renovate the building versus building a new one. And its sale value has been appraised.
"We're trying to foretell the future," Mr. Travlos said.

HEADLINE: CUNY, Short on Faculty, Is to End Free Term for Seniors 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Trying to raise money to hire more full-time professors, the City University of New York plans to end a 10-year-old policy of not charging four-year college students for their last semester of school.
 The plan also calls for a new student technology fee and greater administrative and operating efficiencies. 
 CUNY abandoned its century-old policy of free tuition in the mid-1970's during New York City's fiscal crisis, and tuition for state residents is now $3,200 a year at the four-year colleges. But in 1992, as a salve to compensate for tuition raises of $600 imposed that year, CUNY adopted a policy that gave students on the verge of graduation their last semester free. The first class to benefit graduated in 1996. 
The CUNY trustees' fiscal affairs committee approved a plan late Monday that includes an end to the free-last-semester policy, and the full board is expected to do the same later this month. The student representative on the fiscal affairs committee protested that the higher charges conflicted with the university's mission of "keeping the costs of higher education affordable."
"We will never support measures that only provide pain for students and their families and put the interests of a few ahead of the needs and dreams of thousands of New Yorkers," said the student, Valerie Vazquez, who recalled CUNY's long tradition of free tuition.
CUNY officials predicted that the plan would save nearly $45 million a year when phased in over the next few years, and pledged that the savings would go directly to the campuses. Ms. Vazquez called the technology fee "a back-door tuition hike."
CUNY's chancellor, Matthew Goldstein, said that by ending the free-last-semester program the university would raise $9 million in tuition revenues each year, which would pay for 150 additional full-time professors. And he said that those professors would help more students than the approximately 6,000 students each year who benefit from the free last semester.
Because of budget pressures, the number of full-time professors at CUNY has fallen below 6,000, from the 11,268 on the payroll in 1975; they have been replaced by part-time adjunct professors who are paid significantly less. Many educators feel a college without a sufficient proportion of full-time faculty members loses its cohesiveness and mission.
In some academic departments, the number of full-time teachers has plummeted strikingly. At City College, for example, there are 31 full-time education professors now, down from 69 in 1981, while the English department, which now includes speech and theater, has fallen to 33 from 68 in the same period.
Dr. Goldstein said that because of state and city budget stringencies, CUNY was short $150 million a year needed to implement its master plan, which was approved by the trustees and the New York Board of Regents. The university has a $1.5 billion budget this year. Tuition has not been increased since 1996.
Several CUNY trustees applauded the money-raising proposals and called them an example of "thinking outside the box."
"This is not the old way of doing business," said Joseph J. Lhota, a trustee who served as a deputy mayor and city budget director under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and is now chairman of CUNY's fiscal affairs committee.
Dr. Goldstein said that a technology fee of $150 a year for full-time students and $75 for part-time students would allow CUNY to provide badly needed computer services and longer computer hours for students.
CUNY also provided a chart showing that the proposed fee was far lower than the fees of $238 to $1,400 a year charged by the various campuses of the State University of New York.
Sherry Brabham, CUNY's vice chancellor for budget, finance and administrative computing, said that New York City high school graduates who maintain at least a B average now have access to a Peter F. Vallone academic achievement scholarship, which provides close to half of the cost of tuition for up to five years. She said the scholarships, which did not exist when the free-last-semester program was set up in 1992, are potentially worth more than the last-semester tuition break.
Allan Dobrin, CUNY's senior vice chancellor and chief operating officer, outlined some of the ways that CUNY could save money through operating efficiencies. They include using a specialized consultant to scour university phone bills for billing errors, adding four digits to ZIP codes on mailings and centralizing telephone and other services.
He also said that CUNY planned a pilot project that would combine administrative services at its three campuses in the Bronx -- Lehman, Hostos Community College and Bronx Community College -- by looking at which campus handles which services most efficiently..
"For backroom personnel processing," Mr. Dobrin said, "I assume that no student really cares where we do this."

Graphs track tuition per semester (adjusted for inflation) and full-time faculty from 1975-2000.(Source: City University of New York)

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL; 
A Long-Sought Rally Takes the Chill Off a Boston Winter

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 5 

 BODY:
Like color rushing back to the cheeks of a weary patient, a parade of red, white and blue flushed the winter-gray landscape here today. The Patriots' victory lap, along a two-mile downtown route before an estimated 1.2 million people, could not have arrived at a better time for Gail Chamberlain, who just received a pink slip from her employer, Lucent Technologies. 
 "I'm losing my job in 60 days," she said, "but the Patriots won the championship!" 
 With the economy trying to get a grip, the pain of Sept. 11 still tangible, and Boston dour with February cold, "it's a depressing time of year," said Chamberlain, 44, of Salem, N.H. "But people here are happy. We needed this." 
Her co-worker, Karen Kemp, 44, of Nottingham, N.H., said their bosses thought it suspicious that they called in sick -- a day in advance. "We have the New England flu!" she declared to the crowd around her.
Even Paula Reynolds, 50, the third in their party, could be only mildly upset when she spied her 16-year-old daughter among the throng of fans, instead of at school. "Her father is going to be mad he's the only one who didn't come," she said with a laugh. 
Patriots fan or not, it was a holiday. One lawyer said her firm told employees either to stay home or join the fray, because no clients were willing to brave the traffic and subway congestion. Those few businessmen who were trying to cross the financial district on foot were all but swallowed by the masses. Acting Governor Jane Swift gave nonessential state employees an hour leave for the occasion, although there was no need to pad the audience.
Students organized their own field trips. Mark McDonnell, 17, and two friends skipped out of classes at Winnacunnet High School in Hampton, N.H. "This is the first championship of our generation," he said, adding that he was only a toddler when the Celtics won.
Slightly older-timers in the crowd debated the comparison: Was this five times as big as the parade for the Boston Celtics when they won it all in 1986? Maybe 10 times? 
The parade route ran from Copley Square to the rally at people-drenched City Hall Plaza. Fans climbed walls, lampposts, trees, vehicles and each other, aching for a better view of the procession. Many saw only a glimpse of Coach Bill Belichick and the players as they passed.
Men who, in the football tradition of pain and painted chests, went without shirts today said that adrenaline was keeping them warm. (Fans joked that skeptics had said it would be a cold day when the Patriots won the championship.)
Someone decided the statue of Samuel Adams that stands outside nearby Faneuil Hall needed to wear team colors, and stretched a T-shirt over his bronze frame. He was a patriot, after all. 
Supposedly, spectators lacked alcohol to warm themselves, it being banned by the Boston police along with backpacks and bags.
Some voices were hoarse from Sunday night's revels and Monday's water-cooler talk, but the roars began early in the morning and kept going into the evening. David Lustig, 19, from Roslyn, N.Y., came along with friends, and was stunned by the spectacle. 
"I've been to every Yankees parade in the last decade, and this is completely different," he said. "Everyone here wanted it that much more."
The actual rally show was brief but spirited. "City of Boston, it's been a long time coming, huh?" cried defensive back Lawyer Milloy, who then led the crowd in a chant of "We're No. 1!"
Quarterback Tom Brady, who slapped hands with fans and signed footballs throughout the event, did not speak. But after being urged on by cornerback Ty Law, he did a victory dance on stage with the team's owner, Robert K. Kraft.
Noticeable by his absence from the parade was Drew Bledsoe, the veteran quarterback who lost his job to Brady this season but did come to the rescue in the playoff game against Pittsburgh after Brady was injured. Bledsoe apparently went home to Montana.
There were equal sightings of Brady and Bledsoe jerseys, and every face with Bledsoe's "11" painted on one cheek turned to show a Brady "12" on the other. Eric Park, 29, a Bostonian who owns a sports collectibles business, said that no matter where Bledsoe may go from here, "he's always going to have a place in the hearts of Patriots fans."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Baseball Won't Drop Teams in 2002

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Unable to hurdle legal roadblocks, Major League Baseball yesterday abandoned its plan to eliminate the Minnesota Twins and the Montreal Expos for the coming season. Commissioner Bud Selig strongly stated his intention to shed at least two teams and as many as four for the 2003 season, but circumstances, including more legal challenges, could also short-circuit the new plan.
 Members of the Twins were elated with the expected development. Members of the Expos were silent. "We have no comment on any aspect of contraction since at no point in time have the Expos been said to be one of the teams," Claude Delorme, an Expos vice president, said. 
 The Expos, however, as the major league team with the lowest revenue, have been the No. 1 target of the contraction plan the owners approved last Nov. 6, only to have it challenged immediately by the operator of the Metrodome, the Twins' home, and the players' union.
Despite the challenges, Selig had steadfastly refused to scuttle the plan, that is, until the Minnesota Supreme Court refused Monday to hear baseball's appeal of an injunction that forced the Twins to fulfill their lease by playing the 2002 season.
"While the clubs would have preferred to contract for 2002 and begin addressing the economic issues immediately," Selig said in a statement, "events outside of our direct control, including yesterday's court decision in Minnesota, have required us to move the date of contraction to 2003."
Baseball's economic state makes contraction "absolutely inevitable," Selig added, "as certain franchises simply cannot compete and cannot generate enough revenues to survive." According to figures Selig gave to the House Judiciary Committee in December, the Expos had $34.2 million in operating revenue last year and the Twins the next lowest total, $56.3 million.
In his statement, Selig mentioned the negotiations for a new labor agreement with the players, which expired last November. The results of those talks, he said, will be "important to our ongoing effort to achieve economic reform and competitive balance."
Many clubs, Selig said, favor elimination of four teams. He did not rule out that possibility but said baseball "will continue to evaluate our weakest franchises to determine how much contraction is warranted and in the overall best interests of baseball and its fans."
The Twins, whose owner, Carl Pohlad, was prepared to sacrifice his team because he wanted to get out of baseball, could be salvaged by a number of developments before 2003. The Expos have fewer possibilities of rescue.
Donald Watkins, a Birmingham, Ala., banker and energy entrepreneur, has initiated talks with Pohlad about buying the Twins. He has also indicated a willingness to finance a new park, which baseball has considered a requirement for the Twins to remain in business. The Minnesota Legislature, which in the past has rejected providing any money for a new park, is prepared to reconsider the idea. 
The Expos, whose attendance of 619,451 was less than half of the next lowest attendance in the majors last season, cannot survive in Montreal, but prospective ownership groups in Washington and northern Virginia are eager to acquire a team and may be willing to pay enough to make it worthwhile for baseball to sell the Expos rather than extinguish them.
Jeffrey Loria, a New York art dealer who currently owns the Expos, is buying the Florida Marlins, whose owner, John Henry, heads a group that is buying the Boston Red Sox, and Major League Baseball will acquire the Expos. The owners are expected to approve these transactions next Tuesday.
Loria plans to take a large number of his Montreal employees to Florida, including Manager Jeff Torborg, the interim general manager, Larry Beinfest, and assorted scouts and player development people. He is giving a $5,000 bonus to each Expos employee who accepts his offer to work for the Marlins.
The Expos, meanwhile, will be operated by people baseball hires.
"The commissioner and the executive council are committed to ensuring the Montreal operation will be independent," Bob DuPuy, baseball's chief lawyer, said yesterday, "and the management team, once assembled, will be given full discretion to run the team as any other major league team would be run."
That team is expected to be put in place in the next few days. Tony Tavares, until recently the president of the Anaheim Angels, is considered the leading candidate to be the Expos' No. 1 business executive.
The general manager could be named from a group including Doug Melvin, who held that position with Texas; Gord Ash, who was Toronto's general manager; and Omar Minaya, senior assistant general manager with the Mets. Frank Robinson is expected to be named manager. The Expos will also have a full complement of minor league teams.
The Twins have their management team intact, including Ron Gardenhire, who was named manager last month. Carol Gardenhire said her husband was on a fishing trip and might not even know that he would have a team to manage this season. "I don't know if he knows or not," she said by telephone from their home in Little Canada, Minn. "I haven't talked to him. But it's very exciting. I'm so happy."
Terry Ryan, the Twins' general manager, said the team's employees had been working toward this moment despite the uncertainty.
"Now we can move forward without 2002 being affected," he said by telephone. "We have an opportunity to see what transpires over this season. There's a lot of optimism and energy in this market. There will be a lot of people who will be relieved around these offices."
Dave St. Peter, senior vice president for business affairs, said that despite the question about the team's existence, he expects the Twins to surpass last year's season-ticket total of 5,500 by 1,500. "We can get the focus back to where it should be," he said, "selling tickets and getting ready for spring training."
Twins outfielder Torii Hunter told The Associated Press: "It's the front-office people who needed to know in case they had to find other jobs. And the beer vendors and other workers."
In the news release announcing the contraction decision, Paul Beeston, baseball's chief operating officer, criticized the players' union for challenging baseball's right to eliminate teams unilaterally.
"I, personally, had hoped that the union had an interest in helping us solve our economic and competitive balance problems," said Beeston, baseball's principal labor negotiator. "It is evident now that they have no such interest and that is a great disappointment to me."
The union's "vigorous opposition" to contraction, Beeston added, was inconsistent with discussions the two sides held last spring and summer. Donald Fehr, the union chief, welcomed the contraction decision but said, "It is regrettable that the clubs continue to assert that they can and will act unilaterally, rather than by negotiation and agreement."

 BODY:
 The EMI Group said full-year profit would fall 42 percent, as music sales faltered. Pretax profit will be about $:150 million ($214 million), less than analysts had expected and down from the $:260 million the company earned the previous year. 
EMI and rivals have been hurt by the soft economy, slowing sales of compact discs and the ability of customers to copy music from the Internet free. Since Alain Levy took over at EMI in October he has dropped artists like Mariah Carey and reorganized management. Last week, EMI said its Virgin Records unit would move to New York from Los Angeles and would be led by Matt Serletic. EMI also named Roger Faxon as chief financial officer. David Munns, who Mr. Levy hired after he came on board last October, will be the chief executive of EMI Recorded Music North America. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

HEADLINE: Truck Maker's Profit Falls 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: BELLEVUE, Wash., Feb. 5 

 BODY:
 The truck maker Paccar Inc. said today that its earnings fell 20 percent in the fourth quarter. 
Cost controls partially offset reduced sales in a weak economy, higher insurance costs and declining used-truck values. The company, which makes Kenworth and Peterbilt trucks, said profit fell to $50.4 million, or 65 cents a share, in the quarter ended Dec. 31, from $62.7 million, or 82 cents, in the period a year earlier. Revenue fell to $1.54 billion, from $1.67 billion. Still, earnings were well above the average 49 cents a share expected by Wall Street analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Paccar's stock rose $2.98, or 5 percent, to $66.36 a share.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
PayPal and Other Post-Bubble Signs of Life on the Internet

BYLINE:  By ADAM COHEN 

 BODY:
PayPal has all the trappings of a classic dot-com bubble story. The company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., was conceived in 1998 by Peter Thiel, a smooth-talking hedge fund operator, and Max Levchin, a Russian-immigrant computer geek. It started out with the dubious business model of helping people "beam" money from one Palm Pilot to another. When the market for beamed money proved elusive, it switched to enabling people to e-mail each other cash. Mr. Thiel and Mr. Levchin, who declared that their little start-up would revolutionize commerce, persuaded venture capitalists to pour in more than $225 million.
 Unlike many such dot-com escapades, this little start-up has survived -- and thrived. PayPal has been enthusiastically adopted by the online community. In a single four-month period in 2000, registered users shot up from 10,000 to one million. The company now has over 13 million users, and annual revenues, generated by taking a small percentage of each transaction, of more than $100 million. PayPal isn't a sure thing. It's still not in the black, and it's had trouble with fraud. But it so dominates the fast-growing online payments business that Salomon Smith Barney is expected to take it public tomorrow in one of the most eagerly anticipated Internet I.P.O.'s in nearly two years. 
 Eagerly awaited Internet I.P.O.'s seem hopelessly late-1990's. The dot-coms, we have been told repeatedly, were an end-of-the-century bubble, a "mania" unequaled since the Dutch tulip mania of the 1630's. Many in the news media have been harsh, particularly just after the April 2000 dot-com crash, reveling in the lost fortunes and even the layoffs. The publishing industry has been worse. Last year saw the arrival of a slew of books with titles like "Dot.bomb" and "Boo Hoo," a lacerating look at the upscale clothing retailer Boo.com. Headed to bookstores this year are two books whose titles turn "Dot.com" into "Dot.con."
But despite the consensus that dot-coms are dead, there have recently been some intriguing signs of life. Amazon made headlines last month when it announced that it had been profitable in the fourth quarter of 2001, a first for the e-commerce giant. Priceline, the online travel site, was flailing last year -- the joke on Wall Street was that its "name your own price" policy applied to the company's stock. But last week Priceline, which has done an impressive job of cutting costs, surprised Wall Street by announcing that it, too, had been profitable last quarter. And e-commerce appears to have surged this past holiday season. The 51 million weekly visitors to online shopping sites were a 50 percent increase over the same period in 2000.
Those shopping numbers underscore a critical factor that dot-com skeptics overlook: that even if the pundits have cooled on the Internet, the public has not. The Commerce Department reported yesterday that the number of Internet users in America surged 26 percent last year. Some 143 million Americans, or 54 percent of the nation, used the Internet in 2001, the first time a majority of the country was online. Many parts of cyberspace are booming, both obvious ones like online news sites, which are attracting millions of visitors a week, and less expected ones like photo editing and sharing, software for which is now installed on 21 million wired computers nationwide. 
The worst excesses of the dot-com era are gone. We will probably never again see business models based on the belief that people will buy all of their canned pet food online (and pay the shipping costs). And investors are unlikely to be won over, in the future, by the old dot-com rallying cry that being first is more important than being best, or that dominating a space is more important than turning a profit. 
But companies that take advantage of the unique efficiencies of the Internet show more promise than ever. PayPal caught on because it did just that. It allows users to send money from their credit cards or bank accounts to other people, who can receive the funds, by wire transfer or check, starting with a visit to PayPal's Web site. The great majority of those first million users were eBay buyers and sellers who were miffed that after having conducted a sale online, they had to make the payment by sending a check through regular mail. PayPal made the payment as easy as the auction.
Amazon is holding its own because the service it provides -- offering millions of books and other items quickly and easily from home at any hour of the day or night -- is a real one, and one that was impossible before there was an Internet. The auction giant eBay leverages the Internet the most. There is no way 42 million people could trade with each other except through an online network like eBay's. And it is doing best of all. Profitable from its first month, eBay is on track to pull in $1 billion in revenues this year, and it's growing at an annual rate of 70 percent. It had real net income of $25.9 million in the fourth quarter of last year. 
When tulip mania dies down, all that remains are pretty flowers. When bubbles burst, nothing is left but soapy residue. But the Internet revolution, for all its speculative excesses, really is changing the world. We are beginning to see quiet signs that despite all the naysaying, dot-coms will be back, better than ever.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: A CASE STUDY; 
Enron Is Grist for Business School Courses

BYLINE:  By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
Business school professors across the country say they are latching onto the Enron scandal as a way to make courses on everything from Accounting 101 to crisis management come alive.
 Some teachers are treading cautiously, partly because business-school case studies usually focus on historical events, not unfolding dramas, and partly because the Enron collapse is so complicated. 
 But the revelations about the maneuverings of Enron Corporation executives and the actions of the company's auditor, Arthur Andersen, are too tempting to pass up, professors say.
Roger D. Martin, an assistant accounting professor at the business school at Indiana University, says he introduced a graduate accounting class on the company early in November, when Enron had to restate its earnings and "things started smoking." 
Professor Martin said he planned to use Enron's financial meltdown for years to come as a case study in his advanced accounting class. "This is a classic case in almost everything related to accounting," he said. "If anything, it might make it tough to keep the conversation going in just one direction because there are so many angles."
Other business school professors say they are eager to use Enron to enliven business cases that too often focus on old examples like the Ford Pinto gas tank of the 1970's. "Students now are largely unimpressed if something is more than four to five years old," said Al Hartgraves, an accounting professor at the Goizueta Business School at Emory University in Atlanta.
Before his students left for their Christmas break in the second week of December, Professor Hartgraves promised to e-mail them a summary of the company's situation, and did so at the end of the month. Then a couple of weeks ago, he created a computer bulletin board about Enron over the internal e-mail system that connects roughly 1,000 Emory business students. Within 24 hours, he said, more than 100 students had asked him for bulletin board access.
"We've seen audit failures before with companies like Waste Management and Sunbeam," Professor Hartgraves said, "but never anything as big as this."
At Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., Alfonso F. Canella, an adjunct professor who teaches a class in financial modeling, said he planned to use Enron to illustrate the mechanics, as well as the riskiness, of putting together limited partnerships, especially when the deals were not listed on a company's balance sheet.
Not everyone is convinced that Enron's troubles belong in every classroom. Jan Barton, an assistant accounting professor at Emory, thinks that it is appropriate to use Enron in an introductory course on financial statement analysis, but that its accounting and energy-trading practices may be too complicated for most students.
Even when it comes to teaching more advanced students, Professor Barton said, he preferred to focus on companies like Dell Computer, Sears Roebuck, Wal-Mart and Microsoft, whose financial statement practices and products are easier to understand.
"I don't want to talk about a company that operates in a funky industry, like utilities, and whose transactions involved things like financial derivative contracts," Mr. Barton said.
Still, Diana C. Robertson, an associate professor of organization and management at Goizueta, in time concluded that the Enron case could not be ignored.
In December, she decided to stick to well-documented cases like the antitrust charges against Microsoft and Nike's foreign labor practices for her business ethics classes. But as Enron unraveled, she decided that using a business story in the making, rather than one that is years or decades old, was too "wonderful" to pass up.
Raymond D. Horton, chairman of the Columbia University Business School's management division, said he would allocate plenty of time to the subject this winter in his course on the modern political economy. "We're all itching to discuss it," he said, pointing to a pile of Enron news clippings on his desk. 
Robert Rupe, a second-year finance student at Columbia, said one lecture for a course on corporate turnarounds he just signed up for is titled simply "Enron."
A useful point in the Enron case, business professors say, is the light it sheds on the evolution of the American corporation into unexpected forms. For example, Anne Carter, an economics professor at Brandeis, says it helps illuminate the nature of the modern corporation, which often bears little resemblance to the "mythical" manufacturing and farming companies that appear in many textbooks. For one thing, she said, Enron is a good way to show students just how much of an imbalance there is in the information investors typically receive, and how a company can exploit that imbalance.
Professor Carter plans to devote three classes to Enron this semester in an undergraduate course she teaches. "I really think that Enron shows students that the market now is very different from the market that was shaped by Adam Smith's invisible hand," she said.

HEADLINE: Choosing The Right Enemies 

BYLINE:  By Michael O'Hanlon; Michael O'Hanlon is a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
In his State of the Union address, President Bush took aim at what he called an "axis of evil" -- countries like Iraq, Iran and North Korea together with their terrorist associates. He implied that the United States might take strong action against all parts of this global collection of unpalatable actors.
 However, Mr. Bush is wrong to lump these countries and terrorist groups together. We will harm our security if we fail to appreciate the great differences among them. 
 This is particularly true of North Korea and its tyrannical ruler, Kim Jong Il. North Korea remains heavily armed and threatening, and largely as a result of its excessive military spending, its citizens are extremely poor. But for all its flaws, the North Korean regime is not like Saddam Hussein's Iraq. We can work with Kim Jong Il -- provided that we are smart about how we do it.
Consider how much things improved in the years before Mr. Bush took office. Until 1994, North Korea appeared on its way to developing a sizable nuclear arsenal. In 1998, it fired a three-stage rocket over Japan, suggesting it might soon develop an intercontinental missile capable of delivering weapons of mass destruction against the United States. Not long ago, American intelligence officers considered Korea the world's most dangerous flash point, with the likelihood that any outbreak of war would lead to thousands of American deaths and hundreds of thousands of Korean casualties.
By the end of 2000, the situation had improved on almost all fronts. In 1994, the Clinton administration worked out a deal for shutting down and monitoring North Korea's major nuclear facilities. That "agreed framework," which has held to this day, called for South Korea, Japan and the United States to provide North Korea with fuel oil to replace the energy that the nuclear reactors would have produced -- and, eventually, to build North Korea new nuclear reactors with less capability for contributing to a nuclear weapons program.
More recently, the United States convinced North Korea to impose a moratorium on long-range missile testing in exchange for a lifting of most trade sanctions and an improvement in diplomatic contacts. That moratorium also continues to hold. And a process of detente began as well, including a meeting in 2000 between the leaders of the two Koreas.
North Korea's support for terrorism has declined drastically in recent years; there is no evidence the regime actively supports major terrorist organizations. Even so, all is not well on the Korean peninsula. North Korea remains hypermilitarized; it still exports missiles and other arms, though in far smaller quantities than a decade ago; it may still be quietly working on its long-range missile program; it might even have a "basement bomb" project to develop nuclear arms. Its economy remains a shambles. And, since Mr. Bush took office and showed little support for the "sunshine policy" of South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, toward the North, the process of detente has essentially been frozen.
What to do? The Bush administration resists the idea, preferred by some in the Clinton administration, of simply buying out North Korea's missile programs. For this administration, that smacks of blackmail and could encourage extortionate behavior from Pyongyang. But the Bush administration has failed to offer a serious alternative to Mr. Clinton's policy. Threatening rhetoric does not amount to a policy and may actually increase the chances of war on the peninsula.
Rather than merely buying out North Korea's missile program, the United States and its allies should insist that North Korea accept an arms control regime that would scale back conventional weaponry on the peninsula. If North Korea were willing to begin economic reform, perhaps along a Chinese model, the United States, Japan and South Korea should commit to providing substantial economic assistance -- not as bribery, but as genuine aid to help convert the North Korean economy. 
What will not work is treating Kim Jong Il like Saddam Hussein or Mullah Omar. As bad as Mr. Kim may be, he has displayed some recognition that he needs to improve relations with the outside world. He can possibly be coaxed, but probably not bludgeoned. As he prepares for a trip to South Korea in less than two weeks, Mr. Bush needs to make sure that he wields both a carrot and a stick in his dealings with Pyongyang -- a combination that has worked well in recent years.
