HEADLINE: Empty Airport Hurts Operators Getting the Rent 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
When the soaring new Terminal 4 opened last spring at Kennedy International Airport, the mantra of its operators was "passenger service" -- a nod to the wide array of shops, restaurants and other services that would cater to a growing surge of air travelers.
 They were so confident of that surge that rather than setting fixed rents in their leases with tenants, they took the unusual step of letting the rents float, based solely on the number of passengers passing through the terminal. 
 But what happens when the passengers don't show up?
That is the question now facing the operators -- a consortium of the Dutch firm Schiphol, the Wall Street financial company Lehman Brothers and the real estate company LCOR Inc. 
In the last year, the number of passengers going through Terminal 4 has plummeted 22 percent, largely because of the economic downturn and jitters among the nation's air travelers after the Sept. 11 terror attacks.
Suddenly the consortium is suffering from falling revenue from leases for the airlines, shops and other tenants in Terminal 4, which was one of the first in the nation to be managed by a private concern other than an airline. Last week, Fitch Ratings downgraded the consortium's bonds to speculative levels.
As if that were not enough, the consortium continues to be besieged by the effects of bitter political disputes between New York City, which owns Kennedy, and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates it under a lease. (The consortium, in turn, leases the terminal from the Port Authority.)
Because these disputes have made the fate of the airport's operations uncertain after the Port Authority lease with the city expires in 2015, the consortium has had to make provisions to repay its debt earlier and take on financing costs 40 percent higher than it originally envisioned.
The bond issue in 1997 that financed Terminal 4, which replaced the International Arrivals Building, totaled $1 billion. 
In downgrading the bonds, Fitch analysts stressed that they thought the consortium could probably rebound, given its combination of an experienced airport operator, Schiphol, and the financial acumen of LCOR and Lehman Brothers. But they were concerned, they said, about the passenger-based leases.
"This is not your normal arrangement," said Jessica L. Soltz, an analyst with Fitch, noting that most other airport leases set a minimum rent that allows terminal operators to recoup basic costs. "It is an arrangement that is good when things are good, but the real problem is on the downside."
Back in the late 1990's, when the consortium took on operation of Terminal 4, trends in the airline industry were pointing to larger numbers of foreign travelers using Kennedy. With the airways crowded and the resulting delays, the consortium predicted that people would spend more time in the airport, and spend more money. 
Of course, Terminal 4 is not the only airport business feeling the pinch. David Z. Plavin, president of the Airport Council International of North America, said that bond rating and financial companies have put nearly all of the nation's airport operators on watch lists in the wake of the economic downturn and the Sept. 11 attacks. 
"But mostly what this is," Mr. Plavin said of the plight of the Terminal 4 consortium, "is a blow to all of the people going around trying to sell privatization of airport operations of the kind you have at Kennedy."
Terminal 4 was intended to be the Port Authority's showpiece of privatization's promise of efficient and profitable airport management. But it suffered from Rudolph W. Giuliani's criticism of the Port Authority's stewardship of the airport from early on in his mayoralty. 
He said the agency lavished capital improvement and marketing resources on Newark International Airport at the expense of Kennedy and the city's other major airport, La Guardia, stunting city revenues under the lease. In his second term, Mr. Giuliani set out to hire a company to monitor Port Authority airport operations -- a move the agency greeted with defiance.
According to one of Mr. Giuliani's economic advisers at the time, John Dyson, and to officials of the consortium, the Port Authority would not let the consortium disclose to the city the terms of its lease for Terminal 4 as it was being developed. 
Authority officials say it is standard operating procedure to keep terms of leases secret while they are being negotiated. But Mr. Dyson and others pointed out that the authority had provided such details for at least two other airport tenants that led to the city's granting them extensions beyond the 2015 expiration of the Port Authority's lease. Because it could not see the terms, Mr. Dyson said, the Giuliani administration refused to extend the consortium lease into the time when the city would regain control over the airports.
As a result, said David A. Sigman, development general manager for the Terminal 4 operators, the consortium had to structure bonds based on a repayment schedule of 15 years rather than 30. This meant a "dramatic increase" in debt payments between 2000 and 2009 -- $11 million to $32 million more a year, he said.
"It was something we put in place to get the deal started," Mr. Sigman said. "No one expected that we would live with this arrangement for the whole time."
Back when projections for passenger traffic were optimistic, the consortium saw itself meeting even these onerous debt burdens in the short term, as well as making a profit. So, too, did analysts. But with the decline in passengers, the consortium was unable to pay the additional debt for 2001 and will not be able to cover it this year, Mr. Sigman said. Instead, that debt will accrue to a large balloon payment by 2015.
Victor Van Der Chijs, president and chief executive of Schiphol USA, concedes that the passenger-based leases are "very sensitive to downturns," but he and others insist that long-term trends will smooth out what seems like a roller coaster ride now. 
One hopeful sign, he said, is that the Port Authority and the new administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg are getting along. The consortium has entered into serious negotiations with the city to extend its lease on Terminal 4 beyond 2015, enabling it to spread out its debt payments. But city officials caution that those negotiations depend on resolving broader issues with the Port Authority. 
For its part, the port agency has allowed the consortium to share lease and other financial information with City Hall.
Still, the recent drop in passengers, and revenue, comes as a bit of a shock to Schiphol, which has been known for efficient and profitable operation of airports in Amsterdam and elsewhere.
"We at Schiphol have not experienced any decline in passengers in 80 years until now," Mr. Van Der Chijs said. "The hiccup in the economy is just a little deeper and a little longer than most forecasted. But we still believe in the New York market as one of the most important in the world."

HEADLINE: Lessons for Nation-Builders 

 BODY:
Nation-building aided by outsiders is a project many believe is doomed to fail. Yet international attempts to create a society from the ground up have sometimes succeeded. A recent example is East Timor, which offers a few lessons for future efforts in places like Afghanistan. 
 In 1975 East Timor was forcibly annexed by Indonesia in a brutal invasion. Over the next two decades, a fifth of the population was killed. In 1999, Indonesian troops and their allied local militias went on a spree of destruction, burning much of the area's infrastructure to the ground and holding a civilian U.N. mission hostage. The carnage was stopped only by a coalition of United Nations troops led by Australia. 
 Remarkably, East Timor today is secure and peaceful, with much rebuilt infrastructure. It has the institutions of democracy and will hold presidential elections before it becomes an independent nation on May 20. The U.N. has been training Timorese to take over administrative posts.
One important lesson to be drawn from East Timor is the need for a strong peacekeeping force with robust rules of engagement. The U.N. forces were able to stop militia raids into East Timor from West Timor, which is part of Indonesia, by getting permission for their peacekeepers and police to aggressively protect themselves and the Timorese people. They can shoot first if threatened. After independence, 5,000 peacekeepers will stay.
Problems faced by the U.N. in East Timor are also worth noting. The process would have benefited from less rivalry between departments. All hiring was done from New York, much of it based on little information. The mission was slow to put local people in positions of authority, hiring them only as drivers, guards or interpreters. After much criticism and World Bank help, the U.N. began to hire and train more local people. 
Whoever takes on the enormous task of nation-building in Afghanistan and elsewhere needs to learn from these lessons. The most important job is not to run the country, but to enable its citizens to do the job themselves.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Lawyer's Warnings to Enron On Deals Went Unheeded
In a series of memos to senior Enron executives that began nearly a year before the company's collapse, a senior lawyer warned about the appearance of sweetheart deals and dubious transactions.
 The lawyer proposed several ways to correct the problems, but his warnings were largely unheeded, committee investigators say, and his memos, provide fresh evidence about when top Enron officials knew that there were problems with transactions. Page A1. 

Wall Street is calling it the Enron effect. The business of mergers and acquisitions has fallen off a cliff. C7.

Quaker Drags Down PepsiCo Profit
PepsiCo posted a 4.4 percent decline in fourth-quarter earnings, largely because of costs associated with its acquisition of Quaker Oats. While the task of integrating Quaker has presented Pepsi with a few pitfalls, questions about its overall benefits have started to emerge more forcefully. Shares of PepsiCo fell $1.71, or 3.37 percent, to $49.10. C2.

Cisco Beats Wall St. Expectations
Cisco reported second-quarter earnings that beat Wall Street's expectations by 4 cents. Recovering from a steep loss in the first quarter, Cisco reported a profit of $660 million, or 9 cents a share, for its fiscal second quarter, which ended Jan. 26. C4.

More Millionaires Pay Less in Taxes
The number of Americans with million-dollar incomes nearly tripled from 1995 to 1999, government figures show. The percentage of their income that went to pay federal income taxes, however, fell 11 percent. The incomes of all other Americans grew as well, though by far less, and the share of their income that went to taxes rose slightly. A22.

Tyco Backs Away From a Deal
Tyco International said that its earnings would fall short of its previous forecasts and that it would not complete a takeover previously announced. Market Place. C9.

Computer Associates Shares Plunge
Shares of Computer Associates fell about 14 percent after Moody's Investors Service said it might lower the rating of the company's bonds because its cash flow is falling, which raised questions about its long-term health. C4.

Stocks Continue Downward Slide
Stocks fell for a fourth consecutive session on concern about corporate profits. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.51 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,083.51. The Nasdaq composite index lost 25.81 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,812.71. The Dow Jones industrial average slid 32.04 points, or 0.3 percent, to 9,653.39. C9.

Dubai Airline Overcomes Adversity
The Sept. 11 attacks and the fighting in Afghanistan did not slow down Emirates Airlines in Dubai. In November, it ordered new jetliners and it plans to add routes to North America. "There was a kind of perception that, despite appalling evidence to the contrary, the closer you are to Afghanistan, the greater the risk," Maurice Flanagan, the airline's top executive. "But business has come back already." World Business, Section W.

Flat-Rate Calling Plan From AT&T
AT&T will allow its residential long-distance customers to place unlimited domestic calls to one another for $19.95 a month in an effort to stanch the bleeding in its consumer unit. C4.

Can Volunteers Pick Up the Slack?
The president wants Americans to volunteer to pick up the slack in social services. One economists questions if that will be enough.
Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL; 
Contraction Plans? Anyone's Guess

BYLINE:  By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
What evil lurks in the hearts of men? If the Shadow knows, he should tell Jeffrey Loria whether anyone in Major League Baseball's hierarchy has any evil thoughts about contraction.
 Loria, for a few more days, is the owner of the Montreal Expos, the team most likely to be eliminated if contraction occurs. But Loria is selling the Expos to baseball for that very reason and buying the Florida Marlins. 
 What if during the course of the next six months or so officials decide that the Marlins should be eliminated along with the Expos? That would place Loria in double jeopardy. He would become the only owner in baseball history -- sports history -- to lose two teams in one year. 
The fate of Loria and the Marlins, however, awaits further deliberation. Here, meanwhile, are the current secret thoughts of the contraction planners 2003:
The Minnesota Twins are off the list because they have been sold to a banker from Birmingham, Ala., they are getting a new ballpark and the stadium commission lawyers are in court again making legal life difficult for our lawyers.
The Expos are still the No. 1 contraction candidate, but they are also the No. 1 candidate for relocation. Think of how many hundreds of millions we could get from those guys salivating for a team in the Washington-Northern Virginia region. We could kill off the Expos and move another team in there, but we own the Expos and we can decide what to do with the money they would bring.
So let's look around and see who else would be probable contraction candidates.
*Marlins: Last year, they had the third lowest revenue, behind the Expos and the Twins, and in the last four years they have lagged behind every team in revenue except the Expos, the Twins and the Kansas City Royals. They will never make it without a new park, but Loria seems to feel he has a decent chance of getting a new park.
Plus we've done economic somersaults to enable him to buy the team, which we had to facilitate because how else could we make it possible for John Henry to buy the Red Sox? So we have to give Loria a chance to make it work there. If only Wayne Huizenga hadn't undermined the chances for a new park by decimating the team four years ago. But we can't go back and get a do-over.
*Royals: They are in the same economic boat as the Marlins and do not have the prospect of a new park or new revenue. Unlike the Marlins, they have not developed a band of good young players who, if kept together, could become a contender. Ewing Kauffman's money sustained them, but his memory won't.
*Oakland Athletics: They have shown a surge in revenue, but the increase has matched the improvement of the team. Billy Beane has been responsible for that improvement, but without increasing their spending significantly they will not be able to keep him as their general manager. To keep the Athletics viable for the long haul, we might have to let them move to the San Jose area, and the Giants will kick and scream about that possibility.
*Tampa Bay Devil Rays: A disaster, just a disaster, but we have to share the blame because we put a team in that dreadful park in that poor location. But how were we supposed to know they would be run so poorly? They should be No. 1 on the list of other candidates, but we would have to contend with the 25 years that will be left on their stadium lease and a court battle with the Florida attorney general.
Random thoughts: It's good that the Cincinnati Reds are only a year from moving into their new park because they could be in trouble otherwise. We would hate to have to even consider eliminating them, given their history.
What about the Anaheim Angels? Disney wants to sell them. Given their revenue in wealthy Southern California, you'd think they were a small-market team.
Talk about a team having a bizarre appearance, the Philadelphia Phillies have done a good imitation of a small-market team. Their revenue last year was the 10th lowest among the 30 teams, and their revenue the last four years was 9th lowest. Well, we can't exactly make them disappear.
If the San Diego Padres encounter any more lawsuits that block construction of their new park, they could still be a contraction contender. So could the Toronto Blue Jays if they do not figure out how to become a division contender again. Their revenue last year was only 2 percent higher than it was in 1995.
Maybe that's an idea. A lot of owners, including our wealthy brethren in New York, think we should lump four teams in our contraction package. We could wipe Canada and Florida off the baseball map and shrink our problems as well as our geography. We could go back to our pre-1969 borders.
Hmmm, if only we could go back to our pre-1969 payrolls.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: JOURNALISTS; 
Prominent Muslim Militant Is Named a Suspect in Pearl Case

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
Pakistani and American officials identified a leader of a Pakistani militant Muslim group today as the chief suspect in the disappearance of the American journalist Daniel Pearl, saying that he came to their attention because of his role in the kidnapping of four Western tourists in India in 1994.
 The suspect, Ahmed Omar Sheikh, a 28-year-old born in Britain, was imprisoned by India in connection with the 1994 case. But he was freed in Afghanistan in 1999 in a prisoner-release deal related to the hijacking of an Indian Airlines jet. Pakistani security officials said they lost track of him after his release. 
 Mr. Sheikh's group, Jaish-e-Muhammad, was founded by one of his fellow kidnappers in the 1994 case, and is thought to have close allies in Pakistan's intelligence service.
According to officials familiar with the Pearl case, American law enforcement officials began considering Mr. Sheikh a potential suspect just days after the kidnapping of Mr. Pearl, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal. The officials noticed similarities between the 1994 case and the disappearance of Mr. Pearl, 38, on Jan. 23 in Karachi after he did not return from a meeting with a source.
Despite those suspicions, Pakistani authorities were not so willing to focus on Mr. Sheikh and his group, which has broad support in Pakistan. It was not until today, after three suspects arrested in the case Tuesday implicated Mr. Sheikh, that he was first mentioned by Pakistani and American officials as a focus of the investigation.
One of those three suspects was a low-ranking member of a special branch of the Karachi police with responsibilities that include counterterrorism. That suspect, identified by the Pakistani police officials only as Adeel, is believed to have delivered photographs of Mr. Pearl in captivity to a confederate identified as Fahad at an Internet cafe in Karachi late most month. It was there that the photographs were apparently scanned and e-mailed to news organizations.
The involvement of a leader of a well-established Islamic militant group, rather than a criminal gang, in the kidnapping of Mr. Pearl would mark a bold and direct challenge to the president of Pakistan, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who has promised to crack down on terrorism. Although his government has arrested hundreds of militants, many others have remained free.
Mr. Sheikh and the Jaish-e-Muhammad group have links to another, older Islamic extremist organization, the Harkat ul-Mujahedeen, or Movement of Holy War. That group has been on the State Department list of terrorist organizations since 1997.
Many of its former members, including Mr. Sheikh, are believed by Pakistani intelligence to have re-established themselves as Jaish-e-Muhammad, which was founded in 2000 by Maulana Masood Azhar, an even more prominent figure among those freed by India in the 1999 release of prisoners. On that occasion, Mr. Sheikh, Mr. Azhar and one other prisoner were freed at the airport in Kandahar, Afghanistan, after being flown there by the Indian government and released in exchange for 155 hostages who had ended up there aboard a hijacked passenger jet.
After his release, Mr. Azhar returned to Pakistan and became an outspoken champion of the militant cause, leading rallies in the port city of Karachi. But he ran afoul of the authorities in Pakistan, who later moved to restrict his activities. Since late December, Mr. Azhar has been in Pakistani custody.
Pakistani officials said today that Mr. Sheikh, however, essentially dropped out of sight after his release, although there were reports from time to time that he had been sighted in Afghanistan and had moved into a leadership role in Jaish-e-Muhammad.
It was not until last December that the group was added to the American list, despite its members' links to the 1994 kidnappings and other attacks. The decision to list Jaish-e-Muhammad was driven by India's contention that the group was among those who carried out a fatal Dec. 13 attack on the Parliament in New Delhi.
Under pressure from the United States, General Musharraf banned the group and several others as part of the crackdown against terrorism that he promised last month. Despite that, support for Jaish-e-Muhammad among some members of the Pakistani intelligence service is widely seen as having been translated into relatively gentle treatment for the group. Several dozen or so members of the group who have been arrested in recent weeks have reportedly been charged under an internal security statute that allows them to be held in prison for no more than three months.
Mr. Sheikh was born in London, the son of Pakistani clothes merchants. He studied mathematics and statistics and was fluent in English, French, Urdu, Hindi and Pashto, members of his family have said. 
He studied at the London School of Economics for a year beginning in 1992, then left to join in the fight for the independence of Kashmir, the only Muslim-majority state in predominantly Hindu India.
He was arrested in the kidnapping of four Western tourists in India in 1994 near the site where one hostage, an American, was being held. Three other hostages, who were British, were held in a separate location and were freed by the police in a gun battle that left two policemen and one kidnapper dead.
In recent days, a number of Pakistani and Indian experts have pointed out similarities between the 1994 kidnapping and last month's abduction of Mr. Pearl.
In both cases, the victims were apparently lured by their kidnappers to a clandestine meeting rather than being abducted by force.
Both may also have been part of attempts to secure the release of fellow militants. In the 1994 kidnapping, Mr. Sheikh sought to exchange the Western tourists for the freedom of 10 jailed Islamic militants.
In the Pearl case, kidnappers who have issued their claims in the name of a previously unknown group have also demanded concessions, including the release of Pakistani prisoners from the Afghan war and of Mullah Abdul Salam Zaeef, the former Taliban ambassador to Pakistan who is now being held in an undisclosed location.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ahmed Omar Sheikh, 28, shown in an undated photo, is a leader in the group Jaish-e-Muhammad. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Parolees and Security 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Although satellite tracking for parolees ("Putting Parolees on a Tighter Leash," Jan. 31) may sound liberating to some chronic offenders, and its ease, economy and efficiency appeal to the authorities and tax groups, this new technique should cause the rest of us great concern. 
 Real-time monitoring will likely "widen the net" (and extend the duration) of control to include misdemeanor drug users and other minor offenders who otherwise would be left to informal surveillance or none at all. 
This undermines our safety and diminishes our freedom.
Genuine security comes from self-restraint and voluntary compliance. Without adequate rehabilitation, job training or proper after-care -- not to mention a change in the structure of employment opportunity for released offenders -- satellite tracking becomes a behavior modification tool that is sure to backfire, fostering more clever avoidance and augmenting prisons as schools of crime.

ROBERT P. WEISS
Plattsburgh, N.Y.

The writer is a professor of sociology and criminal justice at the State University of New York at Plattsburgh.

HEADLINE: DaimlerChrysler Dividend May Be Cut More Than Half 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
The management board at DaimlerChrysler proposed today that the company's dividend be cut by more than half in the first reduction since the merger of DaimlerBenz and Chrysler in 1998.
 The company also announced that earnings this year would be much less than previously forecast. And it reported a net loss for last year. 
 But a spokesman said the company was sticking to previous projections that its Chrysler Group unit, the third-largest United States automaker, would break even this year. Still, analysts expect it to lose more market share and continue to be a drag on DaimlerChrysler's earnings. 
In Frankfurt, shares of DaimlerChrysler fell 1.94 euros, to 42.81 euros. In New York, its shares fell 97 cents, to $37.01.
The company made the announcements after a meeting today of its management board in Stuttgart, Germany. Further details will be released at its formal earnings announcement on Feb. 20, and a final decision on its dividend will be made at its annual shareholders' meeting in Berlin on April 10.
DaimlerChrysler has yet to emerge as the dynamic global powerhouse envisioned at the time of the merger by the chief executive, Jurgen Schrempp. The ouster of Chrysler's United States executives was followed by an aggressive corporate revival strategy, announced early last year by Chrysler's new German executives. But in the last year, a variety of external market forces have weighed on the industry and clouded the projections of Chrysler and its parent.
"The reality is that the fundamentals have become more uncertain and the task more challenging," the company said in a statement.
Specifically, incentive costs soared further for the Big Three after Sept. 11, when General Motors started an interest-free financing binge that Chrysler and Ford Motor matched. Chrysler has tried to resist the extent to which it is pulled into the price war but said last week that it would increase rebate spending to be more competitive with G.M. and Ford.
"They're going to struggle," said Michael Bruynesteyn, an analyst at Prudential Securities, referring to the Chrysler unit, which he also expects to continue to lose market share this year. Sales of the Ram pickup will soften and the company has only a limited number of new car and truck models, he added. 
United States auto sales figures for the entire industry in January fell from a year earlier but were better than expected. Still, despite continued heavy incentive costs, demand for passenger vehicles is expected to narrow this year.
DaimlerChrysler also faces shrinking demand for its commercial trucking operations. Eckhard Cordes, the head of commercial trucking, was quoted at a European trade show today as saying that the company would cut 6,500 workers, or 7 percent of its commercial trucking work force, through voluntary buyouts. Daimler officials neither confirmed nor denied the figures.
Financial analysts had expected DaimlerChrysler to revise its 2002 projection down and to reduce the dividend, but they were somewhat surprised by the extent of both. The dividend would be lowered to 89 cents from about $2.09. Ford has also sharply cut its dividend in an effort to return to profitability. 
DaimlerChrysler said today that it had a net loss of $589 million, or 59 cents a share, last year, including one-time charges. Operating profit, excluding the charges, was $1.2 billion, the company said.
DaimlerChrysler said it expected to more than double its operating profit this year. But last year's results were drained by red ink from Chrysler, and the company had projected a year ago that DaimlerChrysler would have a profit of as much as $5.8 billion in 2002. 
The company said it was confident it would reach those profit levels but "at slightly later dates."

A Plea to Washington
 (By Reuters) -- Top executives of the Big Three auto manufacturers have sent a rare joint letter to the White House, asking President Bush to appeal to the Japanese government to stop weakening the yen to lift the profits of Japanese automakers, industry officials said yesterday.
The chief executives of General Motors, Ford Motor and the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler, which together account for nearly 4 percent of the United States economy, said in the letter sent last week that the weak yen was a threat to recovery.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: WALL STREET; 
Looking Very Hard Before They Leap

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
Wall Street is calling it the Enron effect.
 The business of mergers and acquisitions, so often an indicator of confidence in the stock market and the economy, has fallen off a cliff. Merger activity in January had its slowest start in the United States since 1988, and deal makers, already contending with a shaky market, do not expect the first half of the year to fare much better in the post-Enron environment. 
 The lessons of Enron may have already helped scuttle a couple of sizable deals. According to one investment banker, a pharmaceutical company pulled out of a $10 billion acquisition at the 11th hour two weeks ago over concerns about the seller's accounting practices and coming drug disclosures. Another deal in the energy sector has been postponed, and a $5 billion telecommunications deal was also delayed, a lawyer involved in both deals said. 
"Before Enron happened we were already in an environment where C.E.O.'s were much more cautious," said Donald Meltzer, global head of mergers and acquisitions at Credit Suisse First Boston. "Enron and the accounting issues are now just another leg in the stool of C.E.O. insecurity."
Deal makers said that the due diligence that acquirers conduct -- the thorough review of the financial and commercial soundness of a pending deal -- might also become more stringent. When Dynegy canceled its proposed acquisition of Enron -- a deal that came together in less than 10 days in November before Enron filed for bankruptcy -- it said it had been unable to uncover all of Enron's troubles in the short time it had to conduct due diligence.
Potential acquirers or investors also want to know if a company has hidden liabilities.
For example, Bristol-Myers Squibb may have missed crucial deficiencies in ImClone's application to the Food and Drug Administration for its colorectal cancer drug before it agreed to invest $2 billion in ImClone last fall. In December, the drug agency refused to consider ImClone's application for approval of the drug, Erbitux, and on Tuesday, Bristol-Myers said that it wanted to restructure its agreement with ImClone. But it defends the quality of research it did before investing in ImClone.
Other issues of unexpected liabilities also make potential deal makers nervous. Shares of Halliburton, for example, have fallen more than 70 percent in the last 12 months because of fears that it could be overwhelmed by asbestos-related judgments. While Halliburton knew about asbestos liabilities when it bought Dresser Industries in 1998, a later court ruling swelled the number of claims.
Dennis S. Hersch, who heads the mergers practice at the Davis Polk & Wardwell law firm, said, "You can't get around the fact that people will now work more closely with accountants and look more closely at the balance sheets."
"People used to do a deal over the weekend in the late 90's," Mr. Hersch added. "That's probably over."
Most acquirers have long relied on the audited balance sheets of the seller as sufficient evidence, but some bankers and lawyers expect that audited balance sheets may not be enough now to make boards feel completely comfortable. Acquirers may even begin hiring accountants to re-audit the companies they plan to buy.
But Stephen Munger, Morgan Stanley's co-head of global mergers and acquisitions, said he thought that companies would cut off the acquisition process if accounting questions were raised. "I don't think you're going to buy a company if you have to redo their audit," he said.
Still, Mr. Meltzer said, boards may be more likely to shoot down a merger proposal or at least require management to negotiate more ways out of a deal in case accounting irregularities surface. 
Steven Baronoff, head of global mergers at Merrill Lynch, said, "Representations and warranties as they relate to financial statements will be much tighter."
Deal makers predict that the effect of Enron's troubles may make it a buyers' market, giving them much more latitude to find out more information about prospective acquisitions.
But until a little confidence is restored, it is not clear that there will be that much research to do.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED; 
Tenet Testimony: 'A Nation at War'

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the testimony of George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, to the Senate Select Intelligence Committee yesterday as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. The full text is available at The New York Times on the Web at nytimes.com/world:
 Sept. 11th brought together and brought home literally several vital threats to the United States and its interests that we have long been aware of. It is the convergence of these threats that I want to emphasize with you today: the connection between terrorists and other enemies of this country; the weapons of mass destruction they seek to use against us; and the social, economic and political tensions across the world that they exploit in mobilizing their followers. 
 Sept. 11th demonstrated the dangers that arise when these threats converge and remind us that we overlook, at our own peril, the impact of crises in remote parts of the world. . . . 
These threats demand our utmost response. The United States has clearly demonstrated since Sept. 11 that it is up to the challenge. But make no mistake: Despite the battles we have won in Afghanistan, we remain a nation at war. Last year I told you that Osama bin Laden and the Al Qaeda network were the most immediate and serious threat this country faced. This remains true, despite the progress we have made in Afghanistan and in disrupting the network elsewhere. 
We assess that Al Qaeda and other terrorist groups will continue to plan to attack this country and its interests abroad. Their modus operandi is to continue to have multiple attack plans in the works simultaneously and to have Al Qaeda cells in place to conduct them. 
We know that the terrorists have considered attacks in the U.S. against high-profile government or private facilities, famous landmarks and U.S. infrastructure nodes such as airports, bridges, harbors and dams. High-profile events such as the Olympics or last week's Super Bowl also fit the terrorists' interests in striking another blow within the United States that would command worldwide media attention. 
Al Qaeda also has plans to strike against U.S. and allied interests in Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Southeast Asia. American diplomatic and military installations are at high risk, especially in East Africa, Israel, Saudi Arabia and Turkey. Operations against U.S. targets could be launched by Al Qaeda cells already in place in major cities in Europe and the Middle East. Al Qaeda can also exploit its presence or connections to other groups in such countries as Somalia, Yemen, Indonesia and the Philippines. 
Although the Sept. 11 attacks suggest that Al Qaeda and other terrorists will continue to use conventional weapons, one of our highest concerns is their stated readiness to attempt unconventional attacks against us. As early as 1998, bin Laden publicly declared that acquiring unconventional weapons was a religious duty. Terrorist groups worldwide have ready access to information on chemical, biological and even nuclear weapons via the Internet, and we know that Al Qaeda was working to acquire some of the most dangerous chemical agents and toxins. 
Documents recovered from Al Qaeda facilities in Afghanistan show that bin Laden was pursuing a sophisticated biological weapons research program. We also believe that bin Laden was seeking to acquire or develop a nuclear device. Al Qaeda may be pursuing a radioactive dispersal device, what some call a dirty bomb. 
Alternatively, Al Qaeda or other terrorist groups might also try to launch conventional attacks against the chemical or nuclear industrial infrastructure of the United States to cause widespread toxic or radiological damage. . . . 
The terrorist threat goes well beyond Al Qaeda. The situation in the Middle East continues to fuel terrorism and anti-U.S. sentiment worldwide. Groups like the Palestinian Islamic Jihad and Hamas have escalated their violence against Israel, and the intifada has rejuvenated once-dormant groups like the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. If these groups feel that U.S. actions are threatening their existence, they may begin targeting Americans directly, as Hezbollah's terrorist wing already does. 
We're also watching states like Iran and Iraq that continue to support terrorist groups. Iran continues to provide support, including arms transfers, to the Palestinian rejection groups and Hezbollah. Tehran also has failed to move decisively against Al Qaeda members who have relocated to Iran from Afghanistan. Iraq has a long history of supporting terrorists, including giving sanctuary to Abu Nidal. 
The war on terrorism, Mr. Chairman, has dealt severe blows to Al Qaeda and its leadership. The group has been denied its safe haven and strategic command center in Afghanistan. Drawing on both our own assets and increased cooperation from allies around the world, we are uncovering terrorist plans and breaking up their cells. These efforts have yielded the arrest of nearly 1,000 Al Qaeda operatives in over 60 countries and have disrupted terrorist operations and potential terrorist attacks. . . . 
That said, I must repeat that Al Qaeda has not yet been destroyed. It and other like-minded groups remain willing and able to strike at us. Al Qaeda's leaders, still at large, are working to reconstitute the organization and resume its terrorist operations. We must eradicate these organizations by denying them their sources of financing, eliminating their ability to hijack charitable organizations for their terrorist purposes. We must be prepared for a long war and we must not falter. . . . 
We have already seen in Afghanistan and elsewhere that domestic unrest and conflict in weak states is one of the factors that create an environment conducive to terrorism. More importantly, demographic trends tell us that the world's poorest and most politically unstable regions, which include parts of the Middle East and sub-Saharan Africa, will have the largest youth populations in the world over the next two decades and beyond. Most of these countries will lack the economic institutions or the resources to effectively integrate these youth into their societies. . . . 
Let me underscore what the president has affirmed. Islam itself is neither an enemy nor a threat to the United States. But the increasing anger toward the West and toward governments friendly to us among Islamic extremists and their sympathizers clearly is a threat to us.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
TBWA/Chiat/Day Undergoing Changes

BYLINE:  By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
Three offices of TBWA/Chiat/ Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group, are undergoing changes.
 Almost half the 90 employees at the agency's San Francisco office are being laid off after the loss of the Levi's jeans account from Levi Strauss & Company. 
An additional five or so employees are being laid off at the offices in Playa del Rey, Calif., and New York. 
 Carisa Bianchi, 43, president at the San Francisco office, will become a managing partner at Playa del Rey, overseeing the Sony PlayStation account for Sony, which is accompanying her from San Francisco. Robert LePlae, president at Playa del Rey, will now also oversee San Francisco.
At the New York office, the account of Orbitz, the online travel agent operated by five airlines, is leaving after two years. Spending was estimated at $12 million for the first nine months of 2001, according to CMR, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.
Carol Jouzaitis, a spokeswoman for Orbitz in Chicago, confirmed a report of the change in Advertising Age. Orbitz is considering working with Fusion Idea Lab in Chicago for the creative part of the account, she said, adding that a decision would be made soon. The airlines that own Orbitz are American, Continental, Delta, Northwest and United.

HEADLINE: German Unemployment Is Growing Problem for Schroder 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
The German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, suffered an expected but still stinging political blow today when it was announced that German unemployment figures rose sharply in January, above the psychologically important four million total.
 Four years ago, Mr. Schroder made one of his few campaign mistakes, promising to hold the number of unemployed below 3.5 million by the next election, which is scheduled for Sept. 22. If not, he said, "we don't deserve to be re-elected." 
 His opponent in that election, Edmund Stoiber, a conservative from Bavaria, is concentrating his fire on Mr. Schroder's handling of the economy. He accuses Mr. Schroder of being too dependent on labor unions and failing to reduce labor market rigidities that hamper the creation of new jobs.
In what could be even worse news for Mr. Schroder, economists say they expect unemployment to keep rising through much of the summer.
The influential daily Bild, which generally supports Mr. Schroder, had a huge front-page headline today with the unemployment total and the question: "Chancellor, What Now?" A front-page article ended: "Chancellor, what are you doing for us?"
The figures come on top of a budding scandal about the falsification of job-creation figures by state employment offices. The Federal Audit Office issued a report on Monday that found serious procedural violations and concluded that employment offices had filled far fewer positions than statistics showed. The offices "outwardly created a better picture of labor-market structures and job placements" than the reality, the report said.
The labor offices said they had found jobs for 3.8 million people last year, half of all those who found jobs during that period. The auditors, however, said that only 20 percent found jobs through the offices; another finding was that only 22 percent of the jobs listed with the offices were filled, not the 76 percent as claimed. The auditors said officials drove up placement totals by using a computerized job-listing system to "fill" jobs more than once. 
Mr. Schroder is also trying to face down another challenge to his reputation for economic stewardship, this time from the European Union. 
The union has said it wants to issue formal cautions to Germany and Portugal because their budget deficits are approaching the limit of 3 percent of gross domestic product set for members of the euro zone.
The limit was originally urged upon the European Union by Germany under Chancellor Helmut Kohl. At the time, Germany feared that the fiscal indiscipline of countries like Italy and Greece could make the new euro currency unstable. But the spending cap now makes it impossible for Mr. Schroder to create jobs through large public works, as the United States might do.
Mr. Schroder has said he sees political motives, not just economic ones, behind the move for a formal caution, and he may succeed in avoiding it.
But today Mr. Schroeder's coalition partners, the Greens, broke ranks to say that the European Union was fully entitled to warn Germany. "We as Germans should have the necessary humility to accept this caution from Brussels -- it is only an early warning," said Oswald Metzger, the Greens' financial spokesman.
Germany's economy is heavily dependent on exports from traditional industries like engineering and car manufacture, and the worldwide economic slowdown has hit hard. But German officials hope that the American recession will be short, and that its end will quickly improve the climate here.
The seasonally unadjusted unemployment figure was 4.289 million, a two-year high, bringing the rate to 10.4 percent, from 9.6 percent in December. Adjusted for factors like seasonal hiring and weather, the unemployment figure increased by 31,000, to 3.978 million. But the newspapers here concentrate on the unadjusted numbers.
At the same time, the total number of unfilled vacancies rose to 422,425 from 389,145, which supported industry's complaint that many of the unemployed prefer to get generous benefits rather than take low-paying or unpleasant jobs.
Mr. Schroder's efforts to get employers and unions to agree to voluntary reforms of Germany's inflexible labor market have not been successful, and the unions are currently asking for pay increases more than two times the inflation rate.

HEADLINE: Senate Abandons Effort to Boost the Economy 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
The Senate today abandoned its effort to pass a plan to boost the economy, but then briefly put aside partisan recriminations to approve a narrow measure extending unemployment benefits for 13 weeks beyond the current 26-week limit.
 After months of maneuvering for political advantage and sporadic negotiations, Democrats and Republicans found themselves no closer to agreement on how best to help the economy and used procedural votes to kill each other's plans. 
 To the end, Republicans insisted on a sizable package of tax cuts that they said would create jobs, and said the Democratic proposal would do little but add to government spending. For their part, Democrats called for an emphasis on temporary measures to help unemployed and low-income workers, and said the Republican plan would dig the government into a deeper budget hole. 
Both parties agreed that the issue had lost some urgency in recent weeks as the economy began to perk up. But neither wanted to be cast in the role of blocking the stimulus plan, especially because there is no guarantee that the economy will continue to recover and because unemployment is likely to continue rising for months even if the recession ends quickly.
With many Americans facing the loss of their unemployment benefits, the Senate agreed unanimously to extend the benefits at federal expense for 13 weeks, a step Congress has routinely taken in past downturns. Most states limit benefits to 26 weeks, although a few have extended them. The 13-week federal extension is expected to cost about $8 billion.
The fate of the benefit extension now rests with the Republican-controlled House. Republican aides said there was some division within the party about whether to try to package some tax cuts with the extension of the unemployment benefits or pass the extension as a stand-alone bill.
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research organization, said up to two million people might exhaust their benefits in the first half of this year. About 7.9 million people are unemployed, and the unemployment rate in January was 5.6 percent.
President Bush said extending unemployment benefits was necessary but not enough.
"They need to take care of the workers, at the very minimum," Mr. Bush told reporters on a visit to New York. "But it's important for Congress to realize that our economy has not yet fully recovered. And, therefore, I believe we still need to provide stimulus for economic growth so there's jobs."
Both sides said they were open to renewed efforts at compromise, and members of both parties were clearly aware of the political risks should they be blamed as failing to address an issue that has continued to top voters' lists of concerns even during the war on terrorism.
But they lambasted each other all day, with Republicans focusing their criticism on Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader.
"The Senate majority leader has put politics ahead of people," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa.
Mr. Daschle said it was Republicans who had been obstructionist, in part by trying to load up what was intended to be a short-term stimulus bill with tax cuts that would not have any economic impact for years.
"The Republicans killed the economic stimulus bill today, just as they attempted to kill it now for the last three weeks," Mr. Daschle told a news conference.
The plan offered by Mr. Daschle and the Democrats sought to bridge the differences between the parties by including only those elements that both sides agreed on: a one-time payment of up to $300 for low-income workers, a tax incentive for businesses to invest in new equipment, money to help states weather the economic downturn and the extension of unemployment benefits.
Republicans responded that the Democratic plan would not do anything to create jobs and get the economy rolling again. They said the best way to do that was to cut both business and individual taxes. 
Mr. Daschle brought the debate to a climax today by subjecting both plans to the requirement that they win 60 votes to cut off debate on the Senate floor. His package received 56 votes, four short of what was necessary to keep it alive, with 39 senators voting against it. The Republicans then offered a plan based on the bill passed by the House last year, a package close to the plan sought by the Bush administration. It got 48 votes, 12 short of what was necessary, with 47 senators voting against it.
Mr. Daschle then pulled both bills from the floor, effectively killing them.
The development led Republicans in the House and Senate to say there was one benefit from the death of the stimulus plan: the money that would have been used to boost the economy could now be put toward narrowing or perhaps even eliminating the projected federal budget deficit for next year.
Based on the White House's figures, the projected deficit would shrink to $3 billion next year from $80 billion if the money allocated to the stimulus plan was not used for anything else.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Republican senators prepared to criticize the majority leader, Tom Daschle, yesterday after votes on the economy. From left are Kay Bailey Hutchison, Charles E. Grassley and Don Nickles. An aide is at the far rear. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Cisco Recovers, Reporting Profit in Quarter

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
Showing a return to the steady performance that made it a favorite among investors, the technology bellwether Cisco Systems reported second-quarter earnings today that nearly doubled Wall Street's expectations.
 Citing a misdirected e-mail message that tipped off some 12,000 employees to the results, Cisco foreshadowed the earnings report with an unusual announcement early this morning that it would beat estimates when it released results later in the day. 
 Recovering from a steep loss in the first quarter, Cisco reported a profit of $660 million, or 9 cents a share, for its fiscal second quarter, which ended Jan. 26.
Profit was down sharply from the $874 million earned in the comparable period a year earlier, but surpassed Wall Street's expectation of 5 cents a share, as compiled by the market research firm Multex. 
Cisco shares fell $1.39, or more than 7 percent, in after-hours trading today as investors wondered if business would continue to improve. In regular trading before the earnings report, shares of Cisco rose 11 cents, to $18.61. 
In the late 1990's, Cisco, the leading maker of networking equipment, earned a reputation for consistently beating the goals set by Wall Street. But sharp cutbacks in spending by corporations, especially Internet and telecommunications providers, sent Cisco into a decline.
After a year of declining sales, Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., said in November that its sales had finally improved over the previous quarter for the first time in 2001. The company repeated that today, when it reported revenue of $4.8 billion, an 8 percent increase from the $4.4 billion in the first quarter. In the comparable period last year, Cisco had sales of $6.7 billion.
John T. Chambers, Cisco's president and chief executive, said in a conference call that the company had gained market share from its smaller rivals but remained hindered by a shrinking industry. He said Cisco's second consecutive period of quarter-over-quarter growth established "a second, slightly higher plateau" to build from, but he predicted no dramatic changes until his large service-provider customers begin making money again.
Mr. Chambers, who had attended the World Economic Forum in New York, said that while economists are predicting that the economy has begun to improve, he and other chief executives think that their businesses have leveled off after the slide and are spending accordingly.
Cisco predicted that sales in the current quarter would be flat or slightly up from the second quarter.
Ray Hirsch, an analyst with American Express Financial Advisors, said that Cisco had executed remarkably well on the restructuring plan it put in place last year, and that it had turned a profit out of a market that was still beating up most of its competitors.
"You're starting to see superior management make something out of nothing here," Mr. Hirsch said. "Pretty soon people will put them back on a pedestal again, where they were a year ago."
As Cisco has struggled, it has dragged down the consulting firms, systems integration companies and corporate resellers -- together known as the channel -- that rode the wave of profits created by the technology giant. Near the end of 1999, the channel sold $14 in computers, software, services and other additional products with every $1 they sold in Cisco networking equipment, according to Global Touch, a market research and consulting firm in Berkeley, Calif. By December, the additional products had dwindled to $3.70 for each $1 in Cisco gear.
"Cisco has been the driver of so much business in this industry," Denise A. Sangster, president and chief executive of Global Touch, said. "When Cisco hit a blip, it caused a catastrophe among so many other companies."
Cisco was caught off-guard the night before its report, which was scheduled to be released after the markets closed today. Late Tuesday, as a senior executive was preparing a videotape to be released after today's earnings report, an assistant meant to e-mail the executive a copy of his script. Instead, the assistant sent it to 12,000 members of the executive's division, a spokeswoman for Cisco said.
The script did not disclose specific revenue or earnings results, but talked about the quarter "in positive terms" and said the company had booked $3.9 billion in new product orders, compared with its internal goal of $3.75 billion, according to the statement released this morning. To avoid violating securities regulations, Cisco said it made the leaked information public before the Nasdaq opened for trading today.

HEADLINE: More Get Rich and Pay Less in Taxes 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The number of Americans with million-dollar incomes more than doubled from 1995 through 1999, as their salaries and their profits from stocks soared, government figures to be published today show. The percentage of their income that went to federal income taxes, however, fell by 11 percent.
 The incomes of Americans who made less grew as well, though by far less, and the share of their income that went to taxes rose slightly, according to Internal Revenue Service income tax data for the five years through 1999, the latest year available. 
 The wealthiest Americans paid a smaller share of their income in taxes because in 1997 Congress reduced taxes on capital gains, which account for a significant share of their income. 
Congress also cut taxes for the middle class, but only one in five taxpayers qualified for those cuts, which involved new tax credits for children and education expenses. So, as a group, the portion of their income going to taxes rose.
For those with million-dollar incomes, the share of their income that went to taxes fell to 27.9 percent in 1999, from 31.4 percent in 1995.
For those Americans who did not make a million dollars, the portion of their income going to taxes edged up in those years, to 12.8 percent from 12.5 percent.
About 205,000 taxpayers made $1 million or more in 1999, up from less than 87,000 in 1995. The average income of those who made $1 million or more rose by $568,000 to $3.2 million.
Critics of the latest Bush administration economic stimulus and tax cut plan, announced this week, regarded the latest figures as evidence that the wealthy have received too many breaks. 
"Congress cut taxes on rich people in 1997," Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a nonprofit Washington organization with labor union backing, said. "The rate that they pay fell by quite a bit, while they didn't do much for everyone else and their taxes went up a little. The law did what Congress intended. Their intent was to make sure the wealthier people paid less in taxes and they weren't worried about the rest of the people."
President Bush, who won a major tax cut from Congress last year, and his supporters argue that permanent cuts in tax rates encourage investment, which results in more jobs and economic growth. 
"We need to pass a bill that will help workers and help stimulate the economy," Mr. Bush told reporters on Tuesday.
The president's new tax cut plan appeared to die on Tuesday when Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota and the majority leader, moved to shelve it. 
Those making a million dollars or more, just one of every 625 taxpayers in 1999, more than doubled their slice of the nation's income to 11.2 percent that year, from 5.4 percent in 1995. These high-income taxpayers also captured a quarter of the nation's total personal income growth from 1995 through 1999. 
The incomes of taxpayers making less than $1 million also rose, though not as sharply. The income of everyone making less than a million dollars averaged $41,000 in 1999, up from $33,500 in 1995, a 22 percent increase, the data, using adjusted gross incomes, showed.
The tax return data show that the number of taxpayers reporting incomes of less than $25,000 declined slightly, while those reporting incomes at higher levels increased.
William Beech, an economist at the Heritage Foundation in Washington, which supports lower tax rates to foster economic growth, said that these figures may be misleading in several ways. 
The data fail to capture the growing number of the working poor, and their meager incomes, because many of them are immigrants who work off the books, he said. 
"The reported income that the I.R.S. picks up from tax returns reflects people who are making their way up the economic ladder," Mr. Beech said. "If we had fully accurate reporting of income, we would see that within the poorest fifth, the median income would be falling because of the millions of people coming into the United States, who mostly earn low incomes." 
He also noted that among those who file income tax returns, many of who appear poor may actually be retirees with substantial investments. But they need only modest incomes because their mortgages are paid off and their children are grown.
The stock market played a large role in creating more million-dollar annual incomes, the figures show. Capital gains over all more than tripled during the five years, with almost three quarters of the increase going to those with million-dollar incomes. 
The capital gains tax cut of 1997 appeared to favor the 400 richest taxpayers most of all. Harvesting 7 percent of all capital gains in 1998, these very rich Americans paid just 22 percent of their incomes in taxes that year, down from 30 percent in 1994. 
Although more than half of all families are investors in the stock market, largely through 401(k)'s and similar retirement plans, wealth in America is more highly concentrated today than at any time since 1929, said Professor Edward N. Wolff, a New York University economist.

The rich doubled their share of overall income from 1995 to 1999, from 5.4 percent to 11.2 percent. HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
The president wants Americans to volunteer to pick up the slack in social services. But will that be enough?

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu.

 BODY:
FROM an economic perspective, the most interesting proposal in last week's State of the Union address was President Bush's call "for every American to commit at least two years -- 4,000 hours over the rest of your lifetime -- to the service of your neighbors and your nation." That works out to around 80 hours a year for every adult. Although that sounds like -- and is -- a lot, by some counts the average American is already volunteering that much. Why do so many people give away so much of their time?
 Richard Freeman, a Harvard economist, has studied why Americans -- 44 percent in 2000, according to a recent survey -- volunteer for charities, youth development programs, religious organizations and other causes. He concludes that voluntary labor is best thought of as a "conscience good or activity -- something that people feel morally obligated to do when asked, but which they would just as soon let someone else do." 
 By contrast, the standard economics treatment is to view volunteer work as the outcome of a trade-off among competing uses of time: working for pay, volunteering or enjoying leisure. The "price" of volunteer work is the opportunity cost of individuals' time -- the earnings one forgoes. As a person's wage rises, he or she finds volunteering more expensive; this should discourage volunteering compared with donating money.
Professor Freeman finds, however, that the standard model goes only so far in explaining why people volunteer. Although a high opportunity cost discourages some people from volunteering, on average those who volunteer are better paid and more likely to be employed than those who do not. Higher pay is associated with only a small, statistically insignificant shift from volunteering to writing tax-deductible checks.
Over all, there is little evidence that people cut down on volunteer work when their labor market opportunities improve or that they view cash contributions and volunteer time as substitutes.
Will the president's call have an effect? Mr. Freeman is skeptical. Most people seem to volunteer only when asked, and particularly when asked by a member of their community, close friend or relative.
Recruiting volunteers will require more than preaching from the bully pulpit. According to Mr. Freeman, a grass-roots campaign is required. Unless the president engages organizations that need volunteers in his effort and provides them with the necessary support to recruit from their communities, his call is likely to go unheeded.
Remember America's Promise, an initiative begun with much fanfare five years ago to channel volunteers to improve the lives of youth, headed by Colin L. Powell with the support of four former presidents? So far, there is little indication the program has lived up to its promise. An evaluation by Public/Private Ventures and the Search Institute concluded, "Though there are some programmatic successes, they are scattered and modest in scope and size."
President Bush's call for a minimum of 4,000 hours is likely to be met with the same fate unless his administration devotes energy and resources to develop a grass-roots coalition of service organizations to recruit and deploy volunteers. There are already signs that the outpouring of volunteers after Sept. 11 has tailed off, and the frequency of volunteering has returned to normal.
Jean Baldwin Grossman, vice president for research at Public/Private Ventures, also stresses that for charities, "voluntary labor is not free." Resources are needed to screen, train and monitor volunteers. Indeed, nonprofits often find it cheaper to hire full-time employees with appropriate skills than to train volunteers.
Some volunteer jobs, like mentors and tutors, have been found to have a high social benefit, while others, like teacher aides, have a low benefit. In most cases, however, little evidence exists on the social payoff.
In her paper "Making the Most of Volunteers," Dr. Grossman estimates that infrastructure costs around $300 a volunteer mentor. Thus if an additional 100 million or so people participate in voluntary activities, as the president has requested, the management costs would increase by around $30 billion.
Where will service organizations find the financing to provide the necessary infrastructure?
Mr. Freeman says the Bush administration "would do better to copy the old Reagan approach, which was to hit up the superrich and corporations to give more."
Applying the theory of "comparative advantage," it does not make sense for Bill Gates or Larry Ellison to spend time helping out their local fire department, or even writing computer code for the United Way. Their comparative advantage lies in donating money so service organizations can hire people with requisite skills and buy equipment for them to perform their tasks. (It is worth noting that progressive taxation achieves exactly this result. Instead of exhorting Mr. Gates and Mr. Ellison to sit around the fire department, one wonders why President Bush would not prefer to tax them more heavily to pay for modern fire trucks.)
According to a survey by the Independent Sector, in 2001 the average American, including nonvolunteers, donated 81 hours to voluntary activity. Volunteer hours have trended down since 1989 but are still substantial. Charitable contributions soared with the stock market in 2000 but are likely to return to normal levels.
This is cause for concern. The United States has come to rely on volunteers and charitable contributions for many social services. Counting the value of voluntary labor, the nonprofit sector accounts for around 6 percent of national income -- 65 percent more than President Bush's slimmed-down budget spends on nonmilitary discretionary programs, like education, job training and workplace safety.
"It is not from the benevolence of the butcher, the brewer and the baker that we expect our dinner," Adam Smith famously observed, "but from their regard to their own interest." Increasingly, however, American society depends on the generosity of its citizens for social services, a need that will intensify as government shifts resources toward national security and away from social programs.
If not dinner, benevolence provides a snack between meals for those who have difficulty putting food on the table. This makes carrying out the president's call for volunteer work -- as well as increased charitable contributions -- all the more important.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Volunteering works best on a community level. Members of the West Side Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J., worked at a project for Habitat for Humanity in nearby Paterson last month. (Norman Y. Lono)

HEADLINE: Cuba, Too, Felt the Sept. 11 Shock Waves, With a More Genial Castro Offering Help 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
In the wake of the terrorist attacks on the United States, President Fidel Castro of Cuba has muted his hostile remarks about Washington and offered to cooperate with the Bush administration's war on terrorism. 
 Within hours of the attacks on New York and Washington, President Castro offered medical help, including blood and health care brigades, as well as intelligence on the movements of terrorists. In the days when United States airspace was closed to traffic, he also offered to allow stranded planes to land at the island's two international airports. 
 Mr. Castro did not criticize the United States decision to detain Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners at the American military base at Guantanamo Bay. 
His warmer tone appears to be part of an effort to avoid a deterioration in relations with Washington as Cuba faces an economic crisis. Since the Sept. 11 attacks, tourism and remittances from the United States, this country's two leading sources of income, have declined sharply. 
Cuba has been listed by the United States as a country that sponsors terrorists and it became critical for it to take a public stand against terrorism, political analysts said. 
American diplomats in Havana also said they saw President Castro's gestures as a calculated response to the cold front developing at the White House, where President Bush has filled key Latin policy posts with officials who are known for their hard-line views on Cuba. The lineup -- led by Otto Reich as the Latin America policy chief -- makes it unlikely that the administration will ease trade and travel barriers against one of the world's last Communist outposts. As a result, the analysts said, Mr. Castro is seeking to sidestep the White House with diplomatic efforts aimed at the Congress and American public opinion.
Mr. Castro has met and entertained numerous American delegations that have traveled to Cuba in recent weeks. Some 2,000 American politicians, lobbyists, businessmen and university students came to Cuba last month, including a group led by two Republican senators, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, and the Republican governor of Illinois, George Ryan. A number of the visiting legislators expressed support for improving relations with Cuba.
In an interview, the Cuban foreign minister, Felipe Perez Roque, cited the example of the century-old United States base at Guantanamo, which he said had been transformed in recent years from hostile territory to a symbol of detente.
"We hope that one day the relations on all official matters can be handled with the respect and collaboration that is happening at Guantanamo," Mr. Perez said. He said that American officials had advised Cuba about the prisoner flights to Guantanamo and discussed issues of security around the base. 
Mr. Perez, who served for several years as President Castro's personal aide, insisted, "We have taken a clear position of collaboration"
with the United States, adding: "We do not have a policy against the United States. There is no anti-North American sentiment in Cuba. There is no hatred against the United States or against the people of the United States. On the contrary, there is a feeling of respect."
American diplomats in Havana seem unmoved by Cuba's new language. While Mr. Castro talks about his willingness to improve relations, they said, he has done nothing to move Cuba toward democracy. Vicki Huddleston, principal officer of the United States Interests Section here, said that Mr. Castro continued to forbid free elections and opposition leaders continued to suffer government harassment.
"It's all a facade," she said of Mr. Castro's recent moves. "It's all cosmetic. Castro is very clever. And his No. 1 goal is staying in power."
The United States has not accepted any of Cuba's offers of aid since Sept. 11. 
Mr. Perez said that his government gained a new understanding of the power of public opinion during the furor in the United States over the custody of Elian Gonzalez. Elian, a young Cuban boy, was rescued by the United States Coast Guard after he and his mother left Cuba for Florida on a raft. The boy's mother died during the journey. Despite protests in Miami, United States officials ordered the boy returned to the custody of his father in Cuba.
Elian's return, Mr. Perez said, revealed that public opinion could be the Achilles' heel of the anti-Castro Cuban community in Miami, which Havana regards as the driving force behind American policy toward Cuba. "It caused great impact in Cuba," Mr. Perez added, "It permitted millions of Cubans to understand the power of Americans' commitment to justice and family values."
Since then, at least 150,000 Americans have traveled to Cuba to enjoy its hotels, cigars, rum and rides in classic American cars. Most of the visitors, officials estimate, came in violation of American travel restrictions. Mr. Perez compared the visitors to a "snowball growing out of control," which he said would plow down the barriers that prohibit travel and trade between the United States and Cuba.
"We will keep welcoming them," he said. "Each one who comes goes back to the United States and tells the truth about Cuba. They say they have been to hell, but hell is not as hot as it had been depicted."
Cuban officials said they viewed the United States authorization of food sales to Cuba after a hurricane devastated the island last November as "an act of kindness." They also noted that in the last 18 months the United States Coast Guard had posted an official in Havana to work with the Cuban government on patrol issues. The Federal Bureau of Investigation helped Cuban officials investigate the killing of five people, two of them Miami residents, in an attack in Cuba last December.
Some American lawmakers have said that Cuba's offers of cooperation should be considered. "I believe there are areas where Cuba could be of great assistance on the war on terrorism," Senator Specter said at a news conference during his visit. "Cuba has vast intelligence sources which could be of great aid."
The 75-year-old Mr. Castro, who has presented himself recently more as a benevolent grandfather than a defiant Communist revolutionary, received hugs from American university students who visited last month.
"Your presence here helps," he told them, "because in your willingness to exchange opinions you learn a little more about Cuba and we learn a little about your country."
