HEADLINE: Bush, in New York, Affirms $20 Billion Aid Pledge 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
President Bush flew into New York yesterday and declared that he would stand by his pledge to provide the city with at least $20 billion to help rebuild from last summer's terrorist attacks, moving to dispel doubts raised by Democrats about the depth of the White House's commitment to help New York recover.
 Mr. Bush, in a day that mixed the politics of New York's race for governor with a homage to the police officers and firefighters involved in the World Trade Center rescue efforts, also announced that he supported a proposal to create $5 billion in tax credits in downtown Manhattan to stop businesses from fleeing the area. 
 "I want you to know something: When I say I'm going to do something, I'm going to do it," Mr. Bush said, chopping the air with his right hand for emphasis as he stood on a stage filled with New York City police officers and firefighters. "I told the people of New York that we will work to provide at least $20 billion to help New York rebuild herself. And that includes money apart from the Victims Compensation Fund. And when I say $20 billion, I mean $20 billion." 
Mr. Bush offered his remarks at a time when several recent events -- including statements this week by his budget director -- had raised questions about the permanence of the $20 billion pledge to the city he made shortly after the twin towers were destroyed.
And it came as there have been mounting signs that the dispute was going to become an issue in the re-election campaign of Gov. George E. Pataki. 
Even before Air Force One had touched down at Kennedy Airport, two prominent New York Democrats -- the party chairman, Herman D. Farrell, and Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democratic candidate for governor -- questioned the propriety of Mr. Bush's appearing at two political fund-raisers that raised more than $1.5 million to finance Mr. Pataki's re-election campaign.
Mr. Cuomo held a news conference in which he suggested that Mr. Pataki should instead use his influence and time with Mr. Bush to obtain the money for the recovery effort, rather than for financing his re-election campaign.
Mr. Cuomo went so far as to suggest that Mr. Pataki contribute the receipts from the fund-raising -- including money raised at a $25,000-a-couple reception at the Upper East Side town house of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg -- to make up for what Mr. Cuomo asserted would be the unfilled promise of $20 billion. Fending off concerns about his commitment to the city, Mr. Bush went out of his way at three separate public appearances yesterday to reaffirm the pledge.
And after touring the command center of the New York City Police Department, he seemed to suggest that he had chastised his budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., for saying that $5 billion in federal benefits for families of victims of the attack would be counted as part of the $20 billion in recovery aid.
In comments on Monday, Mr. Daniels also said that the aid plans should not be part of "a money-grubbing game." 
Speaking of Mr. Daniels, Mr. Bush said: "He understands what I said when I said $20 billion, I meant $20 billion. And I'm the kind of fellow who does what I say I'm going to do. And I think it's important for the country to know that a vibrant New York City is vital for our economy."
Mr. Bush's press secretary, Ari Fleischer, noted that Mr. Daniels had retracted both statements. "Everybody's entitled to make a mistake," Mr. Fleischer said.
Mr. Pataki and Mr. Bloomberg, two Republicans elected in a state and city that are overwhelmingly Democratic, seemed visibly relieved at Mr. Bush's statement.
"Mr. President, we understand that a promise made is a promise kept, and we know that you are a man of your word," Mr. Bloomberg said. "On behalf of a grateful city of eight and a half million New Yorkers, thank you for sticking up for us."
Mr. Pataki, standing in front of a huge American flag at a fund-raiser last night, looked into the television cameras across the room and said of the president, "He made his commitment: New York is going to get $20 billion, at least."
In Washington, New York's two Democratic senators, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, said in interviews they were pleased with the president's remarks, suggesting that they might once and for all end concern that New York would end up not getting the money. So far, Congress and the White House have agreed to provide only $11.1 billion in aid, and Mr. Bush included no money for the rebuilding in the budget proposal he made last week.
"I'm glad that he reaffirmed his commitment to the $20 billion, though I would have preferred a specific mention of New York in the budget," Mrs. Clinton said. "But I think this reaffirmation is a good sign that he's going to follow through and we're just intent on getting as specific a proposal from the administration as soon as possible."
Mr. Schumer said he was particularly struck by Mr. Bush's statement of support for the tax credit program, known as Liberty Zones. A version of the legislation, as part of the national stimulus package, passed the House, but it failed in the Senate yesterday, and its prospects for this year now appear bleak.
"Now that the national stimulus package has gone down, we really need the president's help to find a new vehicle to pass the Liberty Zones, either as another tax bill or as a stand alone," Mr. Schumer said. "And we need to do it quickly because businesses are on tenterhooks about whether to stay or leave."
Mr. Bush's visit to New York was his fifth to the city since Sept. 11, and his remarks suggested that his perception of New York, a state that he lost last November, had changed markedly since the attack, as he repeatedly and exuberantly expressed his admiration and respect for a city that he said had come to represent the nation's resilience. 
At one point, Mr. Bush was perhaps overly exuberant. "As I said in my State of the Union, I stand in awe of New York City," Mr. Bush told an audience at a $1,500-a-head reception for Mr. Pataki last night. Mr. Bush actually made no such mention of New York City in his State of the Union speech.
Mr. Bush expressed strong support for Mr. Pataki's re-election campaign, ticking off the reasons why he said he deserved re-election to a third term, at one point in particularly stark political terms. 
"It also makes sense for New York State to have a governor whose phone calls will be returned from the White House," Mr. Bush said.
Upon his arrival yesterday afternoon, Mr. Bush visited the New York Police Department's command and control center, a 2,000-square-foot nerve center on the eighth floor of 1 Police Plaza, where planning for major events such as blizzards, parades and the New York City Marathon is coordinated.
Mr. Bush made his way around a horseshoe-shaped table filled with police supervisors. Sgt. Gladstone Griffith of the Emergency Service Unit told Mr. Bush that 14 members of his unit had died on Sept. 11.
"He said that he appreciated our effort. It meant a lot to me," Sergeant Griffith said.

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES; 
The Prices Of Americana Stay Strong

BYLINE:  By Wendy Moonan 

 BODY:
Despite the recession, Sotheby's and Christie's had highly successful sales last month of Americana, which includes American furniture, folk art, silver and Chinese Export porcelain. Sotheby's had six single-owner auctions, raising a total of $27.3 million. Christie's had two sales, for a total of $12.5 million. Americana dealers also did well at the Winter Antiques Show.
 "A huge amount of material was available so people came in from Maine, Texas, California and many places in between," said John B. A. Nye, the head of the American furniture department at Sotheby's. "A lot of people didn't come to New York after Sept. 11. We gave them a reason to travel. There was pent-up demand, and things were priced to sell." 
 John Hays, the international director of American art at Christie's, said that the weakness in the general economy did not appear in the prices for Americana. "We didn't raise the bar except for some very unusual pieces," he said. "The rest of the market was rock solid and did not go down. It's a thoughtful marketplace, where collectors, not investors, are doing the buying."
Alan Miller, an American antiques consultant in Quakertown, Pa., agreed. "The sales of Americana were stronger than I expected," he said. "It may have been a kind of reaction to the horror of Sept. 11, a return to hearth and home and, somehow, a patriotic statement to buy American-associated stuff."
The 368 lots of the Lammot du Pont Copeland collection raised $12.6 million, a figure approaching the $13.6 million auction record for an Americana sale set at the Eddy Nicholson sale at Christie's in 1995.
"There was a circus atmosphere at the Copeland sale like the Jackie Onassis and Duchess of Windsor sales," Mr. Miller said. "Some of the high prices can only be attributed to aristocracy souvenir hunting."
Matthew Weigman, a spokesman for Sotheby's, added: "There was a kind of frenzied competition at the sales. It was 'buy now or regret it forever.' "
Chipstone, a private nonprofit foundation in Milwaukee, dedicated to scholarship in the American decorative arts, bought Sotheby's top-selling lot for the week at the Copeland sale: a circa 1750 Queen Anne mahogany desk and bookcase. The price was $1.1 million (against an estimate of $400,000 to $600,000).
The desk has a cartouche and shell-within-a-shell ornament whose carving was attributed to Samuel Harding of Philadelphia. "It was by far the most art-historically significant piece in the sale," Mr. Miller said. "In it we are probably witnessing the invention of the Philadelphia cartouche. There are other early Philadelphia ornaments, but this one springs out of no shop tradition; it is a Philadelphia carver's high-relief rendering of a two-dimensional design, probably one based on an engraving."
He added, "It is the highest-concept piece of Philadelphia case furniture surviving from the 1740's." The Harding attribution is based on the shell carving that Harding did in Independence Hall in Philadelphia.
"Some found the Copeland desk ungainly," said Jonathan Prown, the executive director of Chipstone. "I think it is really gutsy and one of the most formidable pieces of mid-18th-century American furniture."
Also at the Copeland sale, Mr. Miller bought a circa 1765 Chippendale mahogany bonnet-top chest on chest with carving attributed to Nicholas Bernard and Martin Jugiez of Philadelphia. He paid $913,250 (the estimate was $800,000 to $1.2 million), the second-highest price in the sale.
"Jugiez was one of the most gifted immigrant carvers who ever came to Philadelphia," Mr. Miller said. "We don't know where he came from, but he arrives, fully formed, in Philadelphia in the 1750's." In the early 1800's, the Philadelphia banker Nicholas Biddle hired him to carve the Corinthian columns for Andalusia, his Greek Revival house. 
Sotheby's sale of property deaccessioned from Gunston Hall, George Mason's Virginia plantation, raised $1.9 million. Six Chippendale carved mahogany dining chairs sold for $368,750 (against an estimate of $60,000 to $100,000). The Wick family's Chippendale dropleaf table, circa 1760, attributed to Gilbert Ash of New York, sold for $346,750 (against an estimate of $150,000 to $250,000). Selections from the inventory of the New York dealer Israel Sack raised $2.2 million.
Christie's had one Americana sale with 538 lots, which raised $10.3 million. The top lot was a pair of French 18th-century pistols made about 1775 by Jacob Walster. Owned by Lafayette, Washington and Andrew Jackson, the pistols sold for $1.9 million, a world auction record for a firearm, according to Christie's.
"History is still the most underappreciated element in the value of Americana," Mr. Hays said. "These sold for $40,000 about 20 years ago in Paris as 'Lafayette pistols.' At Christie's, they sold for $1.9 million as 'Washington pistols.' Form and style are the first criteria; right behind come provenance and condition."
A rare pair of rosewood Empire card tables with female caryatid supports by Charles-Honore Lannuier sold for $1.2 million. "The creme de la creme with Lannuier is his figural pieces," Mr. Hays said. "It's a robust style only he could do."
An 18th-century tall-case clock with a dial signed by James Wady of Newport and a case attributed to the school of Job Townsend Sr. of Newport realized $666,000. Job was the brother of Christopher Townsend, the maker of the Appleton secretary bookcase that Sotheby's sold in 1999 for $8.3 million, the second highest price ever paid for a piece of American furniture at auction. Christie's said the Wady-Townsend clock set a world auction record for an American tall-case clock. 
A single Queen Anne carved walnut side chair made in Philadelphia about 1750 sold for $666,000, a world auction record for a Queen Anne side chair, Christie's said.
Christie's also sold a previously unpublished and unrecorded silver tankard, made in 1710 by the first Huguenot goldsmith working in New York, Bartholomew Le Roux. It sold for $534,000, a record for an American tankard. It was made for Obadiah Hunt, the successful proprietor of a tavern at 35 Pearl Street in Lower Manhattan, and is engraved with the Hunt coat of arms.
While the hefty tankard has some characteristics of Dutch silver -- Baroque engraving and an applied leaf border on the base -- it is distinctively American. "The thumb piece in the shape of a cocoon is definitely a New York characteristic, one you'd never find in Boston or Philadelphia," said Jeanne Sloane, the head of Christie's silver department. "The tankard form is basically English, but the decorative elements are Dutch. To see such a combination tells you it's New York and not Continental."
Unlike Paul Revere, who imitated English forms, the tankard is an example of an original American style, which explains its record price.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Silver tankard made by Bartholomew Le Roux in New York in 1710. (Christie's)

HEADLINE: Poetry Academy, After Budget Uproar, Gets New Chief 

BYLINE:  By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK 

 BODY:
The Academy of American Poets yesterday named Tree Swenson its executive director, succeeding William Wadsworth, whose departure after a dispute with the organization's board last fall provoked angry protests from some prominent poets.
 Ms. 
Swenson, 50, is the director of programs for the Massachusetts Cultural Council. From 1972 to 1992, she was co-founder, executive director and publisher of Copper Canyon Press in Port Townsend, Wash., which became an important nonprofit poetry publisher. Copper Canyon published the work of poets including the Nobel Prize winners Pablo Neruda and Vicente Aleixandre. It also published Lucille Clifton, a member of the panel of poets that advised the academy's board. 
 Mr. Wadsworth, a published poet and former wine-marketing consultant, was the executive director for 12 years and won praise from many academy members for publicizing poets and poetry with programs like National Poetry Month and an elaborate Web site (www.poets.org). 
But the academy's programs also grew expensive, and when the recession cramped fund-raising efforts Mr. Wadsworth clashed with the board over how to reconcile costs and revenues. After his resignation, the academy dismissed 8 of its 17 employees.
Ms. Swenson said she planned to continue Mr. Wadsworth's efforts to raise poetry's profile while also keeping a close eye on the academy's budget.
"Bill was very highly regarded in the poetry world, and I am one of the people who think that he accomplished a lot in his time there," she said.
She is to start her new position on April 1, the beginning of National Poetry Month.
Separately, Paul Gottlieb, 67, a vice chairman of the French Groupe de la Martiniere, was named chairman of the academy's board, succeeding Jonathan Galassi.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

Opera

"IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA." The news of this "Barber" is the Peruvian tenor Juan Diego Florez, who made his Metropolitan Opera debut in January as Count Almaviva; he acquits himself with bravura as a young, slightly spoiled aristocrat with a ringing voice and a rapid vibrato. His vocal standards should be matched by those of his love interest, Rosina, sung by the soprano Ruth Ann Swenson. Dwayne Croft plays a dapper Figaro with a dry-look coiffure, although unfortunately the role lies too high for his voice. In the pit, Yves Abel, the Canadian conductor, keeps the orchestra lean, lithe and agile, stripped of hyperbolic bombast. Tomorrow evening at 8, Metropolitan Opera at Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000. Tickets: Sold out, but returns may be available (Ann Midgette).

"L'ELISIR D'AMORE." To open its new production of Donizetti's light and bubbly favorite, the diminutive Amato Opera includes a Champagne buffet in the price of admission for a premiere gala on Saturday night. Sunday, it's back to business as usual. The indefatigable Tony Amato conducts, and Richard Cerullo, the venerable company's resident designer, has produced sets and costumes for this age-old tale of village love. Tomorrow night at 7 (new production gala), Sunday at 2:30 p.m., Amato Opera, 319 Bowery, (212) 228-8200. Tickets: Saturday gala: $50 a person (includes Champagne buffet). Sunday: $28; $23 for students, 65+ and children under 12 (Midgette).

"LE NOZZE DI FIGARO." The Metropolitan Opera. Apart from a bit of obvious symbolism -- walls in need of a paint job standing for the crumbling of the aristocracy -- Jonathan Miller's 1998 staging of this great Mozart opera is simple, direct and attractive and lets the drama unfold on its own terms. The Met has a good cast, both individually and as an ensemble: Korliss Uecker is Susanna, Ferruccio Furlanetto is Figaro, Kristine Jepson is Cherubino, and there are two fine newcomers to the house, Soile Isokoski, a Finnish soprano, as the Countess, and Peter Mattei, a Swedish baritone, as the Count. Donald Runnicles is the astute conductor. Tomorrow at 1:30, Metropolitan Opera. (212) 362-6000. Sold out, but returns may be available (Allan Kozinn).

"TOSCA." Sylvie Valayre, a French soprano, continues to sing the title role in the ongoing run of "Toscas" at the Metropolitan Opera, animating Franco Zeffirelli's beloved if slightly overfamiliar 1985 production with its true-to-life reproductions of the opera's original settings in Rome. The Cavaradossi is Richard Leech, generally a solid presence, while James Morris retains his position in what began the season's run as a disappointingly dry Scarpia. Daniel Oren, the conductor, favors excessive rubatos, which tend to throw the brakes onto the musical continuity. Tonight at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, (212) 362-6000. Remaining tickets: $30 to $190 (Midgette).

"WENJI: 18 SONGS OF A NOMAD FLUTE." Based on the historic figure Cai Wenji, a Chinese musician and poet abducted from her homeland by a general from Mongolia, this opera by Bun-Ching Lam explores the paradox of the expatriate who no longer belongs wholly in either of her countries. Ms. Lam herself epitomizes the same paradox: born in Macao, living in New York, she uses both Chinese and Western idioms in her music. Blends of cello and pipa, bass clarinet and zhonghu support the three singers in this chamber opera: a Beijing Opera singer (Zhou Long) as various Chinese characters, a Western opera singer (Ethan Herschenfeld) to symbolize the barbarian general, and an opera singer who is Chinese, Li Xiuying, as the woman caught between two traditions, singing Chinese lyrics in a full, Western-trained operatic voice. The text, in Chinese and English (with surtitles) is by Xu Ying; Rinde Eckert, the American performing artist, directs. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, 212-517-ASIA (212-517-2742). Tickets: $25; $20 for society members; $15 for students and 65+ (Midgette).

Classical Music

BANG ON A CAN ALL STARS. Some exciting performers from the new-music world -- the percussionist Steven Schick, the bassist Robert Black, the clarinetist Evan Ziporyn and others -- get together with the Burmese drum master Kyaw Kyaw Naing and the jazz clarinetist Don Byron. New pieces by Mr. Naing and Mr. Byron are on the program, together with works by Scott Johnson and Tan Dun. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $30 (Paul Griffiths).

BARGEMUSIC. This is a weekend for variety at this intimate floating concert hall on the East River. Tonight, Mary Nessinger, a mezzo-soprano, sings some of Haydn's folk song settings with piano trio accompaniment, as well as some Mendelssohn songs. And Stephanie Brown, the pianist; Carmit Zori, the violinist; and Julia Lichten, the cellist, are to close the concert with the Brahms Piano Trio in C minor (Op. 101). Tomorrow and on Sunday, Ms. Zori is to be joined by Ani Kavafian, the violinist; Nokuthula Ngwenyama, the violist; and Ronald Thomas, the cellist, for a program that includes Turina's graceful "Oracion del Torero" and string quartets by Mozart (in D, K. 575) and Beethoven (in E flat, Op. 74). Tonight and tomorrow evening at 7:30; Sunday at 4 p.m. Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing next to the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn. (718) 624-2083. Tickets: $30; $25 for 65+, $15 for students (Kozinn).

JOSHUA BELL. This American violinist, though still in his early 30's, established himself long ago as a solid presence on the concert stage, and his more recent work in the film "The Red Violin," though off camera, carried him to wider attention. He plays with a robust tone and secure technique, and his particular strengths are sheer visceral excitement and passionate lyricism. The program here -- sonatas by Beethoven and Franck, works by Stravinsky and Tchaikovsky, and Sarasate's "Carmen" Fantasy -- should afford ample scope for those qualities. Simon Mulligan is the pianist. Sunday at 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $27 to $47 (James R. Oestreich).

THE CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER. With a stellar lineup that includes the violinist Kyoko Takezawa and the talented young cellist Alisa Weilerstein, the society focuses this weekend on Russian music. Tchaikovsky's dynamic late sextet "Souvenir de Florence" is a highlight of a program that also includes the first piano trio in D minor by Anton Arensky, among that composer's best-known works, with Jonathan Biss on piano; and Prokofiev's Sonata for Two Violins, Op. 56, from 1932. The program repeats on Tuesday evening. Sunday at 5 p.m., Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5788. Tickets: $27.50 and $37.50 (Midgette).

CLASSICS DECLASSIFIED. Leon Botstein, in his conductor-as-music-educator mode (as opposed to his educator-as-conductor mode), has been leading the American Symphony Orchestra in programs he calls "Classics Declassified" for several seasons, each installment taking a single work and exploring its history and meaning as a prelude to a performance. This week's offering is Strauss's "Metamorphosen," a work composed at the end of World War II and susceptible to many meanings. Mr. Botstein will no doubt have plenty to say about it, and about Strauss's attitudes toward the Nazis and his position in German culture during the war years. It is bound to be an enlightening presentation; just watch out for those straw men, Mr. Botstein's favorite rhetorical device. Sunday at 3 p.m., Miller Theater at Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street. (212) 581-1365. Tickets are $15 (Kozinn).

THE CLERKS' GROUP. This English vocal ensemble, founded in London in 1992, prefers to perform clustered around a single partbook, as singers in the Renaissance would have done, and they take the view that the tendency of modern choral groups to prize vocal homogeneity may be ahistorical. Instead, they allow the voices within the group to be heard distinctively within the blend. They gave a superb performance as part of the Music Before 1800 series two seasons ago. Now they're back with a program of Josquin's sacred and secular works, including the "Miserere Mei" and a rarely performed Mass, the "Missa Faisant Regretz." Sunday at 4 p.m., Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street. (212) 666-9266. Tickets: $25 to $30; $20 to $25 for students and 62+ (Kozinn).

CONCERTGEBOUW ORCHESTRA. Riccardo Chailly, the group's music director (recently revealed to be a lame duck), has been turning into a truly insightful Mahler conductor in recent years, so there should be much to ponder in this performance of the "Resurrection" Symphony, repeated from Carnegie Hall on Wednesday. The Westminster Symphonic Choir, based in New Jersey, adds a touch of local color, and Janice Watson and Petra Lang are the vocal soloists. Sunday at 3 p.m., New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722. Tickets: $15 to $68 (Oestreich).

HARMONIE ENSEMBLE. The Harmonie Ensemble boasts a special connection to Aaron Copland, who conducted the group in a Wall-to-Wall Copland Concert at Symphony Space in 1980. On Sunday afternoon the ensemble offers an all-Copland program that includes a few rarities: Two Ballads for Violin and Piano (adapted from sketches for a never-completed sonata), Elegies for Viola and Piano, and a solo piano version of "El Salon Mexico" arranged by, of all people, Arturo Toscanini. Among the performers are the pianist Diane Walsh and two members of the Emerson String Quartet: the violinist Eugene Drucker and the violist Lawrence Dutton. The program includes "Appalachian Spring" (the original version for 13 instruments) and the jazzy "Music for the Theater." Steven Richman conducts. Sunday at 4 p.m., Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, at 73rd Street, (212) 288-8920. Tickets: Suggested contribution $10; $8 for students and 65+ (Anthony Tommasini).

MUSIC FROM JAPAN. The organization presents a concert of the rich and splendid music of Akira Nishimura, who will be there to talk an hour before the event. His Second Quartet, aptly subtitled "Pulses of Light," is performed by the Corigliano Quartet. William Anderson, Oren Fader and Scott Kuney perform "Pipa" for three guitars. And Aki Takahashi presents a new work for solo piano: "Avatars." Tomorrow at 8 p.m. And on Sunday at 2 p.m., the gagaku ensemble Harena plays traditional and contemporary music. Merkin Hall, 67th Street at West End Avenue (212) 501-3330. Tickets: $15 for each concert, or $25 for both (Griffiths).

NEW YORK COLLEGIUM. This promises to be an eventful evening, with Andrew Parrott conducting Bach's "St. John Passion" in his debut as the collegium's music director. Mr. Parrott, who is also a scholar, is in basic agreement with Joshua Rifkin's research suggesting that Bach's choruses typically consisted only of the four solo voices used in recitatives and arias. But here, it turns out, Mr. Parrott will use an additional voice on each line, making for a chorus of eight, still small by most current standards. Tonight at 8, Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, (212) 717-9246. Tickets: $25 and $40; $15 for students (Oestreich).

NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. Love and death come to the concert stage when Kurt Masur conducts the New York Philharmonic in Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" -- a great deal of it, at least. Included are Act II complete surrounded by the Act I Prelude and the Act III Prelude and Liebestod. It will be interesting to hear Mr. Masur's rectitude next to Wagner's steamy music. The cast will be first rate. Especially attractive is the chance to hear Deborah Voigt show what she (in part) can do with a juicy but demanding role that everyone has always assumed would be in her future. Stig Andersen and Violetta Urmana are strong parts of this cast. Tomorrow night at 8. Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: sold out. The performance repeats Feb. 12 and 14 (Bernard Holland).

ORPHEUS CHAMBER ORCHESTRA. It is worth paying attention to almost anything these conductorless players put their collective hand, mind and heart to. Here that is an attractive program of the "Italian Serenade" and songs by Hugo Wolf, and the Sixth Symphony and songs by Schubert. The excellent mezzo-soprano Angelika Kirchschlager is the vocal soloist. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $19 to $89 (Oestreich).

KEITH PHARES. A graduate of the Juilliard Opera Center and a winner of the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, Keith Phares, a young American baritone, made a strong impression earlier this season in the New York City Opera's production of Monteverdi's "Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria." The Marilyn Horne Foundation is presenting Mr. Phares in recital on Sunday afternoon as part of its "On Wings of Song" series at the Kosciuszko Foundation. With Michael Baitzer at the piano, Mr. Phares will sing works by Handel, Wolf, Poulenc, Butterworth and Harold Arlen. Sunday at 3 p.m., Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East 65th Street, Manhattan, (212) 734-2130. Tickets: $15 (Tommasini).

RIVERSIDE SYMPHONY. Bach and his musical heirs is the theme of the interesting program that the also interesting Riverside Symphony will perform tonight at Alice Tully Hall. The music director, George Rothman, conducts Bach's Suite No 1 in C and the Keyboard Concerto No. 4 in A, the latter with the brilliant pianist Christopher Taylor as soloist. Mr. Taylor will also be the soloist in the premier of Matthew Greenbaum's "Spherical Music," a work modeled on Bach's concerto-suite design. The program concludes with the Sinfonia No. 7 for Strings by Mendelssohn, a Bach disciple if there ever was one. Tonight at 8, Alice Tully Hall, (212) 721-6500, or (212) 864-4197. Tickets: $45, $30 (Tommasini).

ST. LOUIS SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA. Several American orchestras are facing financial troubles in the wake of the recession. For a while it seemed as if the St. Louis Symphony might not survive at all. The orchestra's administration now says that the situation is better, and the orchestra will perform as scheduled tonight at Carnegie Hall, its only New York appearance of the season. But adding to the problems, the music director, Hans Vonk, took ill during a performance last weekend and could not continue. So tonight's Carnegie Hall performance will be conducted by David Robertson, who accepted on short notice and has had only one rehearsal with the orchestra. This has necessitated a partial program change. Mr. Robertson will offer Hindemith's Symphonic Metamorphosis on Themes of Carl Maria von Weber and Debussy's "Prelude a l'Apres-Midi d'un Faune." He will also conduct the previously announced "La Mer" by Debussy and Ravel's Piano Concerto for the Left Hand, with Gary Graffman as soloist. Tonight at 8, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $84 to $22 (Tommasini).

TOKYO STRING QUARTET. As the quartet in residence at the 92nd Street Y this season, the Tokyo plays four concerts centered on the major chamber works of Brahms, with contemporary and international tinges added. Each program includes a newly commissioned piece, with the composers drawn from four countries; here Fabio Vacchi of Italy offers his Fourth String Quartet. The Brahms works are the two string quintets, with Phillip Ying as second violist, and the C minor String Quartet (Op. 51, No. 1). Tomorrow night at 8, 92nd Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500. Tickets: $35 (Oestreich).

Dance

ALL THAT TANGO! This tango musical, conceived by Angel Gil Orrios, stars the master bandoneon player Raul Jaurena and three tango-dancing couples who are also accompanied by singing and piano and violin music. Tonight (and next Thursday and Friday) at 8; tomorrow (and Feb. 16) at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sunday (and Feb. 17) at 4 p.m. Thalia Spanish Theater, 41-17 Greenpoint Avenue, Sunnyside; (718) 729-3880. Tickets: Thursday and Friday, $22; $20 for students and those 65 and over; tomorrow and Sunday, $25; $22 for students and those 65 and over (Jennifer Dunning).

ALEXANDRA BELLER. Ms. Beller promises to bend a few genders in the intriguingly entitled dances on this program, among them "Dangling Fruits of Joy or How to Make Love." Tonight through Sunday at 8 p.m. Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, SoHo; (212) 334-7479. Tickets: $15; $12 for students and those 65 and over (Dunning).

BUGLISI/FOREMAN DANCE. A company known for its dramatic expressiveness offers two programs featuring premieres as well as works from the repertory. HEADLINE: Retailers' Deep Discounting Helped Sales During January 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Deep discounting of winter merchandise drew consumers into stores in January, offering many struggling retailers a brief respite from a recent spate of sluggish sales. 
 But while analysts see the sales gains announced yesterday as encouraging, they do not believe the consumer is ready to splurge. Economic uncertainty continues to drive consumers into Wal-Mart Stores and other discounters, which again outperformed the rest of the retail industry during January. 
 Department stores, meanwhile, particularly May Department Stores, and apparel chains, including the Gap, are still struggling, although the sales declines for many were not as bad as Wall Street expected.
"Consumers came out in response to the great values in the stores," said Richard Jaffe, an analyst at UBS Warburg. But, he asked, are they willing to pay regular price for spring merchandise? "It is tough to say," he said. 
The Goldman, Sachs retail composite index showed that sales at stores open at least a year rose 3.4 percent in January from the period a year earlier. It was the strongest monthly rise since January 2001, when the index rose 3.5 percent.
"Americans are not yet ready to go on spending sprees and buying binges, particularly at department stores," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Trend Report, based in Montclair, N.J. "They are willing to spend -- if the prices are real bargains."
Wal-Mart posted an 8.3 percent rise in sales at stores open at least a year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call expected Wal-Mart to report a 6.2 percent gain. The company's total sales for the month were up 15.7 percent.
Costco Wholesale reported a 7 percent gain in same-store sales, beating Wall Street expectations for a 5.2 percent increase. Total sales were up 13 percent in January.
Another surprise came from J. C. Penney, which posted a 5.9 percent increase in same-store sales for its department store division. Thomson Financial/First Call expected an increase of 4.9 percent. Total sales were up 4.1 percent.
Apparel chains and department stores again struggled, but analysts said they thought the aggressive discounting, along with a concerted effort to get spring goods into the stores, helped spur sales.
The Limited posted sales gains of 6 percent in January. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call expected a 2.4 percent decline.
Federated Department Stores reported an 8.8 percent decline in same-store sales, better than the 9.5 percent drop Wall Street analysts projected. Total sales were down 24.2 percent
There were still some disappointments. May Department Stores had a 10.1 percent drop in same-store sales, worse than analysts had expected. Total sales were down 7.2 percent.
The Gap recorded a same-store sales drop of 16 percent, worse than the 13 percent decline that Wall Street analysts had projected. Total sales were down 4.9 percent.

HEADLINE: Citing Strife, U.S. Delays Two Loans To Haitians 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 7 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said here today that the United States would not free millions of dollars in loans and aid to the Haitian government until it resolves a deadlock and curbs political violence. 
 His remarks at a meeting of Caribbean foreign ministers signaled the Bush administration's growing exasperation with President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti, whom the United States restored to power in 1994 after a military coup. 
 The American stance drew immediate criticism from the 14-nation Caribbean community, or Caricom, whose leaders argued that the denial of the money was destabilizing Haiti, the Hemisphere's poorest nation, and generating an increase in refugees. 
In unusually blunt criticism of Mr. Aristide, Secretary Powell all but blamed his intransigence for growing violence in the country. 
"We are terribly concerned about the political unrest that continues to haunt Haiti," Secretary Powell said. "We are concerned about some of the actions of the government, and we do not believe enough has been done yet to move the political process forward." 
"We believe we have to hold President Aristide and the Haitian government to fairly high standards of performance before we can simply allow funds to flow into the country," he added. 
Secretary Powell said the United States would oppose $200 million in loans from the Inter-American Development Bank until the Haitian government and its opposition find a way to settle a dispute that stems from local and legislative elections held in 2000. 
Secretary Powell recalled his role along with former President Jimmy Carter and then-Senator Sam Nunn -- in brokering the agreement that restored Mr. Aristide to power. The reinstatement of Mr. Aristide, a former priest known for fiery sermons in defense of the poor, was bitterly opposed by Haiti's business community and by some Republicans in Congress who predicted he would rule with violence. 
Haiti's foreign minister, Joseph Philippe Antonio, said the Aristide government is doing everything possible to reach an accord with leaders of the opposition coalition known as the Democratic Convergence. Earlier this week, Mr. Aristide offered to hold new elections in November for seven disputed Senate seats.
"There is a will on the Haitian government's part," Mr. Antonio said in an interview. "We are doing everything we can to get out of this crisis." 
Since 1994, the United States has poured hundreds of millions of dollars into Haiti in an effort to help democratic government gain a footing there and to restore the economy. The United States provided Haiti $55 million in aid last year, mostly distributed by relief organizations, officials said.
The administration is blocking the release of two loans that were initially approved in 1997 and 1998. The European Union has also withheld funds, offering to provide $350 million in aid over the next five years if the political situation is resolved.
Edwin Carrington, the secretary general of Caricom, called that approach "not tactically correct" because it deprived the Aristide government of the ability to create jobs and stabilize society.
"You've got to put some more social resources into Haiti so the predilection for violence is reduced," he said. Without an infusion of cash, Mr. Carrington added, "They are never going to get there." 
Janet Bostwick, the foreign minister of the Bahamas, said that her country was coping with growing numbers of Haitian refugees bound for the United States. Last month, authorities detained 800 Haitian refugees at sea, a 40 percent increase over last year.
On other issues, there was greater harmony. Secretary Powell expressed gratitude for the region's cooperation in suppressing terrorism and narcotics trafficking and voiced sympathy for the loss of tourism, an economic mainstay for many nations since the Sept. 11 attacks. He said there was "nothing that would suggest that the Caribbean has become a major haven or potential haven" for terrorists.
Administration officials said, however, that four nations Dominica, Grenada, St. Vincent and St. Kitts have been deemed "uncooperative" with American led efforts to combat money-laundering.
To fight the spread of AIDS, the administration will increase its outlay of funds for programs targeting youth and other high-risk groups, officials said. Funding rose to $20 million last year, a fourfold increase. After sub-Saharan Africa, the Caribbean has some of the highest AIDS rates in the world.

HEADLINE: Payoff of Credit Cards Helps Push Consumer Debt Down 3.7% 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 

 BODY:
Consumer debt unexpectedly dropped at a 3.7 percent annual rate in December, a month after borrowing increased more than at any time in almost six decades, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
 The seasonally adjusted $5.1 billion decrease, reflecting a record drop in credit card debt and other revolving loans, came after a $20.1 billion surge a month earlier. 
 The jump in November, eight months after the recession began, was the largest since the Fed started keeping records in January 1943. The December dollar decrease in revolving debt was also the largest since then. 
The decline, in part, shows consumers "have been cashing out the equity in their homes and using some of that to pay down their high-cost credit cards," said Paul Kasriel, an economist at Northern Trust Securities in Chicago.
Consumer borrowing rose at a 6.4 percent annual rate in the final three months of 2001, reflecting the strongest pace of spending in two years. The rate of borrowing was the fastest since the first quarter of last year as shoppers took advantage of interest-free loans from automakers and incentives from retailers.
Analysts expected consumer credit to rise $8.1 billion in December after November's gain, previously reported as $19.8 billion. Borrowing last year increased 5.6 percent, almost half the 10.2 percent increase in 2000.
A separate report today showed that initial claims for jobless benefits fell last week, ending a month in which the fewest new applications were filed since the recession began.
State unemployment offices received 376,000 claims last week, a decline of 15,000, the Labor Department said. Claims have held at less than 400,000 for five consecutive weeks. The last time that happened was in March, when the recession was starting.
The "unexpected decline in jobless claims is another sign the recovery is under way," said Frank Nothaft, chief economist at Freddie Mac, the No. 2 buyer of mortgages in the United States.
Analysts had expected jobless claims would total 390,000, unchanged from the initial estimate for the previous week. The forecast was based on the median of 29 estimates in a Bloomberg News survey.

HEADLINE: Fashion Week Is Resized to Fit Times 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
As the semiannual Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week gets under way today in Bryant Park, some in the fashion industry are using the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 as an explanation for the event's smaller presence this year.
 The attacks occurred midway through last fall's Fashion Week, traumatizing many participants. Fern Mallis, the executive director of 7th on Sixth, the event's producer, said the attacks prompted designers to rethink their priorities. 
 "There's a new word in our fashion vocabulary which didn't used to be there," Ms. Mallis said, "and it's called 'appropriate.' " 
But many retailers and designers say that Fashion Week had begun to choke on its own success and needed a change long before Sept. 11, and even before the economic downturn, which has hammered the apparel industry.
Critics have said that for one thing, too many fashion groupies and other hangers-on were crowding into the tents, creating a circuslike atmosphere.
Responding to the criticism, Ms. Mallis said: "When they tell you, 'This doesn't work for me,' it generally means that business hasn't been good for a few seasons."
Still, veterans of the front row say the fashion was getting lost.
Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue, said a more intimate Fashion Week would put the emphasis back on the clothes. 
"It's just going to be smaller, more professional, more about the press and the buyers and less about celebrities and the social world," Ms. Wintour said. "Everyone wants the people who ought to be there to be there."
And it's not as if 7th on Sixth has pitched a pup tent this year. Designers like Tommy Hilfiger, Anne Klein and Oscar de la Renta will still put on elaborate shows in the park. "The industry needs spectacle sometimes," said Jacqui Lividini, a senior vice president at Saks Fifth Avenue.
But over all, the scale of the event will be smaller -- from as many as 12 shows a day in Bryant Park to 4. Large tents that could accommodate 900 and 1,200 spectators have given way to spaces that hold 688 and 530. In the past, the tents in the park also offered smaller spaces, but now these can be had only at the Puck Building, at Lafayette and Houston Streets in SoHo.
And while it is nothing new for designers like Calvin Klein and Marc Jacobs to choose sites away from Bryant Park, this year they will be joined by others, like Carolina Herrera and Badgley Mischka. 
Cost is certainly a significant factor this year. "Let's face it, life is tough out there," said Kevin Krier, who is producing seven shows this year, only three of them in Bryant Park. The cheapest space in the tents costs $34,000 to rent, compared with $11,000 for the smallest space in the Puck Building.
One of Mr. Krier's clients, Badgley Mischka, which is known for its beaded evening gowns, has shown in a Bryant Park tent about 10 times, normally before an audience of 800, said Mark Badgley, co-president of the company, which is a unit of Escada. Each show cost at least $250,000, he said. 
For a show on Tuesday at their Seventh Avenue showroom, Mr. Badgley and his partner, James Mischka, trimmed their invitation list to 300. 
"James and I would be the first to say that Fashion Week was sliding out of control," Mr. Badgley said. "This is bringing it back to what the clothes are all about."
The downsizing of Fashion Week could not come at a worse time for 7th on Sixth. Established in 1993, the event used to be run by a nonprofit group, the Council of Fashion Designers of America. Last summer, 7th on Sixth was bought by IMG, a private company. After its first venture in Bryant Park was interrupted by the terrorist attack, IMG paid back millions of dollars to designers who had been unable to show -- money that it has yet to recoup from its insurers, Ms. Mallis said. 
She said the smaller spaces had to be eliminated because the "revenues were way out of line with what it costs to build the space."
Even with its smaller footprint, Fashion Week can be expected to generate significant revenue and tax dollars for the city. Ms. Mallis said that about 10,000 people come and go during the shows, with a core group of about 2,500. She said the press list consists of 1,500 people, down slightly from last year. She could not say, however, how many of the people attending would be coming from out of town.
In 1997, the last year the city released figures, it estimated that the shows -- there were two women's shows and two men's shows then -- brought in a total of about $206.2 million, including $8.9 million in tax revenue, and $86.3 million in visitor spending. City officials would not say how they arrived at these figures. 
John Tepper Marlin, chief economist for the city comptroller's office, said that if 1,250 of the participants -- half of what Ms. Mallis describes as the core group -- were from out of town, a week of shows might bring in about $28 million.

HEADLINE: Painful Choices for States Facing Wider Budget Gaps 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 

 BODY:
With budget surpluses a memory now and tax revenues spiraling further downward, most state governments face deepening budget gaps as costs rise in Medicaid, education and other expensive programs, according to a new national survey.
 In the clearest sign that the statehouse boom times of surplus politicking are history, proposals to raise taxes are under consideration in 19 states, says the survey, by the National Conference of State Legislatures. 
 Nearly all 50 states and Washington, D.C., are suffering revenue shortfalls, with politicians tapping into rainy-day funds and ordering an array of painful remedies, including hiring freezes. More than half the states have had to resort to their rainy-day funds and more than three-quarters have ordered budget cuts or spending slowdowns. 
"This reflects the reality of what's occurring from coast to coast in our country," said State Senator Stephen M. Saland of New York, the president of the national conference, who emphasized the report was prompted by the worsening budget outlook and "painful choices" being forced on state governments. 
"Our initial report last November showed the state budgets were heading south, and this one suggests we're heading perhaps even more southerly," said Mr. Saland, a Poughkeepsie Republican with 23 years of legislative experience.
Even beyond the current year's worsening projections, the senator noted, at least 37 states expect continuing budget gaps next year. Officials are well aware, Mr. Saland emphasized, that there is always a delay between economic recovery and any surge in the flow of tax revenues.
Current state revenues were described as "anemic" by conference specialists. They found nearly half the states have had to lower their revenue forecasts below budgeted levels for the current year and that only 5 of the 50 states may finish at or near the year's initial projections.
"The magnitude of budget gaps has been significant enough that even programs that often are spared from cuts, such as K-12 education, have been reduced in some states," the conference reported in the study, which was conducted late last month.
In California, for example, Gov. Gray Davis has proposed $2.2 billion in spending cuts to cover a growing shortfall in the current fiscal year, with more than $840 million of this coming from earlier, more optimistic spending plans for education.
Medicaid spending keeps rising, going over budget in 23 states, with at least an additional 5 expecting overruns. Other state programs exceeding projected costs include temporary welfare cash assistance, mental health services and prescription drug assistance for the elderly.
Even if early signs of a possible economic recovery pan out, this cannot be immediately factored into state tax coffers, officials said. 
"The state revenue ship is big, not a finely tuned machine, and it often takes a while to get back up to speed," said Arturo Perez, a budget specialist with the conference.
The revenue falloff because of the recession can be seen most dramatically in states that rely heavily on capital gains tax flow for budget balance, Mr. Perez said. For example, there are projected budget gaps for the next fiscal year of $8 billion in California, $5 billion each in New York and New Jersey, $2 billion in Massachusetts and $794 million in Connecticut. 
As budget cutters move in, statehouse victories are being proclaimed when education can be spared the knife. In Ohio, Gov. Bob Taft imposed a 6 percent across-the-board cut but protected spending on kindergarten through 12th grade and school construction. Idaho has already enacted a budget slowdown of 2.5 percent for elementary and secondary education, a half-percent less drastic than for the rest of the budget.
States have rainy-day funds to achieve budget balance in hard times. At the current rate of revenue shortfall, these funds will start being depleted next year unless economic recovery arrives quickly enough to boost state coffers, said William Pound, the conference's executive director. 
The ever-tightening direction of state spending is exemplified by Virginia, which was already implementing a 2 percent across-the-board budget reduction and is considering 3 percent cuts. Some states like Idaho are considering dipping temporarily into tobacco settlement fund revenues. 
Other measures enacted or being considered by states include increasing gaming revenues, delaying scheduled tax cuts and increasing contributions required from state workers to health care plans.

HEADLINE: With Uncertainty Filling the Air, 9/11 Health Risks Are Debated 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Five-year-old Phoebe Kaufman's room was once filled with her artwork. Now all that remains is a single picture of a flower, which hangs by her bed. Her parents threw out everything else because paper is porous and might have absorbed dust from the collapsing World Trade Center towers that blasted into their Lower Manhattan apartment through an open window.
 No one knows whether Phoebe's artwork had become dangerous, and air tests done in that apartment building, about a block from ground zero, have shown the air to be safe. But decisions still had to be made, so everything absorbent -- stuffed animals, mattresses, coats -- went into the trash. 
 It's the floor that has the family in a quandary now. The family's insurance company said it would pay to have their old wooden floor refinished, but that idea was shot down by their pediatrician, who said that the trade center dust, perhaps containing asbestos or other hazardous materials, was deep in the floor's cracks and that sanding would throw it back into the air. 
"It's such a uniquely American thing to think that science can provide an objective truth, but no one has an answer to these kinds of questions," said Phoebe's mother, Elizabeth Berger. "There's no one to turn to."
Community leaders in Lower Manhattan have estimated that about 75 percent of the roughly 20,000 people who lived within a half mile of the trade center have returned to their homes since the Sept. 11 disaster. And all of them are facing the same series of questions and choices about how to live in this altered place and how to assess the environmental risks that the proximity to a disaster site and cleanup project may entail.
This being New York, the diversity of conclusions is boundless. Some people see downtown as a toxic nightmare, a kind of Manhattan Love Canal that has permanently poisoned the area's buildings and apartments with asbestos or chemicals. Others believe the risks are overblown or nonexistent.
But in another way, many residents say, the diversity of views reflects the deeper problem they face: that no answer seems certain, scientifically airtight, or obvious. Because there has been little government testing of apartments for air quality -- and some tests conducted months ago have still not been published -- there is no public body of facts, no set of numbers that can bestow a feeling of certainty. Some building owners have had their properties privately tested; others have not. And every test that is done becomes ammunition for one side or another -- those who see great risk and those who do not. How to clean an apartment or an office that was contaminated, how to know when it is clean enough, whether to pay for expensive tests or filters, whether to worry about how well the neighbors cleaned their apartments and rooftops, are all questions that have for the most part been left to individual tenants, owners and workers.
"People have essentially been left to their own devices," said Representative Jerrold Nadler, a Democrat from Manhattan who represents downtown, and who believes that what he calls the microclimates of downtown -- the homes and offices, the personal spaces and lives of residents and workers -- have been mostly neglected in the disaster response.
But New Yorkers have not waited for science and government to catch up. In the same energetic, impatient ways that have always shaped the city's character, they have simply gotten on with things.
Beth Kaltman, 22, a model, cleaned her own apartment using paper towels. So did Dr. Jessica Leighton, an assistant commissioner of risk and environmental communication at the New York City Department of Health.
Noreen Hennessy and her husband, Elliot Freeman, who live on Warren Street, a few blocks from the disaster site, hired professional cleaners. In the converted factory building on Broadway where Phoebe Kaufman and her family live, some people ripped up their floors. Some mopped up and vacuumed, and others never came back. 
Phoebe's father, Frederick Kaufman, installed filters to cover the air ducts that connect to the rest of the building, working on the theory that dirtier air from other apartments or common areas of the building could infiltrate. He cannot say that this, like throwing away Phoebe's artwork, was a necessary step; he also cannot say, when it comes to the health of his daughter and his son, Julian, 2, that it was not necessary, either.
"You can no longer say this is a rational response, or this is an emotional response, you just have to say, this is what I have to do to feel safe," he said. And without conclusive data, people also have little basis of defending the decisions they do make, he said.
"Anybody doing more cleaning than I is a fanatic, and anybody doing less is crazy," he said.

Measuring the Impact
In the frantic hours after the attack on Sept. 11, as the smoke still billowed from the disaster site with a plume that would be tracked hundreds of miles at sea, responsibility for assessing the environmental impact was carved up, mainly because the job seemed too big for any one government entity to handle alone.
The federal Environmental Protection Agency took the lead responsibility for the air in public spaces -- sidewalks and streets. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration was in charge at ground zero. The New York City Departments of Health and Environmental Protection would take on the questions of building safety. Testing and monitoring began almost immediately -- what would grow in the ensuing months to become a sprawling database measuring everything from chromium, PCB's and lead to asbestos, silica and benzene.
And so, too, began what many health researchers now say was a huge political blunder. Officials from the E.P.A. and the city made broad pronouncements that the air downtown was safe to breathe, and not much of a long-term health concern outside the immediate perimeter of the disaster. Although those conclusions have not been disproved by the thousands of tests conducted since then -- more than 10,000 air samples by the E.P.A. -- the second-guessing and suspicions began almost immediately among many residents, and later physicians, that the tests were inadequate, or partial, or that the many things that could not be known about the air impact were being minimized, resulting in a cloud of mistrust and uncertainty that has still not gone away.
"I have the concern that the initial reassurances were based on the desire to move ahead as quickly as possible -- that reassurances were given because it supported public policy," said Dr. Stephen M. Levin, the medical director at the Mount Sinai-Irving J. Selikoff Center for Occupational and Environmental Medicine at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, who has seen dozens of cases of respiratory ailments related to the trade center disaster.
What ensued, in part, was a war of data and interpretation. The E.P.A., in testing for things like asbestos or other particles in the air, used a 24-hour-averaging system, which was considered the scientific standard for gauging exposures. But that system was attacked because it flattened the periodic spikes that were being recorded as dust and smoke drifted around the area.
The E.P.A. also focused on small particles, based on the scientific literature that said they were the greatest concern. That emphasis failed to reflect the larger particles that physicians and scientists say were causing widespread misery and worry -- from sore throats to red eyes -- across wide swaths of Lower Manhattan.
The size of the asbestos fibers that the government was measuring also became part of the battle. The E.P.A. scientists said that the larger particles they were testing for -- and which were showing up in relatively few numbers -- were the most dangerous because their shape allowed them to be lodged in the lungs, while smaller particles would get sloughed off by the body. Critics said that smaller particles were being deliberately overlooked. Some private tests showed concentrations of the tiniest asbestos fibers -- less than five microns in size -- that were in some cases four times above the government's safety threshold. 
But one of the biggest questions raised by the government's critics was that the government's air program was missing much of the world that people really inhabited -- the spaces inside apartments and office buildings, which had mostly been left to individual building owners and managers. There was no government database, no handy list of indoor air monitors to pull down from a Web site.
The Natural Resources Defense Council, whose headquarters are in Manhattan, plans to release a study next week concluding that the government response, while heroic on many levels, broke down when it came to the environment, especially the issues that affected local residents who faced daunting and often unanswerable questions about their health as the cleanup and recovery proceeded.
Because no one government agency was in charge of the overall environmental impact, the report says, issues of residential indoor air quality fell between the cracks, and because of the emphasis on long-term risks, the impact on susceptible populations was not emphasized enough.
"The residents of Lower Manhattan have to some extent gotten the short end of the stick as government agencies focused on what they considered to be the bigger picture -- cleanup of the site itself, restoration of the overall economy, returning some sense of normalcy," said Eric A. Goldstein, a senior lawyer with the group.
Officials at the Environmental Protection Agency and the New York City Department of Health both say that no new data has emerged suggesting they were wrong in concluding that the air downtown presented little long-term health risk to the general public. But the agency has also not expanded its testing program to include indoor spaces, leaving it mostly to building owners and managers -- some of whom might have an interest in minimizing the risk, or have limited resources to clean what they find.
"We had hard facts to support the claims we were making; it wasn't that everyone was saying, 'Don't worry, be happy,' " said Jane M. Kenny, the regional administrator at the E.P.A.'s office in New York. But people wanted certainty, and science, she said, could not provide that and never has.
They acknowledge that there was, at times, an imperfect fit between the issues they study -- dire health threats -- and the frightening, if short-term, symptoms of respiratory distress and irritation that many people experienced.
At a federal government laboratory in North Carolina, a hundred mice are breathing dust from the trade center collapse. Some have it injected deep into their lungs, while others get intense one-day exposures in a dust-filled chamber, to mimic the dense cloud that people were caught in on Sept. 11. Other researchers are re-examining the health effects of exposure to large dust particles, which have been linked by physicians to the onset of asthma among some people who worked at ground zero in the days after the disaster.
The goal is to learn by comparison. Dust from the trade center is new in the world, a combination of pulverized concrete, steel and other compounds that might have some things in common with a cloud like the one from the volcanic eruption of Mount St. Helens, which has been extensively studied.
In other ways, the dust is perhaps more like industrial pollution that results from combustion, about which much is known as well, said Dr. William H. Farland, the acting deputy assistant administrator for science, at the E.P.A.'s office of research and development. 
Dr. Levin at Mount Sinai said that he thinks the truth about the disaster has gotten lost amid what he said has been hyperbole from different sides. Sometimes, Dr. Levin said, otherwise perfectly healthy people can develop problems like asthma with even brief exposures to highly irritating or noxious particles or chemicals, while others, exposed to exactly the same thing, remain perfectly fine. Biological diversity in human populations is much greater than government officials suggested.
"The blanket reassurances that were given after the disaster don't fit our clinical experience," he said.

Decisions, Decisions
Some people have grown impatient with what they described as a sort of hand-wringing about the risks downtown.
"Life carries on, you just have to get on with it," said Rose De Klerk, who cleaned up the layer of trade center dust that blew into her apartment, and was eager to get her daughter, Madison, 7, back into a school in the neighborhood. Madison was a second grader at Public School 89, which is scheduled to reopen later this month.
"We have to get back to normal," Ms. De Klerk said.
Other people say they feel paralyzed by the lack of information. Ms. Hennessy, who moved back downtown in January with her husband and their 1-year-old son, Sam, after four months living in a cramped temporary apartment uptown, said that going through her family's things has become an exercise in exorcising risk.
"There are too many questions about each object," she said. "So, I look at and I stare at and I end up throwing it away."
At Stuyvesant High School, a few blocks from the site, questions of indoor air quality have divided children and parents.
Dr. Fernando Pacifico, who lives in Queens, said he considered taking his 17-year-old daughter out of the school last fall, after he treated her for respiratory problems that he believes were caused by the dust and smoke. But that would have ripped apart his family.
"My daughter would be very unhappy leaving, and I couldn't do it," he said. "But then I felt guilty for not doing it, so I'm caught in this quandary, removing her for health reasons or keeping her in because she loves the school."
Dr. Pacifico said he was probably courting a family fight for even talking to a reporter about his concerns -- which are focused lately on dozens of idling diesel trucks that take loads of debris to a barge a few hundred feet from the school daily.
"My daughter downplays the air quality issue because she wants to stay," he said. "She doesn't want to hear about it."
Senator Charles E. Schumer also chose to allow his daughter Jessica, 17, to return to Stuyvesant to complete her senior year. He said in an interview that he thought the tests conducted at the school have shown it to be safe, though he said he understood how other people could reach a different conclusion. "The health of your child is the No. 1 thing you care about, so we try to be very careful and read all the materials, but at the same time try not to allow unsubstantiated fear to overcome the actual facts," he said.
Mr. Schumer said that, like Dr. Pacifico's daughter, Jessica largely dismissed the environmental concerns at the school as issues that only older people would worry about. But the senator said that he and his wife, Iris Weinshall, the commissioner of the New York City Department of Transportation, also had to think about how, as public officials, their decision might be perceived and interpreted. In this case, the decision, based on Jessica's health, became a testament to their faith in downtown, one that he brings up in talking to residents.
"I figure if you do the right thing for her you're doing the right thing for the public," Mr. Schumer said.
Other people denied that they have made any decisions whatsoever, and say that all the talk about risks is mostly a creation of the news media.
"I never had any decisions to make," said Elli Fordyce, an actress and singer, who moved back into her apartment on Rector Place in late September. As for the dust from the trade center that was in her apartment, she said, "My housekeeper came in four or five hours and then my landlord, who has insurance, had guys who don't do any better but charge $2,500 to come in."
In some buildings, even when to open a window has become a decision. Armando Buria, who lives in a building on West Street -- where many tenants are on a rent strike over environmental issues and rents -- said that while the air is definitely cleaner now than it was a few months ago, he still does not want to be exposed to it. Only when the wind is from the sea, or New Jersey, will he open his window.
"I'm a database consultant," he said. "I need to keep everything real time and fact based and I don't have the information." 
Ryan Conklin, on the other hand, is exulting in the choice he made -- a new apartment downtown, better than the one he was renting farther north in Greenwich Village, and less expensive, too.
"I'm one of the takers," he said.
But Mr. Conklin, 26, an investment banking analyst who is single, is also hedging his bets on downtown's future. His new landlord did offer three- to five-year leases, but Mr. Conklin chose the one-year option. Too much about downtown and its environmental issues, he said, could still change.
"You don't want to be trapped here for too long -- you never know, especially nowadays," he said.

HEADLINE: Suozzi Says Income Tax for Nassau County Is Just One Option Among Many 

BYLINE:  By ELISSA GOOTMAN 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y. Feb. 7 

 BODY:
One day after County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi publicly refused to rule out the possibility of a countywide income tax for Nassau, he called a news conference to emphasize that he was not ready to rule it in, either.
 "It is on the table, as well as dozens of other ideas are on the table," Mr. Suozzi said today. "Anything that's been done in the history of municipal finance, we're looking at." 
 But today, Republican legislators criticized the concept of an income tax and some Democratic legislators distanced themselves from the idea, with one Democrat going so far as to say that certain book-balancing measures simply should not be considered, no matter how dismal the county's fiscal state may be.
"An income tax should not be considered," Craig M. Johnson, a Democrat from Port Washington, said. "We should be addressing and resolving this deficit through spending cuts, elimination of services and other measures."
An income tax would "shift the burden to a different segment of the population in order to resolve the fiscal mess," Mr. Johnson said, adding that the idea would be so unpopular in some quarters as to be politically infeasible. 
"My wife and my own father may not vote for me if I supported this thing," he said. 
The County Legislature's Republican minority leader, Peter J. Schmitt, was similarly definitive in rejecting the concept. 
"With what our residents are going through in terms of the national economy, the state economy, school tax increases, economic uncertainty with layoffs and all of that, I just do not believe now is the time to even consider an income tax," Mr. Schmitt said. "It's crazy." 
Moreover, Mr. Schmitt said, an income tax could encourage people and businesses to move to neighboring Suffolk County, or elsewhere.
Other Democrats shared Mr. Suozzi's unwillingness to rule out the possibility of an income tax as one among many suggestions for closing a budget gap that he has said could grow to $428 million in four years. Still, even legislators willing to consider levying an income tax appeared annoyed by the flurry of publicity surrounding the idea. 
"I don't think we're in a position to foreclose any idea that is going to bring in revenues and bring us closer to a stable financial situation, but I know that there's been no recent discussions within the Democratic caucus about it," Jeffrey W. Toback, a Democratic legislator, said. 
A spokeswoman for the Democratic majority leader, Judith A. Jacobs, said, "The concern is that it may be represented as an initiative on the part of the entire Democratic caucus, and that's not what occurred."
