HEADLINE: Argentina Paying Heavily For Squandering Blessings 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
Everywhere they gather in these days of crisis and collapse, Argentines are asking themselves the same question: how could it have come to this? How has this country, whose name derives from a Latin word meaning money and whose elegant capital faces an estuary called the River of Silver, managed to go bankrupt?
 "Our case has got to be unique in modern world history," said Daniel Bellini, a high-school chemistry teacher, as he sat with friends at an outdoor cafe on the Avenida Nueve de Julio, a stately boulevard that recalls the country's former glories. "To start off with such abundance and end up this poor, that, my friend, takes a very special talent." 
 Not so long ago Argentina really did seem "doomed to success," to use a favorite rallying cry of Eduardo Duhalde, the country's fifth president since December. Early in the 20th century this was the seventh richest country in the world, with a per capita income ahead of those of Canada, France, the Netherlands, Italy, Japan and Spain and not far behind that of the United States. 
Today, the average Argentine income is less than a quarter of America's, and 40 percent of the country's 37 million people live below the poverty line. Unemployment is at a record 22 percent, and the situation is getting worse: the government acknowledges the economy will shrink by 5 percent this year, but most independent forecasters talk of a decline of 8 percent or more.
How and when Argentina will recover from this economic collapse, which has been accompanied by a loss of confidence in the political and social institutions, is unclear. Mr. Duhalde admits that the local banking system cannot pay depositors and the country has become a pariah on international credit markets since defaulting on $141 billion in public debt in December.
Argentina's long slide into insolvency both baffles and enrages its populace because this country is blessed with some of the most fertile soil in the world, under which ample supplies of oil also lie. In the prosperous past -- and still today -- herds of cattle roamed the endless pastures known as the pampas. Wheat, corn and, more recently, soybeans grew almost effortlessly, leading to a typically cocky saying that "a good harvest can fix everything."
In the midst of such plenty, it was easy for Argentines to believe that they were destined for greatness. The attitude that came to predominate, Argentines now acknowledge, was predatory and self-indulgent, based on the certainty that the country's riches were inexhaustible.
"Argentines were bitten by the disturbing bug of self-complacency," said Mariano Grondona a columnist for the daily La Nacion, who has written of two books about the cultural prerequisites of development. "In love with themselves, they became narcissistic."
Over the years, Argentina has veered from a closed state-run economy to a deregulated, free-market model, the only constants being the venality of those in power and their reckless squandering of the nation's wealth. The country's greatest modern writer, Jorge Luis Borges, once said of the Peronists, the dominant political party here for more than 50 years, "They are neither good nor bad, just incorrigible."
The pampas influenced the country's development in another way, instilling a sense of isolation and a suspicion of authority perhaps even more extreme than in the American West. The epic work of Argentine literature taught in every school, Jose Hernandez's "Martin Fierro," glorifies those values through its solitary hero, a gaucho cowboy unjustly sent to fight on the Indian frontier.
Distrust of the state, however, gradually developed into disrespect for the rule of law, from rampant tax evasion to the military's murder of political opponents. The verdict of G. Bevione, an Italian writer who visited this country in 1910 seems prescient: Argentina is "a country where the judicial branch has no independence and the executive branch knows no restraint." 
One result can be seen in the current spectacle of a politicized Supreme Court, beholden to a former president and feeling threatened by a new one, trying to torpedo the current administration's economic strategy. On Friday, the justices, ignoring Mr. Duhalde's warning that the banks were without funds, ruled that a two-month-old freeze on withdrawals from accounts was unconstitutional and must be lifted. 
But instead of bowing to the decision, Mr. Duhalde threw his support behind an effort to impeach all nine members of the court and replace them with justices more to his liking. He also refused to abide by the ruling and decreed that no one might challenge his defiance in the courts, a step that constitutional experts here agree is itself of dubious legality.
Even more than the United States, modern Argentina is a nation of immigrants: at the peak of the influx, nearly one-third of the population was foreign-born, more than double the highest rate in the United States. But instead of forging a sense of nationhood that could substitute for the absence of other values, Argentines came to see their country as a "piece of Europe that broke off and landed in South America," in the words of a diplomat here.
Rather than integrate with the rest of Latin America, Argentina held itself apart from and above its neighbors, an attitude encouraged by its isolation at the southern end of the continent. Other Latin Americans responded in kind, with sayings like: "An Argentine is an Italian who speaks Spanish, wishes he were English, acts like he is French and suffers under a German army."
But beginning with a military coup in 1930, that self-image failed one test after another. For the next 50 years, the country remained imprisoned in a disastrous cycle in which authoritarian military rule gave way to civilian governments so inept that they provoked new army uprisings, culminating in the brutal dictatorship in which more than 20,000 people disappeared between 1976 and 1983.
Though the armed forces remain so discredited that they are no longer seen as a threat, 20 years of democracy have only left Argentines discouraged and humbled. Years of four-digit inflation were followed by a burst of dollar-fueled growth and frenzied consumption, but that quickly evaporated into a four-year recession, one that has yet to hit bottom.
Reluctant to accept that reality, "we Argentines continue to be fascinated by the rich country Argentina once was" instead of the poor country it has become, Mr. Grondona said. Though the evidence of ruin is everywhere, "we continue to deny it in the name of a fantasy."
Over the last decade, Argentina has opened to its Latin American neighbors and the rest of the world, finally realizing that it could no longer afford standoffishness. But the old problem of a rapacious ruling class has been compounded by the arrival of foreign companies willing, it appears in retrospect, to do anything to get a slice of the pie, including payment of bribes in return for sweetheart contracts.
"The looting of the country comes from both within and outside," said Marcos Aguinis, author of "The Intolerable Charm of Being Argentine," a recent best seller. "Foreign investment here didn't take risks either. What came was volatile short-term capital looking for a quick return and an easy exit, content to earn a 20 percent rate of return and send the money home instead of reinvesting."
No one can say that Argentines, the most highly literate population in Latin America, are not reflective about themselves or their national malaise. Buenos Aires is said to have the heaviest per capita concentration of psychoanalysts of any city in the world, and even with the country in ruins, fliers continue to be posted on walls here inviting the depressed to group therapy sessions that teach how to "live with joy and little money."
Borges was no friend of psychoanalysis, and as he saw it, the typically Argentine bemoaning of "our solitude, our perdition and our primitive character has, like existentialism, the charms of poignancy." But even that emphasis on melancholy self-examination has now come to be seen as a symptom of the country's ills and skewed priorities.
"Instead of investing in technology and science, the effort was put into training psychiatrists and lawyers because that was easier and didn't require as much expense." said Mr. Aguinis, a former minister of culture. "We had the same level of human talent as Brazil, if not better. But they were the ones who ended up industrializing, not us, because they were willing to spend money on equipment and laboratories to train engineers and chemists."
What the current crisis requires, most Argentines say, is action, and not more "cafe chatter." But the country remains divided and disorderly, perhaps as much so as in 1925, when Argentina was nearing the end of its golden age and Albert Einstein, visiting here and puzzled by what he saw, asked, "How can so disorganized a country progress?"

HEADLINE: Primedia Quarterly Loss Widens 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Primedia Inc., the publisher of magazines like New York and Seventeen, said its fourth-quarter loss widened to $608.3 million on expenses for writing down the value of acquisitions and reduced advertising spending. 
 The loss expanded to $2.60 a share from $257.3 million, or $1.62 a share, in the period a year earlier, Primedia said. 
Sales fell 1.7 percent, to $451.4 million. 
 Primedia is selling $250 million in assets, like Modern Bride magazine, to pare its roughly $2 billion in debt. The company also has cut jobs and reduced other spending as it copes with a slowdown in advertising spending caused by the recession. 
"The magazine ad market is extraordinarily challenged," said Peter Appert, an analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown who rates Primedia "buy" and doesn't own the stock. In addition, the company has "a ton of debt," he said. 
The loss included $470.9 million in pretax expenses for a decline in the value of acquisitions, mostly for the $426 million purchase of Internet guide company About.com in March. 
Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization expenses was $62.6 million, in line with analysts' estimates, said Jim Magrone, senior vice president for investor relations. By that measure, the company expects to earn $245 million to $260 million in 2002 and $28 million to 30 million in the first quarter, Magrone said. 
Primedia, based in New York, publishes about 290 magazines. Shares of Primedia fell 21 cents, or 7 percent, to $2.97 a share.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS; 
Tribes to Get Their '15 Minutes'

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 7 

 BODY:
Clifford Duncan sat in a breakfast nook in a downtown hotel, poking at a bowl of oatmeal, nibbling on sourdough toast and recalling his great-grandfather.
 "He was born in Heber Valley, before the reservations," said Duncan, 68, a tribal elder of the Northern Ute nation. "Unkadavanikent, or Red Morning, was his name. During federal allotments, he was given a number and then his English name, John Duncan. That made it easier for the government to tell us apart." 
 Duncan sat across from his son, Baldwin, a member of the Red Spirit Singers, who will pound the buckskin hide of their drums Friday night and chant the ceremonial words of their ancestors, pushing the opening ceremony of these Winter Games with a throaty, emotional crescendo.
But after their performance, they will give up their hotel rooms for International Olympic Committee members, their passes will be invalidated, and they will return home, a three-hour drive northeast, to the Uintah-Ouray Reservation, in the farthest corner of the state. That is where they were ordered to live by executive order of Abraham Lincoln in 1861.
"I guess this is our 15 minutes," said Daniel Cesspooch, 23, one of the singers, as he slung his black braids over his shoulder. "Then it's back to the reservations."
On some levels, the coming together of Utah's five tribal American Indian nations -- Ute, Navajo, Paiute, Goshute and Shoshone -- and the Salt Lake Organizing Committee is a modern case study in ethnic harmony, clear acknowledgment that a people had settled Utah before the Mormons. On another, their presence at the Games reopens deep wounds of a violent past, echoing through the Great Basin, back through time, to a frontier none of them care to remember or forget.
American Indians make up nearly 30,000 of the state's 2.3 million population. They are to Utah what the Aboriginals were to Australia at the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney: original inhabitants of a continent, summoned to the international stage to protect the integrity of the event and perhaps to reduce the guilt of the white man.
Either way, the Ute tribe, for whom the state is named (not to mention that it inspired the University of Utah mascot), is not criticizing the exposure. It will have its moment before millions on NBC, and if that spurs talk about what happened -- who did what to whom and why -- then all is well and good.
"Indeed, it's a great honor to be here, to be recognized as a group of people," Duncan said. "But it's a small token in a way. It's a world event. It's really not an event being considered American. The truth is, we all know many treaties have been broken. You can't hide the racial attitudes of non-Indians toward us. All we can do is move on and hope our life ways are one day respected."
Utah's American Indians are not asking for reparations for their people as much as an honest dialogue with the Mormon Church, which they believe has yet to fully accept its role in their demise as a people.
Church leaders are careful not to admit culpability in atrocities that may have been committed by their ancestors -- the battles and massacres are annually debated by local historians on both sides -- and insist that the mistreatment received by the Utes and other tribes was no worse than that inflicted by other white settlers making the American West their own in the 1800's.
But as the layers of resentment and mistrust are peeled back, the more strained the relationship grows over time.
Like the Aboriginals, Utah's Indians also lay claim to a stolen generation -- 20,000 to 25,000 Indian children were put into the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints Indian Placement Program in the mid-1900's. The Utes and other tribes saw the program as a tool to recruit and baptize for the church. The cultural loss, they believe, did not outweigh any potential educational gain.
"The thing that was most painful was the children who lost connection with their culture," Forrest Cuch, the executive director of Utah's Division of Indian Affairs, said. "And although their physical needs were met, their cultural needs were not. A lot of them failed later in life."
In 1978, Congress passed the Indian Child Welfare Act, which gave tribal courts sole jurisdiction over placement of Indian children whose home is a reservation. 
Boyd K. Packer, the acting president of the second-highest governing body of the Mormon Church, is a 76-year-old former educator with a slight drawl and a brilliant arrowhead collection on the wall of his South Temple Avenue office in the church headquarters here.
His grandparents served as missionaries to the Sioux in Montana, and he was responsible for educating 2,000 of the Navajo tribe in a church-run school in the 1950's. "I used to chase Indians all over the country," he said, referring to his close ties with Utah's American Indians.
His take on the placement program: "In those days, if this hadn't happened, they wouldn't have had schooling," Packer said. "We sent them back home for summers. The families saw them on to college and into missions."
The church says the program was intended to strengthen opportunities for Indian children, not to recruit them. It maintains it was voluntary. 
Those are just the recent problems. The Mountain Meadows Massacre, involving the slaughter of 120 white settlers on Sept. 11, 1857, still carries pain. The church refuses to accept culpability for its involvement, even though the rededication of the burial site in 1999 led to forensic evidence concluding that victims were shot to death, not bludgeoned by Indians. The Mormons had long blamed the massacre on Southern Paiutes.
"We will forgive, but don't deny," Cuch said. "We won't forgive if you deny. We get the message: There is something wrong with us and our children suffer. Some of that is yours. Let's be fair here. If we are true human beings, then you've got weaknesses as well as I."
The church has preferred to rely on other documentation that it says exonerates Brigham Young, its revered leader then, from any involvement. "I think it's an extension of what Brigham Young said when he came west, 'It is better to feed them than to fight them,' " Packer said. 
Fourteen years was all it took to displace the Utes and the other tribes from their ancestral homeland. In 1847 the first Mormons arrived. By 1861, after several armed conflicts with the Mormon settlers and at the request of the Mormons through the Treaty of Spanish Fork, the Utes were forced to leave Provo Valley and move to the Uintah Basin, where they operate their own tribal government and supervise about 1.3 million acres of trust land. 
On the Uintah-Ouray Reservation alone unemployment is 65 to 70 percent. Average household income ranges from $15,000 to $20,000, far below the national average. "And that's some of the better situations," Cuch said. "The Goshute poverty is atrocious, families taking in maybe six or seven thousand a year."
Beyond the opening ceremony, the American Indians have performed at the torch relay and at the welcoming ceremony in the athletes' village. An exhibit of the five tribal nations at the Utah Museum of Natural History is popular. Cuch and Larry Blackhair, founder of the Native American 2002 Foundation, have worked to make the American Indian presence at the Games more prominant.
Antonio (A. J.) Kanip, 27, an inventory clerk at a tribal gas station who makes $6.50 an hour, was asked what he thought about performing in a stadium that uses his tribe as a mascot. "If it's something you can change, it bothers you," Kanip said. "If it's something you can't, why bother? But I wonder if it would bother these people if we had a basketball team back home called the Roosevelt Mormons. Or the Washington Blackskins. Would people take notice then?"
Clifford Duncan was one of five American Indians who retrieved the Olympic flame from Athens in January, the first to carry the torch home.
He is uncertain if Indian participation in the Games is a step toward the healing process, or merely a savvy marketing move. Politically correct or morally right, Duncan does not seem too concerned. Red Morning's great-grandson is just happy not to be thought extinct.
"They know about us, but they think we're in a museum," Clifford Duncan said. "They have to put away the concept that Indians are gone, only to be found in a museum or a book. The man you see riding the horse in the museum is not dead. I'm actually alive."

HEADLINE: Kelly Plans to Hire Outside Consultant to Speed Police Recruiting 

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER 

 BODY:
Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that he was planning to hire a full-time outside consultant to recruit potential police officers, in part because of the difficulty the Police Department has had in attracting interest in the job.
 The step is the latest taken by the department to recruit candidates, a need that has become more acute because of a surge in retirements. 
 It had been thought that the glowing praise police officers got for their work on Sept. 11, combined with the weakness of the local economy, would make a job in law enforcement more attractive. But interest has not materialized and so, Mr. Kelly said, the department must do a better job of "getting the story" out to potential candidates. 
"There is this kind of sense that, post 9/11, more people are interested in coming into public service," Mr. Kelly said at a briefing yesterday at 1 Police Plaza. "We have to do an effective job of harnessing that, to get people who want to come into the Police Department."
Mr. Kelly said he was disappointed that only about 6,000 candidates had showed up to take an examination on Saturday, one of several police tests being offered this month. He conceded that the starting annual salary for police officers, $31,305, was an impediment to some people who might consider taking the exam.
Police union officials have long said that low pay is the prime reason for the recent exodus of officers.
"Solving this issue is not a difficult or complex one; it comes down to salaries," said Patrick J. Lynch, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. He added that of the 3,776 officers who left the department last year, 807 had less than 20 years on the job.
Mr. Kelly said he would like to see officers' pay "more gradually increase" over their first five years of employment. Robert W. Linn, the union's chief negotiator, said that currently, the average officer's pay does not rise significantly until after five years, when it reaches $52,268, including $3,245 in longevity pay.
In the last two years, the Police Department has spent more than $10 million on recruiting campaigns with only limited success. Mr. Kelly said that volunteers in the business community had helped with advertisements. He did not say how much the new consultant, who has not yet been chosen, would be paid. The department must continue to reach out to military bases and other states for potential candidates, he said.

HEADLINE: Baltimore Currency Trader Is in a State of Legal Limbo 

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER and JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
At the end of a winding gravel driveway shaded by mature pines, John Rusnak has been living the kind of respectable life that his work might imply.
 An American flag hangs above the double-door entrance to his Victorian home. A swing set, jungle gym and sandbox are nestled in the landscaped backyard. Two small scooters, decorated with miniature Maryland license plates that spell out his children's names, often sit outside, leaning on their sides. 
 "He just seemed like the All-American dad, and I never had any reason to believe anything else," said Michael O'Connell, his neighbor.
But today Mr. Rusnak, a currency trader for Allfirst Financial in Baltimore, is under investigation for circumventing the company's safety controls, running up losses of $750 million and concealing them with fictitious transactions.
One of Mr. Rusnak's lawyers, David B. Irwin, said yesterday that he believed that the bank would be shown to have had inadequate control systems for its traders. "I suspect we will find that the regulation and audit standards were not up to current large corporate standards," he said.
For now, Mr. Rusnak is in a state of legal suspension, his two lawyers said. No legal charges have been filed and Mr. Rusnak is still an employee of the bank, although he has been suspended. In the meantime, the United States attorney for Maryland, Allfirst and Mr. Rusnak's lawyers are conducting investigations to determine exactly what happened and who is responsible.
"Right now we're really not negotiating," said Bruce S. Lamdin, the other lawyer representing Mr. Rusnak. "We're on hold. Once investigations are done, we'll see where they lead us."
Mr. Rusnak is cooperating with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States attorney, his lawyers said. And, they added, he never vanished, as the bank implied. He remains in the Baltimore area. "We've certainly proved that he's not a fugitive," Mr. Irwin said. "We'll prove that he wasn't a thief, either."
At his work, Mr. Rusnak had a trading limit of $2.5 million. This means that at any point he was not allowed to be involved in trades whose aggregate dollar value topped $2.5 million.
One currency analyst said yesterday that this was a reasonable limit for a trader at a regional bank. But he added that "there was no way" that Mr. Rusnak could have had losses of $750 million over the last year without exceeding that limit.
Frank P. Bramble, the chairman of Allfirst, said in an interview Wednesday that Mr. Rusnak had "created fraudulent options -- cleverly, unfortunately, in a way that he managed to hide them from all the reporting systems."
Our internal controls were compromised," he added.
Mr. Rusnak's lawyers said they were still investigating what happened and would make no comment on their client's role. 
Another thing that is still unclear is which currencies Mr. Rusnak was trading. Currency traders said they had noticed a lot of yen trading by Allfirst, and they now suspected that Mr. Rusnak was betting that the yen would rise in value against the dollar. The yen has fallen about 20 percent in the last year, and that could help explain his losses. But Allfirst said that Mr. Rusnak was trading in more than one currency.
Shares of Allied Irish Banks, the parent of Allfirst, rose 6 percent yesterday, after falling 16 percent Wednesday. Jim Power, chief economist with Friends First Asset Management, an Irish money manager with $3 billion in assets, said Allied Irish might now be "a prime candidate" for a takeover.
The board of Allied Irish met in Dublin yesterday to question executives about the bogus trades and currency losses. The board said it had "expressed its extreme disquiet that controls and supervision of the treasury operations in Allfirst had failed to uncover, at a far earlier stage, the fraudulent activities." 
If there were any signs that Mr. Rusnak would find himself besieged by allegations of deception and fraud, few were evident to those around him. John and Linda Rusnak always made sure to stay active in the Shrine of the Sacred Heart, the Catholic church where they went to Mass and sent their two young children to parochial school. Mr. Rusnak's financial expertise drew him to serve on the board of a local arts organization.
Allfirst considered Mr. Rusnak an employee in good standing for all of his nine years there -- that is, until his trading habits drew the suspicion of a boss last week.
Raised in Bristol, Pa., a working-class suburb of Philadelphia, Mr. Rusnak grew up far from the rarefied circles of currency trading and banking. His father, Emil, worked for U.S. Steel. His mother works for the state, Mr. Rusnak's lawyers said, keeping track of death certificates.
Mr. Rusnak studied economics at Bucknell University, where he graduated in 1986. From there, he started a gradual ascent in the world of finance. First came a low-level job at First Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia. By 1989, he had stepped up to the foreign exchange division at Chemical Bank in New York, satisfying his longstanding desire to test his mettle in the financial big leagues.
He did not stay very long. In 1993, Mr. Rusnak took a job as a currency trader at what was then the First National Bank of Maryland and is now called Allfirst. After nearly a decade, his salary stands at about $85,000, the company said.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 9, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about John Rusnak, a currency trader for Allfirst Financial in Baltimore who the company says lost $750 million and concealed the losses with fictitious trades, misspelled the surname of a neighbor who commented. He is Michael O'Connell, not O'Connel.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Ad sales for the home-court Olympic Games happily surprise NBC.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
REMEMBER the millionaire who surprised Auntie Mame by leaving a cab with the meter running in the middle of the Depression? Well, in one of the worst advertising markets since then, the three NBC networks carrying the Winter Olympic Games have run up a surprisingly robust $720 million on the sales meter for commercial time during the 375.5 hours of coverage from Salt Lake City starting tonight.
 "We're happily at our goal" with commercial time on CNBC, MSNBC and NBC "virtually sold out" through the closing ceremonies on Feb. 24, said Randy Falco, president of the NBC Television Network division of NBC in New York, part of the General Electric Company. 
 "We went through some incredible frustrations and turns -- first the economy, then the terrible Sept. 11 disaster," he added. "So to reach this is one of the more extraordinary things I've seen." 
For all that, "Happy Days Are Here Again" is unlikely to become the official song of the Games. Had the economy been less depressed, commercial time would probably have been sold faster and at higher prices than the estimated average rate of $600,000 for each 30-second spot in prime time. Also, in adspeak, "virtually" sold out, which translates into about 98 percent of all available commercial time, means that a marketer still eager to spend money can be accommodated, just as Fox Broadcasting did for several last-minute advertisers during Super Bowl XXXVI on Sunday.
Indeed, the proximity of the Super Bowl to the start of the Winter Games had initially been considered a drawback to commercial sales for both, along with the national economic woes and the uncertain mood after Sept. 11. One negative, though, seems to be becoming a positive for the Olympics: the patriotism generated by the terrorist attacks is intensifying the typical nationalistic fervor felt whenever the Games are held in the United States.
"Americans always pull for the home team," said Dale Hayes, vice president for brand management and customer communications at United Parcel Service in Atlanta, which is introducing a campaign carrying the theme "What can brown do for you?"
"The circumstances may heighten that national interest and pride, which could lead to higher viewership than was planned," Mr. Hayes said. "And that could be wonderful from an advertising perspective." The campaign is the first for United Parcel by the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
"Given everything going on around us, the Winter Games on American soil -- the home-court advantage, so to speak -- may be wonderful from an advertising and marketing perspective," said Marc Goldstein, president for national broadcast and programming at Mindshare in New York, the media services agency owned by the WPP Group.
That anticipation, he added, is in stark contrast to the disappointment suffered by advertisers when the NBC coverage of the Summer Games in 2000 drew record low ratings in prime time. That shortfall led NBC to concentrate large parts of its ambitious promotional campaign for the Winter Games on drawing viewers ages 18 to 34 -- famously desired by advertisers, but notoriously hard to reach -- with fast-paced, irreverent commercials celebrating young American Olympic athletes.
"The real lesson of Sydney was don't take the Olympics for granted," said John Miller, who with Vince Manze is co-president of the NBC Agency, which creates campaigns for all three networks. "There's a difference between people over 35 and younger, and you have to target all demographics to succeed."
"The only stone we've left unturned is getting Jeff Gillooly to come and hit someone on the knee," he added, laughing, referring to the former husband of Tonya Harding jailed for the Nancy Kerrigan clubbing incident, which helped lure enormous audiences to watch the 1994 Winter Games.
Among other blue-chip advertisers joining United Parcel during the 17 days of coverage: AT&T, promoting a new flat-rate domestic long-distance calling plan; Bank of America; Campbell Soup; Coca-Cola, with commercials for Coca-Cola Classic, Dasani and Diet Coke from several agencies; Delta Air Lines; Eastman Kodak; Electronic Data SystemsHallmark Cards; Home Depot; McDonald's; Nike; Office Depot; Sprint PCS; and Xerox.
"Economies go up and economies go down and you never know which way they go, so we don't cut back advertising because of the economy," said Bruce Nelson, chairman and chief executive at Office Depot in Delray Beach, Fla., which will run additional commercials from its current humorous campaign, which carries the theme "What you need. What you need to know."
As for the light-hearted nature of the spots, "There still has to be a way for people to have a little fun in the otherwise serious world in which we live," Mr. Nelson said. "We're trying to be careful and do it with taste and judgment." The commercials are by the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group.
Several humorous, emotional commercials for Coke Classic, developed before Sept. 11, will "talk about the human connection and the refreshment of the human spirit, which are especially important right now," said Steve Hutcherson, brand business unit manager at Coca-Cola North America in Atlanta.
Though Coke Classic has American roots, he added, "that did not lead us down the path to overt patriotism or flag-waving" because the brand is sold globally and the Games are intended "for all people."
Coca-Cola did not run commercials during the Super Bowl, but many advertisers that did will be back for the Olympics, that other midwinter festival of sports and commerce. Among them are: AT&T Wireless, continuing the talked-about "Welcome to mlife" campaign by the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of WPP; Anheuser-Busch; General Motors, for 2002 and 2003 models sold by divisions like Cadillac, Chevrolet and Saturn; the Monster.com unit of TMP Worldwide; Charles Schwab & Company; Visa; and Volkswagen.
Having both "big events" at practically the same time appealed to Anheuser-Busch, said Tony Ponturo, vice president for global media and sports marketing in St. Louis, because the one-two punch "gets our year kicked off in a great way."
"For the Super Bowl and Olympics, we've been the exclusive beer sponsor for some time," he added. "They're two major properties our competition doesn't have, and that helps differentiate us." Anheuser-Busch will be selling beers like Budweiser and Bud Light as well as a new malt beverage, Bacardi Silver, being produced with Bacardi.
Whether Anheuser-Busch will run during the Games the contentious Super Bowl spot that showed the Budweiser Clydesdales bowing in a salute to New York City could not be determined. A company spokesman, Bill Etling, said he could not make other executives available because they were unhappy with some critical comments this columnist made about that commercial and others the company ran in the Super Bowl.
It will be fascinating to watch whether Anheuser-Busch and the other Olympic advertisers will try to capitalize on terror and war with patriotic peddling, jingoistic jingles or worst yet, exploitive commercials that will be perceived as patridiotic.

HEADLINE: Advisory Panel Tells Congress That Amtrak Should Be Split 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 

 BODY:
A panel created by Congress in 1997 to advise on the future of Amtrak said today that the railroad should be broken up and that the job of running trains should be opened to competition.
 But most of its members quickly added that their report was unlikely to be more than a starting point for a national debate, involving federal, state and local governments, on what to do about passenger rail. 
 "The stars are lining up" for such a debate, said Gilbert E. Carmichael, the chairman of the commission. He pointed out that Amtrak was due for reauthorization by Congress this year and that its finances had recently taken a turn for the worse. George Warrington, the president of Amtrak, said on Feb. 1 that it would cancel dozens of long-distance trains if it did not receive $2.1 billion in operating and capital money, despite a 1997 law that it meet its operating costs from internal revenues by December 2002. 
The inspector general of the Transportation Department said last week that the railroad was no closer to self-sufficiency now than it was in 1997.
While members of the advisory group, the Amtrak Reform Council, derided the railroad for its losses, most agreed that to maintain an intercity rail system, huge public subsidies would be needed for the next 20 years. But Amtrak has not spent its money well, and new money should go into a better-run enterprise, they said. 
"All we're doing with these subsidies is subsidizing excessive costs," said Wendell Cox, a consultant who was appointed to the council by Newt Gingrich when Mr. Gingrich was House speaker.
Another member, S. Lee Kling, a finance and banking expert appointed by Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader of the House, said: "Funding should not be provided without the rail system operating like a business, having the controls, the accountability, the planning and the marketing. It has to operate like a business or it shouldn't be funded." 
Amtrak said in a statement that the council's report "sidesteps the underlying policy and funding issues that must be determined."
"First, a federal commitment to define, develop and invest in the passenger rail system must be made," the statement said.
The 11-member council called for "relieving" Amtrak of the burden of owning and maintaining the Northeast Corridor, the Boston-to-Washington route that is one of the few stretches of track that it owns, so that it could concentrate on running trains. Mr. Carmichael said that would make Amtrak more like an airline, which did not have to build the airports it used. But critics said the report did not make clear how a new public entity created to handle infrastructure would pay for improvements. 
The council sought to break up Amtrak's monopoly on running passenger trains, suggesting that other potential operators be brought in to bid on providing service. A slimmed-down central authority would pick contractors and maintain a unified reservations system.
The report was approved with nine votes; Norman Y. Mineta, the Secretary of Transportation, who is a member of the commission, abstained, and a labor representative, Charles Moneypenny, issued a sharp dissent.
Two Congressional hearings have been scheduled on Amtrak's problems. The president's budget, released Monday, lists $521 million for Amtrak, the amount it received in operating aid in the current fiscal year, but the deputy transportation secretary described the number as "a place-holder," until a policy could be set. Amtrak wants $2.1 billion.
Members of the council said that Amtrak's threat, to simply shut down long-distance trains, did not seem to be a likely outcome. 
"We are aware of the groundswell of public support for better trains in this country," said James E. Coston, a Chicago lawyer who managed a program of chartering weekend excursion trains from Amtrak. He was appointed to the council by Senator Tom Daschle, now the majority leader. But members of Congress are not sure how Amtrak should be financed now that the budget has returned to deficits, Mr. Coston said.
The National Association of Rail Passengers, a nonprofit group based here, said that particularly since Sept. 11, trains had proved their utility. While Amtrak said it was suffering the same recession-related declines as other travel-related industries, it showed small gains in the number of miles it carried fare-paying passengers in September, November and December, and a small drop in October, compared with steep declines for the airlines.
The rail passengers' group said that cutting long-distance trains and maintaining only the profitable short-haul trains was not a good strategy because some of the money-losing trains delivered passengers to the ones that make a profit. Concentrating all of Amtrak's overhead on a few profitable routes might make them unprofitable, the group said.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 10, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about a commission's recommendation that Amtrak be broken up misstated the amount of the subsidy that the railroad intends to request from Congress this year. It is $1.2 billion, not $2.1 billion.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
Fed Up and Going After the Terrorist Himself

BYLINE:  By ELVIS MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Arnold Schwarzenegger as a man of feeling? His eyes puffy with tears? That's just one of the unforgettable, yet strangely irrelevant images from "Collateral Damage," in which Mr. Schwarzenegger plays Gordy, a Los Angeles firefighter who finds out exactly how ineffectual the United States government is when his wife and young son are killed by a Colombian terrorist, Claudio (Cliff Curtis).
 When it's obvious that Gordy is a pawn being used by a bloodthirsty C.I.A. agent, Brandt (Elias Koteas), to further his goals in battling Colombian terrorists, Gordy takes things into his own hands. And instead of wrapping his guttural mutterings around wisecracks, the hero of "Damage" begins an odyssey that takes him to the jungles of Panama, through which he treks in order to slip into Colombia to avenge his family. 
 "Damage" was withdrawn from an intended fall 2001 release after the events of Sept. 11, though it feels like a film that's been kept on the shelf since 1989. The movie sat around for so long that it has managed to become newsworthy again: a public service commercial ran during the Super Bowl equated cocaine use with financing terrorism, an idea that may give "Damage" a new lease on life. And "Collateral Damage" -- the title derives from the observation that Gordy's wife and son were collateral damage in the battle between Colombian terrorists and the United States -- could use a new lease.
Except for the brief passings of emotion on Gordy's face, this is an exhausted rehash of Mr. Schwarzenegger breaking through red tape to struggle against his nemesis of the moment. The trumpeting of past triumphs by the director also surfaces. The ads remind us that the movie is directed by Andrew Davis, the man behind "The Fugitive." Mr. Davis also directed "Chain Reaction," another limp, somnolent action picture with a generic martial title. And like "Reaction," "Damage" shows real confidence only during the action sequences, like the one involving a fire that Gordy and his men fight during the opening credits; the flames roar and hiss like Godzilla. 
After these sequences, Mr. Davis can't find a way to get back to the war of conscience that he juxtaposes with the conflagrations. As a result, the attempts to bring characterization to the movie -- like awkward exchanges on political stances when Gordy and Claudio meet -- are so awkward that you expect the actors to break up.
"Seems like we're both willing to kill for a cause, so what's the difference between you and I?" Claudio sneers smugly, after having been accused of murdering innocent women and children on his path to his political ends. (The speechifying will have a leaden effect on audiences.) "The difference," Gordy says, shifting his granite facial planes toward the camera -- bringing to mind an SUV twirling on a pedestal in a commercial -- "is I'm only gonna kill you."
There are moments when "Damage" wants to stretch its tired action-man skin in a new direction. Gordy is trapped as much between his own anger and guilt as he is in a struggle between the two warring sides. The C.I.A. wants to use him as bait while the terrorists want to take him hostage.
He befriends a Colombian woman (Francesca Neri, who, like most Colombians in "Damage," speaks good English). When these elements are playing out, the picture shows glimpses of aspiring to a Graham Greene story. But as the bodies pile up and Gordy's jaw becomes more deeply set, the plot is more like a Graham Cracker story -- crumbly and insubstantial. 
And Claudio, despite his intellectual poses, is still capable of the kinds of baroque violence redolent of Arnold Schwarzenegger movies. When a subordinate of Claudio's lets him down -- apparently, even with the sorry state of the world economy, good criminal help is still hard to find -- Claudio has the man's mouth forced open so that a snake can crawl into his body.
Amazingly, given its brief 110-minute length, "Collateral Damage" still manages to squeeze in several different endings -- like a bad pop song that doesn't know when to fade out. But as Mr. Schwarzenegger's stature as an action figure diminishes, his effort to retain a piece of the market is touching.
"Collateral Damage" has one thing going for it -- it's one of the few movies in which an American (John Turturro) plays a Canadian, instead of the other way around. He is Armstrong, a lower-tier reprobate who is a kindred piece of casting to the bouncing, bow-legged cocaine factory owner portrayed for a couple of scenes by John Leguizamo. The only times that Mr. Schwarzenegger seems comfortable is with these calculated scene-stealers. At least with them, "Collateral Damage" doesn't seem hypocritical, attacking the same violence that infuses it.
"Collateral Damage" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for its strong language and wall-to-wall violence, including a fight in which Gordy goes Mike Tyson and bites the ear off one of his attackers.

COLLATERAL DAMAGE

Directed by Andrew Davis; written by David Griffiths and Peter Griffiths, based on a story by Ronald Roose and David and Peter Griffiths; director of photography, Adam Greenberg; edited by Dennis Virkler and Dov Hoenig; music by Graeme Revell; production designer, Philip Rosenberg; produced by Steven Reuther and David Foster; released by Warner Brothers. Running time: 110 minutes. This film is rated R.

HEADLINE: Can Congress Discipline Itself? 

BYLINE:  By Leon E. Panetta; Leon E. Panetta, chairman of the House Budget Committee from 1989 to 1993 and director of the Office of Management and Budget from 1993 to 1994, is director of the Panetta Institute for Public Policy at California State University at Monterey Bay.

DATELINE: MONTEREY, Calif. 

 BODY:
In the early 1980's, President Ronald Reagan tried to cut taxes, increase defense spending and balance the budget. The result was a 10-year period of deficits that quadrupled the national debt. Twenty years later, President Bush is in danger of making the same mistake.
 The president has proposed a $2.13 trillion federal budget that makes the large tax cuts enacted last year permanent, increases defense spending by $48 billion and returns the budget to deficit. For the fiscal year starting Oct. 1, the shortfall will total $80 billion, and the budget is not projected to show a surplus again until 2005. 
 Administration officials have a simple explanation for this return to deficit spending. "This is a budget to win a two-front war," said Mitchell Daniels, the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget. But the nation now confronts a war on three fronts -- the threats at home and abroad from terrorism and the new threat from future fiscal instability.
Few question the need for additional spending for the war against terrorism. Spending for homeland security nearly doubles, to $38 billion, while the Pentagon's budget increases by 14 percent, to $379 billion. Yet the bitter reality is that once the federal government resorts to a borrow-and-spend policy, it is difficult to avoid the slippery slope back to ever more long-term debt.
Contrary to the president's promise in the 2000 campaign, the budget uses all of the Social Security surpluses to fund various government programs through 2013. A year ago, the administration projected it could slash the amount of federal debt outstanding to $1.6 trillion by 2007. Instead, the debt will rise to $3.4 trillion by 2007.
The lessons of the past 20 years of fighting deficits are clear. Presidents typically finance their own priorities at the expense of Congressionally favored programs. Once Congress gets done with the budget submitted by the president -- usually adding money for its priorities -- the red ink is likely to run much deeper. With the deficit reappearing, most members of Congress will feel entitled to push for new spending for their favored programs.
President Bush proposes deep cuts in programs like highway spending, job training and technology research. Eight agencies take actual cuts or receive increases of 1 percent or less in discretionary spending. But it is difficult for him to argue for spending restraint while providing a virtual blank check on defense and homeland security.
Adding to the deficit problem are costs that are not included in the budget. It includes nothing for the reform of Social Security, for example, even though the 10-year cost for the administration's reform plan has been estimated at $1 trillion. The budget also fails to include the cost to raise the income limits on the individual alternative minimum tax, which will otherwise adversely affect more than 40 million taxpayers over the next decade. That fix alone could exceed $300 billion.
And the budget squeeze could get tighter if revenues fail to live up to expectations. The budget's economic assumptions are based on the passage of the economic stimulus plan this year, which failed in the Senate two days ago. The administration itself predicted that, without the stimulus package, growth for the remainder of this year would be reduced by half a percentage point.
Finally, the most important tools for budget discipline no longer exist. In the 1990 budget agreement, the president and Congress agreed to enforce mandatory caps on discretionary spending and required that any new tax cuts or spending initiatives be paid for so as not to add to the deficit. Both Democrats and Republicans were willing to enforce these rules.
Now that the law requiring these spending limits has expired, there are no mandatory caps on discretionary spending. Nor is there any requirement that all new programs be paid for. With a Congress unwilling to discipline itself, the result will be a larger deficit.
Of course, the veto pen of the president is another restraint on the budget process. But relying on a presidential veto often leads to fiscal and political crisis. When presidents of one party propose budgets unacceptable to the other party, and that party controls the House or Senate, the result is gridlock -- or, all too often, pork-barrel deals made to end it.
For the last four years, crisis has driven the budget process more than consensus has. These last-minute agreements between the president and Congress inevitably lead to increases in spending. Last year alone, Congress added more than $726 billion to the president's proposed budget.
Fortunately, those increases were cushioned by large surpluses. Now that those surpluses are gone, avoiding a runaway deficit will require leadership and will power from the president and Congress. Unless they're willing to enforce budget discipline, the nation is likely to embark upon another long era of deficit spending. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mayor's Deficit Estimate Grows to $4.5 Billion 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city's budget deficit next year would be $4.5 billion, which is much worse than city budget officials previously feared.
 This latest figure is $500 million greater than Mr. Bloomberg's earlier estimate, and $1.6 billion more than the Giuliani administration forecasts when its officials left office on Dec. 31. The revised figure comes as the Bloomberg administration is putting the finishing touches on its first budget proposal, which he plans to unveil on Wednesday. 
 "We will not solve that problem without pain," Mr. Bloomberg warned yesterday. "We are going to have to stop doing certain things. And that is going to be contentious, painful."
A budget forecast is a moving target, as the city tries to estimate what revenues it will take in and measure those against estimated costs. The forecasts are difficult to make even in more normal years. In a year in which the city's economy has been buffeted by the attack on the World Trade Center and the national recession, future costs and revenues are even less predictable.
Mr. Bloomberg's deficit prediction is at the high end, putting him at variance with some budget watchdogs, including several that are normally considered quite conservative in their estimates. Most outside budget monitors have generally put the deficit for the coming fiscal year, which begins on July 1, at $3 billion to $4 billion.
Administration officials declined to explain the higher figure. Jordan Barowitz, a spokesman for the mayor, would only say that an explanation would be provided when the budget proposal is released on Wednesday.
The Giuliani administration projected a $2.9 billion deficit when it left office, and predicted that the city would end the current fiscal year with a surplus of $375 million to $697 million. One of the actions the previous administration and City Council took to close the gap was to allow a surcharge on personal income tax to continue, adding $362 million in revenues next year.
But fiscal monitors have warned that the Giuliani administration's forecast contained a number of risky assumptions. They warned that it underestimated the costs of health insurance, judgments against the city and pension costs. The also noted that it included some doubtful sources of revenue, like $250 million from the proposed sale of the Off-Track Betting Corporation, which may not materialize this year, and more than $170 million in rent payments from the Port Authority for airports that might be in danger.
Mr. Bloomberg revealed no details of his plan yesterday. He emphasized that his proposal would only be the first step in a long process.
"It will start a discussion process where we try to get some help from the federal government, where we try to get some help from the state government and where we involve the community and they will have a chance to give input," he said. "And then in the end, I will put in a final budget, and it has to be approved by the City Council."

HEADLINE: Betraying the Unemployed 

 BODY:
President Bush and members of Congress all said they wanted a bill this winter to revive the economy. Yet the chances of passing such a bill died in the Senate on Wednesday, despite bipartisan support. Instead the Senate passed a narrower measure to extend jobless benefits for 13 weeks beyond the 26-week limit. Congress has approved these extensions almost reflexively in recent recessions, but incredibly, House Republicans now threaten to block the bill unless it includes tax cuts for corporations and wealthy individuals. Their obstructionism must not be allowed to defeat a measure needed by those hit hardest by the recession. 
 With Alan Greenspan and others suggesting that the economic slump is easing up, the pressure to enact an economic stimulus bill started dwindling in December. Mr. Bush repeatedly blamed Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, for holding it up. But the administration never made the reasonable concessions that would have cleared the way for the legislation. On Tuesday Mr. Daschle put forward his own stripped-down version of a stimulus measure that would have provided extended unemployment benefits, rebates to lower-income Americans, tax incentives for business investment and aid to states. The bill got 56 votes, including several Republicans', but not enough to break a Republican filibuster. Had Mr. Bush backed this bill, it would have made the difference. 
 When Mr. Daschle's stimulus bill failed, the Senate easily passed an even narrower measure extending unemployment benefits, which would cost $8 billion and help an estimated two million people who face the possibility of exhausting their benefits this year. According to analysts at the Center on Budget Policy and Priorities, a liberal research group, 180,000 of these unemployed are in New York State. It would be unconscionable for the House to hold such a worthy measure hostage to the hard-right tax-cutting agenda of some in the leadership. But that is what was being threatened yesterday.
President Bush has been traveling around the country telling Americans he feels their pain in the recession. If he cares about the unemployed not being cut off in the downturn, he will tell the House Speaker, Dennis Hastert, not to hijack this bill and tie its fate to unnecessary tax cuts. This is a time for setting aside recriminations and passing a bill that has broad support across the board.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Olympic Boon? More Likely A Boondoggle

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
ALREADY Donny Osmond has taught Katie Couric and Matt Lauer how to pronounce "Utahan," and the Mormon Tabernacle Choir has done the Wave on national television. During the next two weeks, as Salt Lake City's skyline dominates the global village, its proud residents will be quoted repeatedly using the phrase "world-class city."
 Should New Yorkers feel jealous when the Olympics open tonight? Do we want the world crowding in here for the Summer Games of 2012? 
 The city's bid for 2012 is enthusiastically backed by political leaders, particularly Daniel Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development. Before joining the Bloomberg administration, he was president of NYC 2012, the private group in charge of the city's bid. 
In releasing its 700-page bid, the group promised "17 days of Olympic glory" and "a lasting legacy for the people of New York." The report presented visions of new parks, a new Olympic stadium reached by an extended subway line, 135,000 new jobs and $11 billion in economic benefits. 
It was the work of confirmed optimists. The report, which was issued in May, featured a chapter on security beginning with this sentence: "New York City faces no known threat or risk from any activist minority or terrorist group, according to the New York City Police Department." 
Hmm. Maybe we need to think this over. Let's reconsider the arguments for holding the Games here:
Glory. The chief reason cities have traditionally played host to the Olympics, aside from politicians' desire for publicity and their campaign donors' desire for construction contracts, has been to show off. For many cities, it's their one chance for fame. But New York is already famous. We don't have to tell anyone we're world class.
Tourism advertising. No matter how well known our skyline is around the world, tourism officials say there's no such thing as too much publicity -- look at what Coca-Cola spends to keep up its brand. But while the exposure from a successful Olympics would probably produce long-term benefits for the tourist industry, there's no guarantee that the Games will go smoothly. A terrorist attack would be a distinct possibility -- and a distinct turnoff for tourists.
Even if terrorists don't strike, the extraordinary security precautions might scare off some potential tourists, and there could be lots of other bad publicity from obnoxious natives. Whatever sympathy New Yorkers have gained recently could be wiped out if the rest of the world gets a look at our sports fans in action.
Visitors' cash. The Olympics would fill the city's hotels, but most of those rooms would have been filled with visitors anyway. In a typical August, three-quarters of New York hotel rooms are filled, according to PKF Consulting, which has tracked occupancy rates for three decades.
Free fields of dreams. Mr. Doctoroff predicted that the privately financed Olympics would leave New York with a billion dollars' worth of new and renovated parks and sports facilities. There would be a new stadium on the West Side, a rowing course and swimming pool in Queens, an indoor volleyball arena in Coney Island, an equestrian center in Staten Island.
CAN the revenue from the Games really pay for all that? Construction costs in New York are so high that it's easy to imagine the money running short and taxpayers being soaked. Andrew Zimbalist, an economist at Smith College and the co-editor of a scholarly compendium, "Sports, Jobs and Taxes," said the Olympics were an iffy proposition. 
"Thanks to the television money for the Olympics, you do in essence get free sports facilities," he said. "But the city has to kick in for infrastructure and then pay for maintenance. The city also has to contend with high costs for security, and there are issues of disruption and congestion. It's hard to know on balance whether the pluses would outweigh the negatives. But I would be very suspicious, because it's not as if New York City needs all these new buildings."
The most suspect building is the costly new Olympic stadium, which is being promoted as a new home for the Jets as well as an extension of the Javits Convention Center. But it's hard to justify using precious Manhattan real estate for a building and parking lots that will probably sit empty most of the time -- and cause traffic jams the few Sundays football is played. The West Side needs taxpaying residents and businesses, not another subsidized white elephant like the Javits Center. Even a free stadium there would be no bargain.

HEADLINE: City Reconsidering Moving Museum Into Tweed Courthouse 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Backing away from another major initiative of his predecessor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged yesterday that he was reconsidering a controversial plan to move the Museum of the City of New York from East Harlem to the lavishly renovated Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan.
 Asked at his news briefing whether he was reconsidering the deal, Mr. Bloomberg confirmed that his administration was talking with museum officials about many problems the move would entail. "The problem with moving the museum down," Mr. Bloomberg said, was that "not everybody wants it to come down." He added that the museum had to raise money to make the move downtown, and that the old courthouse's landmark status meant there were questions of whether it could house a museum. 
 "So we certainly are talking to them, and we'll see how that works out," Mr. Bloomberg said. "But the Tweed Courthouse is one of the great assets of New York City, $80 million was spent on renovating it, it is just beautiful, and we have to make sure that it's used wisely."
The new mayor held his inaugural reception there, and some of his aides said yesterday that the administration might use the space for city offices. Some elected officials have suggested several times in the last few months that the deal was unraveling. 
Scuttling the move could cost the city millions, though, and a Giuliani administration official who helped arrange the deal was sharply critical of abandoning it. 
The official, John S. Dyson, the former deputy mayor who negotiated the deal as the chairman of Rudolph W. Giuliani's Council of Economic Advisers, a post for which he was paid $1 a year, called the notion of canceling the deal and using the old courthouse as city office space "crazy" and "ridiculous." 
"It would bring a smile to Boss Tweed's face," Mr. Dyson scoffed. 
"It's ridiculous," he said, "using a building we spent $80 million restoring as office space. It will be the most expensive office space for bureaucrats north of Brasilia." 
Mr. Dyson said the contract required the city to reimburse the museum for all of its expenses should the city back out of the deal. A member of the museum's board estimated that the city would have to pay about $3 million to cancel the contract. The museum has hired consultants, lawyers, architects and designers in planning the move. 
Redoing the building to suit the needs of a museum would cost about $40 million more, officials said, although it was not immediately clear how much of that would be paid by the city and how much would be raised by the museum, since there is a complex matching formula in the city's agreement, an official said.
Representatives for the museum stressed their interest in seeing the deal go through. "We have been working with the mayor's office regarding the future of the Tweed Courthouse," Newton P. S. Merrill, chairman of the Board of the Museum of the City of New York, said through a spokesman yesterday.
"We continue to hope to move to the Tweed and believe that our relocation to this historic landmark would be of significant benefit in the revitalization of Lower Manhattan," Mr. Merrill said. "The Tweed Courthouse is one of our city's greatest buildings, and our plans are to tell our city's history both in it and through it." 
The courthouse, named for the infamous Tammany Hall boss William M. Tweed, has been synonymous with corruption for generations, and its renovation, the cost of which went from an estimate of $37 million to more than $80 million, was a capstone to reclaiming the civic center in Lower Manhattan, championed by the former mayor. 
Giuliani administration officials had considered using it as a visitors' center, a restaurant and even a charter school before settling upon housing the museum. 
Moving out of the stately East Harlem building would free it for a different use, and community advocates have expressed fears that it would be luxury housing. City Councilman Philip Reed, who represents the area, said that the city's request for expressions of interest in the building was heavily weighted in favor of housing development, although El Museo del Barrio, a neighborhood cultural institution, had expressed interest in taking it over.
Doubts began to arise about whether the deal would hold up toward the end of the Giuliani administration, but Mr. Giuliani insisted that the deal was final and proceeding nicely. The rumblings resurfaced earlier this week in a report on a Web site, Politicsny.com, saying there were plans to tailor the Tweed to be used like the Executive Office Building in Washington. Through his spokeswoman, Sunny Mindel, Mr. Giuliani declined to comment.
Of highest consideration, Bloomberg officials say, is finding the most cost-effective course, since the city is reeling from impending budget shortfalls. "People are asking a lot of questions because everything is being questioned in context of next year's budget," one official said. "There are no sacred cows."
Mr. Dyson said a detailed architectural study considered numerous potential uses of the Tweed building, even the possibility of turning it into residential condominiums or a restaurant. Ultimately, the study concluded that an exhibition or museum space would be the best use.
A museum board member said that canceling the deal could endanger the museum's future because it could hinder its ability to raise money. 
A former city official agreed. "They have a new board, a new energized board, largely based on moving down to City Hall and helping to do something after Sept. 11," the former city official said. "This runs the risk of jeopardizing the existence of the museum." 
The mayor indicated that he was reconsidering the plan after a news conference, organized in honor of the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics, that was by turns sober and zany. As former Olympic stars like JoJo Starbuck looked on, Mr. Bloomberg ushered Daniel Doctoroff, his deputy for economic development and champion of bringing the Olympics to New York in 2012, down a temporary luge run outside City Hall. Mr. Doctoroff called the mayor's decision that he should demonstrate the luge "an excellent demonstration of delegation at work."
Afterward, Mr. Doctoroff, dressed in a suit, said the experience was fun, but called the resulting body slam into a retaining curb in City Hall Park "a little less fun."
For the mayor, who said he would miss some events at the observance of the Asian lunar new year on Saturday to attend a firefighter's funeral, much of the news conference appeared to be all fun. He ribbed one reporter that if he donated enough money he would name City Hall after him. When another asked what would happen to city employees caught improperly using sirens and flashing lights, the mayor said, "I don't know, we'll shoot them." Mr. Bloomberg, who claimed that the siren in his own car had never been turned on, added with a chuckle: "What do you think is going to happen to them? I mean, come on."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Using the Tweed Courthouse for offices would be "ridiculous," a Giuliani official said. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: European Central Bank President Stepping Down 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Feb. 7 

 BODY:
Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, said today that he would retire in July 2003, opening a new phase in what was already a tangled succession struggle.
 Mr. Duisenberg, who presided over the introduction of the euro as a common currency in 12 countries, has kept European leaders off-balance about his retirement plans for more than a year. 
 But his declaration today merely clarifies when he will step down as Europe's chief steward of monetary policy. It does not resolve the intensely political question of his successor, an issue that French and German leaders thought they had settled more than three years ago. 
President Jacques Chirac of France badly wants the next president to be Jean-Claude Trichet, governor of the Bank of France. The problem is that Mr. Trichet, though respected as a central banker, remains entangled in criminal investigations of the collapse and bailout of the French bank Credit Lyonnais in the early 1990's.
At the time, Mr. Trichet was a director of the French Treasury and a board member of Credit Lyonnais, which was then state-owned.
French prosecutors are investigating whether bank and government officials covered up problems, and the investigating magistrate is expected to decide within a few weeks whether to begin a full trial.
Thus far, European leaders have not challenged the widespread presumption that Mr. Duisenberg's successor will be French. Mr. Chirac had pushed hard for Mr. Trichet to be the central bank's first president, and capitulated only after a long and raucous summit meeting of European leaders in May 1998. 
Mr. Duisenberg, who had been president of the Dutch Central Bank, was Germany's candidate. When Mr. Chirac conceded, French and German leaders tacitly agreed that Mr. Duisenberg would retire before the end of his eight-year term and that he would be succeeded by a French president. 
Mr. Duisenberg has always denied he made any kind of deal himself, and he surprised many people last fall by making it clear he would stay on for at least a year. Today, in a statement, the central bank said Mr. Duisenberg had decided to retire on his 68th birthday, July 9, 2003. 
For the moment, economists said today, the succession struggle is unlikely to have any impact on monetary policy or on the exchange rate of the beleaguered euro. The euro sank precipitously against the dollar in the first two years after it was adopted in 1999, and it has remained weak even after the American economy sank into a recession last year.
Unlike Alan Greenspan, who wields enormous power as the chairman of the Federal Reserve, the president of the European Central Bank presides over a much more decentralized system of national central banks and relies on consensus among the national bank presidents. 
"I don't think it will change very much, because the structure of the European Central Bank has a very different structure from that of the Federal Reserve," said Daniel Gros, deputy director of the Center for European Policy Studies, an economic research group in Brussels. "The European Central Bank is much more collegial. Do you think there would be much difference between Duisenberg and Trichet? I don't know, but I would think no."
Klaus Friedrich, chief economist at Dresdner Bank in Frankfurt, argued today that Mr. Duisenberg was trying to clear a path for another French candidate, Christian Noyer, who is now vice president of the European Central Bank. 
Mr. Noyer's term expires in May, and French leaders have been puzzling over whether to insist that he be replaced by another French official or to wait until they can push for a French president.
Under the national quotas that still govern much of Europe, it would have been impossible to insist that both top jobs be filled by French nominees.
"I think it is a very astute political move," Mr. Friedrich said of Mr. Duisenberg's announcement. "He is giving the French a reading on what the situation will be prior to when the term of the vice president, Mr. Noyer, expires."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wim Duisenberg, second from right, is to step down as president of the European Central Bank. Among those with him yesterday were two possible successors, Jean-Claude Trichet, far left, and Christian Noyer, far right. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Unite to Oppose Plan to Cut Highway Spending 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 

 BODY:
Senior members of Congress from both parties said today that they would reject President Bush's proposal for a 28 percent cut in federal highway spending, one of the largest in the entire budget.
 Lawmakers said the cuts would be unwise as the nation struggles to climb out of a recession and unthinkable in an election year. Building roads creates jobs, lawmakers said over and over. It also provides tidy bundles of federal cash for lawmakers to send to their home districts. 
 "It's hard to say anything nice about this proposal," Senator Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama, said.
The reaction signaled the start of a process that will continue for months, as Congress dissects and rearranges Mr. Bush's budget.
Michael P. Jackson, the deputy secretary of transportation, defended the budget request at a hearing of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee responsible for highways.
"Because of the economy's slowdown in 2001," Mr. Jackson said, "there was a drop in tax receipts flowing into the Highway Trust Fund." A statutory formula, adopted in 1998, links highway spending to gasoline taxes and other trust fund revenues, Mr. Jackson said. The president, he said, simply followed the formula.
Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the Democrat who is the chairwoman of the subcommittee, rejected that explanation. In the president's budget, she said, "there are hundreds of examples where the administration is asking us to ignore existing law or to change the law."
The president asked Congress to cut highway spending by $9.2 billion, to $24.1 billion next year, from $33.3 billion this year.
Senator James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma, one of the most conservative Republicans in Congress, called highway spending essential to the economic recovery that appears to have begun in the last few months. Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri, said that highway spending was "a matter of life and death," because the money was used to build safer roads.
Representative Don Young, the Alaska Republican who is the chairman of the House Transportation Committee, denounced Mr. Bush's proposal as "a drastic cut." He joined members of both parties in introducing a bill to restore at least $4.4 billion, or roughly half the money Mr. Bush wants to cut. A similar bill was introduced in the Senate.
Highway lobbyists said the president's proposal could result in a loss of 360,000 jobs. California and Texas would lose more than $600 million each, and New York would lose more than $345 million, representing about one-fourth of the allotment for each state, according to Transportation Department data.
Mr. Jackson, the transportation official, said the proposed cut was "one of the toughest choices we had to make in this budget." He said the administration would work with Congress to smooth year-to-year fluctuations in highway spending. But he declined to endorse House and Senate bills introduced today.
"We're sticking with the president's budget for now," Mr. Jackson said.
Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, noted that the Highway Trust Fund had an unspent balance of more than $18 billion. "Tax dollars being paid at the gas pump are not being fully used for highway construction," Mr. Byrd, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, said. 
Mrs. Murray expressed concern about other proposals in Mr. Bush's budget, including a cut of 14 percent, or $1.8 million, in efforts to promote the use of seat belts and a cut of 20 percent, or $508 million, in the development of auto safety standards.
Administration officials also told Congress today that the budget included far less money than would be needed to carry out the aviation security law passed in response to the Sept. 11 attacks.
Under the law, the government must take "all necessary action" to ensure that airports have explosive detection systems to screen checked baggage by the end of this year.
John W. Magaw, the under secretary of transportation for security, said that airports would need almost 2,000 machines, but that the existing manufacturers could not produce more than 300 with their current capacity. Some airports need 60 to 65 machines, he said.
Mr. Jackson said the budget would provide slightly less than $300 million for the machines, which can cost more than $1 million each. In some cases, airport terminals must be rebuilt to make room for them.
The available money "is not going to cover the cost," Mr. Magaw said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, holding a copy of President Bush's proposed budget, joined other lawmakers yesterday to oppose its planned cut in highway spending. In testimony by Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill before the Senate Budget Committee, Mr. Byrd took issue with what he regarded as the budget's criticism of Congressional limits on federal decision-making. In a bitter exchange about who represented the public's interest best, the two men wound up arguing about who came from a more impoverished background. (Photographs by Associated Press)
