HEADLINE: Doubts on Tweed Courthouse for Museum Are Part of a Penchant for Review 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
Discussions continued yesterday over whether the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would go ahead with plans to move the Museum of the City of New York to the lavishly renovated Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan.
 A spokesman for the museum said officials there were withholding comment pending the outcome of meetings planned over the weekend. 
 William Cunningham, Mr. Bloomberg's communications director, said re-examining the move was part of the administration's review of "almost every project you could think of," from refurbishing parks to the method for ordering office furniture. Mr. Cunningham said he expected that the city would reach some conclusion about the future of the once-notorious building by Wednesday, when Mr. Bloomberg plans to release his budget. 
Former Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson, who, as the chairman of the previous mayor's Council of Economic Advisers, negotiated the terms of the city's agreement with the museum to use the space, said yesterday that it called for the museum and the city to roughly split the costs of planning and making the move, about $47 million.
Under the agreement, the city and the museum would each contribute $3 million in the first year, 2002, to cover the costs of preparing the plan, which the city would be required to reimburse the museum if it backed out of the deal. To go forward, Mr. Dyson said, the museum would have to raise its share of the remainder of the costs, about $23 million, before the city would roughly match it.
Bloomberg officials have expressed concern about the outlay, given the city's currently shaky finances and the need to delay or cancel many planned projects.
"There are new costs associated with it in addition to what's already been spent," Mr. Cunningham said. "In this budget environment, the question naturally arises, 'Is this a cost that we should have now' " or at all?
But Mr. Dyson said that since the city had already agreed to commit $18 million for the museum, the amount it had planned to contribute to a $36 million renovation of its building on upper Fifth Avenue before settling on the move to Tweed, going ahead with the move would not cost the city significantly more than it had already budgeted.
Yesterday, the matter appeared far from settled. Mr. Cunningham characterized discussions about using the building for office space as "brainstorming" and the "natural percolating of ideas." Those ideas include creating a version of City Hall's bullpen, combining all agencies that have a role in a particular field, like serving the needs of small businesses; mixing office and exhibit space; and going ahead with the museum.
Mr. Cunningham emphasized that those scenarios were examples, and added that while the administration would probably not have the details of a proposal worked out by Wednesday, the budget was likely to clarify those issues. "Money generally has a way of doing that," he said.

HEADLINE: NYC; 
The State of the Column Is Forlorn

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
MORE or less unscathed, we have emerged from the season when the political big shots check our collective pulse, by way of informing us about the State of the Union, the State of the State, the State of the City, even the State of the Parks. With inspiration like that, how can one resist delivering the first, and in all likelihood the last, State of the Column address?
 At this point in the State of the Whatever, most politicians break in to say that things could not be peachier. 
 Just last week, President Bush said that "the state of our union has never been stronger" -- this, microseconds after he reminded us that the country is at war, the economy is reeling and "unprecedented dangers" are upon us. Gee, with strength like that, give us the bad old days when we were weaker. 
You will not get verbal tap-dancing of that sort here. The state of the column, friends, could be a lot better. So many taboo subjects abound that times have grown tough for those of us who pride ourselves on multi-tsking.
Take the city's firefighters, as noble a group as you will find, and that was true long before Sept. 11. But since that terrible day, it has been deemed verboten to so much as raise an eyebrow at almost anything they do. So nothing will be said here about how some firefighters and some relatives of the World Trade Center victims seem to have a powerful absorption with what might be called necropolitics.
They complained this week that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had not gone to any funerals or memorial services for the Fire Department's Sept. 11 dead. The suggestion was that the new mayor displays an appalling lack of respect, even though at almost every turn he talks about New Yorkers' enormous, unpayable debt to the fallen firefighters.
It seems Mr. Bloomberg has missed five such events since taking office on Jan. 1. But two were private affairs, and one took place at the same time the mayor was attending a memorial service for a friend. That means, in reality, he has been a no-show only twice and, perhaps in reaction to the complaints, he plans to go today to a scheduled funeral in Queens.
Only in necropolitical New York can his behavior be interpreted as an insult. But the forlorn state of the column is such that this space will, to borrow from Archie Bunker, stifle itself.
In palmier days, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani always came through. He still does his darnedest. Look at the questionable way in which he spirited his papers out of City Hall while making his getaway. But over the last five months Mr. Giuliani has also ascended to secular saint, a reality that puts a severe strain on the state of the column.
Of course, we now have Mr. Bloomberg, but he has been far less generous than his predecessor in providing material. Oh, he has stumbled a bit, as when he made an unfortunate joke about firing thousands of city workers. But that one was small potatoes. Bigger potatoes may come on Wednesday, when he will present his first budget proposal and presumably will leave buckets of blood on the floor. Thus far, however, the new mayor has benefited from a customary honeymoon period. That may be good for him. But it's not so good for the state of the column.
LET'S see, there is Mark Green, the failed mayoral candidate. He teed off on Mr. Bloomberg so hard this week that he reminded some New Yorkers why they didn't vote for him in November (and reminded others who did support him why they shed few tears over his defeat).
There was no honeymoon offer from Mr. Green in his new role as born-again political commentator. Mr. Bloomberg has yet to offer a single new idea, he said, and is popular only because he has grabbed easy victories, or in Mr. Green's words, "picked the low-hanging fruit."
Some New Yorkers may wonder if this unexpected attack qualified as gracelessness without pressure. But this column has no intention of touching the issue, no matter how rocky the state it is in. Political losers, too, deserve a honeymoon when starting anew.
So, as you see, these are difficult times. There was a glimmer of hope when Edward Skyler, Mr. Bloomberg's spokesman, said that if you want to talk about low-hanging fruit, how about sour grapes? Do you know how long it's been since a press secretary said something that was actually funny?
But one good line is hardly enough to improve the state of the column. The new mayor had better start coming through soon. He can't count on Mark Green bailing him out every time.

HEADLINE: For the Mayor, Jokes Are Part Of the Routine; 
Though His Delivery Is Not Always Smooth, Bloomberg Gets Laughs

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
During his first week in office, Michael R. Bloomberg was asked if it had dawned on him what a difficult job he had taken on. "It's hitting me at this press conference," he said, then exited, stage left. 
 Since taking office in January, Mr. Bloomberg has demonstrated that while he may not be a deft public speaker, he can be funny. 
 With the United States Conference of Mayors in town, Mr. Bloomberg mentioned that he had been asked whether extra security had been ordered. "I told them that I didn't think any of the mayors would be that dangerous," he said.
And while inspecting the preparations at a sanitation yard in Queens for an impending snowstorm, Mr. Bloomberg mentioned that his administration planned a new program employing people whose sole job it would be to announce the coming of winter storms. He waved in the direction of a salt dome, where he said the newest hire was sitting. Resting on the dome was a pigeon. He grinned madly.
Mr. Bloomberg has been sprinkling quips and one-liners through news conferences, speeches, and brief remarks to the dozens of groups that he drops in on each week.
At times, his wit comes off as insensitive, such as during his first radio program two Fridays ago. Asked if he was taking notes, he said: "Thousands of people working for the city, they're about to be fired so I can make the 20 percent cut, but before they go out the door this afternoon, they're going to make these notes."
On Thursday, asked what he planned to do to city officials who abuse the flashing lights and sirens in their cars, he replied tartly: "I don't know. We'll shoot them. What do you think is going to happen to them?"
His taste for politically incorrect gags surfaced during his campaign for mayor, when a reporter unearthed a book composed of one-liners attributed to Mr. Bloomberg that were bawdy and, to some, offensive.
These days, his humor ranges from swift one-liners to semipolished stand-up routines, often used to make members of his staff who barely know him more comfortable.
David Letterman doesn't have to worry about his job just yet. Mr. Bloomberg's speech is stilted; he is prone to stepping on his own applause lines and adding consonants where they do not belong with a voice that few would describe as mellifluous. But Mr. Bloomberg can often elicit a hearty chuckle from the entire room with a small aside. On the day he announced the appointment of his new city planning chairwoman, Amanda M. Burden, he called her "a friend of long standing, not an old friend." 
Sometimes the mayor's jokes seem snappish. But people who spend enough time with him realize that that has more to do with the tone than the tenor of his remarks, and that his witty banter and not-so-gentle teasing come off better without a microphone and a press corps. 
"He's not a guy to tell a long joke or a humorous story," said William Cunningham, Mr. Bloomberg's communications director.
"He is more apt to say something that either pokes fun at himself or to make a deadpan remark that is the exact opposite of what he is going to do," Mr. Cunningham said. "It is his way of breaking the ice." 
The city's giant budget gap is often his favorite comic fodder.
The morning before Mr. Bloomberg's inauguration, at a breakfast with prominent clergymen at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Mr. Bloomberg said: "We are going clearly to go through some tough economic times. As I went around, a lot of you offered me your prayers. But honestly, thank you very much -- I can use them. I could also use $4 billion to balance the budget, if just in case any of you have some extra funds that you don't know what to do with." (Insert crashing cymbals here.)
To help manage its budget woes, Mr. Bloomberg's administration is considering offering naming rights to corporations that want to pay to maintain parts of city parks. Responding to questions this week about that idea, Mr. Bloomberg said to a reporter: "We could talk about it, if you've got enough money, how you name City Hall. We've got a four-and-half-billion-dollar deficit, and if you want to make a material impact on that I suspect all eight million New Yorkers would be behind you and I could see your name right up there now."
And he seems to recognize that he can be rather sensitive. Yesterday, during his radio program on WABC (770), the host, John Gambling, asked him if his skin was thickening as time passes. "I never object when they are unfair to you," the mayor answered quickly. 
New Yorkers do like their mayors humorous. Fiorello H. La Guardia read comic strips on the air during a city newspaper strike in 1945. Mayor Edward I. Koch had a broad sense of humor, but his jokes were rarely at his own expense.
In 1981, when Greenwich, Conn., was suffering from a drought, Mayor Koch said that its residents were having some personal hygiene problems as a result.
"It's getting so you can tell when someone comes from Greenwich," he joked.
Later, when New York suffered its own drought, a Greenwich official offered his home to the mayor for a shower. Not missing a beat, Mr. Koch said: "I'm very grateful that he has extended the offer well in advance, so I can find out where Greenwich, Conn., is." 
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's aides made a habit of laughing hysterically at anything remotely humorous that came out of his mouth, which was often a strong poke at an adversary. However, he would occasionally josh about his taste in art, or his desire to carefully guard public information.
Often, perhaps because he still can't quite believe he won, Mr. Bloomberg will make a joke about his new job. Recently, a small group gathered around the fish tank outside the police desk at City Hall, noting that the hose in the tortured creatures' tank was broken. Mr. Bloomberg fiddled with the hose a bit, and it began to bubble smoothly. Smiling broadly, he said: "That's why I'm the mayor!"

HEADLINE: Fashion Statement: Hip-Hop on Runway 

BYLINE:  By GUY TREBAY 

 BODY:
He has been Sean Combs and Puff Daddy and now styles himself P. Diddy. He has been a rap mogul, a multiplatinum-selling recording artist and producer, a celebrity consort and also a criminal defendant. Now, as Fashion Week begins, Sean John Combs, 32, originally of Yonkers, is the biggest comer on Seventh Avenue. 
 In the two years since Mr. Combs started his clothing label Sean John, for which he directs design, the company has easily lapped its competitors in the urban fashion market, gaining on well-established labels like Fubu, Phat Farm and Ecko, whose customers are primarily young men who favor the loose, hip-hop inspired clothing that has become both an urban and suburban uniform. Sean John is sold in 1,200 stores across the country, with retail revenue of over $200 million last year, according to the privately held company. 
 A clue to Mr. Combs's ambitions came Thursday, when he appeared, along with Terry Lundgren, the president of Federated Department Stores, to ring the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange. Some on hand remembered that the last time Mr. Combs appeared publicly downtown was to hear of his acquittal in criminal court on charges of carrying a concealed weapon in a nightclub. He was wearing a suit on that occasion last year, and he wore an even nattier one of chalk stripes from Versace this week, as he spoke about the importance of giving New York economic support.
"We were going to show our collection in Paris," he said, "but right now with the economy, it's extremely important to be in New York."
In a chastened climate, and during a week of scaled-back fashion presentations, many held in designers' showrooms rather than the Bryant Park tents, Mr. Combs's show at 8 tonight at Cipriani catering hall on 42nd Street is conceived as a break-the-bank extravaganza, just part of its $1.24 million cost going into a specially commissioned video and soundtrack, theatrical curtains so massive that nine workers are required to hoist them, and custom hardwood bleachers and catwalk. 
The 1,000 machine-embroidered invitations, packaged with silk knot cuff links in sueded boxes, cost more than $60,000. Even fashion insiders accustomed to over-the-top theatrics hail the infusion of unabashed show business and entrepreneurial savvy that Mr. Combs and his company have brought to a fashion scene bogged down in image fatigue.
"Everything is so flattened out and dull now," said Kal Ruttenstein, the fashion director for Bloomingdale's. "Sean Combs brings an original point of view, a lot of very smart people who work his design team, and a great editor's eye." 
Mr. Combs makes few claims to being a hands-on designer. Yet he bristles at suggestions that his is just another line of jeans with a celebrity autograph on the rear pocket. As the conceptualist heading a production team that includes an influential stylist, Bill Mullen, his is probably a role not so different from that played by Ralph Lauren at Polo -- the arbiter of his staff's creative suggestions, the entrepreneurial force behind an expanding brand.
"I don't have a huge background in fashion," Mr. Combs said yesterday at the office of his record company, Bad Boy Worldwide Entertainment Group, in Times Square. As a rap impresario, Mr. Combs produced mid-90's stars like Mary J. Blige and Notorious B.I.G.; though he hasn't abandoned recording, he now conceives of it as merely one element in Sean John, the lifestyle brand.
"My background is being a consumer," he remarked, one who shopped early on at thrift stores, and then designer boutiques and eventually in the temples of luxury that line Fifth Avenue. For an interview, Mr. Combs wore a simple white T-shirt and baggy jeans, set off by a diamond-encrusted crucifix worthy of a Spanish infanta and a ring with a single round rock of bottle cap size. The walls of his office were adorned with the covers of daily tabloids reporting his acquittal. 
"I got into fashion," Mr. Combs said, snacking on orange slices from a Tupperware tub, "because fashion, and especially men's fashion, had a lack of style, a lack of risk-taking, a lack of fun." Women play dress-up all the time, Mr. Combs said. It is the rare man who can. His father, Melvin Combs, whom he recalled as one of "the fliest cats on the planet," was one. "My father, who was killed when I was 3, had a Persian lamb suit," Mr. Combs said. "I'm dedicating this show to him."
The sales figures for Sean John clothing are more impressive for being derived mostly from his simply styled, medium-priced clothing (prices start at $32 for a printed T-shirt and rise to $3,700 for a shearling coat) that tends to be narrowly cut and unornamented, except for a script signature so understated it could pass for the logo of an upscale wine bar.
Among Sean John's leading competitors, Ecko says it has annual retail revenues of $500 million. More than twice Sean John's, that figure includes royalties from a wide variety of licensed products. 
The menswear trade publication DNR recently ranked Mr. Combs 33rd on a list of the 100 most powerful people in men's fashion, between the designer John Varvatos and Stan Tucker, a Burberry executive. "He was above a number of people who did more volume," said John Birmingham, the editor of DNR. "We gave him that ranking because of his star power, and his success in putting together a sportswear line with broad appeal."
At the splashy $1 million runway event he staged for his fall 2001 show a year ago, Mr. Combs took the denims that are staples of urban wear and accessorized them with outlandish Mad Max-style overcoats and enough lynx, coyote, lamb, fox, crocodile, shearling, ostrich and mink to set People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals' agenda back 20 years. This season he is moving into tailored styles that draw inspiration from Savile Row. 
"He is building a tailored clothing business that is going to be the next big explosive part of his collection," said Mr. Ruttenstein, of Bloomingdale's. Mr. Combs's choice of direction may have something to do with the demise of casual Friday in a fearful job market. Equally it may result from a desire to sanitize the less salubrious parts of his past. Mr. Combs said, "There is definitely an elegant gentleman vibe."
When Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue, referred last year to Mr. Combs as "a great designer," she was undoubtedly referring to his special talent for returning some buzz to a wayward industry. 
When he began his business, Mr. Combs said, "Fashion was so corporate, so about the money, so not about the glamor, the fierceness, the gaiety, the flair." 
"I want to bring entertainment to fashion," he added. "But that doesn't mean my business isn't completely on plan."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Russia Says It Is Upholding Promise on Oil Export Curbs

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 8 

 BODY:
Russia said today that it was keeping to the letter of its promise to the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, reducing the official count of its exports of crude oil by 150,000 barrels a day. But oil production is still surging, exports of refined products are still rising, and few people here think there is any chance of export restraint after March 31, when the promise to OPEC expires.
 The Russian energy minister, Igor K. Yusufov, announced today that Russia had cut exports by the promised amount, and was now shipping 2.7 million barrels a day abroad. Official oil statistics have a far from ironclad reputation here, and most analysts prefer to compile their own figures. By most such counts, Russia has at least halted the growth in its exports; Petroleum Argus, a respected industry publication, said exports in January were unchanged from the fourth quarter of 2001. 
 But the signs are that unexported crude is simply piling up inside the country. The International Energy Agency in Paris reported today that total output in Russia rose by 60,000 barrels a day, to 7.26 million, worsening a glut within Russia that has driven domestic prices down to $4 a barrel, a three-year low. Stockpiles at electric power plants are 20 percent above normal, and warm weather has trimmed consumption.
"The domestic market is flooded," said Simon Kukes, president of the Tyumen Oil Company, one of the largest Russian producers. "We are very close to capacity at our storage facilities." Once March 31 has passed, he said, "I don't think there will be reductions" in exports.
"Production is increasing," he said, "and we can't continue dumping on the domestic market."
While Mr. Yusufov, the energy minister, said today that no decision had been made on extending export cuts beyond March, recent public statements by high-level Russian officials seem to confirm Russia has already made up its mind. 
Prime Minister Mikhail M. Kasyanov told an audience at the World Economic Forum in New York last weekend that Russia intended to increase its share of world oil output. In an interview on Russian television this week, President Vladimir V. Putin's economic adviser, Andrei N. Illarionov, said Russia had the "historical right" to take back the market share it lost when its economy collapsed in the mid-1990's.
According to executives at Lukoil, Russia's leading producer, President Putin wants oil to be on the agenda when President Bush visits Russia in May. The company has said that by 2005 its fields at Timan Pechora in the far north will be producing 37 million barrels of oil annually for shipment to North America, and that it has discussed financing plans for the project with the United States Export-Import Bank. 
"It's a good route; it is economic," said Leonid Fedun, Lukoil's vice president. "The Persian Gulf is farther from America than Russia. That's the competitive advantage we have."
Russian companies with large amounts of unexported crude on their hands have, meanwhile, been stepping up shipments of refined products like fuel oil instead. That became more profitable when the government, in a concession to the industry, reduced export duties on several refined products -- the move starts to take effect this month. A sliding export tax on crude oil was also reduced on Feb. 1.
Tyumen Oil said its exports of refined products rose 20 percent in January from the month before, and Lukoil also increased exports. 
The increased shipments of oil products are pushing prices for them down, and are indirectly putting downward pressure on world crude prices. But the Russian oil companies have little choice. 
"It is a heavy burden for them to carry on these OPEC restrictions," said Raivo Vare, chairman of Pakterminal, the largest oil terminal in Estonia, where large amounts of Russian oil exports are handled. "Market prices have gone down so deeply it's just not economical to supply to domestic refineries. Sooner or later they will try to increase exports of crude."
For the moment, world crude prices are steady, and OPEC has toned down its calls for Russian cuts. Domestic demand in Russia will pick up in April, when the planting season begins, oil companies said.
"The feeling I get is, the boat's not sinking, so don't rock it," said Adam Sieminski, an energy strategist at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown in Maryland. "With world prices holding, no one sees any particular reason to challenge the Russians to some fight for market share."

HEADLINE: Time for A Special Counsel 

BYLINE:  By Ernest F. Hollings; Ernest F. Hollings, a senator from South Carolina, is chairman of the Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
This week, when Kenneth Lay, former Enron chairman and George W. Bush's largest campaign contributor, failed to show up to testify before Congress, I became convinced that it is time to appoint a special counsel to investigate Enron. We need to name a special counsel, rather than relying on the Justice Department, because conflicts of interest abound in this case, particularly at the Justice Department. Federal law allows the attorney general to appoint such a counsel when the Justice Department's involvement would present a conflict of interest.
 Attorney General John Ashcroft recused himself from the Enron case because he had taken $57,000 from Enron in his failed bid for the Senate in 2000. His chief of staff also recused himself, since he was Mr. Ashcroft's 2000 campaign manager. That leaves Larry Thompson, deputy attorney general, to oversee the case -- or to appoint a special counsel. 
 While Mr. Thompson is a capable attorney, his former law firm has represented both Enron and Arthur Andersen, giving a taint of a conflict of interest. Moreover, Mr. Thompson may already be the busiest man in Washington because he is overseeing the Justice Department's counterterrorism activities.
A special counsel can also be appointed if there are "extraordinary circumstances" that would cause the appointment to be in the public's interest. What could be more extraordinary than the largest bankruptcy in American history? When was the last time a corporate collapse had Wall Street so jittery, with investors questioning the accounting practices of every company and so many ripples spreading out through the economy? 
I also find it to be "extraordinary circumstances" when a top executive commits suicide, voluminous documents are shredded and witness after witness takes the Fifth Amendment. And in my 35 years in the Senate, I have never witnessed a corporation so extraordinarily committed to buying government. In the last decade, Enron gave campaign contributions to 186 House members and 71 senators, including $3,500 to me.
In the 2000 election, Mr. Lay and his employees, as well as Enron and its political action committee, contributed some $700,000 to Mr. Bush and the Republican party. There was money for the party convention, the recount of votes in Florida, the Bush inaugural. And Enron airplanes for the campaign.
The Bush administration says it did nothing for Mr. Lay this fall when he sought its help. I believe this. But what about help given before? The administration has provided jobs for a stable of Enron alumni and friends. Thomas White, a former vice chairman of an Enron subsidiary, became the secretary of the Army and quickly moved to turn the military's energy needs over to private hands, like those of his former employer.
Patrick Wood III abruptly replaced Curtis Hebert as head of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission; Mr. Hebert hadn't agreed with Mr. Lay on electricity deregulation. The trade representative, Robert Zoellick, had served on an Enron advisory board. Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham took $13,500 from Enron as a senator. I could recite many more connections.
Mr. Thompson, who is now in charge, ought to pick someone with the credibility of an Archibald Cox, who developed a sterling reputation with the public for his objectivity during the Watergate investigation. If someone of this ilk finds no wrongdoing, people would have confidence that the investigation was done right.
In addition, the Senate should have one committee investigating Enron, not six. Senator Ted Stevens, a Republican from Alaska, and I have asked the Senate leadership to establish a bipartisan select committee to address the policy implications of Enron's collapse. The policy concerns are vast: consumer fraud, electricity deregulation, employee pension funds, Securities and Exchange Commission regulations, auditing and accounting standards, tax compliance and shareholder rights.
Through a special counsel and a select committee, the government will ensure a thorough investigation without a taint of conflict. Only then will the American public know the Enron problem and its associated consequences are not swept under the rug.

HEADLINE: To Detroit's Dismay, McCain Proposes Rise in Fuel Standards 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 8 

 BODY:
Senator John McCain of Arizona, the ranking Republican on the Senate Commerce Committee, introduced a bill on Thursday night that calls for an increase of up to 50 percent in automotive fuel economy standards by 2016. 
 The bill also proposes closing the gap between standards set for passenger cars and light trucks, an issue that has been a chief concern of environmental groups. And it seeks a complex trading system that would permit automakers to swap credits for reducing greenhouse gas emissions with companies in other industries. 
 Senator McCain's proposals are not as ambitious as those in a similar fuel economy bill submitted today by the Democratic leaders of the Commerce Committee, John Kerry of Massachusetts and Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolinian who is chairman of the committee. But coming from a leading Republican, the McCain bill was a setback for the auto industry, which has lobbied to allow the Bush administration, not Congress, to decide what action to take on fuel economy standards and has resisted any big increase of current requirements.
Senator McCain's staff and Democratic staff members on the Commerce Committee are exploring whether a bipartisan plan on fuel economy standards can be reached as part of the Senate's energy bill.
Even if the proposal that ends up in the Senate's energy bill has Senator McCain's support, lobbyists and legislators doubt that it will make it through a Republican House and White House. Federal fuel economy standards have not changed since the 1980's.
Senator McCain said in a statement that his proposals "will strengthen our national security while significantly reducing greenhouse gas emissions over the next decade and beyond."
Energy security in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks has given the fuel economy issue new momentum. That is not good news for auto industry trade groups, which did not welcome the McCain bill.
"It seems a lot like the Kerry bill," said Gloria J. Bergquist, a spokeswoman for the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, which includes most major automakers. "We think the proposals are absurd, and we think consumers will be outraged when they realize that they eliminate S.U.V.'s, minivans and pickups," she added. 
Ms. Bergquist was referring to the proposal to close the gap between light trucks and passenger cars, which domestic automakers have said would be too costly. Corporate average fuel economy standards, known as CAFE, now require each manufacturer's annual fleet of new passenger cars to average 27.5 miles a gallon. Each automaker's fleet of light trucks -- sport utility vehicles, pickups and minivans -- is required to average 20.7 miles a gallon.
The Kerry-Hollings bill would combine car and truck standards and increase the combined standard to 35 miles a gallon by the model year 2013. Senator McCain's bill would increase the standard to 36 miles a gallon, but not until 2016. And companies could reduce that requirement by as much as 10 percent by swapping greenhouse gas credits with companies in other industries. Both plans would be phased in.
According to a preliminary analysis of the two bills by the Sierra Club, the environmental group, the McCain bill would save 300,000 to 500,000 barrels of oil a day by 2012, compared with a million barrels a day under the Kerry-Hollings plan. By contrast, an energy bill passed by the House proposed savings of about 47,000 barrels a day in the second half of this decade. Automobiles in the United States now consume about eight million barrels of oil a day.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE NEW LEADER; 
Afghan and Pakistani Pledge To Move Beyond Old Grudges

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Feb. 8 

 BODY:
The leaders of Afghanistan and Pakistan today reached back more than a decade to find common ground for their countries' future relationship, agreeing that "misunderstandings and misperceptions" of the past should be left behind.
 "They are buried," said Hamid Karzai, Afghanistan's interim leader, responding to a statement by Gen. Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's president, that the two focus on the future. General Musharraf then echoed the comment of Mr. Karzai, who was making his first official visit to Islamabad, saying, "Yes, they are buried." 
 It was Pakistan that provided much of the logistical, financial and ideological support for the Taliban during its five-year hold on Afghanistan. But it was also Pakistan that was the main base for Arab and Western support for the anti-Soviet mujahedeen in the 1980's. This campaign was waged by what later became the Northern Alliance, which went on to oppose -- and finally defeat -- the Taliban.
Although deep divisions remain between the countries, today's gestures of comity seemed to represent a natural progression. With American support, the two sides now cast themselves as leaders in the war against terrorism. They have been mostly in the same camp since October, when Pakistan finally agreed that Afghanistan should no longer be governed by the Taliban.
Mr. Karzai, who maintains a home in Quetta, Pakistan, was perhaps the Afghan leader best equipped to declare his government a new partner of Pakistan's.
As a result of General Musharraf's turning against the Taliban, Mr. Karzai declared that the Pakistani leader was poised to make his country "the cornerstone of this region's work against terrorism and radicalism in the future."
For his part, General Musharraf said that he had been "extremely impressed by the able and sagacious leadership being provided by Chairman Karzai at this hour of need."
The two sides tried to gloss over the most significant matters dividing them. On whether Pakistani prisoners held by the Northern Alliance, Mr. Karzai said that his government hoped soon to release as many of the former Taliban fighters as possible. He said he wanted to make sure that his country did not surrender those with ties to Al Qaeda.
On the issue of 1.6 million Afghan refugees in Pakistan, Mr. Karzai said he hoped to make it possible for them to return home soon, but was grateful for Pakistan's patience in allowing the situation and the economy to stabilize in a way that might make that repatriation as smooth as possible.
Given their long and porous border, Afghanistan and Pakistan still face a future that could quickly become unstable, with the potential for militants in Pakistan opposed to the Afghan government infiltrating easily. In recent months, Northern Alliance leaders have sharply warned against meddling by Pakistan, with Dr. Abdullah, the foreign minister of Afghanistan's interim government, saying, "What is required of Pakistan is not to impose a puppet in Afghanistan."
With its large Pashtun population, Pakistan has close ties with the Pashtun tribes of southern Afghanistan, the core of the Taliban. It has had deeply hostile relations with the predominantly Tajik and Uzbek tribes of the north, the source of the greatest opposition to the Taliban, including the warlords of the Northern Alliance.
As for matters within Afghanistan, Mr. Karzai was asked when he might ask American forces to leave his country and abandon their quest for Osama bin Laden. His answer suggested that he did not want that moment to come any time soon.
"Let's be very frank with you here again," he told a Pakistani journalist. "Without help from the United States we would have found it very, very difficult to defeat terrorism in Afghanistan.
"The war against terrorism is not yet over. We will have to go and look for them, in their hideouts, their caves, wherever they are.
"If you come to Afghanistan, you will see what they have done to us. Come and see for yourselves. It is absolutely shocking."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pervez Musharraf, right, welcomed Hamid Karzai yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: RETIREMENT MONEY; 
Plan to Put Limits on 401(k) Holdings Draws Fire

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
When the collapse of Enron largely wiped out the retirement savings of thousands of its employees, several Democratic lawmakers embraced what they thought was a way to prevent workers at other companies from suffering a similar fate.
 These lawmakers suggested a cap, perhaps 10 percent or 20 percent, on the amount of an employee's 401(k) plan that could be invested in one company. The idea was to prevent workers from putting too much of their nest egg in one basket; at Enron, for example, employees had 62 percent of their 401(k) holdings invested in the company's stock. 
 Of the many ideas that lawmakers have proposed on how to protect the savings of workers, the idea of a cap has stirred the most debate. 
Senator Jon S. Corzine, Democrat of New Jersey, an outspoken advocate of caps, said that because the federal government was spending more than $70 billion a year to subsidize 401(k) plans, it should make sure that participants use the most basic of investment principles, diversification. 
The subsidies take the form of tax breaks to 401(k) participants and to the companies that contribute both stock and cash to it.
"I believe subsidizing savings to promote retirement security is a good thing," Mr. Corzine said. "But subsidizing risky investments is not. If people want to risk all their investment dollars by placing all their investment in their employer, fine. But they should do it on their own dime, not the taxpayers.' "
Mr. Corzine said a cap was needed because workers at many companies, including Enron, Global Crossing, Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks, Carter Hawley Hale and Color Tile, have had much of their retirement savings erased by drops in the price of company stock. He and Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, have proposed a 20 percent cap on how much of one company's stock can be held in a 401(k) plan.
But the idea has come under heavy fire. Corporate executives say employees should be free to buy as much stock as they want because it shows that they have faith in the company. Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao has also criticized the proposal, saying it violates a fundamental principle: freedom of choice for investors. 
"Washington shouldn't be allowed to dictate to workers how much company stock they can own," Ms. Chao said. "Arbitrary restrictions on Americans' financial choices would not be progress and would not necessarily make people's retirement savings any safer."
Even some liberal economists say a cap would be hard to carry out and might anger many shareholders. 
For example, they say, if a company develops a technological breakthrough and its stock starts to climb, many employees might use their 401(k) plans to buy more shares. Those purchases, along with the appreciation of the stock, might push employees over the 20 percent cap, forcing them to sell. This would undoubtedly generate employee complaints, the economists contend, that an intrusive government was making them miss out on the run-up in their companies' share price.
In short, critics of a cap say its supporters have taken a Big Brotherish "government knows what's bestfor you" attitude.
"In December, I received an e-mail from a constituent, James, who said, 'I have made my retirement possible by investing 100 percent of my 401(k) in Texas Instruments stock at opportune times,' " Representative Sam Johnson, Republican of Texas, said. "He really does not feel that the U.S. Congress, or anyone else in the government, should tell him that he doesn't know what he is doing."
Many companies like having employees invest a high percentage of their retirement savings in their shares because it ensures loyalty and keeps large blocks of stock in friendly hands. Some corporate lobbyists warned this week that if caps were enacted, that might discourage companies from matching employee contributions with company stock. That, the lobbyists contend, would hurt the employees that Congress wants to help.
Responding to the Enron scandal, President Bush has proposed letting employees sell stock that employers contribute to their 401(k) plan after holding it for three years. Enron barred employees from selling this stock before age 50.
But the president's plan, which has widespread Congressional support, would have limited sweep in Enron's case because it would apply to only the stock contributed by the company, which represents 11 percent of the stock held in the Enron 401(k) plan. Employees bought the other 89 percent with their 401(k) savings.
Some lawmakers and economists say another reason a cap is needed is that employers press employees to load up on company stock, in their 401(k) plans and elsewhere. At Enron and many other companies, executives repeatedly urged employees to buy company stock, telling them the shares were undervalued. At some companies, not to hold large amounts of company stock is viewed as disloyalty. 
The Employee Benefit Research Institute reports that 27 percent of workers in plans that offer the option of buying company shares have invested more than half their holdings in them. At Procter & Gamble, 94 percent of the 401(k) plan is invested in company stock and at Abbott Laboratories, 90 percent.
Mr. Corzine, a former chairman of Goldman Sachs, repeatedly points out that money managers who run defined benefit plans cannot invest more than 10 percent of the fund in any one company. "If we believe such diversification requirements are appropriate for sophisticated financial firms, why would we leave ordinary investors exposed to such inordinate risks."
But the awkwardness of enforcing caps has some supporters of diversification looking for alternatives. 
Alicia H. Munnell, an economics professor at Boston College, has proposed denying employees the option of buying company stock in 401(k) plans in which the companies' matching contribution is in employer stock. She said, "If employees want to make imprudent investments, they should have to do it outside of the subsidized pension system."

HEADLINE: Peace as a River 

BYLINE:  By Alexander Frater; Alexander Frater's most recent book is "Chasing the Monsoon."

 BODY:
 THE RIVER'S TALE
A Year on the Mekong.
By Edward A. Gargan.
Illustrated. 332 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $26.95.
 EDWARD A. GARGAN'S yearlong journey from the Mekong's source in Tibet to the delta region of Vietnam, where the river empties into the South China Sea, was made to better understand a continent that had obsessed him since his college days. An opponent of United States military involvement in Southeast Asia, he had refused to register for the draft and spent two years in a federal prison (a compact freely entered into; being nearly blind in one eye, he knew the Army medics would have packed him straight home). A doctorate in medieval Chinese history eventually led not to academia but to a job with The New York Times and postings as a foreign correspondent in West Africa, China, India and Hong Kong. Though placed exactly where he wanted to be, Gargan felt, after 15 peripatetic years, a need to "weave together my passion for Asia with a longing to travel at my own speed, to wander as I wished, to find a river that would pull me through Asia. . . . That river is the Mekong."
Issuing from the 16,000-foot heights of the Tibetan Plateau, the Mekong plunges south through a geological wonderland of dizzying escarpments, hanging valleys and steep gorges for a distance Chinese geographers now calculate at just over 3,000 miles. In 1998, Gargan, knowing there was "no certain trail along the Mekong . . . no boat schedules, no bus routes, indeed, sometimes no roads," set out by car from a yak pasture 70 miles from the source. Almost four months later, down on the Chinese-Burmese border, he finally got afloat.
Up to 100 million people live around the Mekong watershed, many belonging to "fractured or dying cultures . . . societies that had turned on themselves or been savaged by outsiders." In Tibet, where Beijing dismisses 1,000 years of Buddhist piety as an "invidious splittist superstition," Gargan found a loathing for China so profound it could only be matched by China's own determination to destroy every vestige of Tibet's past. But there was some hope amid the gloom; he met up with a Tibetan friend who, having opened a successful carpet shop on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, now ran a busy hotel back home.
But "The River's Tale" really gets started farther downstream. In Laos, the Mekong, after a turbulent descent of 14,393 feet, finally relaxes into a waterway suitable for shipping. Yet it would continue to taunt Gargan; ahead lay impassable falls and rapids -- and developments that virtually closed the Mekong down. The unexpected emergence of shoals one morning, for example, halted all southbound traffic for the season.
By now, Gargan had arrived in the first of the countries on his tour on which Washington had waged war. The two million tons of bombs dropped on Laos, he discovered, still defined the aims and objectives of its leadership, a cabal of weary, reclusive, secretive old Marxists whose tunnel vision had reduced their land to penury. Its currency, the battered kip, was virtually worthless, its economy derelict, it exported little but opium (though plenty of that) and offered its people lives of unremitting torpor. Thailand lay, teasingly, just across the Mekong, and foreign travelers on the river couldn't help being perplexed by the contrasting political systems on show. One bank offered busy freeways, high-rise buildings, riverfront restaurants and, after dark, an affluent, electric glow in the sky, while the other featured only "scraggles of bamboo huts on stilts" and forgotten people staring "hopelessly at the bright lights just a quarter of a mile away."
When geographical hazards didn't interrupt Gargan's journey, people and politics did. In Laos, two men hired for a 48-hour passage abandoned him at a remote hamlet. Planning to get to Cambodia by boat, he was halted by a sign "announcing that no boats went to Cambodia. Never." When Gargan made it to Cambodia and attempted a similar crossing to Vietnam, an official at a sleepy riverine border post idly leafed through his passport, then tossed it back. "No Vietnam," he said. No boat, he meant. (Gargan, accepting the inevitable, went by plane instead).
Aboard a Cambodian pirogue, he learned that the river once teemed with dolphins; then the Vietnamese invasion force arrived, set up machine guns and shot them for sport. It was a bleak reminder of what the Khmer Rouge did to its own people. Virtually everyone he met had lost loved ones. "Almost every conversation I had had pivoted on memory and mourning." In Phnom Penh, like many tourists he visited one of the killing fields, saw a skull display and bought a $2 ticket to tour an extermination center, where a blackboard still bore the instruction: "While getting lashes or electrification, you shall not cry out at all."
Paranoia lingered everywhere. "No one is really safe," a businessman told him. Rick Droz, an American making wheelchairs for amputees (and married to Punya, whose entire family had been slaughtered), spoke of "a national post-traumatic stress syndrome," and a United Nations official described Cambodia as "a country bathed in violence." While this was the pragmatic foreign view, it was left to an elderly artist to express how the Cambodians themselves felt: "In the Khmer language we say 'broken down.' " Then, anxious that Gargan should understand, he added, "people's hearts and minds are broken down."
In good travel books, the reasons for making a journey often take precedence over the journey itself. At the heart of this one lies Gargan's portrait of a Western government that, while punishing its disaffected citizens back home, pursued a campaign of "murderous" imperialism abroad. The Mekong, floating him through civilizations wrecked as a consequence, becomes a ghostly tributary that, we come to realize, also flows directly from Gargan's past. Sacrificing two years of his life for a point of principle was a brave thing to do, and his brave Asian adventure provided the reassurance he needed to find personal peace. It's a remarkable story, grittily told.
It concludes, along with the river, in Vietnam. Saigon, now called Ho Chi Minh City, where America's doomed campaign began, was, ironically, in good shape, with upbeat people and new glass-walled office towers and hotels; even the old French opera house had been scrupulously restored. And down there in the delta, almost a year out from Tibet, when a boatman ferrying him toward one the Mekong's mouths suddenly shouted "Eastern Sea!" Gargan dipped in his hand and finally tasted saltwater.

HEADLINE: THE CLOSE READER; 
Danger: Romantic Love

BYLINE:  By Judith Shulevitz 

 BODY:
Why is it so hard to commit to someone or to get someone to commit to you or, for that matter, to stay in a committed relationship? Advice to the lovelorn may seem like a frivolous subject for this book review, but consider all the brow-furrowing books that ponder these questions. Public policy analysts fret about declining marriage rates. Evolutionary psychologists posit genetic motives for philandering. Biologists, historians, economists and anthropologists -- they all have their big theses. 
 None of them, however, helps us understand love as we experience it personally. No matter how much lip service we pay to the larger sweep of biology and history and to the thought that we no more control our fates than does plankton caught in the backwash of a cruise ship, few of us will avoid entirely those long and lonesome nights in which we blame ourselves for falling out of love or not taking it when it was offered or failing to find any at all. There are only three places to look for insight into such matters: women's magazines and other platitudinous divisions of the self-help industry; fiction, which in its quest for the specific shies away from the applicable; and the frequently maligned discipline of psychoanalysis, whose practitioners are among the few trained to deal with these issues concretely, one on one, as well as abstractly, and to measure success in the most modest increments of decreased misery. 
 Stephen A. Mitchell, who died two years ago at the unripe age of 54, was a leading American psychoanalytic theorist who was also devoted to the Sisyphean task of helping patients live life more fully. (Mitchell is best known for his contributions to the field of relational psychoanalysis, which holds, contra Freud, that people are the products of an innate need to interact with others, not of impersonal drives like sex and the death wish, and that our sense of self is woven into a web of intimate relations; it is not a thing unto itself.) "Can Love Last? The Fate of Romance Over Time" is Mitchell's posthumous contribution to the effort to give greater depth and texture to daily existence. In it, he ventures to explain why we allow our love lives to grow stale and dull. His answer is blunt and a little cruel. Love, he says, doesn't fade on its own. We do our best to kill it, even when we want it to live. Particularly when we want it to live, because we can't stand how naked and unsettled deep romantic longings can make us feel.
To understand how this works, you have to understand Mitchell's psychoanalytic habit of flipping everything we take for granted onto its head. Do we feel too safe in our relationships and fantasize about something more exciting? Mitchell argues that the real fantasy is our conviction of safety, a sort of theatrical backdrop that partners jury-rig so that each may avoid what lurks behind the familiar facade of the other. Husbands believe their wives are devoted. Wives believe their husbands are dependable. Each ignores evidence to the contrary. Both act in accordance with the other's beliefs. Each, when this collusive contrivance disintegrates, exclaims, "He/she is not the person I thought he/she was!" Mitchell calls this illusory deadening "a protective degradation, a defense against the vulnerability inherent in romantic love." 
Sex? Together we do what we can to strip it of enigma and power, since without a patina of dullness it is too destabilizing to sustain, involving as it does "multiple surrenders, relinquishments of self-control . . . immersion in the sensations and rhythms of the other." Aggression? Perfectly natural. Love makes us aggressive because it makes us scared, and we respond to threat with anger. The problem arises when we channel our aggression into subtly denigrating the other, which reduces his or her power over us but also his or her allure. Idealization? A very good thing, in Mitchell's opinion. Idealization exercises both the passions and the imagination and allows us to correct our blinkered vision so as to better see the true wonder of things. 
Mitchell, in short, is more Romantic than romantic. Like some methodologizing William Wordsworth, he places his faith in the redemptive capacity of the imagination. This is another of his ways of upending conventional thought. Freud thought fantasy clouded reality. Mitchell and the post-Freudian thinkers he draws upon say that fantasy -- in the sense of allowing oneself to perceive things or people as more beautiful or valuable than other people consider them to be -- is a window into a reality beyond the walls of ordinariness, walls we have built out of necessity, certainly, but also out of a self-defeating urge to lessen the intensity of authentic experience. 
But how are we to learn to keep our wattage high enough to tolerate this somewhat alarming-sounding authenticity? Here is where Mitchell's plain-spoken style grows slightly misty. Psychoanalysis seems to be required. You'd have to have a strong sense of self to withstand life as he envisions it -- and a dose of healthy narcissism, in order to forestall the withering fear of self-dramatization that might otherwise impede an embrace of life as a grand emotional adventure. Philosophical sophistication wouldn't hurt, either. Mitchell invokes Nietzsche, who thought that to live keenly we need to grasp life's tragic fragility, and even its futility. Nietzsche's image for tragic man or woman was of one who keeps building sand castles even while aware of the incoming tide.
It is one of the charming if unintended ironies of this book that Mitchell takes as his icon Nietzsche's builder of sand castles but avoids the philosopher's dark, Germanic tone. Most of the analytic case studies offered as examples end relatively well. Cheerful, open and humane -- you'd definitely have wanted him as your analyst -- Mitchell reminds us that psychoanalysis is at heart a hopeful profession, notwithstanding its minimal guarantees. After all, no one would do what analysts do, over the course of years and with results that are impossible to measure, without a deep faith in people's ability to make themselves happier. This devotion to self-improvement may explain why psychoanalysis became so popular in the United States, even as it remained marginal in Europe.
And yet personal progress is exactly what the tragic sense of things casts into doubt. Can we really do better? Or can we just learn to put up with everyday desperation with a more generous dollop of grace? Mitchell overestimated psychoanalysis if he thought that a psychoanalytic book on love (as opposed, say, to an actual analysis) would ever help anybody. On the other hand, he was probably right when he said that consistently overestimating is the more satisfying way to live.

HEADLINE: And Bear In Mind 

 BODY:
 (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

RAPTURE, by Susan Minot. (Knopf, $18.) The action of this brief novel is a single act of oral sex, but its life is found in memories of a doomed affair and the thoughts of Kay and Benjamin, its partners; they know each other well, but not what is happening between them.

TEPPER ISN'T GOING OUT, by Calvin Trillin. (Random House, $22.95.) A Manhattan driver, the hero of this novel, seeks the island's best parking spaces and occupies them, sitting and reading while the meter runs; his offhand concentration makes him a kind of Zen saint and leads to a struggle with a mayor whose rage for order suggests Rudolph W. Giuliani.

THE ENGLISHMAN'S DAUGHTER: A True Story of Love and Betrayal in World War I, by Ben Macintyre. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A remarkable excavation of an improbable incident, the concealment for 18 months by French villagers of some stranded British soldiers, one of whom fathered a local woman the author met in 1997.

LAZY B: Growing Up on a Cattle Ranch in the American Southwest, by Sandra Day O'Connor and H. Alan Day. (Random House, $24.95.) An engaging portrait, by the Supreme Court justice and her brother, of a distinctive, vanished way of life on 250 square miles without electricity or running water but plenty of grit.

JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES. Volume Three: Fighting for Freedom, 1937-1946, by Robert Skidelsky. (Viking, $34.95.) The final installment of the life of the most influential economist since Adam Smith, who gave his all in Britain's struggle for survival in World War II, negotiating finances with the United States and trying to save Britain's market economy.

SERVANTS OF THE MAP: Stories, by Andrea Barrett. (Norton, $24.95.) A collection of stories complete in themselves but linked by threads of association or neighborhood or interest or family into a kind of imaginative collaboration that covers most of the last two centuries, always inhabited by characters who share a passionate interest in trying to figure out how things work.

MRS. PAINE'S GARAGE: And the Murder of John F. Kennedy, by Thomas Mallon. (Pantheon, $22.) A journalistic inquiry into Ruth Paine, the woman who welcomed Marina Oswald -- and sometimes her husband, Lee -- into her suburban Dallas home in 1963; it offers a novel theory about the antecedents of the assassination.

10TH GRADE, by Joseph Weisberg. (Random House, $23.95.) A first novel, told in the voice and mentality of Jeremy Reskin, a high school sophomore whose perception is sometimes wasted on his ordinariness, but who renders well the supreme importance of social distinctions and the misery of teenage self-analysis.

THE LOVE OF STONES, by Tobias Hill. (Picador USA, $25.) An international thriller by a British poet, concerning a spectacular medieval jewel, a modern Englishwoman who is galloping after it as hard as she can, and two Jewish merchants who arrived in Britain long ago with gems sewn in their cloaks.

GRAPHIC: Photos (Dinah Minot Hubley; William Bodenschatz)
