HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Monsey; 
Low Inventory, Lots of Kugel, Some Deer

BYLINE:  By CHERYL PLATZMAN WEINSTOCK 

 BODY:
IT has been just four weeks since Chana Rabinowitz; her husband, Arie, an investment banker at L. H. Financial in Manhattan; and their three children moved from Flatbush, Brooklyn, to the hilly Rockland County hamlet of Monsey and already they feel quite comfortable here.
 "There are so many reasons we enjoy it," Mrs. Rabinowitz said. "I have my dream house that has everything I've always wanted, and we have a quiet, more serene style of life that's not as hectic as it used to be. I have a forest in my backyard where I often see squirrels and deer." 
 But Mrs. Rabinowitz said the best part of her family's move has been the reception they got when they arrived in the hamlet, which is in the town of Ramapo. "Many neighbors came by to give a hand, and others bought us challah for Shabbos, candies and kugels. It was amazing. This is what I call a warm welcome. It's a great feeling when you come to a neighborhood, and everyone is happy to see you." 
That the Rabinowitzes moved to Monsey in search of a different lifestyle is no accident. Mrs. Rabinowitz's best friend moved there a year ago and, for months, she bent her ear with happy stories of the unique, small, close-knit Orthodox Jewish and Hasidic community. Many Monsey residents said this is the way they found their way to the hamlet.
"The shopping is also perfect," Mrs. Rabinowitz said. "It's very convenient and well organized into shopping centers. I don't have to circle around for a parking spot and can get my errands done in half the time it used to take."
One resident who has been in Monsey far longer is Shimon Mendlowitz, who moved to the community with his parents in 1950. "What used to be the suburbs of Monsey is now the middle of Monsey because it's grown so much," said Mr. Mendlowitz, owner of Monsey Glatt Kosher Supermarket and Wesley Kosher Supermarket. And, indeed, to many residents the boundaries between Monsey and surrounding neighborhoods can be vague. 
"I remember when Monsey was mostly just bungalow colonies with few year-round residents and I used to help my father bring kosher meat here from his butcher store in Williamsburg," Mr. Mendlowitz said. 
Christopher P. St. Lawrence, Ramapo's supervisor, said growth has been rapid in recent years. "In Monsey, things are booming," he said. "There are very few vacant stores and a great demand for housing. We have a lot of large families moving in and what they're doing is buying small Capes and splits, tearing them down and building larger, beautiful homes that have been a benefit to the community."
Monsey's blend of rural ambience, diverse housing stock, eclectic shopping from ornamental silver and chocolates to bagels and pizza, and a selection of more than 200 synagogues and 50 yeshivas, including the 1,600-student Yeshiva of Spring Valley, has created a strong housing demand, said Chaya Rosenberg, owner of Rosenberg Realty in Monsey.
"But the problem is that there's a tremendous lack of inventory here," she said. "A good house, priced right, sells right away. In my neighborhood, I might have five customers for one house."
Esther Ingber, owner of Esther Ingber Realty of New Hempstead, said while the pool of housing for sale is shallow, it is nonetheless wide. "There's something here for everyone's budget," she said. "Right now there are homes on the market ranging from $265,000 to $950,000, and, occasionally, someone can even find a small three-bedroom, one-bath ranch, Cape Cod or semiattached home that needs lots of t.l.c. for between $200,000 to $250,000."
From there, Mrs. Rosenberg said, three-to-four-bedroom bilevels, split levels and ranches that may be in need of repair can range up to $350,000. Larger homes of similar style of 2,600 to 3,000 square feet with four and five bedrooms on a half acre range from $375,000 to $450,000.
Five-, six- and seven-bedroom 3,700-square-foot homes on an acre with more amenities are priced from $450,000 to $650,000, while custom-built colonials with multiple kitchens for keeping kosher and preparing Passover meals, great rooms and three-car garages can reach $950,000.
About half the single-family homes in Monsey are renter occupied, said Ramapo's supervisor. Rentals, which Mrs. Rosenberg said were "very hard to find," range from $1,800 to $3,000 a month, depending on size and amenities.
The boom in Monsey's popularity has officials trying to balance varying concerns. "We're drawing up a master plan," Mr. St. Lawrence said, "to address the housing shortage in the hamlet. We're cognizant that we want to keep a certain suburban ambience to Monsey and don't want every space built upon. But we're hoping to build town houses so our seniors and young families with no children yet will have affordable places to live." 
The supervisor is also planning to revitalize Monsey's downtown shopping district by calling for a new shopping plaza on Orchard Street near Main Street. "More neighborhood shopping will enhance the area and take away bottlenecks on Main Street," Mr. St. Lawrence said. "We're looking to make it a showcase in Monsey by building retail space on the first floor, office space on the second and housing on the third."
BESIDES the town's plans for the area, Monsey residents have also been busy putting the finishing touches on improvements. Two and a half years ago they raised $5 million to build the Mikvah of Rockland County, a stone and stucco building with 60 rooms and eight ritual bathing pools for women. 
Though most residents of Monsey send their children to yeshivas, the hamlet is within the 9,200-student East Ramapo school district. "We're one of the most unique school districts in New York State because we have to accommodate two different communities," said Jason P. Friedman, the superintendent, "but I think for the most part, we do a good job." 
The school budget allocates $20 million to provide transportation, special education and remedial services to its 13,000 private school students residing in the district. "We'll go as far as we can for them as long as it meets the litmus test of being legal," Mr. Friedman said. 
Mr. Friedman said the school tax increase has been under 2 percent each year for the last five years because "we're cognizant of the fact that large families pay large tuition bills." He added, "We've done well for the most part, but every now and then there's been a bump in the road," an example of which is the recent $64.4 million bond referendum proposed in December, which was earmarked for school expansion and a full-day kindergarten.
Dr. Susan Gordon, the school board president, said: "The bond was defeated by more than 800 votes, mostly from the polls where Orthodox voters cast their ballots. Out of 17,000 voters, 5,000 showed up. If more public school parents voted, we could easily have won."
Nathan Rothschild, fire commissioner of Monsey, is the sole Orthodox member of the nine-person school board. He said: "The private school community felt that the timing of the bond was wrong, the amount of it was wrong and on an economic basis we found the bond too much of an onus to accommodate at this time."
Mr. Friedman said the amount of the bond might be reduced and the measure reintroduced. In the meantime, he said, the district is continuing to make academic strides despite its space constraints. "In 1999, 30 percent of our fourth graders met the reading standards; in 2000, 50 percent of them did, and, in 2001, 57 percent did," he said. "That's nearly a 100 percent increase in three years."
The sprawling school district is economically and ethnically diverse; its students represent more than 40 different nationalities. The district has a prekindergarten school; five primary schools covering kindergarten through third grade, including two in Monsey; five intermediate schools for Grades 4 to 6, one of which is in Monsey; two middle schools, one in Monsey; and two high schools: Spring Valley High School and Ramapo High School, on the Monsey border.
This year, two high school students enrolled in the district's decade-old science research program, which teams pupils with medical researchers and scientists, are Intel Science Talent Search semifinalists. The College Boards of last year's graduating class were 487 in verbal and 495 in math, very close to the state averages.
The town's recreation department tries to meet the needs of Monsey residents. Edwin Lockwood, Ramapo's director of parks and recreation, said: "We offer lots of Sunday programs for only girls or boys so our Orthodox population can participate in them. We also keep the 36-acre Manny Weldler Park in Monsey open till midnight on Saturday nights, and its vending machines stock kosher snacks." The park has eight lighted tennis courts, four handball courts, four ball fields and a playground.
In addition to the 10-acre Besen Park in Monsey, which has a small ball field, basketball court and a playground, the hamlet's residents can use 300 acres of town parks and other facilities. The 30-acre Reisman Sports Complex of Eugene Levy Memorial Park is scheduled to open this summer. It will have several ball fields, as well as volleyball, tennis and basketball courts.
D ESPITE all the new construction, Monsey is still home to several older businesses. They include the 160,000-square-foot American Tack and Hardware Company, a manufacturer of decorative switch plates and a distributor of accent lights and plant hardware, which moved to Monsey in the late 1960's and employs nearly 7 percent of its residents.
The first church in the hamlet, the Monsey Christian Reformed Church, was built in 1827. The congregation moved in 1869 to Route 306, and its building there was recently taken over by the New Hope Christian Church. St. Zita's Villa, a Roman Catholic convent that has been in Monsey since the early 20th century, operates an assisted living home there for about 60 women.
When the Erie Railroad came through in 1841 and established a station in the hamlet, the stop became known as Monsey, taking its name from Munsee, chief of the Lenape Indians, who settled the area, said Craig H. Long, Ramapo town historian. Monsey got a post office in 1846. The world's largest printing press for the blind opened in the hamlet in 1927 in a converted carriage house to print the Matilda Ziegler Magazine for the Blind. It operated until 1965, when it transferred operations to Cincinnati.
Monsey was basically an agricultural community until the construction of the Tappan Zee Bridge in 1955 increased its access to New York City.
In 1990, the Viznitz, a Hasidic sect, created Kaser, a tiny village within the hamlet, so they could build denser housing for their large families. About 35 percent of its homes are three- and four-family dwellings. The 3,316-person village contracts with Ramapo for most services.

The turnpike was eventually built around the hamlet. Ten years later, however, the Erie Railroad was able to come through. Mr. Long said construction crews filled in a portion of the swamp and laid their iron rails straight through the area. HEADLINE: Long Island Museums Retrench in the Face of a Flat Economy 

BYLINE:  By PHYLLIS BRAFF 

 BODY:
THE financial shock waves felt by museums across the country in the past year have affected Long Island institutions too. Endowment income is down; proceeds from once-popular benefit events are falling short of objectives; foundation and corporate support is disappointing; and competition for government grants is tighter.
 As a result, exhibitions have been canceled or postponed; jobs have been cut; and publications have been curtailed. While all museum administrators are concerned, the direct effects and subsequent pain varies among the institutions. 
 Administrators say the situation has forced them to look for ways to become more relevant to local communities by planning new initiatives. They are also trying to make more use of their permanent collections and to attract more individual supporters.
"We want to be sure the museum continues to be part of what the community needs," said Trudy Kramer, director of the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton.
After the Sept. 11 attacks, museum administrators say, their audiences have grown. Some suggested this was because people want to stay closer to home.
The administrators also said the numbers of Long Island school children visiting local museums have increased since the September attacks. In Roslyn Harbor, the Nassau County Museum of Art has instituted special Monday openings to accommodate the waiting list of classes.
"The school visitation has been fabulous," said Jacqueline Day, director of the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages in Stony Brook. "And for our current exhibition, 'Norman Rockwell: Drawing the American Dream,' all available school slots were booked immediately."
Museum education departments have benefited from this development; when reduced budgets have resulted in job cuts, other positions have suffered.
At the Heckscher Art Museum in Huntington, no jobs have been lost, but a wage freeze is in effect and the museum has cut the pay for two positions. One is that of Beth Levinthal, the museum's director, who said she volunteered for the cut, and the other is that of a consultant.
Production expenditures for exhibitions and mailings have also been trimmed. Ms. Levinthal attributed the general belt-tightening to reduced corporate donations.
The Heckscher's other economy-related disappointment is a big one. Two federal grants designating $6 million for its building expansion are stalled in Congress. But the Town of Huntington has allocated $37,000 to bring items from the museum's study collection and other materials to children and adults who cannot visit the museum, including those in hospitals and nursing homes.
The Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages is facing a bleak cash flow from endowment investments, which in the past have provided 45 percent of its operating budget, Ms. Day said. The staff has been reduced, no publications are contemplated this year, and it may become necessary to cut the number of annual exhibitions from the present total of 11, she added.
"We are trying new things, like programming for Girl Scouts and Boy Scouts," Ms. Day said. "And we are considering ways to have special fund-raising events that relate to highlights of our collection."
The Nassau County museum has canceled "Eighteenth-Century French Splendors: The Paramours of the Kings," which was scheduled to open in May, and would have consisted mainly of works from European lenders. Constance Schwartz, the museum's director, said trans-Atlantic shipping and insurance expenses had become too high.
"It was going to be impossible to make this happen because of the costs involved and because potential lenders to the show have become reluctant to ship valuable art," she said.
Facing a $60,000 cut from foundations and sponsors, as well as likely reductions in federal and state grants, Ms. Schwartz said that she expected to plan more benefits, but that she still might have to change the exhibition schedule. Financial uncertainties, particularly the extent of Nassau County's contribution, may delay a building restoration project, she said.
At the Islip Art Museum, the National Heritage Trust Fund has provided grants to pay for improvements to the historic structures that house the galleries. But Mary Lou Cohalan, the museum director, said she was worried about the future availability of such grants, and about tighter local government budgets, which would affect the institution's maintenance needs.
The annual budgets for basic expenses are covering operations at Long Island's two university-based museums, the Hofstra Museum in Hempstead and the Hillwood Art Museum on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville, officials there said.
But the Hofstra museum's director, David C. Christman, said he was worried about raising money needed for an exhibition on winter-sporting themes in 17th-century Dutch paintings planned for 2004. The show would include works borrowed from overseas, and rising insurance costs for trans-Atlantic shipments may prove prohibitive, he said.
At the Hillwood, Barry Stern, the director, said he was writing grant applications for education initiatives, including expanded after-school programs. 
The Guild Hall in East Hampton and the Parrish have also found their budgets squeezed. Officials there said they began to feel the effects of the economic downturn early last year when usually popular benefit events failed to meet goals.
At Guild Hall, Ruth Appelhof, the director, said an exhibition of sculpture by John Chamberlain had been postponed because transporting the pieces from major collections in the United States would have been too costly this year. As a substitute, an exhibition from the permanent collection will be mounted, she said. She added that a building expansion was also postponed.
The Parrish has not canceled any exhibitions, because it was hoping to close for a major expansion project. Those plans are on hold awaiting construction approval from Southampton officials and because of continuing opposition from some local residents.
Ms. Kramer said the museum was changing its fund-raising strategy. While it once had focused on holding large benefit events, it now was hoping to woo local residents to become members and donors, and provide continuing support.
One program designed for "young professionals in the community," she said, was a five-part series in which small groups will be taken to the storage vaults to see works there. The works will then be discussed by the museum curator, "in the context of American art history," she said.

HEADLINE: Batteries Included 

BYLINE:  By ALLAN RICHTER 

 BODY:
REID GOLDSMITH, a 47-year-old court reporter who lives in Syosset and works in Queens, used to start his day by watching commuters off the night shift wade bleary-eyed from the Hicksville train station platform to their parked cars. Before long, Mr. Goldsmith learned to identify the cars so he could position his station car, a gas-guzzling former police cruiser he bought at auction, to swoop into one of their spots and begin his train ride to Jamaica.
 But over the years Mr. Goldsmith found that the strategy isn't foolproof. In his worst months, he amassed as many as four parking tickets for illegal parking at the station. Mr. Goldsmith talked about the accumulation of tickets -- at $25 each -- as if it were a nasty cigarette habit. He swore the latest would be his last. 
 "That's a thing of the past," he said the other day at the station. "It's a beautiful thing." 
There's good reason for Mr. Goldsmith's newfound confidence. His new station car comes with a rare perk: a reserved spot in the station's parking lot.
That spot also comes with a battery charger. Mr. Goldsmith's new car is powered solely by electricity, and he is the first of about 30 commuting Long Islanders expected to trade gas for electricity during rush hour in the next few years. 
Mr. Goldsmith and other participants in an experimental program just getting underway at seven suburban rail stations will lease their cars for $199 a month for 34 months. They will receive a $21 rebate on their monthly L.I.R.R. tickets from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and a $40 monthly insurance credit from the New York Power Authority. A wall-mounted corded battery charger installed at their homes is free; so are electric charges at the Hicksville and Huntington stations and five other stations: White Plains, Chappaqua and Brewster in Westchester County, Nanuet in Rockland and Little Neck in Queens.
"When you subtract the $20 and $40, you're really paying $140 a month," said Hank Liebowitz, 39, a trust and estate attorney who lives in Woodbury and was expecting to pick up his electric car last week. "I certainly can't get a new car for $140 a month that includes free fuel. It's too good a deal to pass up."
Called the Think City, the Ford Motor Company car is a two-seater that can go about 50 miles on a single charge. No large families for this vehicle, and no extended trips. The Think City is meant only for short jaunts to and from the train station and weekend runs to the market.
"I'm excited by it, but I'm also a realist," Mr. Goldsmith said. "It's just not practical without another car. They need to extend the range a little and add some seats."
Statewide, 100 Think City cars are available in the pilot program. Despite a wave of initial interest last fall -- program sponsors approved about 350 applicants from the seven counties -- only 41 commuters had put down deposits as of last week. On the Island, 17 of 30 cars are accounted for. (Commuters can apply at www.nypa .gov/ev and www.thinkmobility.com or call (800) 252-4221.)
Sponsors blamed the lukewarm response on an off-season introduction of a brand new concept -- few cars are leased in the winter -- but some applicants who considered leasing the car said they backed out because of the car's small size and high insurance costs.
"I happened to have liked the idea; my wife didn't," said Glenn Pollock, 47, a printer from Roslyn who said he was quoted an annual $1,800 insurance rate.
But the $2 million electric car program's main sponsors, the state Department of Transportation, the federal Department of Energy, the New York Power Authority, the Long Island Power Authority and Ford, hope the concept will catch on and are lauding the car's environmental impact and savings: one charge costs no more than $1.50, less than the cost of 50 miles' worth of gasoline for all but the most fuel-efficient of conventional cars.
Besides the cost benefits, consumers who have embraced the car seem to enjoy being pioneers without the hefty premium that typically comes with being an early adopter.
"I always wanted to get an environmentally friendly car, but the electric cars that are on the market are too expensive," said Chi Cheng, 40, an electrical engineer who lives in New Hyde Park, commutes from Little Neck to Manhattan and is awaiting delivery of his Think City.
"I think Honda and Toyota are cheaper than they used to be, but they're still in the mid-20's," Mr. Cheng said, referring to hybrid electric vehicles that use gasoline part of the time. "For that price you can get yourself a pretty decent conventional car."
The Ford car, which is not for sale yet, is a Rorschach test on wheels. Some said it resembles a Volkswagen Beetle whose front and rear ends have been lopped off. Other images came to mind. "It does look a little like the car that 20 clowns get out of at the circus," Mr. Liebowitz said. "Hopefully people won't laugh at me."
Last week, Mr. Goldsmith and his thermoplastic-paneled car turned heads and elicited smiles and looks of bewilderment around town. Even Mr. Goldsmith poked a little fun, saying his dark blue Think City with the silver roof looked like the older cousin of his children's plastic Cozy Coupes -- those familiar red and yellow toy cars that are ubiquitous in suburban playrooms and backyards.
When the weather warms, Mr. Goldsmith said he would try to work the car into the magic act that he performs part-time for kids' parties.
Despite the car's appearance, most drivers interviewed were impressed by how the 2,075-pound Think City picked up speed quickly and navigated tight turns. Mr. Goldsmith's wife, Elizabeth, said the Think City's bucket seats were more comfortable than those in the family's other cars. And without a traditional motor, the car rolls along in virtual silence until it hits higher speeds and whirs in a high pitch like a golf cart. (The car's quietness made Mr. Goldsmith worry that pedestrians might not hear it coming.)
Mr. Goldsmith was extra cautious on his first outings. Setting out on his Sunday errands, he carefully plotted a course to avoid running the electric charge too low. First he headed to the most distant point, a medical supply store a few miles from home, then on to a more local loop that included stops at a drugstore and a pet store where he bought a cricket lunch for the family frog.
"It's changing my habits," he said. "I have to plan my trips more because it's got a shorter range. If I go 30 miles one way I'm not going to make it home. Planning is not as relaxing as just getting in the car and going."
It turned out that Mr. Goldsmith's planning was unnecessary. After his errands, the in-dash meter showed he had run down only about 27 percent of the car's power.
Running his Sunday errands, Mr. Goldsmith had no reservations about driving alongside mammoth S.U.V.'s on local roads. But the next morning, safety concerns dictated his decision to avoid his usual Long Island Expressway route to the train station and take Woodbury Road instead.
"They say top speed is about 60 miles per hour, but to tell you the truth I don't want to try this on the highway," he said. "It's crash-tested to 35 miles per hour, which is fine, but if you get hit by one of those Explorers or Excursions, I don't know how it will handle."
Insurance companies are apparently uncertain as well. Despite the sturdy steel and aluminum frame that Ford says makes the car safe, consumers in the pilot program found no breaks on insurance. Ford set up a program through the Hartford Fire Insurance Company for the electric car, but some consumers said a new policy creates more headaches than adding the electric car to an existing policy.
Mr. Liebowitz said Geico, which insures the 10-year-old Nissan 300ZX that he now uses for his hops from home to the train station, first balked at the idea of insuring an electric car but then relented.
"The cost of the insurance is about the same as I was paying for my Nissan," Mr. Liebowitz said of the roughly $1,200 yearly outlay. "I initially thought it would be cheaper since the Nissan is a sports car, which you always pay higher rates on, and this is a car that can't go more than 50 miles per hour."
But a drive around town soon helped Mr. Goldsmith forget his insurance worries. He relished the attention from gaping passersby and his role as grassroots environmental ambassador.
During dinner at an International House of Pancakes the other night, Mr. Goldsmith and his new car found themselves the subjects of a homework paper after two girls in the next booth overheard him discussing the vehicle with his youngest son, Daniel, 11.
At traffic lights on Woodbury Road, Mr. Goldsmith was happy to roll down his window and answer questions from gawking motorists in adjacent lanes. And parked at the Plainview Centre strip mall, he let strollers sit in the car's bucket seats.
"The free parking spot at the train station is just a parking spot," Mr. Goldsmith said. "I'm really hoping that this program goes somewhere. It does feel good to be at the forefront because maybe I can enlighten some people. Everywhere I go I extol the virtues of that car. There are a lot of things that need to be worked out to make it a fundamental main car instead of a secondary car, but wherever I go I say, 'You should try it.' "
Mr. Goldsmith's mood dampened when he pulled into his new railroad parking space at the Town of Oyster Bay garage across the street from the station, where about a dozen spots were allotted for the electric car drivers. Mr. Goldsmith found most of the spots open, but an electric feed to the chargers hadn't been installed. 
Then he spotted a rusty Volkswagen Jetta and a red Ford Focus squeezed into two of the tiny electric car spots. "This is the other thing I'm worried about: that cars that aren't electric are going to take spots from cars that are," he said.
If that weren't enough, Mr. Goldsmith soon found the electric car spaces challenged by Al and Ann Loffredo, a couple in their 80's who pulled up for their part-time jobs as tax collectors. The electric car spots were taken from spaces that had been designated for taxpayers, and the prospect of hearing more complaints from irate residents didn't sit well with the Loffredos.
The Think City rollout comes as New York lawmakers, environmentalists and car makers debate how electric and hybrid electric-gas car use will be legislated in the state. Like Massachusetts and Vermont, New York had planned to begin requiring the sale of electric cars in the state by 2003. But New York is considering delaying the requirement until 2007.
"The governor was coming under pressure from the manufacturers with the claim that they couldn't meet the quota and that there wasn't demand for it," said Steve Levy, a state assemblyman from Holbrook. "Whether that's true or not, we feel it's important to provide incentives to increase demand."
Last month, Mr. Levy, a Democrat, introduced a bill that would grant electric and hybrid car drivers access to H.O.V. lanes, free tolls in the state for two years and sales tax exemptions.
Without improvements in range, those additional perks may be needed to stimulate electric car demand. John Casesa, a Merrill Lynch auto industry analyst, said he doesn't believe cars like the Think City will find much of an American audience. Gas prices are too low and the Think City car, with its Scandinavian minimalist design, is too unfamiliar. 
"It's a nice idea," Mr. Casesa said, "but there are alternatives that get you pretty close in economy and emissions that require much less adjustment on the consumer's part."
If the electric cars fail to take hold, commuters like Mr. Goldsmith and Mr. Liebowitz can always go back to spotting the parked cars of commuters coming off their night shifts. "I suppose three years from now," Mr. Liebowitz said, "I'm back to memorizing license plates."

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
Hiring?You're Everyone's Best Friend

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
CYNTHIA MCKAY, the chief executive of Le Gourmet Gift Basket Inc. in Castle Rock, Colo., is being stalked.
 Her pursuers, however, are not love-struck loners. They are out-of-work executives and other professionals. 
 They pester her with calls, asking for job leads or referrals. They accost her in her company's parking lot, entreating her to look at their resumes. One man even cornered her on an airplane for three hours to promote his job skills. 
Some of the supplicants are friends. Some are acquaintances. Some are strangers who found her name in a newspaper clipping. They are all looking hungrily for one thing: a job. "Honestly, I'm feeling victimized," said Ms. McKay, whose company has more than 400 distributorships nationwide. "I've never endured this level of harassment."
Business specialists say the recession has created a new, onerous chore for corporate executives: coping with more intrusive, insistent pleas for work than ever before.
"All the rules of networking have flown out the window," said Andrea Nierenberg, president of the Nierenberg Group, a consulting firm in Manhattan. "It's as if they've forgotten their manners."
Some job-seeking former managers don't bother to hide their desperation, as they might have in the past. Marian Salzman, director for strategy and planning at Euro RSCG Worldwide, a marketing communications firm, says an acquaintance recently left a voice mail message that began, "I recognize you are busy, but the courtesy of an introduction to your human resources department is the minimum I demand."
Before Ms. Salzman could return the call, she received a second message from the man, who was seeking a high-level marketing position. "Are you aware that my wife does not work, that my mortgage is significant and that this is the third time I have been out of work in the last five years?" he asked.
Ms. Salzman, who did not submit his name for consideration, said, "That's not the kind of message which inspires confidence."
The most shocking aspect of the trend, experts say, is the experience level of the people who most often commit these networking faux pas: they are not scrappy, young executives, but senior-level ones who should know better.
One of their ploys, Ms. Nierenberg said, is to send mass e-mail messages to everyone in their Rolodexes announcing their availability. She herself recently received a message addressed to more than 25 people that read: "Dear Friend: Happy holidays. I'm still looking for a job. Please forward all of your contacts A.S.A.P."
"This really violates basic networking 101," she said, which emphasizes the personal touch.
Another technique is the friendly call to an executive who happens to be a long-lost acquaintance. The job hunter asks her how she is doing and wonders if she has any job openings or advice.
David Collins, a lawyer at Garfunkel, Wild & Travis in Great Neck, N.Y., says he has been getting at least two such calls a week over the last eight months. He recently received one from someone he didn't remember from the Widener University School of Law in Delaware, who opened the conversation with, "How's it going?" and was soon asking for help in finding a job.
"If you ask me, that's a really weaselly way to go about getting help," Mr. Collins said.
THE self-promotion of some down-on-their-luck managers can be inelegant. Mark Scott, vice president for marketing at HomeBanc, a mortgage company in Atlanta, recalls how an out-of-work business acquaintance set up a breakfast appointment with him, then arrived 30 minutes late and split the check with him. Afterward, she called him every morning with greetings like, "Hi, sweetie, it's me," and requests for any job leads.
The approach backfired. "I wouldn't subject this obnoxious woman on anyone," said Mr. Scott, who fretted that his reputation would suffer if she dropped his name in interviews. He says he prefers to help people he meets at local marketing association functions or at networking dinners he sets up periodically at local bars and restaurants.
"I like people to develop longstanding relationships with me before they ask me for something," he said.
He has a soft spot for colleagues who have shown an interest in his career as well as their own by giving him advice or talking up his expertise. "If you're in it just to help yourself, it's not effective," he said.
THE worst sin that an out-of-work manager can commit, specialists say, is to become a nuisance. After Dane Madsen, chief executive of YellowPages.com, an online business directory, received a resume from an executive he had met recently, he promised to send it along to his chief operating officer. Three days later, the man called him back and complained that he hadn't heard from that officer, who was out of town on a business trip. The job hunter, who was seeking a high-level position in the company's project development department, followed up with more phone calls to Mr. Madsen and sent him more copies of his resume.
"At that point, I wrote the guy off completely," Mr. Madsen said. "If you don't have a little respect for my time, forget it."
Ms. McKay of Le Gourmet Gift Basket says the eagerness can take almost comic forms. Recently, when she invited one unemployed lawyer to send her resume, it arrived in a picture frame. The woman, who was seeking a position as an in-house lawyer, also sent her a postcard from her vacation. It included a big smiling face and the woman's signature.
"It was as if she was my best friend," Ms. McKay said. "I threw the card right in the trash. It was beyond stupid."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Some Municipal Bonds Leave a Corporate Taste

BYLINE:  By ABBY SCHULTZ 

 BODY:
WHEN Kmart filed for bankruptcy protection last month, more than $218 million in municipal bonds across the country went into default.
 The troubled bonds belong to a class of quirky securities that are issued by municipalities but depend on corporations for their stream of payments to holders. When corporate revenue falters, the bonds can decline in value. A. G. Edwards & Sons, the investment firm, calls them "corporate munis" and includes in the category industrial development bonds, like those issued for Kmart, as well those to finance construction projects for airlines. Such bonds have fallen in price since Sept. 11. 
 Many investors who thought they were holding safe, steady municipal bonds have had some "very unpleasant surprises" recently, said Brian Tournier, fixed-income analyst at A. G. Edwards.
In Kmart's case, many municipalities sold the bonds from 1981 to last November, according to Thomson Financial. They were to be used to build stores for Kmart, repaying investors with revenue from Kmart lease payments. In 1993, for instance, the Industrial Development Authority in Liberty, Mo., sold $3.9 million in municipal revenue bonds on behalf of Kmart, with a coupon of 5.65 percent. The bonds last traded on Jan. 29 at 48 cents on the dollar, giving them a yield to maturity of 18.54 percent. For the moment, payments on the bonds have stopped, and their value will depend on the details of Kmart's emergence from bankruptcy.
Generally, prices of municipal industrial development bonds can fluctuate far more wildly than those of traditional munis with the same ratings, Mr. Tournier said. "I have spent countless hours on the phone with brokers and in some cases with individual clients who own these bonds," he said, "and in most cases they don't understand these bonds are backed by corporations."
More than $6 billion in corporate municipal bonds are sold annually. They reward investors with yields that are roughly one-tenth of a percentage point higher than those of most traditional munis with comparable ratings, Mr. Tournier said.
Fitch, a bond rating agency, found that the default rate in municipal industrial development bonds was 15 percent over a 20-year period ending in 1999; for traditional municipal bonds, it was only 1.5 percent. "Basically, industrial development bonds are corporate bonds in municipal clothing," said David T. Litvack, a managing director at Fitch.
In 2001, the rate of corporate bond defaults was 12.9 percent, a record, according to Fitch. That compares with 5.1 percent in 2000.
A. G. Edwards estimates that investors in high-quality corporate munis take on as much as 11 times more credit risk than investors in munis with equivalent credit ratings.
Because of the deals' structure, the corporate guarantor often isn't immediately obvious. In March 1999, for instance, Perry County, Miss., issued $23.6 million in pollution control bonds for Leaf River Forest Products. The bonds were actually guaranteed by Georgia-Pacific, the forest and paper products company.
"What you don't know unless you have the offering document in hand is that it's secured by Georgia-Pacific," Mr. Tournier said. The bonds' value has fallen in recent weeks on worry that Moody's Investors Service will lower Georgia-Pacific's rating to below investment grade.
BONDS to finance construction of airline projects, like hangars or baggage facilities, have been hurt by a combination of problems. The sector was weakening as the economy began faltering last year, said Mitchell L. Conery, co-manager of the Delaware National High-Yield Municipal Bond fund. 
Then the Sept. 11 attacks, which led to a sharp reduction in air travel, sent prices of such bonds tumbling. Yields on some of the weakest credits, including those sold for projects backed by revenue from US Airways and United Airlines, a part of UAL, went as high as 16 percent. A revenue bond for a United Airlines project at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago fell from a price of 103 cents on the dollar and a yield to maturity of 6.025 percent on Sept. 10 to 45 cents on the dollar with a yield to maturity of 16.4 percent as of Tuesday, said Patrick P. Coyne, co-manager of the Delaware fund. The bond matures in 2016.
To protect against credit risk from any single issue, the fund takes various measures, including holding about 100 different bonds at one time. It did not protect itself against Sept. 11, however. "How do you model a terrorist attack?" Mr. Coyne sad. "You just can't." 
Delaware High-Yield still returned 5.36 percent in 2001, beating the average of 4.95 percent for all high-yield municipal debt funds tracked by Lipper. General municipal debt funds returned 3.9 percent last year, Lipper said. 
Generally, corporate municipal bonds may gain in price as the economy strengthens, but Mr. Conery is cautious. "We don't think we'll see a gangbuster recovery by any means," he said.

HEADLINE: The Changing Look Of the New Harlem 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
SO the president of the Abyssinian Development Corporation arrives at the Starbucks on 125th Street to meet with the president of the Forest City Ratner Companies before visiting Harlem Center, their joint venture across Malcolm X Boulevard. They are impressed by the pace of construction at the Gap overlooking the Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Office Building and former Hotel Theresa.
 This is Harlem, 2002. 
 Parcel by parcel, uptown is being remade, fueled in part by the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone Development Corporation and the state's Metropolitan Economic Revitalization Fund. While it remains to be seen whether the momentum of the late 90's can be sustained amid recession and civic trauma, there are enough projects in the pipeline to guarantee, for now, that the transformation will continue.
"This gives people an opportunity to shop in their own neighborhoods and it generates jobs and opportunities for more revenue to come back into the community," said C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president. "That's not a bad thing." 
The change is not to everyone's liking, however, by any means. Tensions can be keen when racial and ethnic differences are added to the issues inherent in redeveloping any well-established enclave: the economic alienation and displacement of longtime businesses and residents, the tilt of power from community groups to large corporations and the loss or alteration of beloved landmarks. Complicating matters is the frustration felt by local entrepreneurs who sustained Harlem during its leanest years and now watch government subsidies flow to outside developers and businesses.
"The people who are benefiting the most are those who got here last and who have the least need," said Councilman Bill Perkins, who represents central Harlem. "There's a growing, small entrepreneurial movement that is screaming about the unaffordability of commercial spaces. This we hear loudly in Harlem."
But for better or worse -- or both -- the die seems to have been cast. On its key commercial thoroughfares, at least, uptown is looking more and more like the rest of Manhattan.
Harlem may even be getting its first major national corporate headquarters with the planned arrival of Edison Schools Inc. at Duke Ellington Circle, in an office building alongside a new Museum for African Art.
This is not the only cultural complex being planned. The Apollo Theater at 253 West 125th Street may create a performing arts center that encompasses the neighboring Victoria Theater. Meanwhile, it has closed for two months in the first phase of a $50 million renovation.
Across 125th Street from the renovated Studio Museum in Harlem, Harlem Center is now a 540,000-cubic-foot concrete basin -- think six Olympic-sized pools -- from which the steel framework of a three-story structure is soon to emerge. It will house a 57,000-square-foot Marshalls department store, CVS store and Washington Mutual bank branch.
Citarella is planning to open a store on West 125th Street by year-end and move its food preparation center to the former Taystee Cake Bakery on West 126th Street, said its owner, Joseph R. Gurrera.
At the bustling intersection of 125th Street and Lexington Avenue, where the Pathmark supermarket draws crowds, the three-story, 39,000-square-foot Gateway Building is nearing completion, with Duane Reade as its first tenant and Seaman's Furniture to come. The developers are Nina DeMartini-Day, Terrence Moan and Michael Dirzulaitis.
Across 125th Street from Pathmark, columns and beams frame the three-story, 90,000-square-foot, $24 million Gotham Plaza by the Blumenfeld Development Group. It will open this summer, David Blumenfeld said, with Fleet Bank, Children's Place, Payless ShoeSource, Petland Discounts and Rockaway Bedding Centers. Further into the future, Blumenfeld would also develop the East River Plaza retail project at the former Washburn Wire Factory.
In the three blocks between Second and Third Avenue, 125th and 128th Streets, the Potamkin Auto Group is planning a mall of automobile dealerships, and Grid Properties and the Gotham Organization are planning Uptown N.Y., an urban version of the Woodbury Commons outlet center.
Grid and Gotham were the developers, with the Commonwealth Local Development Corporation, of the Harlem U.S.A. retail center on West 125th Street, where the Hue-Man Bookstore is to open in April. Specializing in African-American subjects, it will stock at least 10,000 titles and "house the culture" of Harlem, said Clara Villarosa, who will run the 4,000-square-foot store with Celeste Johnson and Rita Ewing.
Drew Greenwald, president of Grid Properties, recalled the skepticism that greeted plans for Harlem U.S.A. six years ago. "Everybody said, 'It can't work,' " he said. These days, he said, "Most of the projects that have a ribbon cutting tend to happen."
Ground may be broken by the end of the year at Duke Ellington Circle, overlooking the Harlem Meer in Central Park, for a $125 million, 220,000-square-foot cultural and corporate complex to be developed by the Hines real estate company of Houston.
Edison Schools is to move its headquarters there from 521 Fifth Avenue, at 43rd Street, and the Museum for African Art is to move from 593 Broadway, near Houston Street. There is also to be a 650-seat, tuition-free public elementary school managed by Edison. The noteworthy design team includes Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates for the office and school; Bernard Tschumi for the museum; and Gruzen Samton as coordinating architects and planners.
"Architecturally, we're going to come out with a terrific project," said Councilman Philip Reed, whose district includes the site. "The community is going to be supportive of the school and we're going to bring 400 corporate jobs into the community."
VISITORS to the museum and headquarters can be expected to spend at least $2 million a year at nearby restaurants, shops and businesses, said a study by Allee King Rosen & Fleming. The 542 employees at the complex are expected to spend $1 million annually at local establishments.
The complex would occupy five empty lots between 109th Street and 110th Street, renamed Tito Puente Way to honor the legendary band leader. Edison owns the largest lot, on Fifth Avenue, where the 60,000-square-foot museum would be built.
Edison and the museum are negotiating the acquisition through the Economic Development Corporation of four city-owned lots on which a 160,000-square-foot school and office building would rise. It would be about 14 stories, roughly half the height of the nearby Schomburg Plaza. The City Council approved a rezoning in December that would permit offices on the site.
"We felt very strongly that we wanted our headquarters to be in the same community we serve," said Valerie Corbett, an Edison vice president and the project director. The company estimates that 60 percent of its school staff and 80 percent of its students are African-American and Latino.
Sitting at the junction of black and Hispanic Harlem, at the farthest reach of Museum Mile, the site suited the museum's vision of "building a bridge between communities," said Anne Stark, the deputy director. As the museum searched in 1999 for alternatives to its rented space in SoHo, it came upon the block that Edison had been looking at for its headquarters and school. They agreed to proceed together.
The midblock building will be split into two condominiums. Hines will own the 85,000 square feet of office space and lease it to Edison. The 75,000-square-foot school will be owned by a not-for-profit company. The museum will own its home on Fifth Avenue, which will permit it to build up its permanent collection, double its gallery space and quadruple the educational space.
Another ambitious cultural project that is now taking shape is an Apollo performing arts center that might encompass the Victoria Theater, 233 West 125th Street, whose auditorium is only 15 feet apart from the Apollo on the 126th Street side.
"We'd certainly be in favor of any kind of expansion of the activities of the Apollo into the Victoria Theater," said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, who said the matter was under negotiation. The state owns both the Victoria and the Apollo, which it has leased to the Apollo Theater Foundation for 99 years. One possibility, Mr. Gargano said, is a 3,000-seat theater on the Victoria site. 
Foundation executives said it was premature to talk about reconstruction, demolition, restoration or even acquisition of the Victoria. They focused instead on the renovation of the 1,483-seat Apollo itself, by Davis Brody Bond and Beyer Blinder Belle.
"We've thought long and hard about the best way of holding on to the historical richness of the theater while at the same time bringing it current," said Derek Q. Johnson, president of the foundation. The renovation is to occur in phases; staged so that the performance schedule is not disrupted unduly and also, Mr. Johnson said, "to allow our financial power to meet our real estate aspirations."
Apollo executives see their project in terms of the overall vitality of 125th Street. "The issue is how you keep it busy after 6 or 7 o'clock at night," said David D. Rodriguez, executive director of the foundation. "The key answer is to have a vibrant Apollo."
In the first phase of the renovation, to be completed in October at a cost of about $12 million, the great yellow-and-red blade sign out front will be rehabilitated, the marquee will be updated with light-emitting diodes, the terra cotta facade will be restored, the roof will be repaired, seats will be fixed and carpeting replaced, power capacity will be increased, computer-assisted moving lights will be added and new dimmers, speakers and audio mixing consoles will be installed.
The second phase, costing about $38 million, is to begin next year. It will include the restoration of architectural details and ornament in the auditorium and the construction of a new lobby and gift shop. Seats will be replaced, dressing rooms renovated and restrooms increased. Fiber-optic lines will be extended inconspicuously throughout the theater. All three levels will be made accessible to the disabled.
It is the uncharted phase, involving the 84-year-old Victoria Theater, that concerns Michael Henry Adams, author of the forthcoming "Harlem Lost and Found, An Architectural and Social History: 1765-1915."
Designed by the celebrated theater architect Thomas W. Lamb, the Victoria facade is ornamented with Ionic columns, anthemion leaves, lions' heads, rosettes and rhytons -- horn-shaped cups with animal heads. The Victoria is not a landmark but has been deemed eligible for the National Register of Historic Places, Mr. Adams said. "It is the most architecturally distinguished theater to survive in central Harlem," he said. "It shouldn't be necessary to destroy what is special and unique about Harlem."
One local landmark that has been brought back from near ruin is the former school and convent of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church at 445 East 115th Street, once the heart of Italian Harlem, which is being rebuilt as the National Museum of Catholic Art and History.
Dedicated in its own words to promoting "an awareness and appreciation of Catholic art in all its facets," the museum also plans an exhibition on the rich social history of East Harlem as one of its first shows. Although the private museum is a tenant of a parish church, a spokesman for the Archdiocese of New York emphasized that "there is no other relationship of any sort between the archdiocese and the museum."
The $8 million, cellar-to-attic renovation is well along, with new windows, walls, lighting, elevator and cooling equipment all in evidence. Most of the dozen galleries are nearing completion. Another $1.5 million is needed to complete the work, said Edward J. Malloy, chairman of the museum board and president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York. "I feel comfortable that we'll get it done," he said. "A May opening is realistic."
Arthur Rosenblatt, former vice president for architecture and planning at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is working on the Catholic museum with his colleagues at RKK&G Museum and Cultural Facilities Consultants. "This is not a token effort," he said. "It's a first-class, fully developed museum that's almost real. But like all early efforts, they're spare."
The National Museum of Jazz in Harlem is so spare that it is, so far, nonexistent. But Leonard Garment, the president, said the museum will soon appoint a new executive director, who will hire a staff and begin to address the question of what -- and where in Harlem -- the museum should be.
Among jazz clubs, the "Hottest Spot in Harlem" was Smalls' Paradise. While the Paradise itself is lost, its three-story building still stands at 135th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard (Seventh Avenue). The Abyssinian Development Corporation plans to renovate and expand the building by three floors into the Thurgood Marshall Academy, with an International House of Pancakes at the base. Construction may start next month, said Karen A. Phillips, president and chief executive of the nonprofit development corporation begun by the Abyssinian Baptist Church.
The facade, distinguished by yellow-brick buttresses and Gothic finials, will be restored. There will be lobby displays about Smalls' and the Apex beauty school, another celebrated tenant, and about Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court, who lived in Harlem. The architects of the $40 million project are Gruzen Samton.
BERTRAND MILES, a retired television cameraman and former Smalls' patron, has waged a quixotic battle to reopen it as a nightclub. Ms. Phillips said that was unavailing. "The community thinks that if you open the door, it would still be there," she said, "but it's been gone for years. We talked to so many restaurateurs and jazz club operators. But to get those financed in an inner-city area is difficult."
Citibank is financing the restaurant and the Board of Education is financing the school, which is to have up to 700 students.
The Bank of New York has made a $27.5 million construction loan to Harlem Center, at what was once to have been the site of the Harlem International Trade Center. After that project was scuttled, Abyssinian approached Forest City Ratner about responding to a request for proposals.
Bruce C. Ratner, president and chief executive of Forest City Ratner, said his company -- which is known for building commercial projects in developing neighborhoods -- had been approached many times to undertake something in Harlem.
"I'd always been hesitant," he said, "because it's very political in Harlem. There are a lot of different interests."
In this case, he said, Forest City Ratner was persuaded by the participation of Abyssinian and the commitment of state officials, especially Randy A. Daniels, who is now the New York secretary of state.
The project is divided into two parcels and phases. The 23,000-square-foot Gap is on the midblock parcel. On the corner is a 120,000-square-foot retail building. If a tenant can be signed, an office tower of about 150,000 square feet will rise above that. Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates are the architects for both phases; associated with the Ives Group on the $38 million first phase and with HLW International on the second, which could run to $40 million.
Ground-floor rents at Harlem Center and Harlem U.S.A. are $80 to $100 a square foot annually, a sign that 125th Street generally has escalated beyond what many Harlem businesses can afford. Borough President Fields said that has prompted efforts to strengthen other commercial corridors along 116th Street, 145th Street, Powell and Douglass Boulevards.
Cater-corner from the Masjid Malcolm Shabazz at 116th Street and Malcolm X Boulevard, the mosque at which Malcolm himself ministered, Renaissance Plaza has a mix of national and local tenants: Carver Federal Savings Bank, CVS, a Pioneer supermarket, Mail Boxes Etc., Ashley Stewart clothing store and Petland Discounts, as well as a money-transfer office, beauty supply shop and Christian bookstore. A restaurant, Five Loaves and Two Fish, and a fast-food court are to open this year.
These stores occupy the base of a new 241-unit co-op apartment building developed by Jeffrey E. Levine and Stuart Match Suna. The mosque served as community sponsor.
Not everything happens on such a large scale. At 116th Street and Madison Avenue sits a vacant bank, forlorn but quite noble, with an arcade of stout Doric columns.
Carl S. Redding, the proprietor and chef of the popular Amy Ruth's restaurant, 113 West 116th Street, said he had entered into a long-term lease on the Madison Avenue building. He envisions it as a 300-seat seafood restaurant, Noah's Ark, where culinary training would also be offered. Jack Travis Architect would be the interior designer.
The project needs $5 million to become a reality, but Mr. Redding sounded confident. "Harlem needs what I'm trying to put together," he said. "We're ready for it."

HEADLINE: JERSEYANA; 
Closing the Barn Door

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLL 

DATELINE: WAYNE 

 BODY:
AFTER 56 years of countless gallons of ice cream scooped and tens of thousands of burgers flipped, the Old Barn Milk Bar is just one more shuttered building. 
 A hand-written sign on the door thanks customers for decades of patronage, but says the barn will be closed forever. 
 "It's the economy, it's everything," Gerald McMinn Jr., an owner of the barn, said recently as he stood behind the counter stamping out a cigarette. "I just got tired of doing it." 
But it is not simply the closing of this mainstay that has the town rattled, but the future of the barn, a Dutch timber frame that built in 1790 and the last of its kind in Passaic County.
The McMinn family has a contract to sell the property to Fred Meyers, the owner of the Preakness Chevrolet dealership next door, and the deal is expected to be sealed by late spring. The barn was never designated a historic landmark, and so there are no restrictions on demolishing it.Tesidents and history buffs are concerned that the car dealership will knock down the barn for additional space.
"There is no real plan yet, but probably the barn would not be continued," said Herbert Guston, Mr. Meyers's attorney.
Residents remember the Milk Barn as a place to go after Little League games or to cool off on a hot summer's night. People would wait in line for as long as 40 minutes for a huge cone and then sit on the hoods of their cars or on lawn chairs and chatter while trying to keep the towering scoops of ice cream from falling onto the hot asphalt. "It was the social gathering place of the town, and I'm sorry to see it go," Marge Arenson, a 41-year-old homemaker, said.
For now, Mayor Scott Rumana of Wayne Township said the town had a few ideas about what to do if the barn was indeed endangered.
"We are going to do all we can to save it," Mr. Rumana said. "We have a few places in town where we could move it. It could be a welcome center for our bike path. Or if there is room, we could move it downtown with some other historical buildings."
In 1930, Olaf Haroldson bought the property on the Hamburg Turnpike and opened an ice cream shop in the barn. But because of gasoline rationing during World War II, business never materialized, and Mr. Haroldson sold the barn to Robert McMinn, a veteran, in the mid-1940's.
Mr. McMinn ran the business until the mid-1980's, when he passed the business down to his son, Joseph, and a nephew, Gerald, who both closed the barn doors on Dec. 10.
In a statement made public by Donald Beshada, a lawyer for the two men, the family expressed its gratitude to community members for their support and nostalgia.
"Unfortunately, the realities of operating what, in essence, has become a seasonal business in a very competitive environment, combined with other problems and concerns, led to the informed decision to sell the property," the statement said.
Mr. Beshada said there had been negations with other ice cream vendors to take over the business, but the discussions proved fruitless.
Inside the barn's dark dining room, the tables are etched with thousands of names and initials inside hearts.
"It was a place where a lot romances started and ended," said Tim Blixt, 50, a lifelong resident of Wayne.
"It was never a problem to see 100 people lined up waiting for the ice cream, but it was more than that," said Mr. Blixt. "A lot of it was the charm of the old building."
Terry Fitzpatrick, a 53-year-old salesman who lives in Wyckoff, recalled spending five years behind the counter of the Milk Barn doing everything from scooping cones to washing dishes, and said he remembered the look on people's faces when they got a cone for the first time. 
"First-time customers were stunned because the cones were very big," Mr. Fitzpatrick said. "If you go to a Carvel or a Dairy Queen today and you order a scoop, maybe it's the size of a half-dollar. At the barn, we would make them the size of a snowball."
As Bryan Corrado, a 22-year-old teacher from Totowa, put it: "It's something that went along with your childhood. The barn was part of growing up, and unlike Little League and childhood innocence, it was something you could hold on to as you grew up, and now it's gone."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Old Barn Milk Bar, a fixture in Wayne for 56 years, has been sold to a car dealer next door. Many fear that the 1790 Dutch timber frame barn will be razed, and the mayor has proposed moving it. (Nancy Wegard for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 9; Column 1; Style Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1508 words

HEADLINE: VIEW; 
Tuleh Tells: Designer Confidential

BYLINE:  By JOSH PATNER 

 BODY:
A FEW weeks ago, Andre Leon Talley, Vogue's editor at large, came bursting through the door at Tuleh. He was not even halfway in the room when he boomed out a question: "What does it take to survive?"
 I hadn't the faintest idea how to respond, because truthfully I have never been certain Tuleh will survive. I felt as if he were asking me to share a secret formula. I was stumped then, but I will share my secrets with you now. 
 As this New York Fashion Week kicks off in particularly uncertain times, the question of survival seems all the more pressing. My partner, Bryan Bradley, and I consider our survival almost every day, and some days almost every hour. Exactly four years ago this week, long before big spenders were pinched by the recession and the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 made women question their shopping habits, Bryan and I opened Tuleh with high hopes, high-interest credit cards and $225,000 in savings and family loans. We were going to make the most beautiful clothes in New York! Revive the great legacy of American dressmaking! We would have a salon of our own, a signature perfume, assistants, money, fame, all of it. 
Since then we have sold our dresses to some of the finest stores, including Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman Marcus, and among our clients are a bouquet of the uptown social roses who fill the party pages. We have received encouraging reviews from fashion critics, including Ginia Bellafante of this very paper, who after our fall 2000 show noted "a tasteful sexiness that made you want almost all the clothes that went by."
But the truth of it? We are still packing and shipping boxes ourselves, putting off bill collectors, far from any realization of our dream. Editors and buyers won't find Tuleh on the fashion calendar this week, because there isn't any money to spend, so there is no collection to show. At least not now. 
We have never had a financial partner. We have written at least 15 business plans (aspiring designers be warned: learn to deal with a spread sheet) and talked with at least a dozen potential investors. One guy owned a bowling alley and thought that a fashion investment would increase his luck with the ladies. At times it seems as if half of our debt is in glossy press kits, dispatched to anyone who might have an interest in a fledgling brand. We have turned down about half the deals, and been turned down in equal number. 
It is brutal out there for independent designers. This is the era of the mega group: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, Prada and Gucci dominate the game. The business pages are filled with the financial woes of department stores, where customers have come to expect they can buy everything on sale. Even well-heeled shoppers are wary of overspending or seeming conspicuous.
I will share some financial facts with you. I am not shy about it. When you are a designer trying to build a house, you get used to opening your books on demand. It becomes like dropping your pants at a checkup. 
Our first season we had $75,000 in orders, a figure that has nearly doubled with each season. But as of today, we have about $12,000 in the bank. There has never been any cash to support our growth. We don't even have a line of credit. How has Tuleh survived? Bryan and I will it to survive. Every day. We are owed about $200,000, which, God willing, will be collected over the next six weeks; our current debt is more than that. Manufacturing the runway samples for a collection (excluding payroll, insurance, rent, etc.) costs about $175,000. To produce a fashion show in the group tents in Bryant Park requires a minimum of $40,000. Our shows, which have never been in the tents (we are snobs), have cost considerably more. Keeping up with the cash flow could give a guy dementia. 
But I have learned that money is not the answer. Money has doomed more designers than it has made. Yes, a designer must have respect for money. But managing money is a talent of its own. I don't believe it is a talent that true designers -- people actually cutting clothes -- have. In my opinion, a designer has no business working as a business person. 
Distracted by a constant lack of funds, we spend far more time chasing cash than great design. Believe me, we have trotted some clunkers down that expensive runway of ours. Fashion does, however, have a built-in blessing: there is always next season. I think the first secret of survival is knowing when to turn the page. 
Designers give up any claim to a normal life. We never eat out with friends, and don't have a summer house, a 401(k) plan, even a paycheck. When you own a business, you say goodbye to your sex life and to a fit body. 
Expect instead to say hello to cold, greasy Chinese food, candy, old fried chicken, cigarettes when you don't even smoke, anything to keep your nerves under control. Because you are indebted to anyone who lent you money, did you a favor, returned your call, your nails will be bloody stubs. The small details will get away from you, then the big picture, and then suddenly the whole game. You will beg, plead, humiliate yourself to collect payment from stores while you try desperately to pay your bills. Your mother's calls never get returned. I have tried to chain half-dead seamstresses to their sewing machines late at night before a show. So we come to the second secret: keep focused on making beautiful clothes. 
I think that a lot of people become designers to get invited to A-list parties. Yeah, we dress all the right girls. But in four years we have been invited to only one A-list party. It was in our honor. Aerin Lauder Zinterhofer gave a dinner for us at her home after our fall 2001 show at Harry Winston last March. It was going to be our breakthrough night. Everyone was at the dinner, or rather everyone but us. The show had been a mess: the pants were all hemmed six inches too long. An extravagant fur came down the runway with a huge workroom tag hanging from the armpit. A model wearing a $6 million necklace came out with her pants unzipped. Bryan and I showed up at Aerin's door two hours late, feeling puny and mortified. Third secret: keep your ego in check. A dressmaker should never be rude. 
So why do we even try to survive? Does somebody have a gun to our heads? Are we addicts? What exactly are we addicted to? Sometimes I think we are addicted to the idea of surviving, of proving the doubters wrong. But there are far more subtle, and ultimately more compelling, addictions that drive us on. 
The fourth secret is succumbing to your addictions. I am absolutely addicted to Jacki Deena Tutelman, a saleswoman at the New York office of Ratti fabrics, the Italian mill that makes our prints. Jacki has perfect nails. She pronounces "georgette" as if it were "zior-zette." So glamorous. Amanda Cutter Brooks, our in-house muse and best friend, looks so pretty in our clothes that it shocks my senses -- I can't believe I had anything to do with it. How can we consider closing when our Neiman Marcus buyer, Hila Ekelman, says she has a customer who depends on Tuleh? I worship Raymond Chou, our main contractor, who knows more about clothes than Christian Dior did. Sometimes it is just an idea in my head that keeps me going. And no addict could ever get the pleasure Bryan and I take in seeing a woman turn on in Tuleh. It is a major rush and a very powerful feeling. 
Secret No. 5: learn from criticism and compliments alike. Getting reviewed is a grisly experience. I wouldn't wish it on anyone. Ironically, while nothing feels better than a good review in the heat of the moment, it can leave you stuck the next time. Good reviews can make a designer try to do the same thing again, and then what would there be to buy or to photograph? It is almost better to get a bad review if it makes you work harder. But it sure feels lousy. 
The last secret for survival: our most valued critics are the women who wear the clothes and the people who sell the clothes to them. Good designers must never stop listening. (After all, I'm a guy. I have never given anything I design a test drive.) We have learned that salespeople are the single greatest source of market research in our industry, yet theirs are the least-heard voices. They can tell you how best to finish a seam to make a dress alterable, how much a blouse should really cost, why velvet never sells. 
How has Tuleh survived? There is only one reason: the clothes. The only thing a designer can even hope to control is the clothes. Everything else is madness. It is true that we have been supported by the press, but far less than other designers have been. Our buzz sometimes buzzes out. But Princess Firyal of Jordan called to say that the coat she ordered fits like real couture. And Kim Hersov, an editor at Harper's & Queen, called from London to ask if we could make up a few things we thought she couldn't live without this season. And Helen Ytuarte, a globe-trotting fashion editor, keeps coming back for more. Fortunately, some women love their Tuleh. 
So thank you, pretty ladies. Keep shopping.
