HEADLINE: Love's Journey 

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ; Additional reporting was provided by Laura Puertas in Peru and Seth Kugel.

 BODY:
THIS is a love story. But there is no princess, no white knight. Do not expect a dozen red roses, or dinner at Daniel. There are, however, hearts, aches and letters. Lots of letters.
 For much of the past year, Melania, 42, has lived in a small, dark house in Richmond Hill, Queens, with three middle-aged Peruvian women. She shared a bed with one of the three sisters, their room filled with fake flowers and stuffed teddy bears, some wrapped in plastic, and none of it belonging to Melania. 
 More than 3,000 miles away, in her native Peru, her husband of 26 years, Antonio, and three of their four daughters live in one of the most crowded districts of Lima. Their modest but tidy concrete house sits atop a hill cut by narrow, unpaved streets. They have running water from midnight until noon. There is never hot water for a bath. They cannot pay their bills. 
In January 2001, Melania, hoping to ease her family's finances, boarded a flight from Lima to Washington. She wondered during the 10-hour journey where she was going. "Sometimes I imagined buildings filled with light, all of glass," she said. "I imagined the ground shining like mirrors."
One year, two cities, an expired tourist visa, four apartments and several jobs later, Melania has a more earthbound vision of the United States and of New York. Now Peru seems to be the lighter, more fantastic place.
She keeps letters from her family, which she reads every week. She handles them gently, these Easter eggs, Hello Kitties, happy birthdays, merry Christmases, Powerpuff Girls, rough-cut hearts, poems in childish script.
They spill like leaves from her hands; pledges of love and devotion pour from the pages. It is an intimacy of superlatives, as if adjectives can make up for miles: millions of kisses, the best, the most beautiful. Her youngest daughter, Andrea, sent a math problem. "Mamita, I'm giving you this problem as your homework: 109 + 99 = ." In the blank, Melania wrote 208. "It's my punishment for not being in Peru," she said of the homework.
Melania is not a pioneer. The archetypal immigrant tale features a man striking out across the sea, establishing himself and eventually sending for his family. But immigration has increasingly become an equal opportunity endeavor. Today, most legal immigrants are women, said Guillermina Jasso, a sociology professor at New York University. According to government data, women have made up the majority of new legal immigrants 21 to 65 years old almost every year from 1972 through 1998. That figure does not count those who became legal residents under the provisions of the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986. 
Although data for illegal immigrants are fuzzier, some estimates are that the male-female ratio among the illegal is 60 percent male to 40 percent female.
Melania is not alone. Some 700,000 of the nation's 8.5 million illegal immigrants live in New York State, most of them in New York City. 
Increased border security in the last five years, coupled with heightened vigilance by the government since Sept. 11, have made it harder for illegal immigrants to come and go. Increasingly, they must choose between an old world and a new one. "If she leaves now, they may take note that she overstayed her visa, and they may be less likely to issue her a new one than they would have pre-Sept. 11," said Jeffrey Passell, a demographer at the Urban Institute.
So, Melania stays. She and her family speak several times a week on the phone, but they have no idea when they will meet again. Antonio is a husband without a wife, Melania a mother without children. They all share a love that is both sharpened and distorted by distance. They are a family in mourning with each other, for each other.
LIKE many in Peru, Antonio and Melania have spent their lives slipping in and out of work, sometimes driven to the scrappy world of informal commerce. More than half of Peru's population lives in poverty. 
"I am typical of those little girls who become strong at a very young age," said Melania, who started working at 6, soon after her mother died. At 9, she sold coffee and sandwiches on Lima's streets.
After two companies Antonio worked for went out of business, he started driving an unofficial taxi. Melania worked from home, sewing, teaching, making and selling stuffed animals, and baby-sitting. Five years ago, she opened a pastry shop called La Reina, but when the Peruvian economy slumped in 1998-99, the business failed.
"We prepared the pastries to throw them out," she said. "Nothing sold." The school bills -- $100 each annually for Rosalyn, studying to be an accountant, and Liz, studying to be a nurse, and $50 a month for 8-year-old Andrea -- were impossible. There was a pile of debt: the house, the car, medical bills. The oldest daughter, Nathaly, does not live at home.
Today, the family's monthly budget is $450. Antonio earns between $270 and $400 a month, driving his cab and working occasionally as an electrician. 
"We are a mature couple, so we made a decision," Antonio said during a recent interview. "A very painful one."
He would stay in Lima, but Melania would join the small army of Peruvian expatriates who in 1999 sent home $819 million. "I was more courageous," Melania said. 
Nathaly and Andrea, who is shy, didn't see their mother off. 
"When we got home, Andrea asked for her Mami," Rosalyn said. "We told her: 'Oh, yes, Mami will come later. She has gone on a trip, and when she comes back, she'll bring us some little gifts.' The house was very sad those first days. More than anything, my father was sad. He was a bit stunned by what he felt for my mom."
Antonio had met Melania when he was a 21-year-old assistant at an insurance company and she was 14. "I spoke to her, and she responded," he said.
"We fought," said Melania, recently over pasteria napoletana, torta di limone and coffee at the elegant Italian restaurant in TriBeCa where she had been a pastry chef. Her father managed the building where Antonio worked; Melania sometimes helped with the cleaning. She swept Antonio with a broom when he passed; she threw water on him as she washed the floors.
"One day he said, 'You bother me so much,' grabbed me, and kissed me against my will," Melania said. 
Later, he asked whether she had liked his kiss. " 'Ah, no, it was hateful,' I told him," she said, laughing at her own impetuousness. "I liked having him always at my side. I didn't want to be alone." 
The kisses continued. Antonio started picking her up from school, Melania said, recreating the dialogue of their courtship:
"Don't come to my school to pick me up," Melania told him.
"I'm not going to let anything happen to you," he said to her. 
"And why do you take such good care of me?"
"Because one day, you're going to marry me. Because you're going to fall in love with me, be my girlfriend, and be the mother of my children. Do you know that the mother of my children has to be the most beautiful person in the whole world?"
WHEN the school year ended, Melania's father found her talking with Antonio and forbade her to see him again. "I started crying," she said. "And I told him the truth: 'But, Papi, I love him.' " 
Then, Melania said, her father schemed. "He went to the police and told them, 'Sir, I found my daughter nearly being raped by this man.' "
The police arrested Antonio, whose parents tried to persuade Melania's father to drop the charges. They pleaded. They brought gifts. "They brought a basket with rice, sugar, oil, everything for my stepmother," Melania said. "And for my father, they brought a case of beer." 
After a week, her father relented. But, Melania said, the police said they would release Antonio only if he married her. " 'According to what you have told us, he has sinned against your honor and the honor of your daughter,' " the police said. " 'So, the only way for your daughter's honor to come out clean is if she marries him.' "
The couple's parents settled on a plan: Melania and Antonio would marry, but divorce right away.
On Aug. 23, 1975, Melania, dressed in everyday clothes, and Antonio, who had bought his bride a bouquet of artificial white roses, were wed in a civil ceremony. Their parents waited outside.
"Fortunately, I have a cousin, a very trustworthy guy, a very good person, and I had asked him to lend me -- I don't know where I get these ideas -- to lend me his motorcycle so we could escape after we got married," Antonio said. 
"My husband's cousin was waiting outside with a running motorcycle," Melania said. "So my husband grabbed me, and said, 'As soon as I give a signal, run as fast as you can.' "
Antonio said, "It was practically like a kidnapping."
Of her father's response as they fled, Melania said, "I only heard, 'My daughter!' "
Antonio had indeed found the mother of his children. Melania was three months pregnant on their wedding day.
Melania's life is buttressed by the letters from her family, and her letters home are also treasured. Just as she sends a vision of herself home, so, too, she creates an image of New York.
"What has made an impression on her about life in New York is that everyone has their time regimented," Antonio said. "Everyone works. It's not like here in Latin America. We'll run into a friend on the street corner, and we'll be chatting, sometimes about silly things. But there, no. There everything runs like a machine, people are very orderly, organized. All this has made an impression on my wife."
Last May, Andrea sent a wish list to her mother: a Barbie doll, a car, two computers with the Internet, a four-story house with a staircases, a garden with a pool.
Andrea keeps her mother's letters under a stack of books in her room. "My dearly beloved little ones," reads one letter from Melania. "I wish I could write you every day, tell you minute by minute what I do, what I think. I assure you that the stores would run out of writing paper." 
Still, no volume of paper can add up to her being there. "I miss her physical presence most, Antonio said. "She was the orchestra of the house."
For his birthday Jan. 18, Melania had a small orchestra go to her family's home and play Peruvian music. "When they arrived, everyone was surprised," she said. "They sang, 'We were sent by Myli, your wife in New York.' " 
"I always joke with her," Liz said. " 'Mami, when are you coming?' Or I tell her, 'Mami, I'm heading over there.' She laughs and says, 'O.K., come tomorrow.' "
The truth is that it's hard to get out of Peru. Antonio does not want to cross the border illegally, and has applied for a visa. "I want to go to New York," he said. "I am willing to do any kind of work."
LAST week, the sky in Queens was thick and white. One of Melania's housemates baby-sat at the house. Two children raced around, laughing and grabbing the fingers of a houseguest. On Saturdays, the sisters do the laundry and Melania cooks dinner. It looks a little like a family. "Almost," Melania said. Rain ran down the windows. "The sun is shining in Peru," she said.
Ten days ago, it was 80 degrees in Lima. Antonio wore Bermuda shorts. He woke up at 6 a.m. and had canihua, a cereal of roasted quinoa with milk, cinnamon, and cloves, for breakfast with his daughters. They spoke, as usual, of Melania.
"When I get up, I always greet my mother as if she were here," Liz said. "I have some stuffed animals that she sent me, so I say good morning to them as if they were my Mami." 
For breakfast Melania ate oatmeal and toast with American cheese. After the attack on the World Trade Center, she lost her job, and with it, a big part of her community of friends. As she looks for another job, she does the rounds of relief agencies. She gets $693 every two weeks from the nonprofit agency Safe Horizon, roughly what she used to earn at the restaurant, and collects some money from churches and the Asociacion Tepeyac, an immigrant advocacy group in New York, where she also takes free English classes. After breakfast, she picked up her check from Safe Horizon and cashed it. Later, she wired $200 to her family. 
Antonio spent the morning at an auto shop, supervising repairs on his car. Liz walked three blocks to the open-air market to buy ingredients for lunch: potatoes, yellow peppers, garlic, onion, crackers, cheese, milk, a live chicken. The family ate together.
Melania ate alone: chicken McNuggets, a salad.
In the afternoon, as the family watched a news program about corruption during the Fujimori era, Melania bought her daughters CoverGirl smudge-proof mascara, vitamin C, lipstick and nail polish.
"Sometimes she calls at 7 a.m. to remind us not to forget to put water in Andrea's lunch box," Liz said.
From a distance, Melania realized, her life in Peru seemed a collection of details: waking her daughters, making beds, cooking, shopping, helping with homework. She had escaped. 
And the freedom was unbearable. 
"I felt like a thief had come in the night, and had robbed me of all of my family, and all of my house, and that I was all alone in the world, without a house, without family, without children, without a husband, without anything," she said. "I was alone, alone in the world. I felt my arms were empty, and the only thing to do was to cry and cry and cry."
Her job at the restaurant helped. "Before, I cried every day," she said. "After I started work, I cried only once a week."
Melania was working on Sept. 11. She saw people jump from the towers. For weeks, she dreamed of hands reaching out to her, calling for help. 
She telephoned her daughters. They told her to come home. "I said, 'Mama, come back, please come back,' " Rosalyn said.
Melania said she told her children: " 'No risk, no gain. You have to learn this from your mother.' "
Monday, Melania and her housemates quarreled. Tuesday, she left in search of a new home. She phoned her daughters. They called her, "My little Mami, the brave."

HEADLINE: Car Dot-Coms: The Dust Settles 

BYLINE:  By CATHERINE GREENMAN 

 BODY:
WHEN Simon and Karen Garrett started shopping for a Honda Civic, they took the usual first steps in the car-buying process. The couple, who live in Brighton, Mich., test-drove a Civic at their local dealer, Brighton Honda, and got a quote that was reasonably close to the manufacturer's suggested price. Then, like many Internet-savvy consumers, the Garretts went home and compared the quote at several automotive Web sites, including Autobytel.com, cars.com and Edmunds.com.
 After running the numbers, Dr. Garrett, a chemistry professor at Michigan State University, realized he could find a better price online. "A couple of the sites came up with quotes that were considerably less than the dealer's," he said. "One was about $1,000 less." But instead of buying the car online, Dr. Garrett went back to his dealer with a printout. The dealer matched the online quote, and a Civic was sold. 
 In the end, Dr. Garrett felt more comfortable buying locally. "We talked about getting it through some faceless online dealer, but we were a little worried that we might have to drive a long way only to find out that the car was not as advertised," he said."We preferred to work with someone local." 
The Garretts' experience encapsulates a pesky reality that car-selling sites have struggled with since their inception: buyers use the Internet for research, but the moment of truth tends to occur at dealerships.
"The vast majority of consumers still turn to the Internet for information that helps them negotiate with dealers in the traditional ways, as opposed to looking at the Internet as an alternative means to close the deal," said Chris Denove, a partner at J. D. Power & Associates, a research firm in Agoura Hills, Calif. "This probably won't change in the near future."
It may also explain why, after millions of dollars have been spent and hundreds of marketing minds have been sapped, several of the Internet car sites that started in the late 1990's are no longer around.
The so-called referral sites, like Autobytel, Carpoint.com, and InvoiceDealers.com, continue to operate with varying degrees of success. They refer shoppers to dealerships; the consumers must first fill out online forms describing details like the make, model and features of cars they want, as well as how far they're willing to travel and what financing and insurance packages they are seeking.
Autobytel says it earned about $52.3 million last year in fees from dealers; it says its fourth-quarter revenue was up $3.7 million from a year earlier, to $20.5 million. Carpoint will not disclose its revenue from dealer fees, or its total revenue for 2001, but it says it generates $8 billion worth of leads annually. InvoiceDealers says it has been profitable since June 2000.
The referral sites still struggle to sign up dealers, who must pay several hundred dollars a month to receive customer leads. "When dealers work with a referral site charging on a per-lead basis, they have to factor that into the sale price, and that gets expensive," said Jim Ziegler, a dealer consultant in Atlanta.
And the closing rates from Internet leads can be low. A J. D. Power study released in November found that the typical Internet shopper visited 6.8 auto sites before buying.
"The public has double-crossed the dealers every time they've tried to make a sincere effort on this thing," Mr. Ziegler said. "Consumers are registering with several services, and dealers are paying $25 to $30 per lead for the same lead, or paying for a lead that's miles away."
Other dealers, however, have found that referral sites have significantly helped their business. "The leads from Autobytel are fantastic," said Tom Vann, owner of Team Hillsdale Chrysler in Hillsdale, Mich. Mr. Vann said it cost him about $7,000 a month to get roughly 500 customer leads from Autobytel, and that those leads accounted for 40 to 50 percent of his monthly sales. But Mr. Vann said some sites generated many serious buyers while others produced few good leads.
Sites that let shoppers "name their price" -- like LiquidPrice.com,
BestOffer.com, and the auto service of Priceline.com -- have either shut down or are struggling to adapt the many variables of auto retailing to the online world.
"In an environment where there's an increasing amount of incentive activity, the car-buying transaction doesn't lend itself well to the online experience," said MaryAnn Keller, an independent automotive consultant who was president of Priceline's Auto Services unit from July 1999 to November 2000. "The deal is going to be determined by the dealer based on a person's credit rating, what they are buying and other factors. It's an industry where the manufacturer's suggested retail price has become largely irrelevant, and there are many other variables to consider." Those variables, she said, are often too complex to be negotiated online.
Some sites, like CarOrder.com, which shut down in February 2001, and Greenlight.com, which merged with CarsDirect.com that same month, arranged high-volume deals with dealerships to offer no-haggle prices to consumers. CarsDirect continues to work with its network of 3,000 dealers to sell directly to consumers, but it is also taking steps toward becoming a referral service. It recently began DirectConnect.com, a referral service that charges dealers $299 to $1,299 a month for leads within specific territories.
Who is clearly succeeding in the online car buying world? Sites like AutoTrader.com, and cars.com, which are essentially Internet classified advertising services for new and used car dealers. At AutoTrader, dealers spend an average of $500 to $600 on classified listings, said Jody Scott, a spokeswoman. She said the site now had more than 1.8 million cars for sale.
Cars.com lists 500,000 new and used cars that are also advertised in 150 newspapers owned by seven companies, including The New York Times Company. For $1,200 to $2,200 a month, depending on the market, dealers can list all cars on their lots. For $20, an individual can buy an ad that is posted until the car sells.
To cover their bases, many car-selling sites rely on revenue sources outside car sales. Autobytel says that about 40 percent of its business comes from sales of banner advertising on Autobytel and its three other sites (Autoweb.com, CarSmart.com and AutoSite.com), as well as from sales of insurance packages and dealer training programs.
Sites geared to helping consumers search for car prices and features, like Edmunds.com and Kelley Blue Book (kbb.com), also receive a large chunk of revenue from automakers' er advertising. "Many manufacturers realize that car buyers are coming to our site at some point in time as they make their final decision," said Stephen Henson, vice president for marketing and business development at Kelley Blue Book.
Whatever direction they are taking, the remaining auto retailing sites have adjusted their strategies to include not just the consumer, but also the dealer. "In 1996 or 1997, there was a fair amount of hubris as far as the role the dealer would ultimately play in the car-buying process," said John Holt, president and chief executive of the Cobalt Group, a Seattle-based company that builds and operates Web sites for manufacturers and dealers.
CarOrder.com, for instance, went out of business in 2000 after burning through a $100 million investment from its original parent, Trilogy Development Group. CarOrder had hoped to buy marginal dealerships to gain access to a supply of cars, which it would then sell at prices that undercut conventional dealers.
Now, Mr. Holt said, strong dealer relationships are crucial to the survival of any sales site. Jeffrey Schwartz, president and chief executive of Autobytel, said of dealers, "They are our principal customers, and the heartbeat of the company."
Car-selling sites that are not affiliated with manufacturers or dealers face growing competition from automakers and from dealers who strike out on their own with ambitious Web sites that let consumers configure models and compare prices.
"There's been a tremendous growth in manufacturers' sites over the last year," said Julia Ask, an analyst at Jupiter Media Metrix in New York. Ford and General Motors have also gotten into the dealer referral game with Forddirect.com and GMbuypower.com.
Analysts agree that the consumers who do buy online tend to visit manufacturers' sites to learn about the cars' features, but they prefer to negotiate through independent sites. "When it comes to finding hard facts and figures about specific vehicles, most feel that the manufacturer's site is the better source," Mr. Denove said. "But when it comes to filling out a referral form, most consumers believe that the independent sites are the way to go." Those sites still outsell manufacturers' sites by two to one, Mr. Denove added.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 24, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in the Automobiles section on Feb. 10 about automotive Web sites included an outdated figure for the percentage of revenue that Autobytel, an online service that refers car shoppers to dealerships, receives from banner advertising. In 2001, sources other than dealer fees, including advertising on its four sites, dealer training programs and insurance packages, accounted for 26 percent of revenue; the 40 percent figure was for 2000.
The article also referred incorrectly to a dealer-referral business recently begun by CarsDirect.com. A shopper can use the service, called CarsDirect Connect, by entering a ZIP code and desired vehicles on the CarsDirect site, not at DirectConnect.com.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF; 
A Lurid Tale, Overtaken by Events

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

 BODY:
THRILLERS blending business dealings and derring-do form a genre in their own right, and "The Day Trader," by Stephen W. Frey (Ballantine Publishing Group, $24.95), fits admirably into this high-octane niche. It is a tale of market misdeeds and murder with characters ranging from traders shorting stocks to table dancers dealing in quite different commodities.
 But there's a problem: after the bull market days that seem to have inspired the book -- and that certainly inspired many day traders to gamble their life savings on magical stock valuations -- fact has become stranger than any fiction. 
 Consider, now, an author scanning that figurative blank page (or, more likely, a glowing screen and a blinking cursor) for the beginnings of a plot. Where to begin when reality has already outpaced what would once have passed for the fantastic? 
How about, for instance, a story about a big accounting firm shredding a client's internal documents? Improbable? Or a chief executive from an energy giant with close ties to the White House subpoenaed to face congressional inquiries of the company's collapse? Too unlikely? Or, maybe the discovery of a foreign-exchange trader who, his employer says, ran up $750 million in losses? Could that happen? (Ask Allied Irish Banks, Ireland's biggest bank.)
Financial thrillers, of course, are a particular breed. Ideally, they should leaven a sinewy plot with enough insider detail to give the outsider an initiation into a secretive world and still offer enough realism to draw in the expert.
Mr. Frey, a principal at Winston Partners, a private equity firm in McLean, Va., and the author of successful novels like "Trust Fund" and "The Takeover," achieves those goals easily, drawing on his own experience in corporate finance and in the mergers and acquisitions unit of J. P. Morgan.
From the first page, the reader is invited into the disconsolate world of Augustus McKnight, a sales representative at a paper products company, unhappy in his job, picked on by a vindictive boss and going home to an unhappy marriage in which he suspects his wife of infidelity.
But Mr. McKnight's world turns out to be even more complex when, finally, a stroke of luck on the initial public offering of a stock gives him the capital to fulfill his longstanding ambition of becoming a day trader. The move transports Mr. McKnight from a world of predictable slights and minor deceits into a high-risk play in which the imponderables ultimately go far beyond the rise and fall of the stock market.
Of course, this is meant to be a fast-paced read -- and it is, barely slowing for the technical passages that explain, for instance, an initial public offering or a lock-up provision. If anyone starts reading this book not knowing what put options or margin loans are, he will certainly finish the book with a working knowledge.
As the plot unfolds, Mr. McKnight swerves between a hint of romance and murder (swerving, literally, on one occasion in the sleek new BMW that is the token of all success). Mr. Frey takes the reader along on a roller coaster that almost moves fast enough to cloak the occasional improbability in the plot.
In quick succession, the narrative encompasses a motley array of day traders who share utter duplicity and a passion for elusive riches. There is, too, a sympathetic police officer who investigates after Mr. McKnight's wife is found slain.
To twist the narrative tighter, Mr. McKnight is the beneficiary of a million-dollar life insurance policy on his wife, enough to give any day trader a start-up stake and make any police officer, sympathetic or not, suspect murder. As the plot strips away half-truths that had defined his life, Mr. McKnight must confront realities he had never suspected.
BEYOND that, though, the book comes as a reminder of just how fast the financial and business world has changed since the days -- only a couple of years back -- when day traders were making headlines as contributors to the volatility of a bull market that was racing toward the bursting of the Internet bubble. Then, as the book reminds, stock was king not just as the currency of pay packages and takeovers, but as the stuff of dreams among small investors hunched over computers and swapping tips on Internet bulletin boards.
These days, the market's gyrations reflect a flight from risk that has become all the more apparent since the Enron affair raised doubts about the financial health of once-unassailable corporate icons. If individual investors once thought they could make their fortune on a wise play in the stock market, they are far more worried now about the health of their 401(k) plans.
But one thing that shines through Mr. Frey's traders is humanity's capacity for hope -- defined as an optimism that denies fact and, in the stock market's case, gravity. Like gamblers everywhere, the players in "The Day Trader" thrive on the belief that a twist of good fortune will redeem all their past errors. 
It has not been long since such beliefs transformed day traders into symbols of the bull market. Given the speed of economic change, it could well be that Mr. Frey's latest work is not so much a story of times past as a signal that the get-rich-quick dream is just hibernating.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Commodities: Down So Low They Have Room to Grow

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
STOCKS may be stalled right now, but at least they have recovered nicely from the sell-off after Sept. 11. Commodities have not. That may be an opportunity for adventurous investors.
 There are two reasons for investors to be interested in commodities. One is that if the economy is set for a rebound, a rally could be in store because commodity prices are very low. The other is that commodities tend, over time, to move in the opposite direction from stocks, so they are a good way to bring diversification to a portfolio. 
 First, the rally. Since Sept. 11, the Goldman Sachs Commodity index is down 17 percent while the Dow Jones-AIG commodity index is off 11 percent. The difference exists because the Goldman index, which consists of 26 commodities, gives more weight to energy. The AIG index, not as well known, was unveiled in November with more than a decade of data; it has 20 energy, metal and food commodities. It has been lower than it is now less than 20 percent of the time since 1990.
So there is room for commodities to rise, if the economy is indeed turning around. Demand should increase for energy commodities and industrial metals if manufacturing picks up around the world.
"If commodity prices just go back to where they were before Sept. 11, that is a double-digit gain," said Adam De Chiara, senior vice president at AIG Trading Group, which is working to increase awareness of its commodities index.
Now, for diversification. In their most recent decline and rally, commodity prices performed this role quite well. As prices of goods from crude oil to coffee, copper to pork bellies, and zinc to sugar were falling 42 percent from May 1997 to February 1999, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 49 percent. But from February 1999 to January 2001, commodities climbed 56 percent while the S.& P. 500 eked out a 6 percent gain.
All the major commodity sectors declined last fall, with crude oil and crude oil products leading the way with a 62 percent plunge. Precious metals had the smallest fall, declining 12 percent. In the rally, crude oil led again, with a surge of 210 percent, while grains fell 20 percent.
Diversification, however, is not a route to big returns and is not always a buffer. Last year, commodity prices and stocks both fell sharply. Diversification is a way to balance a portfolio so that when there is bad news in one sector there may be good news elsewhere. Success depends, in part, on owning a basket of commodities so that local factors that affect price, like the weather, do not become too dominant. "The wider you cast your net, the more likely those micro factors will cancel each other out," Mr. De Chiara said.
Analysts do not advise going whole hog into commodities because they are mainly a portfolio diversifier. Five percent seems right.
The problem for individual investors is that buying commodities is complicated and risky. There are futures contracts on the two commodity indexes. But owning even one represents a big exposure for small investors. The face value of the AIG futures contract is over $50,000, which is much more than 5 percent of most small portfolios.
In addition, it is easy for investors to get sucked into much bigger losses than they expect with futures contracts because they can buy a contract on margin for much less than its face value.
One possible option, although still risky, is the Oppenheimer Real Asset fund. It is a $120 million mutual fund that tries to match the performance of the Goldman Sachs total return commodity index, which also includes fixed-income investments to enhance returns. An investor can get in for $2,500.
In 1999 and 2000, the Class A shares of the Real Asset fund performed spectacularly. It rose 37 percent in 1999 and 44 percent in 2000, as the S.& P. 500 climbed 20 percent and 10 percent. But last year, there was no hiding from declines. The Real Asset fund declined 31 percent, while the S.& P. 500 fell 13 percent. So far this year, the Real Asset fund is off 0.6 percent. That is less than the 5 percent decline for the S.& P. 500, but holding on for the year will be an adventure.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Olympic Cheer: Put Out More Flags

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY 

 BODY:
IT was a diplomatic tango as delicate as any performed in the halls of power. But this international incident unfolded at the 19th Winter Games, when the International Olympic Committee last week rejected a plan by American athletes to march in the parade of nations with a tattered flag that once flew at the World Trade Center. This irked more than a few self-styled patriots, and the I.O.C. eventually allowed eight athletes to carry the flag early in the opening ceremony.
 Such confrontations are inevitable, given the abrasive marriage between nationalism and transnationalism that has always existed in the modern Olympics. Nowhere are there more expectations for sport to transcend the politics of international borders, but nowhere does it fail more visibly. 
 In some ways, the flag-waving of the Games is becoming more of an anachronism, as borders open up and the influence of nation-states wanes next to the power of organizations like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, and corporations that span the globe. The euro is now circulating to surprising enthusiasm. But the events of last week, as well as the history of the Olympics, show that not only is nationalism far from exhaling its last breath, but the Games remain crucial in perpetuating it.
"Every couple of years, these sports reflect the dialectic between the national and the international," said Jeffrey O. Segrave, a sports historian at Skidmore College. "It's a way of taking stock of ourselves, of what we've made of this planet, which is a sense of increasing global identity on the one hand, and on the other hand you have this sense of national identity."
Outside of war, the Olympics may well be the world's most visible forum for nationalism. Having a delegation in the opening ceremony legitimizes a country as much as joining the United Nations, said Peter Donnelly, a professor of sports sociology at the University of Toronto. When the Taliban lost power, there was immediate speculation about whether Afghanistan would field an Olympic team (it didn't), as if this could complete its transformation from a pariah state. 
But even more than participating in the Games, the awarding of an Olympic site to a country is seen as a validation of the host's nationhood. When the I.O.C. gave Beijing the 2008 Summer Games last year, many Chinese said their homeland had finally been recognized by the international community.
Competition in the Olympics is often the only chance that countries with little diplomatic clout have to reinforce their national identity. The Winter Games are dominated by often overlooked nations like Canada and Norway. In the 2000 Summer Games, Cuba spoke with its fists when it won more gold medals in boxing than any country since 1970. (Its geopolitical nemesis, the United States, won no gold medals in the event for the first time since 1948.)
SINCE its founding, the Olympics have been rooted in nationalism, despite organizers' efforts to dress it in politically neutral garb. In the second half of the 19th century, a British doctor named W. P. Brookes organized the Olympian Games in his country to strengthen candidates for the army.
The founder of the I.O.C., Baron Pierre de Coubertin, had similar motives, said Mark S. Dyreson, a sports historian at Penn State. De Coubertin was taken with Brookes's idea while searching for a way to build up the French army, which had been routed in the Franco-Prussian War. Only later did he promote the Olympics as a venue for international good will.
The first modern Olympic Games, held in 1896 in Athens, ignited conflict between colonizer and colonized, a dynamic that continued for decades, said David C. Young, a classicist and Olympic historian at the University of Florida. Edwin Flack, an Australian runner and Oxford student, insisted in 1896 that his two medals go to Australia, only to have Britain take them. In Stockholm in 1912, Russia tried coercing a Finnish runner into declaring his three medals for Russia, which had taken over Finland in 1809. A 1956 Melbourne water polo match between Hungary and the Soviet Union almost ended in a riot, coming as it did shortly after the anti-Soviet uprising in Hungary. "It was a subject country trying to gain independence," Young said.
Then there are the most infamous expressions of nationalism: Adolf Hitler using the 1936 Berlin Games to promote Nazism and Palestinian terrorists murdering 11 Israeli athletes in Munich in 1972, as well as the exchange of cold war boycotts between the United States and many Eastern bloc countries during the 1980 and 1984 Summer Games in Moscow and Los Angeles.
But one of the most famous social statements at the Olympics pointed to the Games as a potential forum for transnational politics. It came in Mexico City in 1968, when two American medal winners, John Carlos and Tommie Smith, raised their gloved fists in a black power salute as they stood on the awards podium. With "The Star-Spangled Banner" playing, the two were rejecting what their nation represented to emphasize what they insisted was the universal blight of racism. 
That defiant gesture shook the Mexican government as much as that of the United States; days before the Olympics, government troops in Mexico City had killed what historians now estimate were hundreds of student protesters. By kicking Carlos and Smith off its Olympic team and sending them home, Washington demonstrated its allegiances during the political conflicts of the 1960's that superseded borders.
These days, transnationalism can show itself in a far different manner. During the 1996 Summer Games in Atlanta, Visa ran ads promoting a "Visa decathlon team" made up of sponsored athletes from different countries. Multinationals like McDonald's and Coca-Cola now pay the equivalent of more than $50 million to be called "worldwide sponsors." These messages of universality are far different from anything that Carlos, Smith and de Coubertin could have imagined.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Where the Minorities Rule

BYLINE:  By GREGORY RODRIGUEZ; Gregory Rodriguez is a senior fellow at the New America Foundation, a nonpartisan research institute.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
FOR more than two decades, a mural on the wall of a public housing project in East Los Angeles has been exhorting the neighborhood's mostly Mexican-American residents to stop thinking of themselves as members of a minority group. "We are NOT a minority!" the image of a finger-wagging revolutionary declares. 
 After a generation of mass migration, this slogan is becoming a statistical reality in Los Angeles and other areas across the Southwest. Last week, the Census Bureau announced there are more immigrants in America than ever before in the nation's history -- numerically though not proportionally -- and the largest single block is from Mexico. While Latin American immigrants now live in all parts of the country, 1 in 2 Latinos are in two states: California and Texas. Even as the Census Bureau has announced that Hispanics are on the verge of becoming the largest minority group, many live in cities or states where they are either already the largest minority group or members of the majority. 
 As a result, many 1970's-era policies designed to integrate nonwhites into the mainstream have been rendered moot or now serve to ensure white participation in predominately nonwhite programs and school districts. Indeed, in cities and counties where Latinos are either the single largest ethnic group or have become the absolute majority, it is often unclear what diversity means and at what ends integration policies should aim. More significant, class is replacing race as the primary political preoccupation of the predominately Mexican-American cities of the Southwest.
Last year, just days after the Census Bureau announced that the nation's most populous state, California, had become the first big state where whites were in the minority, the San Diego City Council banned "minority" from official documents and discussions. Arguing that the word was outmoded and demeaning, council members pushed the debate into the national spotlight.
For many Latinos in heavily Hispanic regions, the term has become too confining and parochial for their reality. Their growing demographic presence in the Southwest has translated into increased local representation and wider political aspirations. No longer playing a supporting role, Mexican-American officials are diversifying their political portfolios and expanding their electoral bases. "Now that we are no longer banging on the door to get in, but are seated at the table," said the Los Angeles City Council president, Alex Padilla, "we have the responsibility to address broader issues that affect the entire city, state and country. The Latino agenda becomes safer communities, good schools, jobs -- in other words, non-ethnic considerations." As Latino politics mature, race-specific issues take a back seat to matters of economic mobility. 
The debate that has flared up over the redrawing of two California Congressional districts shows how changing demographics are reshaping Hispanic political strategy. Last year, when the Latino rights organization Maldef (the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Educational Fund) charged that the redrawing discriminated against Latinos, prominent Latino lawmakers and union officials argued that non-Latinos could well represent the interests of Latino constituents. In The Los Angeles Times, the liberal state senators Martha Escutia and Gloria Romero argued against creating Latino-majority districts through civil-rights litigation. "We should not relegate ourselves to a few court-imposed barrios," they wrote in an op-ed article. 
Foreshadowing this transition toward majoritarian politics, California's lieutenant governor, Cruz Bustamante, declared three years ago that Latino elected officials "have to de-ghettoize ourselves." 
This sentiment is being felt in other fields. While cultural politics don't always adhere to the same internal logic as electoral politics, Latinos' shift toward majority status has also begun to affect the ethnic marketplace. Last year, for example, the film director Robert Rodriguez said he believed Latino audiences don't want to see Latino-specific films "because they don't want to feel like a niche." 
In her book on the emergence of the Hispanic consumer market, Arlene Davila, a New York University anthropologist, argues that while ethnic marketing has brought unprecedented attention to Latinos, it also defines them away from the American mainstream. 
What more and more Southwest Latinos can agree on is that they are becoming less content with the circumscribed opportunities that their official minority status and multiculturalism now afford them. For example, in the Los Angeles Unified School District, which is 71 percent Hispanic, Latinos' majority status actually puts them at a disadvantage when applying to magnet schools. Originally developed as an alternative to forced busing, the city's select magnet program was designed to integrate ethnic minority students and encourage them to look beyond their neighborhoods.
But today, whites' newfound minority status gives them an advantage when applying to magnet schools. While the district is only 9 percent white, 22 percent of its magnet students are. The racial formula used to balance the makeup of the magnets also ensures that blacks and Asians are over-represented, while Latinos make up no more than 40 percent. While such policies were designed a generation ago to allow members of ethnic minority groups in the door, today, in many parts of the Southwest, they are becoming glass ceilings.
NONE of this is to say that integration is not a major concern in the heavily Hispanic regions of the country. But the focus is shifting toward the socioeconomic integration of immigrants. Changing demography does not eradicate the traditional obstacles that newcomers still face in America. Indeed, politics in many cities that have survived wholesale ethnic succession indicate that future battles will be fought along economic lines.
Weeks before last year's mayoral race in El Paso, Tex., a city nearly three-quarters Mexican-American, Pat O'Rourke, a former county commissioner, declared that all longtime El Pasoans were culturally Hispanic. "We are all Mexicans in this valley," he wrote. "What causes resentment among groups today is not ethnicity, but economic differences."
Indeed, two years ago, in McAllen, Tex., a coalition of churches and schools working to improve the city's socioeconomic ills successfully championed a ballot measure that changed the at-large election system to create single-member political districts. Opposed by Mayor Leo Montalvo because it would dilute Hispanic voting power, activists argued that ethnicity was no longer as important as geography and class. 
Of course, in most of America, Latinos remain a fledgling minority group. The immigrant experience in the South or Northwest, where Latino immigrants have a small but growing presence, bears little resemblance to life in the Southwest. In most regions, the term "minority" and traditional integration policies still make sense. "In Oregon, Latinos are the largest minority group, but we're still only 8 percent of the state," says Amalia Alarcon-Gaddie, director of the Metropolitan Human Rights Center in Portland. "Here we do still need to be vigilant about minority integration." 
Still, last year demographers concluded that Texas, the second most populous state, could follow California and become the second majority-minority state by 2004. Hispanics are now the largest ethnic or racial group in its two biggest cities, Houston and Dallas.
Though the emergence of Latino America has been depicted as the addition of one more color to the nation's multicultural rainbow, the Mexican-American experience in the Southwest is subsuming the region's entire color spectrum and challenging American notions of minority membership.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Unlike Market Bubbles, This Variety Doesn't Pop

BYLINE:  By Jennifer 8. Lee 

 BODY:
Many of today's most popular toys are infused with circuits, infrared sensors and quasi-artificial intelligence, but how about a toy that can entertain simply by not disappearing?
 At least two toy companies at the American International Toy Fair in New York, which begins this weekend, are pinning their hopes on bubbles that won't pop for days. 
 Spin Master Toys of Toronto will be showing off Catch-A-Bubble, which produces catchable and stackable bubbles. The product, created by Peter Fish, an Australian toy inventor, has already been a hit in Australia and Singapore. Spin Master executives spotted the bubbles at a toy show in Hong Kong last month and signed a contract with Mr. Fish within hours. They have a suggested retail price of $2.99.
Jakks Pacific Inc. of Malibu, Calif., has its own version on exhibit, a product called Liqualoons. It says Liqualoons will be available later in the year at a suggested retail price of $4.99. Jennifer 8. Lee

HEADLINE: Big Farms Making a Mess Of U.S. Waters, Cities Say 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: DEDHAM, Iowa 

 BODY:
By the time the Raccoon River winds through the western hills here, passing corn fields and livestock pens before reaching Des Moines miles to the east, it is so polluted the city has to put it through a special nutrient filter to meet government standards for drinking water.
 The culprits are not industrial plants or mines belching toxins into the river. They are Iowa farms, which send fertilizer and animal wastes into the groundwater and into the river. 
 "Farmers are the problem," said L. D. McMullen, the general manager of the Des Moines Water Works. "And they are entirely unregulated." 
The issue goes beyond Iowa. Across the country, metropolitan water agencies are battling increasing pollution from the countryside. The river pollution is spreading and helping to cause dead zones in the open seas. A recent study by the Pew Oceans Commission, an independent group examining government policies, called huge livestock feedlots and farm fertilizer runoff among the fastest-growing sources of pollution in oceans thousands of miles away. 
As a result, the $171 billion, 10-year farm bill, once seen as a parochial issue for rural lawmakers, has been scrutinized by members of Congress from urban and suburban districts who realize that the upheaval in agriculture has implications beyond the grocery store. 
The bill includes several proposals to reduce water pollution, like increased money to encourage farmers to practice conservation, increased money to protect wetlands, and limits on subsidies so the federal program will not underwrite further farm consolidation. On Thursday, the Senate voted to limit a farmer's annual subsidy to $275,000, half of the current limit. It is unclear if that cap will survive negotiations with the House, which has voted to keep the current limit, $550,000. 
In Iowa, farmers cultivated land with the help of more federal subsidies than farmers in any other state -- $6.75 billion in five years. In a state with no national parks or forests, which keep the land in its natural state, the Iowa countryside has been awash in fertilizers, pesticides, herbicides and animal wastes, some politicians, scientists and environmental groups say.
"We have the most subsidies and the lowest amount of public lands of any state in the union," said Senator Tom Harkin, the Iowa Democrat who is chairman of the Agriculture Committee. 
In the last six years there have been 152 fish kills in Iowa -- leaving 5.7 million fish floating dead in rivers and lakes polluted by fertilizer runoff or leakage from hog and cattle manure lagoons. 
Half of Iowa's lake beaches were temporarily closed last year because of agricultural pollution, said Craig A. Cox, executive vice president of the Soil and Water Conservation Society, based in Iowa.
"Over the last 20 years, we've farmed fence row to fence row, encouraged by federal subsidies, and changed the whole landscape of Iowa," Mr. Cox said. "Farmsteads with groves of trees, patches of wetland and well-planted river banks have been eliminated. Without those natural buffers, we've short-circuited the natural filters and ended up with these water problems."
But those who have large farms say it is wrong to blame them for water pollution. John E. Conrad and his three brothers operate a 5,000-acre spread in Rose Hill, Iowa, that received $921,654 in subsidies over five years and is among the top recipients in the state. 
When the government started paying farmers to practice conservation, the Conrad brothers planted grass strips along most of their streams. They have resisted building manure lagoons for their 3,000 hogs in confinement pens; instead they recycle the waste on their fields.
"We have everything the smaller farmer has for conservation," Mr. Conrad said. "If our subsidies were limited, we'd go out of business." 
The relationship between federal subsidies and the water problems begins with farm payments that encourage big farms to grow bigger, buying out smaller farmers who tend to be better conservationists, said Michael Duffy, an agricultural economist at Iowa State University.
The big farmers then "plant for subsidies, not for the market," Mr. Duffy said, producing some of the best yields of corn in the state's history. A glut in the global market means farmers are paid $2 less than their cost per bushel. But federal subsidies essentially make up the difference. That cheap corn is then bought by large farms, which feed it to animals, leading to profitable business for meat packers. 
"The most drastic charts don't begin to show the revolution in agriculture in the last 10 years," Mr. Duffy said. "Sometimes I think the government is wearing blindfolds when it ignores how the farm program is creating the misery out there."
The number of big farms has doubled over the last two decades while middle-size family farms that manage to stay in business have lost half their earnings. The average number of hogs per farm shot up to 1,300 in 2001, from 400 in 1995, creating the huge manure lagoons scattered across Iowa.
At the same time, the state's water quality has declined, although debate continues about who bears the greatest responsibility. 
Without taking sides, the Iowa Farm Bureau has created programs to plant trees and grass buffer strips and to monitor water pollution. 
For Mr. McMullen, the water manager in Des Moines, about 70 miles east of here, there is little doubt that agriculture and livestock are the source of his city's water problems. Two Iowa State University scientists recently reported how huge hog manure lagoons were seeping into the state's groundwater.
"The water quality this December is the worst we've had in winter," Mr. McMullen said. "And we're expecting the worst spring on record."
For the first time, he and other city water managers are lobbying Congress to put money in the farm bill to clean up water pollution at its source, the fields and livestock pens.
Last summer Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman agreed to give the state an additional $40 million to improve water polluted by excess nitrates.
While farmers may be reluctant to accept responsibility for water pollution, they are eager to be part of the solution. Jon Judson, a farmer and biologist, persuaded his neighbors to plant borders of native big blue stem and switch grasses to filter runoff. 
Mr. Judson's mission was financed by wealthy Iowans who built their homes around an artificial lake that was becoming cloudy. 
Now, through the fog covering his farm, Mr. Judson can point to nearby fields where every stream is lined with frozen grasses and new bare trees break the monotony of low Iowa sky. 
"Once farmers saw the benefits they brought to a neighbor, then it wasn't hard to get them to put conservation into practice on their land," he said.
"They saw what they had forgotten -- that it pays to take care of your soil and water."

HEADLINE: City Hall Seeks Refinancing To Reduce Debt Payments 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
With the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates 11 times in just over a year, many homeowners have refinanced their mortgages at more favorable terms. Now New York City officials want to take advantage of low interest rates to refinance some of the city's $40.8 billion in outstanding debt.
 Refinancing the debt could save the city as much as $200 million by some estimates and would basically entail selling new bonds with lower interest rates to pay off the city's old high-interest bonds. 
 But to do so, the city must first persuade the federal government to ease some restrictions it places on municipal debt. The city may also relax some of its own policies governing debt refinancing. 
The issue has taken on new urgency as the city struggles to close a deficit estimated at $2.9 billion to $4.7 billion for the fiscal year that begins on July 1. 
So far, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been silent about details of the austerity budget, which he plans to announce on Wednesday. But he has made it abundantly clear that all city agencies should expect cuts and that he is dead set against raising taxes. So city officials are looking for other ways to raise and save money, including debt refinancing.
The city constantly borrows money by selling bonds to pay for capital projects like building schools and other public buildings and repairing roads. Unlike businesses, though, the city often finds itself unable to wait for favorable market conditions to sell its bonds, so it sells bonds even when interest rates, and therefore the cost of borrowing, are high.
The city's growing debt load is causing concern among fiscal monitors. The city and state comptrollers have warned that the city could soon find itself paying 19 cents of every dollar it collects in taxes to pay off its debts, money that it could otherwise spend on things like more police officers or teachers. 
When interest rates fall, the city can try to refinance its debt. This is most often done by selling new bonds at the lower interest rates, and putting the proceeds of that sale into an escrow account that earns enough interest to pay off the cost of the original bonds that were sold. Thus, those high-interest bonds are retired, and the city is left paying back the second set of bonds at the lower interest rate. The process is known in the industry as advance refunding.
Now, though, with the city in dire fiscal straits, it finds itself unable to take advantage of tantalizingly low interest rates because of a 1986 federal law that prohibits local governments from refinancing debt more than once. Municipal bonds are tax exempt, and officials wanted to limit the number of interest-earning tax-exempt bonds put in circulation to pay for the same public project.
New York City has already refinanced much of its high-interest debt, only to see interest rates continue to plummet. Its hands, therefore, are tied. If the federal restriction is eased, the city can refinance the debt a second time at the lower rates, saving more money.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has proposed a bill that would permit a second advance refunding in some cases. Her proposal would allow New York City, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the city's water authority and its hospitals to refinance their debt a second time in cases where the original debt issuance has been paid off. This could be done in cases in which the city has already redeemed one series of high-interest bonds by issuing lower-interest bonds, only to see interest rates fall further.
The Bloomberg administration plans to ask the federal government to approve the change, said Jordan Barowitz, a mayoral spokesman.
Before leaving office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wrote a letter to Senator Clinton praising the proposal to allow second advance refundings. "This would result in savings for the city of up to $200 million," Mr. Giuliani wrote in the letter, dated Nov. 16.
The city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., said that he would support allowing a second refinancing. "This would allow us to take advantage of what are almost historic low interest rates," he said. 
Mr. Thompson said that his office was considering relaxing some restrictions that his predecessor, Alan G. Hevesi, had placed on debt refinancing. As comptroller, Mr. Hevesi adopted a policy of refusing to allow an advance refunding to go forward unless it provided a certain level of savings up front and did not drive up the amount of money that the city had to pay on debt service in any future year.
While fiscal monitors praised that strict policy, some municipal finance experts said that some refinancing proposals could be good deals over all even if they did not show a savings every year. 
Mr. Thompson said his office had received several proposals for debt refinancing, including some that did not conform to Mr. Hevesi's standards. "We're looking at it," he said. "We haven't made a final decision. I think the thing that everyone is interested in is in generating savings in ways that are prudent."
Diana Fortuna, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, said that the rules under Mr. Hevesi had served the city well and that the city should think twice before relaxing them. "The point is to protect future New Yorkers," she said. "Without standards, it's too tempting to push costs into the future to solve a budget crunch today."

HEADLINE: Planner Joins Group Overseeing Restoration of Lower Manhattan 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
Alexander Garvin, a member of the City Planning Commission and an adjunct professor of urban planning and management at Yale University, will join the agency created to come up with a development plan for the World Trade Center site and the surrounding areas, a spokesman said yesterday.
 Mr. Garvin will hold the title of vice president for planning, design and development for the agency, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, said Edward G. Novotny, a spokesman for the corporation. 
 He will continue to serve as a city planning commissioner in addition to his role as planning director for NYC2012, the nonprofit organization that is leading efforts to bring the Olympic Games to New York City in 2012.
Several officials, including Gov. George E. Pataki and Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, gave Mr. Garvin high marks for his commitment to the city over the years.
"I am very pleased that Alex Galvin has agreed to serve as chief planner for the L.M.D.C.," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said through a spokesman. "He is a gifted urban planner and committed public servant who brings tremendous perspective and vision to the job. I know his work on behalf of the L.M.D.C. will prove instrumental in reshaping and revitalizing Lower Manhattan." 
Mr. Garvin said through a spokesman: "We need to develop an appropriate way to honor those who perished on Sept. 11th. The residents, business and property owners of Lower Manhattan expect to get back to normal as quickly as possible."
Tara Snow, formerly a policy adviser to Governor Pataki, was appointed the corporation's vice president for community and government relations, to serve as the liaison to government agencies and public officials.
Matthew Higgins, a former press secretary for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, was appointed vice president for communications for the corporation.

HEADLINE: Turn Out the Lights; the Party's Over; 
After Enron, Deregulation Is Looking Less Sexy

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The electricity business was starting to get sort of sexy as deregulation brought new ideas and styles to New York starting in the late 1990's. Blow-dried hipster capitalists were in; starchy government regulators were out. A frontier mentality, epitomized by companies like Enron, the once-giant Houston-based energy trader, blew into New York bearing all the trappings of Marlboro Country. Wildcatters, roughnecks and bright-eyed dreamers staked their claims. 
 Pass the word: the starch is back in town. Government, which was, at least in theory, supposed to be exiting stage right as deregulation proceeded, is instead assuming in many ways a more central role than ever in how energy in New York -- and other states as well, notably California -- gets made, distributed and sold. 
 The even keel for electricity supply that has been predicted for New York City this summer is made possible not so much by the rough-and-tumble open market as by the state bureaucrats at the New York Power Authority, which built 10 house-size power plants around the city last year, providing 400 extra megawatts of power, which is expected to be crucial come July and August. 
At the same time, state conservation and efficiency programs put together last year promise to reduce electricity use during peak periods, like hot summer days, energy experts say, giving New York important breathing room this year to address its long-term energy needs.
But the frontier mentality is also on the run for reasons that go deeper than mere megawatts. The terrorist attack in September, state officials said, reinforced as never before the connection between energy dependability and energy security, which they say must be the government's province. Protecting the system -- through measures like diversification of fuel supplies -- has become a major element in the state energy plan being completed this spring. 
At the same time, the collapse of Enron, which was considered the leading voice for reducing government regulation to a minimum, has made fusty bureaucrats look good by comparison.
California -- both in its energy meltdown last year and its subsequent response, with things like energy-efficiency construction standards -- has further inspired those who think that more should be rendered unto the public sphere and less to the market.
"The Enron mantra that government can screw up anything it touches and markets are superior -- this argument no longer has any credibility whatsoever," said William Hogan, a professor of public policy and administration at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, who is a leading authority on electricity regulation.
"If you stand up after Enron and 9/11 and say something like that, people look at you like you're crazy," he said.
Few experts suggest that the pendulum has shifted so far that states like New York will reverse course altogether and return to the old fully regulated monopoly days, even if they could. (Most power plants that were owned by utilities have been sold to other owners, for one thing.)
But experts from fields as varied as environmentalism and economics say the momentum is clearly toward government, as one industry official put it, "with a thumb on the scale."
Historians say that the deregulatory tilt also had very broad social and economic forces behind it. Many people probably now associate the beginnings of deregulation, in the 1970's, with the conservative get-government-off-our-backs mentality that propelled people like Ronald Reagan into office, as governor of California, and later, as president. But crucial support also came from the political left, said Richard Abrams, a professor of history at the University of California at Berkeley who studies government-business relations.
Although business was irked by pollution and affirmative action laws passed in the late 1960's and early 1970's, Professor Abrams said, there was also a groundswell of opinion against big monopolies fueled by the leftover social impulses of the 1960's. Ma Bell became an object of ridicule, and was later broken up. Ralph Nader argued that regulation tended to reinforce the status quo, rewarding companies that were already connected.
Now, some energy industry officials say they fear things could tip too far the other way.
"The rush to regulation scares me," said M. William Brier, a vice president for communication at the Edison Electric Institute, a trade group. He said that the industry's task, at a moment when people are anxious and things seem to have broken down, is to keep things in perspective. The Enron scandal, he said, is about financial markets and accounting, not about energy and electricity.
"It doesn't have anything to do with us," he said.
For the new government interventionists, there is also a fine line to be walked. The chairman of the New York State Energy Planning Board, William M. Flynn, said that the terrorist attack last fall forced a shift in thinking about energy security by the people formulating the state's new energy plan, which will be released in late spring or early summer.
But Mr. Flynn, who is also president of the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority, which administers a $150 million-a-year fund for conservation and efficiency programs, said his marketing efforts have drawn the line at linking things like energy self-sufficiency or conservation programs directly to public concerns about possible terrorist disruptions.
"It makes talking about these issues much more serious," he said. "But no, we don't have an overt emphasis on security. The programs speak for themselves."
Some electrical-system administrators say that the current period of quiet in the electricity market in New York -- with lower prices, lower demand and adequate supplies forecast through the summer -- also heightens and complicates government's responsibility to keep residents and business leaders focused on long-term needs. 
Many power plants that were proposed for New York are now unlikely to be built because of a tightening in the financial markets as a result of the Enron debacle, and many ratepayers might not think about electricity when the lights stay on and the bills don't go up.
But that is when it falls to government to stand at the mountain top and take the long view, said Steve Sullivan, a spokesman for the New York State Independent System Operator, which runs the state's power grid. 
New York State will need 7,300 megawatts of new power supply over the next five years, he said, but the money and the will must be committed now.
Other experts say that government gets too much credit as it is.
Jerry Taylor, the director of natural resource studies at the Cato Institute, a research group in Washington that favors limited government and free markets, argues that most state conservation and efficiency programs do not really work at all.
The real reason that demand was shaved off the anticipated peaks in New York last year and the summer before, which was far hotter, was the rate structure, Mr. Taylor said. The system allowed higher prices to be passed onto consumers. That meant that when supplies got tight, prices rose, sending a powerful economic signal to customers -- especially big businesses that had the most to lose -- to cut back energy use. 
In California, by contrast, price caps on electricity kept it cheap even during last year's crisis, which gave people and businesses little economic incentive to conserve, compounding the crisis, Mr. Taylor said.
In New York, the rate structure for utilities sends signals that many environmentalists say are also completely contradictory to the state's official goals.
Because utilities like Consolidated Edison, which serves New York City and its northern suburbs, make their profits by moving as much energy through their wires as they can, they have no interest -- or at best a conflicted interest -- in having their customers using less electricity through steps like conservation.
Under the old regulated system, by contrast, utilities were rewarded for reducing demand. Now the state discourages conservation with one hand and encourages it with the other, the critics say. The result might look like smart government, but it depends on your point of view. 
"We still don't have a good long-term strategy, or even a medium-term strategy," said Ashok Gupta, a senior energy economist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a New York-based conservation group. "We have ideology followed by crisis management, but no strategy."

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
If Elected . . .N.C.A.A. Needs A Fresh Man

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
This early in my Year at School, I am certain of what I absolutely know because I know so little. I have attended a few meetings at an N.C.A.A. national convention and I have read many of the hundreds of overwhelmingly supportive e-mail messages sent to thelipsite@aol.com. Most have come from faculty members concerned that their schools have become sports entertainment centers to the detriment of the academy and reform-minded athletic administrators.
 Before I form entangling alliances, lose my innocence, start to see nuances, I would like to offer myself as a candidate for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's presidency, a position that will be available at year's end. The incumbent, Cedric Dempsey, a longtime athletics administrator, recently asked for an extension of his eight-year term to effect reforms, specifically to defuse the financial "arms race" among the major powers. The response of the executive committee was, in effect, "Thanks and so long, Ced." 
 Dempsey has been criticized, perhaps not fairly, as failing to address many of the major issues facing college sports, including the widening gap between rich and poor programs, and the further decline of academic performance among the men who play football and basketball. He was making more than $700,000 a year.
Enter the fresh man. I am not in this only for the money. It's a vision thing.
There has been a growing movement within the N.C.A.A. to hire a university president as its head and send the message that educators are ready to take control of sports. To hire a former coach or sports administrator, the line goes, would be letting foxes guard the henhouse. Beyond the obvious sexism and species-ism of that cliche is its self-service; university presidents are at least as much part of the problem as coaches and athletic directors.
After all, Knute Rockne at Notre Dame, Jerry Tarkanian at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, and now Bob Knight at Texas Tech were all hired by presidents who wanted to buy national attention for their institutions of higher learning without having to go to the trouble and expense of stocking the library or recruiting superstar faculty members. And in every one of those cases, the tactic worked.
So let's get back to my candidacy. There are three main planks in my platform.
ONE. Let's give the 115 schools of Division I-A, the top sports entertainment centers, a break in their struggle to keep their athletes students. I would create three graduation tracks: Grind, Party and Jock. Each would have its own entrance and eligibility requirements. Only Grinds, for example, would be allowed to take such courses in the newly created Athlo-American Studies Department as "Flooding the Zone and the Clash of Civilizations" (why jocks are different); "College Concussions and Middle-Aged Depression" (the medical aspects of competition); and "Pay for Play" (whether the University of Minnesota is getting its money's worth by subsidizing athletics, primarily football, at nearly $9 million a year). 
Students who opt for the Party track would be required to attend all football and basketball games and rallies, home and away, as well as a specified number of other men's and women's sports. They would be graded on the creativity of their cheering and body paint.
Athletes, with permission, would be allowed to take Grind or Party courses. But those in conferences that have booked late weeknight television games, such as the Atlantic Coast, would have no classes scheduled before noon.
TWO. Let's have racial quotas, although I would prefer to call it Color Coordination. An institution's percentage of black or Hispanic or Native-American athletes would be measured against its percentage of black or Hispanic or Native-American Grind and Party students. That will help us arrive at a proper proportion of black or Hispanic or American Indian faculty members and coaches. How will I enforce this without spending the rest of my presidency in court? Easy. Any school in compliance with Color Coordination can be sure that no one on its campus will be investigated by my Resume Inflation task force.
THREE. Let's end the fabricated battle of the sexes. Wise guys have been eliminating so-called minor men's sports and saying that the cuts were necessary to comply with the equity provisions of Title IX. Blame the women when it's all about keeping those bloated football squads with their 85 (85!) scholarships and their enormous costs. Meanwhile, some very intense athletes are being dumped, like gymnasts and wrestlers ("Guys hugging each other on the floor, what could be wrong with that?" asks the Syracuse lawyer Karen DeCrow, who has been handling many Title IX settlement agreements). Tell the truth so athletes don't hate women for the wrong reasons.
Unless I am elected -- or someone in my league is (lotsa luck finding that person!) -- expect the end of college sports as we know it. The N.C.A.A. will be submerged by creeping Olympism, which leads to total commercialism. The nation will be revolted by an Enron-level college football scandal. ("Call it Endrun," says the coach and former Olympian Pat Connolly.) 
Congress will decree sudden death by asking the reform-minded college presidents of the Knight Commission, their warnings unheeded all these years, to preside at jock divestiture. Sports teams will be disengaged from their universities, as cabooses are unhitched from trains.
Is that what you people want instead of me?

This Series So Far
This is the third article in a series that will explore the role of college sports in American culture. Previous articles have included insights into sports' administration and direction gained from the N.C.A.A.'s annual convention last month in Indianapolis and the disparate views of a university president and a discriminating fan.
