HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Who Stands To Benefit As Military Expands

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH'S 2003 budget calls for a $48 billion, or 14 percent, jump in military spending, the biggest increase in two decades. While a sizable chunk is for pay raises, health care and the impact of inflation on programs, weapons procurement would rise 12 percent, reversing a general decline through most of the 1990's.
 Assuming that Congress approves the bulk of the plan amid patriotic fervor, this implies good times for companies that produce equipment, some of which recently proved itself in the war in Afghanistan. 
 Howard A. Rubel, aerospace and defense analyst at Goldman Sachs, took time last week to discuss the industry and which companies were best positioned to benefit. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. Is this military buildup seen as a pretty big deal on Wall Street?

A. You bet. Many weapons systems and platforms of the 1980's are becoming obsolete. Sept. 11 shined a bright light on a host of needs. For example, the average age of the Air Force fleet is somewhere around 23 years, compared with around 16 years then. If current trends continued, we could be looking at a fleet averaging very close to 30 years, an extreme situation for a country that prides itself on being technologically advanced. We had thought there would be a 4 to 7 percent increase, to about $350 billion; twice that is quite striking.

Q. I suppose it's telling that none of the older systems are to be eliminated. Didn't we expect at least one of the three new jet fighter programs to be canceled or cut?

A. We're using 40-year-old B-52's to bomb the Taliban, but it is the precision weapons they carried that made the substantial difference. The force multiplier of technology really worked. And look what happened: we got all three fighter programs.

Q. What surprised you in the budget?

A. It's hard to have a lot of surprises in a $379 billion budget; it requires a lot of planning. The surprise was the overall size and also dividing it into two elements, the core and an additional $10 billion for discretionary items.

Q. Most of the stocks, with the exception of Boeing, are trading near 52-week highs. How do you appraise the group now?

A. There's opportunity for the stocks to deliver very good returns, but it's not a straight line. They are affected by political perceptions, technological innovations and the performance of individual companies. We're at a point where all three are favorable, and this will continue for a while. This industry is much more tightly run, more efficient than the way it used to be.
My call is that we'll see share prices move up in line with earnings growth of from low single digits to midteens, versus probably 7 percent for the market as a whole. But most of the expansion of price-earnings multiples is behind us. We have the group overweighted and have for some time.

Q. Which are your favorites among the military contractors?

A. What I am recommending is a mix of names. One is Boeing. All the civil aviation stocks took a tremendous pounding the first week the market reopened after Sept. 11. To walk away then would have been selling at the bottom, and since then they've provided pretty good returns. While you're going to see declining output at Boeing, its price reflects the essential market risk.
Their space and defense business alone is worth in the low $30's, and with the stock at about $40 you have a call on the global economy when it turns. You don't pay much for a very powerful commercial franchise. Some of its space and defense programs, such as missile defense, are at important crossroads, and they are in the heart of the market as a key supplier of satellite systems such as Wide Band Gap Filler. The company should generate $2.5 billion-plus in free cash this year and possibly more than $3 billion next year, a 9 percent free cash flow yield. The stock should be trading today in the mid-to upper $40's.

Q. What are your other favorite military companies?

A. Last month we added Rockwell Collins, a leading supplier of avionics, to our recommended list. The stock got pounded because investors associated it almost exclusively with Boeing, but the reality is that only about 8 percent of Collins's sales are to Boeing directly. It should earn $1.20 a share this fiscal year and $1.40 in 2003. It has a unique franchise, with many of their commercial applications also serving the military, and a spectacular balance sheet.
Of course, we also like a couple of the big guys that are pure plays, like Lockheed Martin and General Dynamics. All the major companies have evolved to meet changing needs.

Q. Which companies' stocks would you avoid?

A. We have Northrop Grumman and Raytheon as market performers. We're not recommending them.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
On Tax Cuts And Deficits, A Battle Of Believers

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH sent his budget plan to Congress last week, igniting a partisan battle over how to allocate the government's revenue during a time of war and recession.
 But with surpluses giving way to deficits and the prospects evaporating for substantially reducing the national debt, the debate will also focus new attention on a fundamental difference between the two parties. 
 Do budget deficits and rising debt inherently harm the economy by pushing up long-term interest rates? Or are deficits, and a reasonable level of debt, acceptable prices to pay for taking steps like cutting taxes that will help the economy in the long run?
Since early in the Clinton administration, most Democrats have embraced the idea that fiscal discipline creates a virtuous cycle. They are convinced that paying down the national debt by maintaining annual surpluses helps the economy by putting downward pressure on interest rates. 
Conversely, Democrats say, running deficits means more government borrowing and upward pressure on rates. To them, Mr. Bush's budget is a travesty. It shows three years of deficits followed by at least another seven years in which much of the money assumed to be reserved for debt reduction -- the Social Security surplus -- is eaten up by other needs, primarily last year's tax cut and increased military spending.
"If you're not able to pay down the debt, that means the federal government is competing with private-sector borrowers for money, driving up the cost of interest rates," said Senator Kent Conrad, the North Dakota Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. 
"That's a hidden tax on every American family," he said. "Higher mortgage payments. Higher car payments. Higher college loan payments. And so I think we want to think very carefully about what this means to the economic future of the country."
Balderdash, Republicans say. 
The Republicans say they are all for balanced budgets. But they favor fiscal austerity not because of interest rates, but because they believe in small government and the primacy of market forces. 
More to the point, they believe in tax cuts as an economic cure-all. Slavish adherence to maintaining surpluses would make carrying out the tax cut championed by Mr. Bush last year -- and further tax cuts -- complicated if not impossible.
Republicans tend to argue that the first order of business is to get the economy going full-throttle again. After that, they say, surpluses will take care of themselves. 
"It's a good economy that leads to a good budget situation, not the other way around," said R. Glenn Hubbard, the chairman of the White House's Council of Economic Advisers. "The seeds of the good budget for the 1990's were largely the roaring economy and spending restraint."
Democrats, Mr. Hubbard said, have never been able to prove that long-term rates, which move in response to a wide array of factors, are affected in any big way by deficits. "We have very little empirical evidence to suggest much of a link between deficits and interest rates," he said. 
The most-cited piece of economic research on the topic was done in 1998 by N. Gregory Mankiw of Harvard University and Douglas Elmendorf of the Federal Reserve Board. They found that "the interest-rate effects of typical changes in government debt are quite small," Mr. Mankiw said.
But he said focusing exclusively on interest-rate implications of long-term fiscal policy oversimplifies the economic issues. He said those range from generational equity -- do we want to dump all this debt on our children? -- to national savings and approaches to shoring up Social Security.
DEMOCRATS also have some powerful allies on their side. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, is one. Though a Republican and an ardent believer in tax cuts, he has said publicly several times in recent months that the worsening fiscal outlook has had an effect on long-term rates. 
In any case, the changes to the fiscal outlook are considerable. This year, the White House projects that the national debt held by the public in the form of Treasury securities will fall by roughly $1 trillion, to $2.5 trillion, over the next decade. A year ago, the White House projected that the debt could be wiped out by 2011.
Because of the worsened fiscal outlook, Congress will have to increase the government's debt limit again in the next few weeks. Don't look for the debate to end there -- or anytime soon.

HEADLINE: EVENING HOURS; 
Encores

BYLINE:  By Bill Cunningham 

 BODY:

CORRECTION-DATE: February 24, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption with the Evening Hours column on Feb. 10 about a benefit for the Juilliard School on Feb. 4 misidentified the woman shown with Dan Lufkin. She was Jeannie Leff, not Cynthia Lufkin.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
John Q. Public Library?

BYLINE:  By FRANZ LIDZ; Franz Lidz, the author of "Unstrung Heroes," a memoir, is a senior writer at Sports Illustrated.

 BODY:
EVER since the city of Macon christened its minor-league hockey team the Whoopees, we've been thinking of other communities whose names might lend themselves to similarly evocative couplings, like, say, the Spokane Words or the Juneau Whats or the Nome Chomskys. Imagine a Pusan football team called the Boots, or an Algiers soccer squad dubbed the Hisses. And while you're at it, consider the Cali Flowers, the Vichy Swabs, the Delhi Contessas and the Augusta Winds. 
 New York City may be playing a similar name game now that Mayor Bloomberg has asked the private sector to help it through the current financial crisis. To tap into the philanthropic largess of corporations and wealthy donors, Mr. Bloomberg has offered naming rights for areas in the city in much the same way the Selwyn Theater on 42nd Street recently signed an $8.5 million, 10-year deal to change its handle to the American Airlines Theater. 
 In time, the naming offers may even extend to municipal landmarks. Of course, a cynic might say Mr. Bloomberg himself bought the naming rights to the entire city. But that's the subject for another column.
Happily, Crazy Eddie's is no longer around to underwrite the Guggenheim Museum (one Crazy Guggenheim was quite enough, thank you). But what if Nathan's hot dogs donates millions to the U.N.? Can we expect the United Nathans? Or if John Quincy Adams VIII not-so-quietly finances the New York Public Library. There's kind of an empty Everyman ring to the John Q. Public Library.
Sure, some pairings sound relatively benign: the Calgon bath oil bead company might do well to prop up the Algonquin, thus creating the Calgonquin. 
And the Lefrak City complex in Queens could bequeath part of its profits to the Frick Collection, thereby forming the LeFrick & Frak Collection. But please, Wish-Bone salad dressing: Stay away from the Waldorf-Astoria. The last thing this city needs is a Waldorf Salad Astoria. If Grand Central Terminal got sizable contributions from Oldsmobile and Oprah Winfrey, could New Yorkers coexist with the Grand Olds Oprah? 
Other partnerships sound equally unpalatable. If somehow the boxing scribe Bert Sugar and the former "Brady Bunch" actress Eve Plumb pooled their cash to save the Staten Island Ferry, well, care to work this one out for yourself? Similarly, if U-Haul hitched itself to the Museum of Modern Art, would arts patrons think twice about spending a day at U-MOMA?
In his rush to shore up the city's economy, Mayor Bloomberg should start in his own backyard. If Gracie Mansion were to get a windfall from McDonald's, Manhattan would have its first McMansion.

HEADLINE: The World: Thrown Together; 
Unwittingly, Arafat Plays the Matchmaker

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

 BODY:
SEATED together last week in the Oval Office and proclaiming their mutual commitment to a future Palestinian state, President Bush and the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, were the image of personal amity and political optimism. 
 It was an image that testified eloquently to the inaction and ineptitude of Yasir Arafat, who, still under virtual house arrest in the West Bank by the Israeli military, has managed to push the central broker in the region, the American government, squarely into the camp of his nemesis. 
 In fact, lately, the biggest gap between Mr. Bush and Mr. Sharon seems to be whether they should exert fierce pressure on Mr. Arafat (Mr. Bush) or dump him altogether as a peace partner (Mr. Sharon). 
Mr. Arafat's feat was all the more impressive because the Bush administration, after initially trying to stay clear of the Middle East, tilted toward the Palestinians last fall, when President Bush called for a "state of Palestine" -- a formula Washington had hitherto avoided. And after Sept. 11, Washington's first instinct was to woo Arab support. 
But Mr. Arafat's failure to back up his denunciations of terrorism with action, and the Israeli capture of a shipload of weapons apparently ordered through two of the top terror dispensers on America's list -- Hezbollah and Iran -- infuriated the administration. It yanked its envoy, Anthony C. Zinni, out of the region, and left the Palestinian leader at the mercy of Mr. Sharon.
"Not only did the violence of the past 18 months enable Sharon to ride to power, but Arafat has been the glue that's kept the disparate parts of the Israeli government together," said David Makovsky, a senior fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East policy. "And now it's brought Bush and Sharon together. Once again Arafat is the great unifier."
He and other experts do not believe that the United States has embraced Mr. Sharon's hawkish views. But with the peace process in shambles, Washington's focus is now on demonstrating to Mr. Arafat -- and to potential successors -- the need to stop terror. 
There was also speculation that Mr. Bush may have invited Mr. Sharon to discuss a possible attack on Iraq. Such an attack would need Israel's cooperation, if only by promising not to strike back if Saddam Hussein launched missiles its way, as he did in the gulf war. 
Still, the overall impression of Mr. Sharon's White House visit was that the United States had given a free hand to the very Israeli regarded by Arabs as the least likely to make peace. 
So the visit did not go down well in the Middle East. Mr. Sharon, after all, has never concealed his contempt for the Oslo agreements, and his version of a peace deal would give the Palestinians far less than what Mr. Arafat rejected at Camp David in July 2000. In fact, he was elected in the heat of a new intifada precisely because the Israelis concluded that Oslo had gotten them nowhere, and it was time to get tough again. 
Recently, Mr. Sharon also told interviewers that he wished Israel had killed Mr. Arafat 20 years ago, back when Mr. Sharon was orchestrating the controversial invasion of Lebanon. And Mr. Sharon was instrumental in the establishment of Jewish settlements on occupied territories, one of the central Palestinian grievances. 
Given how Mr. Sharon is regarded by the Palestinians and in the Middle East, will this administration's clear alignment with him damage America's credibility and national interests in the region?
"The first thing in every conversation is the absence of evenhandedness by the United States," said Judith Kipper, a Middle East expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies who just returned from a trip through Kuwait, Qatar, Dubai and Saudi Arabia. "It's really, really an issue." 
Ms. Kipper found that extensive television coverage of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict had deepened passions in the streets, and that the Arab governments were having an increasingly difficult time explaining their support for American mediation when American-built F-16's were pounding Palestinian targets, Israeli tanks were entering Palestinian lands -- and the Bush administration criticized only Mr. Arafat. 
Similar sentiments could he heard in the meetings of the World Economic Forum in New York last week, though there is also ample reason to believe that major Arab players in the Middle East would not bemoan Mr. Arafat's exit, and that even his lieutenants are dismayed at where he has led them.
Martin Indyk, the Clinton administration's ambassador to Israel and now a senior fellow with the Brookings Institution, said it was clear to all that Mr. Arafat had forced the United States' hand. He argued that the support America showed for Mr. Sharon could be translated into concrete influence over the Israelis, once the United States reentered the fray. 
Over the years, Mr. Sharon has outlined a basic concept of a peace deal, but it is a far cry from what the Palestinians were discussing with his predescessor. More recently, Mr. Sharon has said that if the violence ended, he would be more generous.
Perhaps, but American support has for now removed any pressure on Mr. Sharon to approach the Palestinians more flexibly.
"Arafat is a great partner for Sharon in a sardonic way, because he relieves him of the necessity to tell Israelis -- forget Americans -- what kind of concessions he is ready to make," said Nahum Barnea, a columnist for the Israeli newspaper Yedioth Ahronot.
"When people ask him the question of the day after" -- meaning after Mr. Arafat is gone -- "he is always very vague on purpose."
WITH so few prospects for a return to peace talks, there is a certain cold realism in staying on the sidelines until something changes, most likely the Palestinian leadership. The problem is that all the while, suicide bombs will be going off in Israeli streets, to be followed by more retaliatory raids. And all the while, the sense of hopelessness, and perhaps resentment of American inaction, will grow.
"The point is, something's got to give," warned Mr. Indyk. "Either a disastrous string of terrorist attacks endorsed by Arafat to bring the whole house down and provoke Sharon, or some political agreement, or Iraq. Something's going to give."
"I think the greatest problem with our policy at the moment, where we are losing points in the Arab world, is the unwillingness to get engaged in an effort to stop the violence," he said. "Instead, we are withholding engagement as some kind of leverage, saying we'll only get involved when Arafat gets serious. It needs to be the other way around."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Budget Fuss; 
Is What's Good for Bush Also Good for the G.O.P.?

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
WHEN NASA announced last week that it was moving millions of dollars of space shuttle work and hundreds of high-wage jobs from California to Florida, federal officials explained that they were taking the most efficient course to cut expenses at the space agency. Yet there was another, unspoken, explanation: the election of 2004. Since Florida was the most contested state in the 2000 election, White House officials are already doing all they can to shore up support there for 2004.
 By contrast, President Bush lost California, and his political advisers see it as a long shot for 2004. So why not boost central Florida's flagging economy -- as well as Mr. Bush's political fortunes in the state? That philosophy makes little sense to the Republican congressman from the California district slated to lose the NASA jobs, Howard P. (Buck) McKeon, who faces re-election in November and called it "penny-wise but pound foolish." 
 For all the gamesmanship over the budget Mr. Bush proposed last week, the most intense struggle is between the politics of the 2002 and 2004 elections. No one should question that the president's priority is assuring his own re-election. That imperative infuses every move of his administration -- from the fine print of the budget to his utterances in the State of the Union address. If he can help Republicans in November, all the better. 
Mr. Bush's aides say he is determined not to repeat the miscalculation of his father, who did not focus on his re-election until it was too late. But the result might differ starkly from the nearer-term objective of Republicans in Congress: to win in 2002.
It is in Mr. Bush's interest, of course, not to jeopardize his party's drive to win back the Senate and retain control of the House. But, inevitably, the president's interests are bound to collide with others in his party.
THE budget is Exhibit No. 1. Given the terrorist attacks, Republicans have not dared question Mr. Bush's emphasis on military spending. But the focus on the military also enhances Mr. Bush's most politically impregnable role: as the endlessly mobilized commander in chief who pledged to stake his presidency on rooting out terrorists. "If this were a budget for '02, it would look at lot different than it does," said Charles Cook, who publishes a nonpartisan newsletter on congressional elections. "There aren't a lot of gravy train items in this budget."
Indeed, many Republicans insist that if he were on the ballot in November, Mr. Bush would not have included such an array of cuts in domestic programs to pay for the military buildup and for his tax cuts. But Republicans find they have competing interests even among themselves. Despite their party's rallying cry of fiscal restraint, many are distressed that Mr. Bush's proposals to cut members' domestic projects will imperil them in November.
Other Republicans, like Representative Tom Delay, the House majority whip, argue that Mr. Bush should balance the budget -- and not endanger lawmakers who based their elections on fiscal discipline and preserving the Social Security surplus. Mr. Delay, for one, vigorously resisted the administration's budget, telling White House officials that he does not want his congressional incumbents to become identified with a budget that calls for deficit spending. (Mr. Delay knows he has little chance of convincing the White House to balance the budget, but he wants to demonstrate to conservatives that at least he tried.)
THE administration's focus on 2004 is apparent in more than just the budget. It is no accident that the president's travels this year have followed the map of states that top the Bush target list for winning in 2004, particularly Florida and Pennsylvania. That also helps explain why his advisers sometimes seem more focused on electing Republican governors rather than members of Congress in states like Florida, Illinois and Michigan: they could help him immensely in 2004.
"Their priority is to protect the president," Representative Tom Davis of Virginia, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said of the White House. "But that's not all bad." If Mr. Bush stays popular, Mr. Davis said, it can only help Republicans this year.
Tom Cole, a former chief of staff to the Republican National Committee, was more blunt. "It's not going to help the White House to get their brains beat out in 2002," he said. "I doubt that they're going to do anything that seriously or consciously puts the House in jeopardy."
But in private conversations, officials at the White House and at the Republican Party often seem more attuned to the politics of 2004 than 2002. Some even suggest that it would be futile to fret about November. They say the best thing they can do for the party is to keep Mr. Bush's popularity above 80 percent. "Their focus is almost exclusively on Bush," said one outside adviser to the White House. "They feel almost powerless in the midterms; it's like, we could win a few, we could lose a few."
Republicans who face the voters in November do not see it that way. The competing interests between the White House and members of Congress flared to the surface last week when Representative Bill Young, a Florida Republican, the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, complained to Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the White House budget chief, that the administration was depriving members of pet projects for their districts.
"All wisdom on the allocation of federal grant funding does not reside in the executive branch," Mr. Young wrote in a letter to Mr. Daniels. "Members know the needs of their districts better than civil servants working in Washington, D.C."
Another example of the tension between 2002 and 2004 is in the firestorm over Mr. Bush's pledge to provide $20 billion for rebuilding New York. For all the sympathy for New York and the terrorist attacks, some Republicans had argued against full funding, noting that New York is about the last state Mr. Bush could win in 2004. Early last week, Mr. Daniels even derided the lobbying for money from New York Democrats, calling it "a money-grubbing game."
But Mr. Bush reversed course and assured New York it would get its full funding (though it still does not actually exist in the budget). Some advisers said Mr. Bush, besides truly believing New York deserved the money, wanted to tamp down the controversy over Mr. Daniels' infelicitous remarks. Others said there was a 2004 motive in helping New York. If he brushed off New York, that could spill over and also hurt him in states like New Jersey and Connecticut, which are more apt to vote Republican.
The White House focus on 2004 was also apparent in the way the administration leaked sections of its budget before the actual document was announced on Monday. In the run-up to the announcement, officials highlighted portions of the budget that appeal to constituencies that Mr. Bush wants to win over in 2004. They also pointed to a host of provisions that would make the case that Mr. Bush is a "compassionate conservative."
There was a measure to give food vouchers and nutrition counseling to more lower-income women and young children each month; millions more to strengthen black and Hispanic colleges; millions to help low-income families pay for their next home, and millions to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly.
But while Democrats squawked that these proposals were mere window dressing, many Republicans squawked just as loudly that their biggest concern was here and now. Even Republicans who pride themselves on balanced budgets are seeking to protect their domestic projects back home on everything from education proposals to rural programs to highway funds to health care for veterans.
An example of the strains between the White House and congressional Republicans is on Social Security. Representative Davis pleaded with the administration not to submit to Congress a measure to overhaul and partly privatize Social Security, warning that Democrats have "chopped our people to pieces" when Republicans have dared to try to tinker with Social Security. Heeding such worries, the White House did decide to put off pressing legislation on Social Security.
BUT the congressional side did not win a complete victory. In his State of the Union address, Mr. Bush still mentioned his desire to overhaul Social Security, which gives Democrats ammunition to make it an issue in the fall.
Yet, as exercised as everyone has become over the budget, this much is important to remember: It is far more a political document of the president's priorities and political positioning than a road map of how federal dollars will be allocated. The White House -- and the Democrats -- know that many of the proposed domestic cuts will never be made.
That is why Representative Todd Tiahrt, a Kansas Republican, hardly seemed alarmed about the proposed cut of a popular education project in his district. In fact, he said, "I'm pretty pleased with the president's budget." He knows his project will survive.

HEADLINE: How Will Washington Read the Signs?; 
Greater Authority for the S.E.C.

BYLINE:  By Stephen Labaton 

 BODY:
The S.E.C. will be the locus of many changes, starting with the choice of four new commissioners to join the chairman, Mr. Pitt. The new political climate has significantly widened their agenda.
 "The commission has been stood on its head," said Patrick McGurn, director of corporate programs at Institutional Shareholder Services, which advises large investors. "It's going to be subject to much more scrutiny." 
 In addition, President Bush has named an advisory group, which includes Mr. Pitt, Mr. O'Neill and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to study several options. Many of its recommendations could affect the commission. Even before Enron became a household name, Mr. Pitt had begun to review the agency's financial disclosure regulations. He has said they too often encourage opaque reporting by companies more interested in avoiding liability than in enlightening investors. 
Commission officials are preparing to suggest new legislation to give them greater authority to suspend or bar unethical executives and directors from serving at public companies. Mr. Pitt has also endorsed in principle a proposal by Senator Jean Carnahan, Democrat of Missouri, to require prompt electronic disclosures of stock trades by senior executives. And Mr. Pitt is preparing new rules to enable executives to share the information they receive about future industry trends, although investor groups have said they fear that the proposals may insulate executives from any consequences of misleading projections.
The agency must also battle heavy turnover. It has struggled to recruit and keep top-quality lawyers, who can earn far more in the private sector.
Although Mr. Bush has said he will seek tougher disclosures and penalties, his proposed budget has left critics wondering how committed he is to more stringent enforcement. Congress adopted a measure last year to pay S.E.C. prosecutors the same as bank regulators, but Mr. Bush's budget provides a raise that barely exceeds inflation.
"This is a paltry increase," said Representative John J. LaFalce of New York, the ranking Democrat on the House Financial Services Committee. 
White House officials say that with a budget deficit and other pressing programs, they can afford to spend no more on enforcement. Stephen Labaton

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AFGHAN-AMERICANS; 
Exiles, Torn Between Countries, Want to Help Rebuild Afghanistan

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va. 

 BODY:
When she was growing up in a southern province of Afghanistan, Sheila Jahan said, her mother implored her to become a doctor. Today, Dr. Jahan, 42, is a busy neurologist in this suburb of Washington. She wears elegant clothes, drives a Mercedes and sends her 14-year-old daughter to a private school. From the outside looking in, her life appears perfect.
 The tears in Dr. Jahan's round dark eyes suggest otherwise. As she watches her homeland emerge from two decades of war, she is caught in a tangle of emotions. She is joyful, at the sight of the Afghan flag, a banner that has not been used for nearly 30 years, rising over the reopened embassy in Washington. She is sad that her parents did not live to see this day. She is bursting with pride and love for Hamid Karzai, Afghanistan's interim leader, whom she praised as "like a brother, a father whom I know is not lying," after hearing him speak during his recent visit to the United States. 
 But most of all, Dr. Jahan is yearning to go home. 
"I am torn between two countries," she said the other day, kneading a damp tissue between her fingers as she spoke. "My plan is to have a clinic, to go for one month, then come back for three months here. It is my duty. I have to go."
As Mr. Karzai sets about rebuilding his tattered nation, countless Afghan-American professionals are heeding his call for help.
A conference on Afghanistan reconstruction was held at the Hilton hotel here in conjunction with the Karzai visit. Several hundred engineers, computer experts, businessmen, educators and doctors, including Dr. Jahan, turned out to hear Mr. Karzai speak. Later, in small working groups, they plotted how to reverse what Haron Amin, the new charge d'affaires at the Afghan Embassy in Washington, calls Afghanistan's "brain drain."
As Afghanistan's elite, these professionals are, in Dr. Jahan's words, "the privileged ones." Some are retired, nearing the end of their careers. Others are in their 20's and, having left Afghanistan as toddlers, barely remember their home country. Despite jobs and mortgages and commitments here, they are determined to help rebuild Afghanistan, physically and intellectually.
"There are legions, ready to march," said Don Ritter, a former Republican congressman from Pennsylvania who leads the board of the Afghanistan America Foundation, a nonprofit organization that opened an office in Kabul last month and is working to connect Afghan-Americans with rebuilding projects. "These people are almost obsessed with moving back, in waves of talent, with their skills -- business, entrepreneurial, educational, medical."
Afghanistan's needs now are very basic, things most Americans take for granted. One businessman, M. Z. Ghaznawi, said he wanted to go back and build glass factories so people could have proper windows.
"Without glass, how can we live during the cold time?" he asked.
Still, obstacles to returning remain. Security is a big issue; no one wants to return if it is not safe. There is the matter of dual citizenship; many Afghan-Americans say they would like to be able to travel with Afghan passports and vote when Afghanistan has elections.
Finances, too, will play a role. Some young Afghan-Americans are proposing that Congress make it easier for them to help in the reconstruction by forgiving their student loans.
"It will be a rough start, but I think within the next six weeks to two months, we will be able to repatriate some," Mr. Amin said. "But it will not be an easy task."
The Census Bureau estimates that 25,000 to 51,000 people of Afghan ancestry live in the United States, but Afghan-American groups put the figure at 150,000. They are concentrated in pockets of California and New York and in the Washington area.
This small slice of immigrant America has long felt invisible. For years, Afghan-Americans have watched, brokenhearted, as their homeland has sunk deeper into despair, abandoned by the world. 
"We cried and we cried and we cried," said Weis Sherdel, 28, a systems analyst, "and nobody heard our voices."
Some remain bitter. But with the international spotlight now shining on their country, most Afghan-Americans are looking forward, not back.
"We've been in the desert for so long, and are so thirsty," said Zalmi Niayz, the owner of Creative Contractors and Remodeling in Annandale, Va. "We finally see water."
Mr. Niayz, a burly man with an easy smile, left Afghanistan when he was 16. He is now 46. He attended high school in Northern Virginia and college at the University of Arkansas, and he says he feels comfortably American. "I have Afghan values," he said, "but I dream in English."
Those dreams include reclaiming his family's house. The house, a large three-story building in the nicest section of Kabul, is still standing, Mr. Niayz said. It has been occupied by Taliban soldiers in recent years and, since the new government took over, by the Northern Alliance. Mr. Niayz has the deed, now worn and faded.
Recently, Mr. Niayz formed a nonprofit organization, the Afghan Reconstruction Association, so he could bid on building projects. He has drafted a 200-page report, "A Vision for Developing a 21st Century Afghanistan," which he shared with Mr. Karzai and members of his cabinet. He also told them about the deed, and asked how he could get his house back. He said it was his dream to house charity workers in it and to live there when he was in Kabul. "My heart," he said, "belongs home."
For young people, the draw to return seems especially strong. Many watched their parents abandon houses and careers to take menial jobs, driving taxis or delivering pizza, in the United States.
Most of the young people have worked hard, too. Mr. Sherdel lived through 10 years of war in Afghanistan and arrived in the United States when he was 14. He supported his family by working at a Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant when he was in high school, and he attended the University of Virginia after graduating fourth in his class. For him, and for others, to go back would be to realize a long-held family dream.
"I remember my father, when the summers would be 100 degrees he would be outside laying tar," said Nadia Aman, 25, a systems analyst in Springfield, Va. Her father was a high official in the Afghan finance ministry in the 1970's. "For over 10 years, we didn't buy a house because there was always talk of going back," Ms. Aman said.
Some can capitalize on their family names. Mr. Sherdel is the grandson of a former mayor of Kandahar. Mr. Niayz, the contractor, is the son of a prominent factory owner. Raihana Rasouli, 28, the executive director of the Afghanistan America Foundation, is the granddaughter of a former mayor of Kabul. Two years ago, she founded her own group, Afghans 4 Tomorrow.
"We have no funds, no grants; for two years we have been doing this from our own pockets," Ms. Rasouli said. Her brother, 23, is in Afghanistan assessing the country's needs, and she plans a trip in March. "You have to go there and feel the people, feel the land, see the land," she said.
As Afghan-Americans organize financially, they are also organizing politically.
Among their leaders is Waheed Momand, 52, a biomedical engineer who left Afghanistan in 1982, three years after the Soviet invasion. Among Afghans' tales, his is familiar. He and his wife trekked through the mountains to Pakistan, mostly on foot. They lived there as refugees, then made their way to Germany, to be reunited with their daughter, who had been sent to live with grandparents. Today, the family lives in Northern California, where Dr. Momand is president of an umbrella organization, the Afghan Coalition.
Until Sept. 11, groups like Dr. Momand's concentrated on social and cultural matters and helping Afghan immigrants. More recently, they have been electing delegates to represent them in dealings with the United States and the new government in Afghanistan. The Northern California election was on Jan. 6.
"This was really the first democratic election ever held in any Afghan community in more than 30 years," Dr. Momand said. "That was really an historic thing."
Despite the determination of Dr. Momand and others to return, it is unlikely that many Afghan-American professionals will move home for good. Some of the young ones, like Mr. Sherdel and Ms. Aman, support their parents financially and are not free to leave. The older ones have children to worry about.
Dr. Jahan said she was investigating boarding school in the United States for her daughter. Asked if the separation would be difficult, she recalled a conversation with her own mother, who died in India a year after the family left Afghanistan.
"I said, 'Mommy, how could you love your country so much you would die for it?' She laughed at me. She said, 'You are too young to understand that your duty is to your country.' Now I understand."

It is my duty." (Photographs by Susana Raab for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Nation: Hearing One Tree; 
Never Have So Many Missed the Forest

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE biggest news out of 10 Congressional hearings on Enron last week was the claim on Thursday -- sharply contradicted by others -- by Jeffrey K. Skilling, the company's former chief executive, that he had known nothing about the company's questionable partnerships.
 But the biggest idea probably came Wednesday, when Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, said that Congress should reach beyond the Enron case itself to see if the apparent sins of Enron and its auditor-enabler, Arthur Andersen, were widespread in American business. "It would be very helpful for the Congress to broaden its inquiry to determine how pervasive these practices actually are," he said. 
 Right now, Congressional committees are chasing the scandal and the television lights like 7-year-old soccer players all flocking to the ball. At last count there were 13 committees and subcommittees at work on Enron. Tom Mann, a Congressional scholar at the Brookings Institution, said never before had as many committees jumped at an issue at once. 
That is especially unusual because this is not a typical topic for a Capitol Hill probe. Congress has always been, according to Joel Silbey, a Cornell historian, "much more willing to investigate political corruption than economic corruption."
The executive branch has been Congress's primary investigative target, from the first inquiry, the 1792 House probe of the military disaster that befell the St. Clair expedition in Ohio, through Watergate and Iran-contra. Government corruption by private interests has been another favored topic, in the Credit Mobilier and Teapot Dome scandals in particular.
But much as Democrats hope that the connections between Enron leaders (and their money) to the Bush administration might produce evidence of that kind of corruption, this case may be more like another, rarer sort of inquiry -- an investigation of a serious problem in the economy in which the government is not involved, but perhaps should be.
As Professor Joel D. Aberbach, a U.C.L.A. political scientist and a student of Congressional investigations, suggests, the questionable Enron-Andersen relationship "touches on some fundamental issues about the free enterprise system," especially the trust investors can place in audits.
The concern is not just academic. Two-thirds of the American public, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News Polland another by ABC News, say they believe that Enron's accounting problems are widespread among American corporations. Stock market jitters suggested similar fears on Wall Street last week.
The most striking past investigations of business were the "money trust" probe in 1912 and 1913 (also known by the name of its chairman, Representative Arsene P. Pujo, a Louisiana Democrat) and the stock market investigation of 1932 to 1934 (unique among Congressional probes because it is not named after a chairman, but after its chief counsel, Ferdinand Pecora).
The evidence of bankers' collaboration and control of the economy from the Pujo investigation shaped the Federal Reserve Act. The revelations of Wall Street double-dealing by the Pecora probe in the Senate banking committee led to the Securities Exchange Act -- and the Securities and Exchange Commission, whose approach to accounting is now under heavy criticism.
But despite Mr. Daschle's suggestion, and requests by a handful of senators for a single select committee to look into the subject, one big investigation seems unlikely, even in the Senate. It's almost too late already. Senator Edward M. Kennedy said last week that "a lot of the committees are well down the road already," with subpoenas served, documents in hand and hearings planned. It's almost unheard of for a chairman to give up a piece of a high-profile inquiry that may make the evening news. Mr. Daschle will settle for efforts to coordinate the probes.
Another reason for not having one special committee do it all is timing. It would take weeks at least -- on the unrealistic assumption that both parties worked together -- to establish one.
SO will Congress answer the question of whether Enron's problems are, in fact, widespread? Representative James C. Greenwood, the Pennsylvania Republican who heads the House commerce committee's investigative subcommittee, says he doubts that the sins are commonplace. "This hasn't been a 'here we go again' experience," he said. "This is different and rotten and unbelievable. That makes me think this is rare." Mr. Greenwood acknowledged the countervailing "cockroach theory -- if you see one cockroach going across the floor, there's a pretty good chance there are others behind the baseboard." But he said he doubted that his subcommittee would "start calling in other companies and ask them whether they do this."
In the Senate, the most comprehensive probe will probably come from the banking committee's examination of accounting and auditing standards and practices, on the theory that investors and the public should be able to depend on audits to prevent or expose sleazy practices. Senator Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland, the chairman, said, "It's going to deal with accounting standards, oversight, public disclosure of financial devices, auditor independence, all the things relating to investor protection and corporate responsibility."
He said he was not sure whether big accounting firms would be called to testify. With witnesses from Enron unlikely to be called, there will not be the constant headlines Mr. Pecora produced when he questioned famous financiers like J. P. Morgan Jr. "Careful analytical examination," in the chairman's phrase, does not draw television cameras.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 17, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the lasting effects of Congressional investigations referred incorrectly to the House testimony of Jeffrey B. Skilling, a former chief executive of Enron. He said he had not known that partnerships with the company were improperly used to hide losses. He did not say he knew nothing about the partnerships.
